HEADLINE: U.S. to Auction Debt 2 Days This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as a 52-week bill and a 12-day cash management bill that will be auctioned tomorrow.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.54 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 4.53 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 4.62 percent. 
 The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce;
Personal information is like gold in the Internet economy, and the rush is on to both exploit it and protect it.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
FOR the last few weeks, the data privacy battle has been waged with such fury that privacy advocates have not known whether to cry, cheer or simply assume the fetal position.
Personal privacy -- the disposition of all those pieces of information that computers hold about each of us -- has been debated in the electronic world for almost two decades. Although the issues are complex, the bottom lines have always been pretty clearly drawn. 
 People and companies that sell personal data want to be able to collect and distribute it pretty much with abandon, and they fight like cornered weasels at even the suggestion of government regulation.
Yet, most people on line -- 87 percent in a 1997 Georgia Tech survey -- want "complete control" over their personal data. And if they feel violated by data collectors, they often scream bloody murder.
In 1991, for example, the Lotus Corporation was forced to cancel shipments of Marketplace, a CD-ROM data base, after receiving thousands of angry E-pistles from people who took grievous offense at the data base's content: the names, addresses, income levels, numbers of children and other data for every household in the United States.
More recently, privacy advocates wrested a hollow victory from the Intel Corporation, after the company announced that its new Pentium III chips contained embedded electronic serial numbers for authenticating documents, E-mail and copyrighted material. Watchdogs warned that the numbers could be used to identify a computer to prying software, or to allow companies or agencies to track a person's movements across the Internet.
Intel refused to remove the number, but agreed to provide software that hides it behind a digital fig leaf, software that some say has already been compromised.
And the California Legislature, often a bellwether for technology issues, is considering more than a dozen privacy laws, including one that would restrict the collection and disclosure of personal information by government, business or nonprofit organizations. It specifically includes information gathered via Internet sites.
Still, plenty of others are rushing to cash in on the data gold rush.
Privacy advocates were extremely cranky after discovering that Florida, South Carolina and Colorado were selling residents' driver's license information to a New Hampshire-based company, Image Data L.L.C.
They were even more outraged to discover that the Secret Service had financed another private company's efforts to develop a national data base of driver's license photographs.
And in the most telling testament yet to the commercial value of personal data in the Internet economy, a start-up called Free PC announced that it would provide a free Internet connection and a free Compaq computer to anyone willing to "apply" by answering a detailed questionnaire and then accepting constant bombardment by advertisers based on the personal profile created from the questionnaire.
Rich Le Furgy, chairman of the Internet Advertising Bureau, an industry group, said that advertisers haven't even begun to tap the Internet's potential. They are now investigating how to aim promotions at individual consumers based on their on-line behavior: vendors want to co-market products in much the same way that convenience stores did after discovering, for example, that people who buy beer also often buy diapers at the same time.
Not exactly music to the ears of a privacy-sensitive consumer. Obviously, on-line advertising organizations find themselves straddling a very pointy fence between companies that pay for advertising and customers who are subjected to that advertising. The constituencies have very different viewpoints, and finding a solution palatable to both is not a task for the squeamish.
For example, Mr. Le Furgy said "it would be a beautiful thing" for consumers to control their personal data -- especially if it meant avoiding legislation and regulation.
"Privacy is an enabler of commerce," he said. If consumers can get money for their personal information and still control it, "they'll be much more willing to provide it."
In fact, a new breed of Internet company is already making a business of that concept.
These companies, known as infomediaries -- a term coined by John Hagel, co-author of "Net Worth: Shaping Markets When Customers Make the Rules" (Harvard Business School Press, 1999) -- will step in and help consumers regain control of their personal data.
For a price, of course.
A recent Wired News feature predicts that an up and coming pack of these entrepreneurs will "cut the consumer in" on the deal when information about them is bought and sold. Infomediaries keep a percentage for themselves for providing the security mechanisms by which consumers can control exactly who buys their personal data and for what purpose.
But some privacy advocates would eliminate even the infomediary and pass laws granting consumers not just civil rights to their privacy, but property rights to their private data, ending the free-market eminent domain that data marketers have exploited for decades.
Citing a Virginia law that forbids the use of anyone's name or likeness without permission, Ram Avrahami, a business consultant, unsuccessfully sued U.S. News & World Report in 1996 for selling his name to another magazine. At the time, Mr. Avrahami's opponents ridiculed him for suing over 8 cents, which is what the magazine had paid for his name.
"The point is this: It's 8 cents for me, for you, for 100 million other Americans, which becomes big money," said Mr. Avrahami, who has since become a leading advocate of private data ownership. "Think of it this way: Free PC proves that our personal information is worth hundreds of dollars. Now, who should get those dollars, if not us?"

HEADLINE: Building on Borrowed Cachet;
Cathleen Black Shakes Up the Culture at Hearst Magazines

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
It was the closest you could get to a debutante party in the mud-slinging, ego-bruising, advertising-hungry world of magazine publishing.
The occasion: a dinner in early February given by the American Jewish Committee in the ballroom of the New York Hilton, in honor of Cathleen Black, the president of Hearst Magazines. But, alas, all eyes were not on Ms. Black. 
 Instead, heads swiveled toward Tina Brown and Ron Galotti, the editor and publisher of Talk magazine, the Hearst Corporation's newest joint venture -- who sat, smiles firmly in place, at a table behind Ms. Black, in their first public appearance as affianced partners of the Hearst company. And a Hearst executive, noticing the rubbernecking, nodded his head toward the pair.
"We're showing them off tonight," he said in the tone a proud father might use to describe a glowing daughter. "Our new gems."
The fact that Hearst executives were swooning over Ms. Brown demonstrates the dynamic of what has become an emerging strategy at Hearst: partnership. In this case, the muscle of Hearst coupled with the ceaseless chattering chorus that seems to follow Ms. Brown everywhere. At a time when magazine publishers, feeling a squeeze at the newsstand, are wary of introducing new magazines unless they are guaranteed sure things, the partnership formula seems to be working for Hearst. The company's two other joint ventures, Smart Money (which is published in conjunction with Dow Jones & Company) and Marie Claire (with Marie Claire Album, a French company) are two of the strongest titles in the industry. With the Talk deal, Hearst has attracted attention from the advertising community by teaming up with two well-known magazine figures -- but only assuming half the financial risk and half the estimated $50 million start-up costs.
But not all eyes will remain glued to Talk; many will be monitoring Ms. Black's progress in changing the company to increase advertising revenue. The decision to become a partner with Miramax Films on Talk is a definite change of pace for Hearst. The $1-billion-a-year magazine division -- which publishes 19 titles in the United States, including Cosmopolitan, Popular Mechanics and Good Housekeeping -- has long been considered the most middle of the road, least daring of the four major magazine companies (the others being the stylish Conde Nast, the mainstream but news-oriented Time Inc. and the scrappy, growing Hachette Filipacchi Magazines).
The decision adds one ingredient advertisers love: glamour. And at half-price.
Ms. Black has changed the company slowly; in three years, she has dismissed or reassigned only a handful of publishers and editors. (By contrast, when Steven T. Florio, the chief executive of Conde Nast, was named publisher of the company, the magazine division of Advance Publications, he made dozens of personnel changes in the first months.) She has concentrated on rehabilitating the magazine company's image among advertisers, who had grumbled loudly in 1995 when Hearst cut its magazines' guaranteed circulation rates. (The decision prompted many big advertisers to slash their spending for advertising in Hearst magazines.)
She has maintained Cosmopolitan's status as a market leader, Despite high-level editorial changes. It routinely pummels its archrival, Conde Nast's Glamour -- now edited by the former Cosmopolitan editor Bonnie Fuller -- at the newsstand, a success that must be sweet for Ms. Black. In December -- in another advertiser-oriented move -- she reorganized the company's magazines into two groups, in an attempt to encourage advertisers to buy pages in several magazines jointly, in effect offering package deals.
An extroverted and aggressive seller, Ms. Black is known for her close ties to the advertising industry, and sits on the boards of two of the country's largest advertisers, the Coca-Cola Corporation and I.B.M. She said that to woo advertisers, brand names like Dow Jones and Miramax, a unit of the Walt Disney Company, are essential.
"If we do a joint venture with anybody," she said, "we want them to be major corporations. Apart from the consumer audience, your advertiser audience is saying, 'Gee, Dow Jones and Hearst,' or 'Gee, Miramax and Hearst are behind this,' then they know we're putting a lot of resources and talent and energy behind the product that an individual entrepreneur just doesn't have."
Like her company, Ms. Black is frill-free. A self-described Catholic schoolgirl from Chicago, she started her career at Holiday magazine, then moved to New York magazine, becoming advertising manager of Ms. Magazine when it was founded by Gloria Steinem in 1972. ("It was real lick-your-own-envelopes-at-midnight work," she said.) She was named publisher of New York in 1979, but made her mark at USA Today as publisher in the 1980's by smartening it up in the eyes of advertisers wary of a newspaper nicknamed "McPaper." In 1991, she became president of the Newspaper Association of America and then moved to Hearst as president of the magazine division in January 1996. (Her husband, Tom Harvey, is a lawyer; they have two children, a dog, and a country house in Connecticut.)
Hearst is a privately held company, and Ms. Black will not discuss numbers -- even good ones, choosing instead to highlight the successes of Smart Money and Cosmopolitan. In an effort to build on Cosmopolitan's growth and the popularity of magazines for teen-agers, Cosmopolitan plans to test a title aimed at teen-age girls in the fall.
But onlookers say Hearst is still not sufficiently focused on fresh editorial product. One advertising agency media director who works with Hearst and spoke on the condition of anonymity said: "Nothing's really happened since she's gotten there. At Conde Nast, they love to toss the thing around. You get the sense that they're constantly stirring the pot. At Hearst, it still feels status quo."
But John Fennell, the chief operating officer at Hachette Filipacchi, who has worked with several editors who are now at Hearst, said that Ms. Black had stepped into an insider culture. "Hearst used to be a country-club, old-boy environment," Mr. Fennell said. "For Cathie to step in at the level she did and make the changes she did, even if they are not enormous ones, was a dramatic move."
Former Hearst editors say the company's culture is not directed toward creative tinkering. "At Conde Nast, editors are treated like entertainment impresarios. At Hearst, they're expected to put on green eyeshades and sign expense vouchers from the photo department," said Randall Rothenberg, an editor at Wired, which is owned by Conde Nast, and a former executive editor at Esquire, which is owned by Hearst.
But Ms. Black sees no conflict between the bottom line and creativity.
"We have an incredible group of lively, energetic, talented editors here, who break new ground every day," she said.
While the Talk deal is a change of tactics for Hearst, it signals a shift for the magazine industry in general as more companies move toward joint ventures in a publishing economy that feels increasingly unsure. Among other problems, magazine newsstand sales are suffering. And editors worry about consumers who spend more time surfing the World Wide Web than curling up with their favorite magazine, a trend that is ominously called "usage erosion" in the industry. The general interest category that Talk is entering is already crowded, with advertisers increasingly drawn to niche publications.
Perhaps in this tenuous market there is room only for sure things and joint ventures. Later this year, Smart Money will test what could become yet another Hearst joint venture, a magazine aimed at parents concerned with their children's financial futures.
E. Daniel Capell, an authority on magazine circulation and the editor of Capell's Circulation Report, said that joint ventures were very appealing, especially to a company like Hearst.
"Hearst has all these other arms available: subscription fulfillment, distribution, circulation, so that makes it very easy to do joint ventures," he said. "The amount of money required to launch a new magazine is so big and you have so much at risk, that when you can split the risk it makes sense."
But Hearst had time to mull the deal, because the Talk team approached both Time Inc., which is part of Time Warner Inc., and Hachette Filipacchi, a unit of the Lagardere Group, first. Time executives balked because they believed that Ms. Brown had never run a profitable magazine in the United States. At Hachette, executives simply did not want to spend the money.
In an intriguing hint of that much-overused term, synergy, Talk may be able to offer unusual package deals to advertisers, because its other corporate parent is Disney's Miramax. Mr. Galotti has said that advertised products may even get placement in Miramax films. Say, for example, Prada buys 50 pages of ads, does that mean that Gwyneth Paltrow will wear Prada loafers and tote a Prada handbag in a Miramax film?
"We're going to help people market products to consumers whatever way we can," Mr. Galotti said. "If there's an opportunity to work with them that way, then we will do that."
Hearst editors seem to bear no ill will toward the new venture and the $25 million Ms. Black will sink into it.
"We're glad she's made Hearst give her the resources to class up the joint," said one Hearst editor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "And that's part of the reason she wanted Talk. She has realized that there is an upside to pursuing glamorous things. It gets advertisers excited."
In the meantime, advertisers await their invitations to the launch party, the all-important soiree at which guests are plied with cocktails and enjoy solicitous bowing and scraping by the publisher. Will it be held at the Four Seasons? Nobu? Or in London? Will there be many supermodels in attendance? Mr. Galotti said no.
"We'll do something more low key," he said. "How about a cookout?"

HEADLINE: Behind Olivetti's Move: Cellular Explosion

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Feb. 28

 BODY:
As any traveler here knows, the tribe of Italians who do not walk around with a cell phone hanging from one ear is quickly facing extinction.
While it is true that roughly 48 percent of Norwegians and Swedes, and fully 58 percent of Finns own them, Scandinavia is only about 20 million people. Italy is more in a league with France and Britain, which have roughly 60 million people each. And among Italians, 36 percent of potential users have wireless phones, compared with 22 percent in Britain and 18.8 percent in France. An even lower portion of Germans -- 17 percent of 80 million -- use them. 
 The likelihood that something like this might happen led Carlo de Benedetti, the chairman of Olivetti S.p.A., the typewriter maker turned computer company, to decide in the 1980's that mobile phones might be what Olivetti needed to replace its ailing computer business.
The shift cost him his job. By 1996, Olivetti had generated so much red ink and debt that its main shareholders -- British and American pension funds -- replaced Mr. de Benedetti with one of his little-known proteges, Roberto Colaninno.
By last year, Olivetti had joined with several big international partners, including Mannesmann A. G. of Germany, Vodafone of Britain and Bell Atlantic of the United States to form a phone business with six million subscribers, making it the No. 2 Italian phone business after the former state phone company, Telecom Italia.
So eyebrows were raised when Mr. Colaninno, 55, announced a week ago that Olivetti would sell its phone business for $8 billion to its phone partner, Mannesmann, then raise $50 billion more through debt and make a $60 billion unsolicited bid for its far bigger rival, Telecom.
"Who are these guys, and can they handle this?" Franco Bernabe, the Telecom chairman, asked about Mr. Colaninno and the investors around him, an associate recalled.
The remark, a tone of wonder mingled with doubt, appeared last week to catch the ambivalent mood of Italians, who seemed captivated by the sheer daring of a minnow seeking to swallow a whale, yet questioned what the bid meant both for Telecom and for Italy's drive to be a more open market.
Olivetti's decision to swallow Telecom, a company five times its size, represents one of the biggest hostile takeover attempts by any company.
"I'm not sure there really is a rational explanation," said an analyst at a large German brokerage firm, who insisted on anonymity. Eighty percent of Olivetti's value was its mobile phone business, he said.
Moreover, Mr. Colaninno's bid, he noted, was "predicated on asset stripping" by selling off Telecom businesses -- possibly including a share in Telecom's mobile phone unit, Telecom Italia Mobile, at a time when the phone business is rapidly shifting from fixed-line to wireless. And the enormous debt would drain Telecom at a time when increased competition was putting intense pressure on phone costs throughout Europe, squeezing industry margins.
Other analysts, however, said the potential for turning Telecom into a leaner, more efficient phone company gave Mr. Colaninno's plan an inner logic.
From an industrial point of view, said Peter Roe, an analyst at Paribas Securities in London, "it makes sense, and you can justify it."
"Telecom has a very strong position in the domestic market and a strong balance sheet," he said. "It's a very significant company in Italy and a large international player as well. So you're going up the size scale very quickly when you take on Telecom Italia."
To be sure, Telecom had floundered since the Italian Government took it public, and successive executives have done little to sort out its tangled problems -- not the least of which is getting its cost structure down by reducing its bloated staffing.
"If you had aspirations to take it, molding it to your image, now is the time to do it," Mr. Roe said.
The problem, of course, was that Telecom shareholders, disgusted with management's dithering, voted last fall to hire Mr. Bernabe, 49, who earned his spurs in the preceding six years reorganizing the former state oil giant, ENI S.p.A., and taking it public. So the question came down to Colaninno versus Bernabe.
Mr. Bernabe lost no time elaborating a turnaround plan, proposing to Telecom's board that he merge it with the profitable mobile phone unit, Telecom Italia Mobile, shed noncore activities like phone equipment manufacturing, and sell minority stakes in foreign phone companies that had no strategic value.
On Thursday, Telecom's board ordered Mr. Bernabe to move ahead, despite Olivetti's hostile bid, and present them with detailed plans.
But Italian securities regulators hampered that effort over the weekend. They had rejected Olivetti's offer, saying it provided insufficient details, but they approved a renewed bid on Saturday.
Under laws enacted in July, companies subject to takeovers are precluded from adopting "poison pill" maneuvers meant to block bids. Only a favorable vote from more than 30 percent of the company's owners at a shareholders meeting can decide otherwise, and analysts said that would be unlikely.
At the same time, Mr. Bernabe is seeking to persuade Italians, generally committed not so much to the quick kill as to finding competitive edge, that Mr. Colaninno's bid, if successful, would fatally weaken Telecom -- and with it, Italy's telecommunications industry.
Meeting with Telecom's union leaders, he cited figures meant as much for Telecom's shareholders as for its employees. If successful, he calculated, Olivetti's leveraged bid would leave Telecom with annual debt service of $2.8 billion.
As if to impress Italian politicians fearful of higher unemployment and their union backers alike, he declared that Telecom, to offset such financial burdens, would be forced to lay off up to 35,000 of its 126,000 employees, beyond the 20,000 to 25,000 he has said must go if Telecom is to be competitive.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
This Column Does Not Mention Monica's Dress

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE irony, said Ken Bode, munching on chips and salsa on an afternoon when he would normally have been at work, was that he had planned to give up his Washington gig anyway.
Commuting here from Evanston, Ill., where he is dean of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, to be the host of "Washington Week in Review," meant spending two and a half days a week away from his wife, and he was tired of missing her. When it came time to renegotiate his contract for the PBS program, he said, "I was going to say, 'Let's do this for one last year.' " 
 Now, of course, that won't be necessary. After clashing with a new boss who thought the show's quiet discussions of targeted tax cuts and Kosovo needed a little more edge and attitude, Mr. Bode was pushed out last week and had to tune in from a friend's place and watch his fill-in smile and thank him for his five years of service.
He had wanted to go on one last time and, before saying "So long," get a panel of four Pulitzer Prize winners talking about the nature of punditry, the argument culture and the "TV wasteland."
"I don't make Tom Friedman come on and say what he thinks about Clinton's morals!" Mr. Bode said of the New York Times columnist, one of his regulars. "He talks about the collapse of the Asian economy, and if that's too dull, O.K." Is there really no room for a show that dares to be serious, and seriously unsexy?
The trend toward news reporters, who are supposed to be objective, loudly sharing their opinions all over television has been a concern of Mr. Bode's for years. A decade ago, as a political correspondent for NBC News, he asked his bureau chief to forbid him to go on "The McLaughlin Group" because he did not have the stomach for what he calls "that food fight."
One small comfort is that Mr. Bode (pronounced BO-dee), 59, appears to have beaten back "attitude." For now, he has probably saved the show from such proposed improvements as visiting high school journalists and man-on-the-street interviews. After a week of bad publicity and questions about whether even public television now requires journalists to break chairs over one another's heads, the program's producer, WETA-TV, has made clear it won't be fiddling with the format. WETA even announced that for a few months the host will be Paul Duke, who was moderator for 20 years and makes Mr. Bode look like Geraldo.
Mr. Bode seems hurt, certainly, and a bit at loose ends. After a long lunch, he seems to feel there ought to be some place to hurry off to. But it is also clear that the real compensation for him is that he has a life to go back to.
His friends tell you right off he's not one of these ultra-driven Washington types who thinks a night off television is dead air -- as do, frankly, a couple of his regular guests, who in interviews seemed quite moved by the nobility of their sacrifice in staying off Friday's show.
"He's outstanding, but he also seems normal," said Elizabeth Piersol, Mr. Bode's producer, who was dismissed, apparently for remaining loyal to him. She called him "the person I've worked with with the most integrity," adding, almost by way of explanation, "He doesn't have to live here full-time."
Which is how he wanted it. Ten years ago, in the prime of his career as a national political correspondent, Mr. Bode quit and moved his family to Indiana so he could spend more time with them. At the time, he says, laughing, even they didn't really get it.
"It hit me one day. I was in Boston debating Pat Robertson on journalism ethics and I had to get home because my daughter was giving the commencement address for her sixth-grade class. I called her and told her I'd be there. Then you know how you put the phone down and it rings right away? It was the New York desk saying, 'On Friday I need this piece.' I said, 'I'll do it, but after the commencement.' "
"I knew then," he said, "that my problem was, I've got the best job but I've also got one chance to be a father, and I'm losing it."
Mr. Bode grew up in Hawarden, Iowa, where his family owned a small dairy that went under when milk bottles gave way to cartons. He earned a doctorate in political science from the University of North Carolina and taught at Michigan State and the State University of New York at Binghamton before moving into journalism. Soon after his epiphany in Boston, he returned to academia, to build a broadcast journalism program at DePauw University and to raise his family in Greencastle, Ind.
THEY were not immediately grateful. "I was on a bike ride with my 11-year-old, and she's crying. Finally, she says, 'Dad, I think it's a big comedown to go from being a Washington national correspondent for NBC to teaching where Dan Quayle went to college.' " But she came around, and both daughters ended up loving Indiana, where they collected "19 varsity letters between the two of them," he brags, and he spent evenings in school gyms. Last year, with both girls at Kenyon College, he took the Northwestern job.
Even after the ugliness of the last week, it is hard to feel sorry for Mr. Bode when he talks about how his family reacted. His daughter Matilda, president of her senior class, sent flowers. His daughter Josie, captain of the rugby team, wrote: "Tell me the name of this guy. I've got a bunch of pals."
His wife, Margo, a writer and designer of educational materials for children who are learning disabled, penned a love letter. "She said, 'We are starting another new phase together. Let's have fun.' "

HEADLINE: 10,000 Welfare Recipients Hired by Federal Agencies

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Federal agencies have hired more than 10,000 former welfare recipients in the last two years, meeting a goal set by the White House 19 months ahead of schedule, Administration officials said today.
Vice President Al Gore plans to announce the numbers on Monday at a meeting in San Francisco with companies that have hired people off welfare. 
 President Clinton ordered Government agencies to hire welfare recipients in a radio address in March 1997. At the time, Mr. Clinton's goal seemed ambitious because the Government was not hiring many people, and the number of civilian Federal employees was at the lowest level in three decades.
But Mr. Gore will report that the Federal Government has hired 10,187 former welfare recipients since March 1997. The White House had set a goal of hiring 10,000 people from the welfare rolls by the end of the next fiscal year in September 2000.
The Administration has repeatedly prodded private employers to hire welfare recipients. Mr. Gore coordinated Federal hiring efforts, and he says he believes that "the Federal Government should lead by example."
The Commerce Department has hired 3,194 former welfare recipients, or 76 percent of the number it was supposed to hire by the end of the next fiscal year. Some of the new employees are helping the Government prepare for the census next year.
The Defense Department has hired 2,094 people from the welfare rolls, exceeding its quota of 1,600, and the Department of Veterans Affairs has hired 1,323, far above its quota of 800.
But data compiled by the White House show some agencies falling far short of their goals. The State Department, for example, has hired only 56 former welfare recipients, representing 25 percent of its quota of 220 through the year 2000. The Justice Department has hired 245 former welfare recipients, or 54 percent of the 450 it is supposed to hire by September 2000.
The Department of Health and Human Services has met its goal, hiring 300 people who were receiving public assistance. Most of the new employees work outside Washington, in offices and clinics of the Indian Health Service.
The White House itself has hired eight former welfare recipients, two more than it had promised to hire.
Fewer than 8 million Americans are on welfare, the lowest number in decades. The number stood at 14.1 million in January 1993, when Mr. Clinton took office, and has fallen 35 percent since August 1996, when he signed a comprehensive bill overhauling the welfare system and establishing strict work requirements.
The changes in Federal welfare policy come at a time of strong economic growth, when many companies are avidly seeking workers.
A private nonprofit group, the Welfare to Work Partnership, formed in 1997 with support from Democrats and Republicans alike, helps companies hire welfare recipients. Vice President Gore will say the 10,000 companies in the Welfare to Work Partnership have now hired 410,000 welfare recipients.
Eli J. Segal, president of the Welfare to Work Partnership, said companies hiring welfare recipients described them as good, productive employees. "Companies report higher retention rates for welfare recipients than for other newly hired employees," Mr. Segal said.
Employers often provide extra training to welfare recipients, and they have discovered that it is useful to assign a mentor, or job coach, to each person hired off welfare, Mr. Segal said.

HEADLINE: As U.S. Buyers Age, Designers of Autos Make Subtle Shifts

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Engineers at the Lear Corporation, the world's largest independent supplier of automotive interiors, labored for months last year to come up with a vehicle that would meet all the needs of older Americans. The seats swivel out for easy access, the dashboard controls and displays are unusually large and the trunk floor partly rolls out at the back for easy loading.
When the engineers were done, they showed the prototype to the 82-year-old father of the company's chairman -- and were crestfallen at his response. Looking at the swiveling seats in particular, he was dismissive. 
 "He said he didn't need it," said Marilyn Vala, Lear's product analysis manager.
The aging of Americans poses quandaries for businesses in many industries, but few companies face as many difficult decisions as auto makers and their suppliers. Power, sex and youth have long been used to sell cars, so anything that suggests buyers might not be as virile and agile as they were could backfire.
"Baby boomers don't want to admit they're getting older," said John Wolkonowicz, an auto industry consultant at Arthur D. Little. "You can't be too catering to age, you have to do it invisibly -- you have to give people vehicles they can get excited about."
Yet driving or climbing into a car can be difficult and even painful for aging bodies. And with millions of baby boomers now entering their 50's every year, the auto industry is starting to redesign its vehicles to meet the needs of older Americans -- without being obvious about it.
For various reasons, the average age of new-car buyers is rising even faster than that of the overall population. Many older buyers would be better served by vehicles designed differently from vehicles for younger buyers, to reflect the less acute vision and reduced muscular flexibility of bodies that are 50 or older.
Until now, older Americans have shown little interest in buying vehicles tailored to their needs and auto makers have paid fairly little attention to selling such vehicles. Auto makers have long been obsessed with luring young buyers in the hopes that brand loyalties, once formed, will persist over the 10 or 15 new cars a prosperous American might buy over a lifetime. Even car divisions like Buick and Cadillac, which did very well selling to older Americans, have shifted their marketing focus to drivers in their 40's and younger.
"Everyone is always going after the young buyer," said Ben R. Level 3d, the Ford Motor Company's executive director of market research. "You very rarely hear about anyone going after the old buyer -- maybe it's cultural."
But there are signs now that attitudes are beginning to change. The main reason for the subtle shift is the enormous and growing market that older, more affluent Americans represent. As auto makers try to accommodate their needs, however, they are trying to be as subtle as possible.
The result -- new car features that are easy to overlook but reflect a new awareness of older Americans' needs. When the new Chevrolet Impala midsized sedan goes on sale later this year, for example, it will have the ignition on the dashboard rather than the side of the steering column -- a seemingly unimportant choice. But the ignition will be on the dashboard because General Motors found that slightly arthritic hands could turn a key sideways more easily if the wrist were not already bent.
Similarly, the new Ford Focus, which will replace the Ford Escort this year, has front door openings that extend farther forward on the car at knee level, to make it easier for older drivers to swing their legs into the car. The Focus and the new Dodge Neon also have seats that are slightly higher, partly because many older people find it harder to climb in or out of a low vehicle.
Even the new Chevrolet Corvette sports car, long a symbol of youthful virility, has been redesigned to make it easier for aging baby boomers to climb in and out. And the trunk has been enlarged to carry golf clubs.
Auto suppliers say that they are starting to receive many requests from auto makers for parts that are designed for older Americans. "The interest is there now -- why it wasn't there five years ago, I don't know," said Kenneth Way, the chairman and chief executive of Lear.
Lear will display its prototype for an older person's vehicle on Monday, at the opening of the auto parts industry convention here, an event expected to include many products aimed at an aging America. Lear modified a Dodge Caravan minivan to show all the products that could be installed on cars to make them easier for older people to use.
Meanwhile, manufacturers are working on seat belts that are mounted on both sides of each seat and clasp in the front, so that older customers will not have to twist their bodies to find and pull seat belts around and across their bodies. They are designing thicker door handles with more contoured grooves, to make them easier to grip.
DaimlerChrysler and other auto makers are experimenting with prototypes of sedans that would not need side pillars. The rear doors would open backward with hinges at the rear, offering more room to climb into the vehicle and enabling handicapped drivers to readily swing a folded wheel chair in behind the seat.
Dashboards increasingly feature big knobs and large displays. Auto designers say that such details also attract young buyers at a time when other fashions include kitchen tools like ice cream scoops that have big, rubber handles that were originally designed for arthritic hands.
"It's coming from the younger generation, they're showing us that suspenders are O.K., and the little granny glasses," said Jerry Hirshberg, Nissan's president of North American design. "It used to be if there were a lecture with ergonomics in the name, I'd probably skip it, but now it has a zing to it."
Auto designers and consultants say that no single car will include all of the possible devices for older Americans, but many cars will quietly incorporate some features. An old, slightly ageist, adage in the auto industry says that an old man will buy a young man's car, but a young man will not buy an old man's car.
Indeed, Detroit auto makers are leery of catering too heavily to older buyers. They recall the early 1980's, when younger customers defected in droves to foreign auto makers and domestic manufacturers like Chrysler were left with mostly older drivers, said David P. Bostwick, DaimlerChrysler's director of North American corporate market research.
Still, the median age of new-car buyers in the United States has risen to 47 from 40 over the last decade, while the median age of buyers of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickups has climbed to 43 from 39, according to auto makers' research. Over the same period, the median age of all Americans has only crept up about three years to 34.9.
Americans over 55 make up a fifth of the population but control up to three-quarters of the nation's financial assets, researchers estimate. After a nearly two-decadelong stock market boom, they can afford new cars even though the average price is now around $20,800.
Dr. Harvey Kornblit and his wife, Doris, who are both 71 and live in Houston, just bought a new $30,000 Jeep Grand Cherokee Limited with such features as radio controls on the steering wheel, so that they no longer have to lean over to change stations. But the couple chose the vehicle not because of these features but because they liked the solid feel of its exterior, Mrs. Kornblit said.
"What I want is a sturdy body that's metal, not plastic," she said.
Late-model used cars have become popular as substitutes for smaller, similarly priced new cars, but mainly among younger buyers.
Some of the ideas now being considered to accommodate older drivers have been tried and abandoned before. The Chrysler Corporation, for example, offered swiveling seats in the late 1950's, although they were not powered and were marketed to women leery of clambering into cars while wearing tight skirts.
Gerry T. Piaskowski, DaimlerChrysler's director of passenger car and minivan interior design, said that the company would take another look at swiveling seats. "Sometimes old ideas," he said, "are good ideas."

HEADLINE: Argentine President Admits Interest in 3d Term

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Seven months after he announced that he was leaving office, President Carlos Saul Menem says he will run for re-election if his supporters can legally overturn a constitutional ban prohibiting a third consecutive term.
Mr. Menem's aides say that he is convinced that the country needs him in office to resist the financial contagion spreading from neighboring Brazil and that he is committed to negotiating a treaty with the United States during the next few years that would replace the peso with the dollar as Argentina's currency. 
 "If there's a possibility of running in the primaries, I'll do it," Mr. Menem said in a radio interview on Friday.
Mr. Menem remains far behind in the polls, and, with the ruling Justicialist Party's primary vote due in May or June and the general election scheduled for October, he may be running out of time. But since he was first elected as a dark-horse candidate in 1989, he has repeatedly surprised analysts with his political resourcefulness and cunning.
After Brazil's problems accelerated with its Jan. 13 devaluation, Mr. Menem's standing in opinion polls improved somewhat. He is generally credited with ending Argentina's long history of hyperinflation by pegging the peso's value one-to-one to the dollar in 1991.
The Argentine Constitution prohibits three consecutive presidential terms. A 1995 amendment specifically barred Mr. Menem from a third term, since the Constitution was written after he was already in his first term. Mr. Menem's supporters are appealing to the Supreme Court to strike that amendment.
Many analysts say the case will be a test of the independence of the judiciary. Over the years, court rulings have favored Mr. Menem. But since he announced he would step down, the courts have shown increasing independence.
Mr. Menem's aides said he could run in the primary while waiting for the Supreme Court to make a ruling. They said Carlos Reutemann, a Senator from Santa Fe Province, could run as Mr. Menem's Vice President.
Mr. Menem is a bitter enemy of Eduardo Duhalde, the Buenos Aires Governor and current leading Justicialist candidate for President. Analysts say that Mr. Menem's campaign may be intended as much to deny Mr. Duhalde the opportunity to lead their party as it is to win a shot at the Buenos Aires Mayor, Fernando de la Rua, who is the Alianza presidential candidate.
The former president, Raul Alfonsin, a leader of the Alianza opposition coalition, said Congress should consider impeaching Mr. Menem for attempting to subvert the Constitution. He said Mr. Menem was acting strangely due to a "strange psychological state." Mr. Menem responded angrily, saying no one should listen to Mr. Alfonsin because "he couldn't govern the country."
Mr. Menem announced that he was not running for re-election last July to save his party from bitter division. He met privately with Mr. Duhalde today to try to keep the party united.

HEADLINE: As Albright Arrives in China, Congress Is Watching Closely

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Every time a Secretary of State comes to China, Congress watches closely. And perhaps no more so than on a brief visit this week by Madeleine K. Albright, who arrived here this evening.
Hours before she left, the Senate passed a unanimous resolution calling on the Clinton Administration to condemn China's human rights policy at the meeting next month of the United Nations human rights commission in Geneva. 
 While she was en route, the State Department released its annual human rights report, chastising China for regression on the matter and expressing disappointment that it had not delivered on the improvement in human rights it had promised.
On board her plane, her spokesman, James P. Rubin, described as deplorable the detention of one dissident and the 18-month sentence given another in the last two days by the Chinese authorities.
The Administration has prided itself on broadening its China policy in the last several years from being focused on just human rights to encompassing other issues, including trade and developing what the Administration dubbed a "strategic partnership."
But with the budding relationship with China in retreat, Ms. Albright will touch on a host of problems that enrage the Chinese, from a proposal for a theater missile defense system in Asia to the cancellation of the sale of an American satellite to a company with ties to the Chinese military.
Ms. Albright will also grill the Chinese on why they cannot help out more in controlling nuclear developments in North Korea, and gauge their readiness to join the World Trade Organization, Administration officials say.
The officials, insisting on anonymity, declined to put an order of priority on the long list of problems that the Chinese would raise with Ms. Albright or that she would put to them. But one of her tasks, Mr. Rubin said, will be to "tell it like it is" about Washington's expectations on human rights.
At the same time, Mr. Rubin and other Administration officials who have prepared Ms. Albright for this trip said they were uneasy with the approach of many in Congress who believe that sponsoring a resolution against the Chinese in Geneva is the best policy.
Administration officials have argued in recent weeks that a resolution against China may make members of Congress feel good but does not necessarily reap results.
China objects to the resolution as an infringement of its sovereignty. It sounded a similar tone in its official response to the State Department human rights report, expressing indignation and resentment at what it termed American meddling in China's internal affairs.
In recent months, Chinese officials have argued that because of the nation's mounting economic problems and unprecedented numbers of unemployed, they cannot allow political dissent from the ruling Communist Party. The Government has expressed concern about the potential of sudden widespread social instability, particularly in the 50th anniversary year of the Communist takeover of China and the 10th anniversary of the student protests and deaths in Tiananmen Square.
Ms. Albright's talks could serve to assess how the Chinese would react if Washington went ahead with a resolution in Geneva in late March. The problem is made even more vexing because the Chinese Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, is due in Washington for an official visit on April 8.
Last year, for the first time since 1991, Washington did not introduce a resolution against China in Geneva, saying China had made some progress in human rights. The Chinese would see any American move toward a resolution this year as a sharp deterioration in their relationship with the United States.
But with three democracy activists jailed late last year for 11 to 13 years and deepening pressure from Congress to take a stand in Geneva, the Administration must decide soon what to do.
The Hong Kong office of the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said tonight that organizers of a planned seminar on human rights in Wuhan this weekend had been detained.
On Friday, Wu Yilong, the founder of a banned political party, was detained in Hangzhou for questioning, and Peng Ming, a liberal intellectual who had tried to run an independent discussion forum in Beijing, was sentenced without trial to 18 months in a labor camp.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Taxpayers: Revolt!

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A half-century ago, government at all levels controlled a fourth of our economy. Today it's up to a third; this is the wrong direction.
This year's rough handling of tax relief was best analyzed by an economist-humorist: 
 "Unless something is done -- and soon," writes Dave Barry, "to relieve the massive buildup of excess tax receipts, the Treasury Building will explode and release its contents into the atmosphere, forming an immense cloud of money. . . . If the wind were to shift, the money could fall back to Earth, where some of it could, conceivably, wind up -- this is referred to in top-secret government documents as 'The Doomsday Scenario' -- back in the hands of taxpayers."
With the Government awash in the profits of prosperity, why has there been no taxpayers' revolt -- no demand that a chunk of today's surplus be left in the pocket of its source?
One reason is that maintaining today's high rate of taxation is being falsely sold as "saving Social Security" -- as if we were squirreling away the decades of anticipated surplus for the boomers' rainy day. But that trust fund is always on loan to the Treasury; it's a pocket-switching business that does not deal with real reform, which would be to raise the next generation's retirement age.
Another reason for the unrevolt is that much of the suddenly discovered bonanza in Rosy Scenario's "projected surplus" could be used to reduce the national debt. Conservatives like that; it means that when massive Treasury borrowing is needed to send out checks to boomer-geezers, interest rates would probably be lower.
So let's deal with reality. If two-thirds of the surplus is earmarked for debt payment, what sort of tax cut is likely? President Clinton would veto a one-size-fits-all 10 percent rate cut, while his array of tailored loopholes would not be passed.
1. A partial fix of the marriage penalty. Social conservatives argue rightly that government should not discourage marriage. Today, two people making $100,000 each have to pay up to an additional $10,000 a year just to have children in wedlock. That's anti-family and it's time to stop it.
2. An equal reduction of everybody's rates, shaving only a couple of percentage points off the fortyish top rate. This is part of what economic conservatives urge to keep the boom booming. If it benefits the top third most, that's because the top third pays most of the taxes and would use that money most productively -- saving, buying, investing, employing. That system has left the redistributive world far behind.
3. Some progress on "death to the death tax." By confiscating 55 percent of your savings beyond a certain amount when you die, the Government punishes you for saving for your children. Tax policy now says: You can't take it with you and you can't leave it behind, so spend it. But most Americans, and not just richies, think that you should be able to leave most of what you save to your kids. A reduction of the estate tax to the percentage of the top income rate is considered fair.
Such a package of tax cuts might be difficult to vote against. Vice President Al Gore would think twice before opposing it. It does not have the sweeping benefit of the historic 1986 reforms, but today's Senate Finance Committee does not have Bob Packwood and Bill Bradley to conceive a daringly simple and fair plan and to build a surprise coalition.
Presented with such a modest but sensible package worked out in the Congress, what would Clinton do? My guess is that he would declare victory on "preserving the surplus" and averting the full 10 percent across-the-board rate cut, scrap his unsalable retirement entitlement and cut a deal on the sartorial tax reductions.
The anticipated Clinton price for tax cuts: Let's take a $200 billion slice of our projected pie in the sky, and let me plan to spend half on education while you spend half on defense.
Would Democrats in Congress go along with this sort of a tax-budget deal? The education lobby would like it; California could use the anti-missile money; some creative credit could be found to pay off contingency-fee lawyers.
There; that would comfort the overburdened taxpayer. Let's keep moving on.

HEADLINE: German Leader Is Popular, but Grip Seems Unsure

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 28

 BODY:
There he was last week, the German Chancellor, no less, on a television talk show being asked if he would submit to a test that would determine if the color of his abundant dark brown hair was real. Yes, Gerhard Schroder said with a coy grin, "This is all genuine, really everything."
It was a moment that captured the extent of Germany's transformation during the four-month rule of the 54-year-old Mr. Schroder. His predecessor, Helmut Kohl, rarely appeared on talk shows, let alone to talk about his (gray) hair. Mr. Schroder, a white-toothed modern image merchant, has popularized the exercise of power. 
 Germans tend to like the change: Mr. Schroder's personal popularity remains high. But has Germany's first Social Democratic Chancellor in 16 years also trivialized governance, to the point where Europe's most powerful country is sublimely coiffed at the top but rudderless?
Abrupt policy shifts on immigration and nuclear power, discordant ministerial voices, rising unemployment, signs of recession and messy decision-making by committee have all raised sharp questions about Mr. Schroder. "Where is the line?" the conservative weekly Die Zeit asked. The centrist Berlin Tagespiegel was blunter last week, alluding to "lunatic amateurism."
Bodo Hombach, the Chancellor's chief of staff, said in an interview that the Government needed time. "In many ways we are a blocked society, but you cannot push things through here over the objections of others," he said. "Action by consensus is an old German tradition, and we will build the necessary bridges."
But time seems short. Uncertain government matters less when an economy is strong and a country's self-image stable. But Germany's combination of stalled growth, an aging population, disappearing jobs, uneasy relations between its eastern and western regions, charged politics of immigration and a continuing quest for a "normal" identity appears treacherous.
The euro, Europe's infant common currency, has fallen 7 percent against the dollar in a month as Germany's Economics Minister has done something long unthinkable: he has bickered with central bankers. The German economy shrank 0.4 percent in the last quarter of l998, a grim sign when unemployment under Mr. Schroder, far from falling by one million as he promised, has already surged to 11.5 percent, from 10.9 percent.
On the international front, Germany's relations with its European allies and with the United States are in the midst of a difficult adjustment reflecting the arrival in power of a new, more assertive postwar German generation.
Jean Glavany, the French Agricultural Minister, expressed his country's dismay by declaring last week that Mr. Schroder's demands for a cut in Germany's huge contribution to the European Union budget reminded him of Margaret Thatcher.
From a Gallic source, such criticism suggests that the French-German alliance, long at the heart of European integration, is in trouble -- or at the very least in flux.
Elected on a largely domestic agenda, Mr. Schroder has found himself thrust abruptly into difficult international issues -- among them reform of the European Union budget and NATO -- for which his Government has sometimes appeared poorly prepared.
"The allies are somewhat flabbergasted," said Joachim Krauze, deputy director of the German Society for Foreign Affairs. "Germany demanding its interests in an assertive way, Germany no longer viewing the independence of the European central bank as sacrosanct. It's worrying and I don't think it's productive."
But perhaps it is what most Germans want. Although opinion polls have recently shown that Mr. Schroder's coalition of Social Democrats and environmentalist Greens would be defeated if a new election were held today, the Chancellor's own popularity was estimated at more than 70 percent this month by Der Spiegel.
It seems clear that the Chancellor's glad-handing style, his informality, his preference for talking about the future rather than the trauma of Germany's past, his popular touch, even his readiness to talk hair have struck a chord with a generation of Germans tired of Mr. Kohl's history lessons.
"Mr. Schroder has understood that people want to be left in peace," said Bernhard Schlink, the novelist. "What we have is a generation of nice passive consumers who are busy in a nice passive way. Why should they bother about big ideas, projects, goals and ambitions?"
The fact is, though, that Germany does appear to have to resolve some basic problems in order to move forward.
One is whether this is "a country of immigration," as Mr. Schroder's coalition initially proposed. Another linked question is whether Germany's vaunted "social market" economy, built on consensus between unions and employers and on extensive social insurance, has stalled irrevocably. If it has, immigration could clearly become an explosive question. No sinking economy embraces foreigners.
Last week, Mr. Schroder was obliged to reverse course on a major element of his proposal to make German citizenship easier to acquire for the country's 7.3 million foreigners.
Faced by a petition that had already gathered one million signatures against his plans, and by a defeat this month to Christian Democrats in a state election in Hesse, he dropped a proposal that dual citizenship be permitted.
The proposal was important because many of Germany's more than two million Turks are reluctant to give up Turkish citizenship (that alone confers the right to buy land in Turkey) although they want to become Germans, and have, for instance, the right to vote in all elections. But the Chancellor perceived -- albeit belatedly -- that his entire immigration revision, aimed at changing a 1913 citizenship law based largely on blood lines, would collapse if this measure was not abandoned.
Once again, as in his earlier reversal on banning the export of nuclear waste, he appeared to have been carelessly drawn into an untenable position by his Green coalition partners. "We underestimated the reaction on dual citizenship, but we will still get a new immigration law that will critically redefine German identity," said Karsten Voigt, a Social Democratic Foreign Ministry official. "That is the main thing."
But Mr. Schroder seems certain to face a battle even on the rest of his proposed law allowing foreigners to request citizenship after eight years of residence -- instead of 15 -- and granting automatic citizenship to children born here who have at least one parent who has lived in Germany since the age of 14.
The fact is that the immigration issue has become steadily more sensitive as Mr. Schroder has so far failed in his central electoral pledge: to reduce the number of unemployed by at least one million people.
In fact, unemployment lines have lengthened by more than 500,000 people in just four months.
If the Chancellor has a discernible passion -- rather than issues that are merely material for image management -- it is putting Germans back to work.
Characteristically, Mr. Schroder, who likes to moderate quietly between opposing factions rather than lead from the front, has asked Mr. Hombach to take the initiative at the head of a so-called Alliance for Jobs. This group of labor unions and employers is reviewing issues including taxation, social security, working hours, pensions, wages, training and education.
Call it German consensus-making writ large. It is unwieldy, slow, and just possibly productive. A lot of people seem to agree on the basic problem: the German labor market is too regulated and too weighed down with high social security charges to generate jobs. But, as Mr. Hombach said, "To get from knowledge to action in this society is extremely difficult."
According to Mr. Hombach, about $350 billion is earned annually in the German black economy. "We probably have four times more worker hours in this black economy than we need to get rid of unemployment completely. So the problem is clear: how do you get this labor out from under?"
The answer, he said, was clear enough: bring down the taxes and charges on legal salaries that make people prefer the combination of off-the-books wages and unemployment benefits to a regular job.
But that, of course, might eventually imply a partial dismantling of the health and other insurance benefits enjoyed by Germans (and immigrants) -- an explosive suggestion.
Germany still seems very far from agreement on reform. Indeed a wage rise of 4 percent (with inflation at close to zero) won this month by the huge I.G. Metall engineering union -- which sets the bar for all other unions -- had many businessmen in a fury.
It is clear that Mr. Schroder is tempted to emulate Tony Blair of Britain. But Mr. Blair, of course, could build on what Mrs. Thatcher had already done. The Chancellor, by contrast, has everything to do and a divided Social Democratic Party to deal with, in which resistance to market reform remains strong.
The figurehead for that resistance is Oskar Lafontaine, the Economics Minister and party chairman. He and the European central bank governor, Wim Duisenberg of Holland, have been engaged in extraordinary low-level warfare as Mr. Lafontaine suggests lower interest rates are really the answer to Germany's -- and Europe's -- problems.
Last week Mr. Duisenberg said that he had never read the book on economics written recently by Mr. Lafontaine and his wife, and that he had "absolutely no intention" of doing so.
As in many of his Government's tiffs and travails, Mr. Schroder has not intervened decisively, leaving the impression that Germany is ready to abandon its long sacrosanct monetary orthodoxy in pursuit of murky new goals.
"Basic decisions have been left untaken, basic lines left unclear," said Mr. Krauze, the foreign policy expert. "A lot of time has been lost on issues that are basically luxuries -- like giving up nuclear power. We need direction."
Mr. Schroder has promised to provide it soon, speaking of "technical problems" in the first months. He leads a coalition made up of a party that has not been in power for almost a generation and another that has never been in power. Teething problems were probably inevitable. But further drift looks dangerous.
"We will get there," Mr. Hombach said, "and with a style that is less encrusted, more relaxed, more open, more frank."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1988 words

HEADLINE: For Women in Medicine, a Road to Compromise, Not Perks

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
By all rights, this should be the perfect time to be a woman in medicine.
The days of women toiling as a mostly unwelcome presence in the country's medical schools are long over: women now account for roughly 45 percent of all medical students, up from about 25 percent in 1980. 
 And once they graduate, they are in high demand: many patients, especially women, now request female doctors because, among other reasons, they are perceived as spending more time with patients. Further, women's health issues -- breast and ovarian cancer most prominently -- are front and center in medical research and political agendas, fostering star-studded fund-raisers, road races and the like in every major city in the country.
But despite these gains, the top tiers of medicine have remained inaccessible to many women, largely, experts say, because they are unwilling or unable to find a balance between the years of study those specialties require and a life outside of medicine.
"Basically, the picture is bad," said Dr. Wendy Chavkin, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Women's Association. "Women comprise very few dean and tenured faculty positions, and there are a lack of them in surgical specialties." The main reason, Dr. Chavkin said, is that in medicine, "there are still issues about career pathways that are the least bit off track, like taking time off for child rearing."
But rather than giving up their medical careers for their families, as so many of their predecessors felt forced to do, or forgoing motherhood altogether, more female doctors today are finding ways to practice medicine part time -- as some women in law, journalism, finance and other demanding fields have been doing for years.
They are joining multi-physician practices, or working as employees for practices run by managed-care companies that give them a chance for an office life that is closer to 9 to 5, willingly sacrificing higher salaries for a flexibility that until recently was virtually unheard of in medicine.
In a recent study, the Commonwealth Fund, a large private philanthropic and research organization in New York, found that 25 percent of female doctors who were surveyed said that they worked fewer than 40 hours a week, compared with 12 percent of male doctors. And 17 percent of female doctors said they worked 30 hours a week or fewer, compared with only 8 percent of males.
In New York State, the trend of women working fewer hours is borne out most dramatically among younger doctors. Over all, female doctors work 9 percent fewer hours than male doctors. But among female doctors under 45, the number jumps to 15 percent, said Edward Salsberg, director of the Center for Health Workforce Studies at the State University of New York at Albany.
"The emergence of managed care has introduced the idea that you can be an employee," said Dr. Erica Frank, an assistant professor at the Emory School of Medicine in Atlanta, and the principal investigator of the Women Physicians' Health Study, the largest national study of female doctors.
"This can mean more flexible hours and fewer of them, and the ability to think about medicine as a profession that doesn't require complete consumption," Dr. Frank said. "And clearly women are leading the way. The pay is lower. But this might be acceptable to some people to have more of a life."
Dr. Rayze Simonson works as an obstetrician in a six-person practice on the Upper West Side. The practice is run by St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, which takes care of administrative tasks like billings, relieving the doctors -- five of whom are women with children -- and of some of the time-consuming hassles of running a medical office.
"The idea was that in a larger group you could balance more your life and career," Dr. Simonson said. "We are only on call every sixth night and every sixth weekend, which in ob-gyn is huge flexibility." Her husband is a journalist, and they rely heavily on a baby sitter.
 
Accepting Less In Pay and Prestige
Yet while this kind of work has become a welcome option for some doctors looking for more balanced lives, experts say that it has created an increasing "pink-collar" level of medicine -- in which more women are concentrated in the lowest-paying, least prestigious specialties.
Indeed, while the number of women practicing medicine has more than tripled in the last 20 years, female doctors still earn roughly two-thirds of their male counterparts' salaries, largely because they work fewer hours a week and because there are far fewer of them in the most prestigious and highest-paid specialties.
Of the 34,882 female residents in the country in 1997, one-tenth of one percent were in the surgical subspecialties. Or, looked at another way, of all residents studying surgical specialties, only 17.2 percent of them were women.
And while the average male doctor in private practice in the United States makes $273,690 a year, his female counterpart makes $155,590 on average, according to Medical Economics, a trade journal. Further, 50 percent of female doctors surveyed by the Commonwealth Fund reported incomes of $100,000 or less, compared with 22 percent of men.
Although health experts, including many women, said there was still sexism in medicine, particularly in the top echelons of academia, they cited the difficulty in combining a demanding profession with a family life as the biggest hindrance most female doctors faced in rising higher in their fields.
"I think a lot of male doctors still have housewives at home," said Dr. Simonson, who has four children, one of them a newborn. "They can stay at work until 10 P.M., and when they get home, their kids are bathed and there is food in the house."
"I just don't have the luxury of staying at work late," she added, saying that means a lower income.
 
Obstacles for Women May Also Hurt Field
Outside of the financial penalties for women, there may be a loss to medicine generally when they are withheld from its top ranks.
"The gains of women help to contribute to an ongoing focus on women's health," said Dr. Karen Scott Collins, a vice president of the Commonwealth Fund. "What they bring is additional important concerns. For example, there is more focus on domestic violence as a medical problem, a lot of attention to counseling for menopause, a focus on reproductive health and so on."
Women in other high-intensity fields face similar challenges although medicine presents conflicts for women that appear more intractable, experts said.
There are years of study and grueling hospital training programs, followed by demanding schedules and unpredictable patients. And unlike, say, investment banking, there are constant critical advances in medicine: stay out of the field for two years to raise children, and one would miss out on entire bodies of research and treatment developments vital to patients' health.
As a result, many women are attracted to pediatrics and primary care "simply because there is not as much training," said Dr. Holly Andersen, a 36-year-old cardiologist on the Upper East Side, especially since most of that training coincides with a woman's prime child-bearing years.
"Why do men care about this?" she said. "They can always marry 25-year-olds."
Dr. Gail Bauchman got her first taste of compromise in medical school in the 1980's. Although her dream had been to specialize in obstetrics, she felt that she would have a hard time managing a family life while tending to patients in labor on weekends and in the middle of the night. So she chose family medicine instead, and built a bustling private practice on the Upper West Side.
At 36, she decided to try to get pregnant. "I realized it was now or never," she said. But after she gave birth to twins, Avital and Natalia, in August 1997, compromises turned to disappointments.
She tried to return to her full-time practice, but found life unmanageable. So she looked for a part-time position. "Most practices said, 'You work full time or you don't work here,' " Dr. Bauchman said.
Her solution was to take a part-time job at the Mount Sinai Adolescent Health Center, for a fraction of her earnings as a private practice doctor. She said the situation works for her, but was hardly what she had hoped for.
"There is this problem with finding the middle ground," Dr. Bauchman said. "I shouldn't be struggling to find part-time work. And if these practices close their doors to part timers, they don't have the benefit of having a female doctor, and therefore you lose patients, because patients say that they want that."
 
Growing Demand For Personal Approach
Even while they are earning less on average, female physicians are more in demand than ever, experts say, particularly in specialties that cater to female patients.
Dr. Alison Estabrook, a prominent breast surgeon and associate director of the breast center at St. Luke's, remembers sitting around her family's kitchen table just a decade ago, listening to her mother's friend say that she would never let a female surgeon touch her.
Today, a female breast surgeon can "basically write her own ticket," Dr. Estabrook said. "As more women patients are seeking power in their own care they are attracted to strong women doctors," she said.
Dr. Estabrook concedes that part of the market value of female surgeons is based on supply and demand, because far fewer women than men are willing to devote their lives to surgery. "Surgery creates tremendous conflicts," said Dr. Estabrook, who is 47 and married to another doctor. She deliberately chose not have children, she says, because she could not imagine where she could trim her professional day.
The demand for female doctors is not limited to specialties that serve women, hospital administrators say. "The minute we put a female physician in a practice," said Dr. Myron L. Weisfeldt, chairman of medicine at New York Presbyterian Hospital, "the appointment book becomes fully booked.
"It is not only women who appreciate these physicians," Dr. Weisfeldt added. "I think it deals with professional attitudes." He said that studies have shown that women tend to spend more time with patients and to focus on them as people rather than on the procedures they need.
 
With Children, Going Part Time
Some women find that when they become mothers, they need to scale back or forgo jobs with prestigious academic medical centers, and instead choose work in large practices, often ones that serve a high H.M.O. base.
Dr. Genevieve Lambert worked for eight years at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, mostly in the Pediatric H.I.V. unit. After giving birth to each of her two children, she cut back one work day. As she awaits her third, she has given up her career at the hospital altogether to loosen her schedule and has joined a private practice on Long Island where she works two and a half days a week and is paid per diem.
"At least half of my female friends from medical school are working part time now," said Dr. Lambert, who is 41. The women, she said, are generally not doing this willingly, but because society as a whole still makes child rearing primarily a mother's responsibility.
"Medicine is fairly egalitarian in that a woman who chooses to rise to the top of medicine can do so now," she said. "The issue of how to bring women to parity with men in the workplace is finding ways to relieve women as primary care givers to children."
Dr. Andersen, who was chief medical resident at Cornell in 1994-95 and is now one of only a handful of female cardiologists in Manhattan, said she is beginning to appreciate the conflicts she will face if she chooses to have a family.
"Being a woman in medicine, there are not that many paradigms we can look to and say, 'This is how they did it, this is the way I can do it, too,' " Dr. Andersen said. "You have to work on it yourself."
