HEADLINE: State Will Transfer Control Of Armory on Park Avenue

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
In a major move to halt the deterioration of the landmark Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, the Pataki administration has decided to transfer control of the building and oversight over the cultural and art shows held there to a private company or a nonprofit organization.
State officials said the transfer would end control of the armory by an obscure state military agency that critics say has long neglected vital repairs. Last March, The New York Times reported that collapsing ceilings, leaky walls and crumbling masonry were endangering parts of the 19th-century building's ornate rooms and a multimillion-dollar collection of American paintings, decorative arts and military artifacts. 
 "Someone has to do something quickly to save this building," said Charles A. Gargano, an economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki who is in charge of forming a rescue plan for the armory.
Mr. Gargano is chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the unit that offers loans and technical assistance to rehabilitate civic projects. He said that a preliminary study indicated that $50 million might be needed for making long-term repairs and adding air-conditioning to the building.
Mr. Gargano said he doubted the state would finance a large part of the repair work, and added that the money would have to be raised mainly by the organization that assumes management control. The funds, he said, could be obtained by raising rental fees for art and antiques shows and by using the armory for concerts and plays year-round. Because it is not air-conditioned, the five-story crenelated building is largely unused in the summer.
In addition to housing a rare collection of Civil War art and military memorabilia, the building is New York City's premier showcase for internationally renowned art, antique and craft shows.
The agency that runs the armory, the Division of Military and Naval Affairs, has long said that it lacked the funds to operate the building. But critics assert that the division ignored maintenance for decades, failed to seek renovation appropriations from the Legislature and without competitive bidding, leased space at bargain rates to a select group of producers who reap huge profits from art fairs and exhibitions in the armory.
Last year the state obtained $1.9 million from rents at the armory, while the division spent $693,000 on repairs and operation costs. The rest went to the state's general fund.
Mr. Gargano said that the state would hire a consulting company this month to help negotiate terms with organizations that submit proposals to operate the armory, which covers the block between East 66th and East 67th Streets and Park and Lexington Avenues.
He said the state expects to turn over full administration of the building next year.
"We want a practical business plan from the private sector that can generate the funds needed to rescue this priceless treasure and to maintain it as a cultural and art center," Mr. Gargano said.
Later this year, he added, the Empire State Corporation will take control of the building from the military division and supervise it until another organization is in place. The military division oversees the state's National Guard units, and under Mr. Gargano's plan, the Guard will continue to use offices in the building for administrative purposes.
Asked if the Pataki administration was displeased with the military division's administration of the armory, Mr. Gargano said, "I won't characterize their management, but I am unhappy with the condition of the building."
Scott Sandman, a spokesman for the division, said its officials had no objections to surrendering control. "A situation as unique and complex as this requires a creative, forward-thinking solution," he said.
Mr. Sandman said the division spent $415,000 last year for renovations, mainly to repair leaks on the building's south side. Water damage and safety concerns forced the closing of two rooms and the removal of dozens of paintings from public view.
Members of a nonprofit organization, the Seventh Regiment Conservancy, said their group would make a bid to run the armory. "Our vision is to turn the building into a venue for performing and visual arts," said Wade F. B. Thompson, the conservancy's chairman. Mr. Thompson is a trustee of the Municipal Art Society, a private group dedicated to maintaining the city's architectural heritage.
A takeover by a private or nonprofit entity, however, could be complicated by a court dispute between the state and a veterans' group, the Seventh Regiment Fund, over ownership of the armory's art collection, which includes a prized Thomas Nast canvas of the regiment leaving the city for battle at the start of the Civil War in 1861.
"This is not the state's building to give away," said Kenyon B. FitzGerald Jr., the fund's president. "They only have the right to administer it as long as it is a state military facility."
Mr. FitzGerald said the fund wants a military museum established in the armory as well as cultural exhibits.
"But we are glad that the military affairs division is being removed," he added, "It was at the low end of the state's food chain and would never be given the money necessary to restore and preserve this landmark."
The armory opened in 1870 after being built on city-owned land with private funds raised by the Seventh Regiment, a state militia unit that no longer exists. In 1942, the National Guard took over the management and maintenance of the building from the city. The state has said the building's artwork was donated to the people of New York, not the veterans' group.
Besides providing office space for the National Guard, the armory houses 100 homeless women in a shelter run for the city by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, a nonprofit, and is used for meetings by the Knickerbocker Greys, a military youth corps, and by veterans' groups.
A privately run restaurant, the Seventh Regiment Mess, occupies the fourth floor. Mr. Gargano said it was unclear whether the new managers would have to keep the shelter, the youth corps and the restaurant.
"We are, in effect, taking the first step to privatize this building," Mr. Gargano explained. "Within a year or so we hope to have it completed."

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
Cars, Sex and Stocks On One Web Site

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
For some people, few things are as sexy as a new Internet stock. At least that's the assumption of Joseph Preston, a 28-year-old entrepreneur in Bethesda, Md. Mr. Preston plans to file documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission today stating his intention to raise $7.5 million in a stock offering for Efox.net.
The business, he said in an interview, will be an electronic-commerce Web site that focuses on "the heterosexual man's favorite pursuits: ladies, automobiles, sports, and stocks." He said the women who pose provocatively for his site -- the "eye candy," he calls them -- will each be paid with 500 shares of Efox.net stock. 
 Of course, in this realm, air-brushed surfaces can be deceiving. The company is only a month old and its Web site right now is little more than a come-hither home page. To date, Mr. Preston has raised only about $100,000 for the operation from private investors. And he plans to dispense with the usual step of finding an investment banker by underwriting the stock issue himself.
In a market where companies raise millions and millions with decidedly less sexy topics like books, Internet broadcasting and on-line access, Mr. Preston's venture raises the question: Why hasn't anyone yet married Internet sex and the stock market?
Sex, as a business proposition, does not necessarily magnetize the average investment banker, said Mark Hardie, senior analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., who is skeptical about Mr. Preston's plan.
Adult-themed sites are among the few that actually make money on the Internet. But they are risky business as far as the financial community is concerned.
"Going public is about convincing a host of risk-averse financial service firms who manage the assets of retirees to plunk down tens of millions of dollars on a porn business," Mr. Hardie said. LISA NAPOLI

HEADLINE: Former Military Ruler Wins Nigerian Presidential Vote

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, a former military ruler who campaigned as the only man capable of holding together this vibrant and fractious country, today scored an overwhelming victory to become the first elected president here in 16 years.
His challenger, Olu Falae, a former finance minister, immediately disputed the fairness of the vote, held on Saturday after years of promises by military dictators to move Nigeria, the most populous country in Africa, toward democracy. 
 It was not clear tonight, however, whether Mr. Falae would formally contest the results, particularly since they showed him trailing by almost seven million votes, with the margin widening in General Obasanjo's favor as more returns came in.
"I said if General Obasanjo won a free and fair election I would congratulate him but clearly this is not a free and fair election," Mr. Falae told journalists before leaving for the capital, Abuja.
A victory for General Obasanjo would cap a tumultuous period in the history of Nigeria, ruled until last June by a callous dictatorship that had turned the country, the world's sixth-largest oil producer and the biggest military power in West Africa, into an international pariah.
It would also be the culmination of an extraordinary personal journey for General Obasanjo, who was released from prison just eight months ago after serving three years for criticizing the military rule.
Tonight, an anxious nation waited for officials to formally declare the winner of the election that many hoped would fulfill the promise of a nation whose seemingly boundless potential has been squandered by years of misrule.
General Obasanjo had yet to make any public statement, apparently waiting for election authorities to give him the official nod.
Before that announcement, reaction to the results was muted in a nation that has often seen its democratic aspirations thwarted.
International election monitors said supporters for both candidates had committed fraud in some areas of the country.
But they said the cheating did not appear significant enough to affect the election's outcome, given the wide margin of General Obasanjo's victory.
Official results tonight showed that the retired general had garnered 62 percent of the votes, compared with 38 percent for his opponent, from 33 out of 36 states, plus the federal capital.
Election officials are scheduled to announce final results on Monday, when they are also to formally declare the winner.
Former President Jimmy Carter, who led a team of American election monitors, praised the current military government's commitment to the transition to civilian rule and the conduct of officials at the Independent National Election Commission, which oversaw the vote.
The Carter Center and the National Democratic Institute, present with the assent of the Nigerian Government, said in a report on the elections that there was "no evidence indicating that electoral abuses would have affected the overall outcome of the election."
"There has not been a pattern of nationwide fraud or irregularities," Mr. Carter said in an interview.
But he said that monitors had observed fraud and irregularities in a number of states, including ballot boxes that were stuffed, vote tallies that were inflated and results that were manipulated.
Clement Nwankwo, the chairman of the Transition Monitoring Group, an umbrella organization of Nigerian organizations that dispatched thousands of observers on Saturday, said General Obasanjo would have to win over the public, because the irregularities had been serious enough.
"The winner must immediately embark on popular measures to deal with the severe economic problems of this country and build popular support for himself," Mr. Nwankwo said.
If Mr. Falae contests the results, he will have to appeal his case to a tribunal, which can decide to hold elections again in certain areas or throughout the country. The new President is scheduled to take office on May 29.
Most significant for General Obasanjo might be the effect of a challenge by Mr. Falae on people in the south.
According to the results released tonight, he performed according to expectations by winning most of the north.
But Mr. Falae won the southwest, which is dominated by the Yoruba, one of the three main ethnic groups in Nigeria, along with the Ibo in the southeast and the Hausa-Fulani in the north.
Both men are Yoruba. But because of General Obasanjo's close ties to the north, many of his fellow Yoruba distrusted him and considered him a candidate imposed by the northern-dominated military.
The Yoruba have been angry especially since one of their own, Moshood K. O. Abiola, a billionaire businessman, had his apparent victory in the 1993 presidential elections annulled by a northern general.
That led to five years of brutal dictatorship under Gen. Sani Abacha, which ended only with his sudden death last June. After Mr. Abiola also died unexpectedly a month later, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, the current President, announced a timetable for elections and handover to civilian rule.
Mr. Falae was the candidate of the Alliance for Democracy, which is essentially a Yoruba party with little reach outside the southwest. The All People's Party, which is strongest in the north, joined forces with the Alliance for Democracy and presented Mr. Falae as their common candidate. During a weeklong campaign period, Mr. Falae attacked General Obasanjo as a soldier in civilian disguise and said an Obasanjo presidency would be a continuation of military rule.
The theme resonated among many Nigerians weary of the military, which has ruled Nigeria for all but 10 years since independence from Britain in 1960. But Mr. Falae, weakened by poor organization and the shakiness of the alliance that backed him, was unable to spread his message.
By contrast, General Obasanjo tried to use his military past to his advantage by arguing that he was the only one close enough to military officers to prevent them from snatching back power, as they have done in the past. He would serve as a bridge, his campaign argued, to a civilian administration.
His party, the People's Democratic Party, enjoyed the most money and the backing of the retired military elite. The party dominated in elections since December for local and statewide government seats, as well as for the national assembly.

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the presidential election in Nigeria on Saturday described the election incorrectly. It was not Nigeria's first presidential vote in 16 years. A presidential election was held in 1993; its results were annulled by the military government.

HEADLINE: A Rocket Substitute For Shuttles Falls Short

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
An experimental rocket that is at the heart of NASA's plans to develop a low-cost, re-usable vehicle that may eventually replace the space shuttle has fallen more than a year behind schedule for its first flight because of mounting technical problems.
The rocket, called the X-33, represents a radically different approach to launching space payloads. Proponents say the new approach may drastically reduce costs and expand access to space for new types of uses, including tourism. 
 Critics charge that the X-33, a half-scale prototype that is to demonstrate an array of new technologies for future launchers, is behind schedule and under budget pressures because it is designed to do too much under a tightly limited program.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the project's lead contractor, the Lockheed Martin Corporation's Skunk Works Division in Palmdale, Calif., acknowledge that unexpected technical problems have delayed the experimental rocket project. But they say such troubles should be expected with a cutting-edge program and should be considered part of the price of innovation.
Problems affecting the X-33 include difficulty in manufacturing its engines, a new design that has never flown before; trouble in making its lightweight, graphite-reinforced plastic fuel tanks, and excess weight that will reduce the craft's performance.
"When we picked this X-33 concept in the summer of 1996, we knew this design was brand new and nothing like it had been built before," said Gary Payton, head of NASA's re-usable launching vehicle program. "When you choose an aggressive and daring project, you know you will run into problems," he continued, "That's one way of knowing you're really pushing the technology, which is what we wanted to do."
The X-33 program is a cooperative Government-industry effort to demonstrate that it is possible to make a rocket that is cheaper and easier to operate and maintain than anything now flying. It costs about $10,000 per pound to orbit payloads with the space shuttle and one of the goals of the new rocket would be to reduce this to $1,000 a pound, or less.
NASA has committed $941 million to the project and Lockheed Martin and its industry partners have put up about $230 million.
The envisioned vehicle is called a single-stage-to-orbit rocket because it is intended to fly into space and return to Earth in one piece, much like an airliner. Conventional rockets, even the space shuttle, are not totally reusable because with each use they discard parts like fuel tanks, booster rockets or spent lower stages.
NASA and Lockheed Martin hope a successful X-33 program will prove the feasibility of building a larger rocket, called the Venture Star, which would be able to carry space shuttle-size payloads into space at much reduced cost. The plan calls for the company to seek private investment of more than $5 billion to build two Venture Stars that it would own and operate, selling launching services to government and commercial clients as early as 2004.
But some are skeptical about the program's chances for success. John E. Pike, director of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists in Washington, said developing a privately owned space launcher of this scale would take more time and money than proponents acknowledge.
"I don't think a dozen flights of a sub-scale vehicle will give you a firm handle on the reliability and flight rates of a Venture Star that you can take to investors," Mr. Pike said, "The main challenges of Venture Star are not technical, but economic."
Henry Vanderbilt, a spokesman for the Space Access Society, a national advocacy group for cheaper space flight, said the designs of the X-33 and Venture Star were too complex to reduce costs enough to open space to small businesses and individuals. And failure of the project could cause potential investors to turn away from other, more promising, low-cost rocket proposals, he said. "It would be a tragedy if Venture Star made people think the single-stage-to-orbit concept can't work," Mr. Vanderbilt said.
The winning Lockheed Martin design, the most ambitious of three candidates proposed in 1996, is a vehicle shaped like a flat arrowhead with fins at the bottom. It is designed to take off vertically using a new type of nozzleless rocket engine, to re-enter the atmosphere protected by a novel metallic thermal covering, to fly back horizontally with the help of lift generated by its flat body, and to land on a runway like an airplane.
Standing 67-feet-tall and measuring 68-feet-wide at the tail, the unmanned experimental craft is not designed to reach orbit with its two engines powered by liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. But engineers say it should be able to fly 50 miles high at hypersonic speed, more than enough to prove its design and test its components under the harshest conditions.
The X-33 was originally to begin a series of 15 test flights this month, but a number of manufacturing and engineering problems forced the first launching date to slip, first to July, then to December. Program officials said last week that the new target date was July 2000.
Gene Austin, NASA's X-33 program manager, said project delays were attributed to a range of problems, including late delivery of parts by suppliers and difficulties in assembling components. For example, trouble bonding high-temperature engine parts at the Boeing Company's Rocketdyne engine division added $36 million to project costs and pushed the schedule back several months, he said.
The X-33 and its successor are to be powered by linear aerospike engines, which save weight and complexity by forgoing the movable, bell-shaped engine nozzles used for conventional rocket engines. Each of the X-33's engines, which generate 205,000 pounds of thrust, has small combustors, or thrust chambers, that fire along curved open exhaust ramps instead of through a nozzle. The two ramps form a V-shape with thrusters, aligned along the top outside surface of each side, that fire downward toward the point.
The ramps are made of a copper alloy sheet milled to include internal passages through which coolant is circulated. The copper is backed by a brazed-on steel sheet, but temperature differences throughout the ramps and other problems made the bonding much more difficult than expected, Mr. Austin said.
In a problem related to the engine, which has been tested extensively on the ground since the 1970's but never in flight, NASA and Lockheed Martin announced in November that they had given up on a more than three-year effort to test-fire a small aerospike engine atop an SR-71 research plane during high-speed runs.
During the $27 million program, known as Lasre for Linear Aerospike SR-71 Experiment, a small engine carried in a one-tenth scale model X-33 flew aboard the former reconnaissance jet seven times, but was never fired.
Jerry Rising, the Lockheed Martin executive in charge of the X-33 program from the beginning, said persistent fuel leaks in the test model's plumbing system made live firings dangerous and the company felt it was not worth spending more money to fix the problem. Fuel flow tests during the flights and ground firings of the engine helped the company validate computer predictions of how the aerospike's hot, open exhaust plume would behave in flight, he said, and further investment in Lasre was not warranted just to fire the engine in the air.
A bigger problem arose in December when part of one of the X-33's two liquid hydrogen fuel tanks came apart when it was being heat-cured. A 28-foot-long section of the tank's skin, made by laying sheets of composite material, pulled apart from its inner surface and has to be completely replaced, engineers said. Mr. Rising said that it would cost $6 million to make and replace the damaged tank skin, but that there were no estimates of the total cost of correcting the snag.
The X-33 also has had a weight problem, at one point growing from its intended 65,000 pounds to 78,000 pounds, Mr. Rising said. The craft is now down to about 75,000 pounds, he said, but the company has decided not to invest in a severe weight-reduction program because it would be costly and most of the rocket's flight objectives could be reached without being lightened further.
"We are already taking what we are learning with X-33 and applying it to the design of the Venture Star, and that's where we are making the weight-reduction measures," Mr. Rising said.
Weight is one of the reasons the X-33 will not meet an original program goal of flying at a top speed of Mach 15, or 15 times the speed of sound, a little more than 11,000 miles per hour.
Mr. Rising confirmed that the craft's maximum speed is now down to Mach 13.8, about 10,000 m.p.h., but said this was sufficient for the craft to meet all its test objectives.
Launched vertically from a recently completed site at Edwards Air Force Base in California, the X-33 is to make test flights in which it would land at military bases in Utah or Montana and then be brought back to California by truck.
Early flights will be to the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah, and higher, longer-ranged tests will take it to Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana.
Mr. Rising said the problems with the X-33 should not detract from the program's accomplishments so far, including completion of its launching site ahead of schedule, certification of its metal heat-shield system as flight-ready, successful testing of the systems that pump fuel to the engines and control their thrust, and completed verification testing of the system of small rockets that will control the spacecraft at high altitudes.

HEADLINE: China's Human Rights Record

 BODY:
A disturbing pattern is developing in the Clinton Administration's relationship with China. The more Washington seeks to broaden its agenda with Beijing, the more harshly China treats its democrats and dissidents. In the face of a new wave of political repression in China, President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright must do more than repeat stale complaints and then change the subject to trade. Americans will not support a policy of engagement and improved relations with China if the price is American inaction on human rights abuses.
Ms. Albright traveled to China this week just days after the State Department published a withering report on repression in China. It found that in 1998 Chinese leaders broke their promises to respect international human rights conventions, held thousands of political critics and religious activists in prison, tortured detainees and tightened restrictions on the press. Beijing has been using long prison sentences to crush the formation of independent political parties. 
 Ms. Albright talked bluntly about the dismal record in her meetings with Chinese officials yesterday, as she has done before. That seemed sufficient when China's conduct was improving, but as President Jiang Zemin has tightened controls on political expression in recent months, the American criticism has seemed increasingly hollow and ineffectual. Ms. Albright's words were further muffled by the primary purpose of her visit, which was to advance the Administration's policy of building diplomatic links with China, specifically by advancing Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization and preparing for a smooth visit to Washington next month by China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji.
Washington can act more forcefully on human rights by sponsoring a new United Nations resolution on Chinese abuses in Geneva later this month. Last year, for the first time since 1991, the United States did not support a resolution condemning China before the U.N. human rights commission in Geneva. The Administration hoped that this gesture would encourage Beijing to ease political repression. American silence on the issue this year would be unconscionable.
Mr. Jiang and his fellow Communist leaders fear social unrest. As economic growth has diminished because of Asia's financial crisis and Beijing's own incomplete economic reforms, political protests have spread and the Government has tried to intimidate those who favor greater freedom and democracy. But as President Clinton noted last week, sooner or later China will have to realize that it "cannot purchase stability at the expense of freedom."
If the repression grows worse in the weeks ahead, the Administration may have to reconsider its commitment not to link China's admission to the World Trade Organization to its human rights performance. For now, the membership decision will depend on Beijing's willingness to lower tariffs to international standards. Concerned that too rapid an exposure to free trade will increase Chinese unemployment and unrest, Beijing wants an extended transition period. Some accommodation is reasonable. But the point of admitting China into the W.T.O. is to bring it more fully under the rules of the international trading system. Excessively watering down those rules to have an agreement ready in time for Mr. Zhu's visit to Washington would be a mistake.

HEADLINE: Index of Manufacturing in U.S. Shows First Increase in 9 Months

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Manufacturing expanded in February for the first time in nine months, adding fuel to an economy already benefiting from rising incomes and increased construction spending, new reports showed today.
The factory index of the National Association of Purchasing Management rose to 52.4 last month from 49.5 in January as production, orders and hiring all increased. It was the best reading since 52.5 last April. 
 "The signal from this survey is clear: The manufacturing slowdown is over," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
Another report showed that consumers' incomes rose six-tenths of a percent in January, after falling one-tenth of a percent in December. Spending slowed to a rise of three-tenths of a percent in January as Americans bought fewer cars, Commerce Department figures showed; spending in December had risen seven-tenths of a percent.
Construction spending was up 1.6 percent in January, the largest gain in seven months and a bigger increase than the 1.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department said.
Manufacturing was the one weak spot in the United States economy last year as housing and consumer spending surged to records. As factories rebound, the economy's expansion is on track to begin a ninth year in April and set a record for longevity a year from now.
While the reports were all positive, the January gain in income may be hard to replicate in the months ahead because it includes the yearly Federal cost-of-living adjustments and pay increases for civilian and military personnel.
Spending was restrained by a 2.1 percent decline in big-ticket durable goods, like cars, after a 3.3 percent increase in December.
In the purchasing management association index, a reading above 50 means the number of manufacturers who said business improved was greater than the number of those saying it deteriorated. Readings below 50 suggest the manufacturing economy could be contracting.
Today's report showed that the production index, a gauge of current output, rose to 56.9 in February from 53.1 during January. The index of new orders rose to 57.2 in February from 51.3 during January. And the employment index, a gauge of hiring plans and labor market conditions, rose to 45.0 in February from 44.8 during January.

HEADLINE: Political Battle Threatens To Destabilize Paraguay

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 28

 BODY:
This small landlocked country in the heart of South America has just reached a major milestone in the life of any nation, its first 10 years of uninterrupted democracy.
But on the streets here there are no streamers, posters or other reminders to suggest that the February anniversary brought joyful celebration or even relief. Instead the graffiti here feature obscene gestures and demand that a handful of politicians across the political spectrum be hauled off to jail. 
 The conflict is paralyzing this poverty-stricken nation and could bring the impeachment of the second popularly elected president of the decade of democracy.
The clash grows out of President Raul Cubas Grau's defiance of a Supreme Court order to send a close political ally back to prison. The ally, Lino Oviedo, a retired general, is accused of leading an unsuccessful coup attempt against President Juan Carlos Wasmosy in 1996, after Mr. Wasmosy had dismissed General Oviedo and he refused to leave the barracks. After General Oviedo had won the primary for the governing Colorado Party, Mr. Wasmosy had him arrested, and he was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Soon after he became President in August, Mr. Cubas freed his friend by decree.
The President's action was hardly a surprise. He had been General Oviedo's Vice-Presidential running mate in the elections last year and became the Presidential candidate only after General Oviedo had been imprisoned.
Mr. Cubas, an uninspired speaker, appealed to voters as the shadow of the former general.
Last week, a judge here refused to prosecute the President for refusing to send General Oviedo back to jail. But he sent the prosecutor's case on to Congress, the first step in a possible impeachment.
Although it is too early to say how the case will fare, Mr. Cubas appears to be growing increasingly isolated. On Friday, the ambassadors from most of Paraguay's regional trading partners met him over lunch. But the Argentine ambassador stayed away.
The American ambassador, Maura Harty, spent three hours last Tuesday evening meeting with Vice President Luis Maria Argana. A spokesman for the embassy denied that Ms. Harty had discussed a possible Argana Government and insisted that the meeting was routine. But Paraguayans read the meeting as a highly visible show of support for Mr. Argana.
Paraguayans, new to the workings of democracy, are not sure where the limits of the conflict lie. Some fear that it could set off a move to hold power by force. Others say they believe that Mr. Argana will maneuver to take over the Presidency. Persistent street demonstrations, although largely peaceful, have raised fears of civil violence.
The nation now has the trappings of democracy, with periodic elections, a Constitution and separate branches of Government. But there is little confidence in the independence of the courts and the Congress.
Paraguay regularly figures among the most corrupt countries in surveys by organizations like Transparency International, which issues annual reports. The official economy, at $10 billion, is dwarfed by an underground economy centered on counterfeit goods, arms and drug smuggling that is generally estimated at $12 billion a year.
Rosa Palau, who oversees a center that maintains archives from the military dictatorship, said the crisis could drag on indefinitely and inconclusively. "This is an improvised country," Ms. Palau said.
In the atmosphere of uncertainty, investment is at a standstill. Stores remain virtually empty, and public works appear to have stalled.
"How can people believe in democracy?" Ms. Palau asked. "How can they believe in anything when the President simply decides to ignore an order of the court and nothing happens?"
The currency, the guarani, has lost 25 percent of its value in the last month. Tax collections this year are 21 percent below expectations, and international reserves have shrunk to a less than $800 million.
Dr. Alfredo Boccia Paz, a hematologist in Asuncion, said the crisis seemed to have paralyzed the economy and spirits.
"We can continue like this for a long time," Dr. Paz said. "We'll reach the end of the year poorer and with people still talking about the same things."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Bond Prices Plunge Again; Stocks Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Fresh signs of strong economic growth preyed on the bond market again yesterday, pulling down stock prices early, but major market gauges pared their declines and closed narrowly mixed on unusually light volume.
A stronger-than-expected gain in the index of manufacturing compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Management led to wholesale selling in the bond market. In its survey, the association said its index for February climbed to 52.4, the first time it had risen above 50 since last May. A reading above 50 indicates growth in manufacturing. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 9/32, to 94 2/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.66 percent, from 5.57 percent on Friday.
The increase in yields pushed long-term rates back to levels last seen in August, before Russia defaulted on its debt.
"One of the themes everyone talked about earlier in the decade was that the bond market helped to self-regulate the economy," said Lou Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates.
"That whole mechanism was ignored in the second half of last year," he said. "The bond market ignored the ongoing strength in the U.S. economy, and that stimulated absolutely stratospheric performance in interest-sensitive sectors of the economy, like housing. Now bond yields have gone back to levels where mortgage applications will slow."
Besides the deterioration in bond prices, fears about the high prices of technology shares caused problems for stocks early in the day. Then, to the surprise of some, the market rallied and closed little changed.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.20 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 9,324.78. Hurt by a pounding in Intel shares, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.17 points, or nearly two-tenths of a percent, to 1,236.16. But the Nasdaq composite index managed to rise 7.15 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 2,295.18. And the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks gained 2.13 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 394.39.
"The market was reminiscent of that old Timex watch commercial," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "It takes a licking but keeps on ticking."
Bill Allyn, director of listed trading at Jeffries & Company, said, "We are still in this push-pull, rip-tear environment, where the market has violent swings but doesn't end up going very far."
On the Big Board, a relatively sparse 699.5 million shares changed hands. On the Nasdaq market, where volume has routinely approached one billion shares lately, slightly more than 771 million shares traded.
Normally, activity tends to pick up at the start of a new month as pension funds and other institutional investors put fresh money into their stock portfolios.
But given the uncertainties about market valuations and the state of the economy, analysts said it was not altogether surprising that the pace of business had slowed.
The markets will pay particular attention to Friday's employment report from the Labor Department. "Who wants to make a big commitment in front of the employment numbers?" Mr. Meehan asked.
Most analysts are expecting the report to show a rise in nonfarm payroll employment of 250,000, but they are bracing for a surprise.
"The numbers have come in above consensus for the last three months," Mr. Crandall said. "There would be a certain amount of relief if we got through the report with no nasty surprises."
Worries about slowing sales of personal computers, set off last week by a report from Compaq Computer, continued yesterday.
Intel, the biggest maker of computer chips, led the S.& P. 500 index lower, dropping 2 7/8, to 117 1/16, after Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette cut its ratings on the stock. Compaq fell 1 27/32, to 33 17/32, and I.B.M. lost 1 3/8, to 168 3/8.
But financial stocks, which have never fully recovered from last summer's selloff, did well. So did companies with performances that are closely tied to the strength of the economy.
Among financial stocks, Citigroup gained 2 1/2, to 61 1/4; American Express rose 3, to 111 1/2, and Chase Manhattan was up 1 1/8, to 80 3/4.
Caterpillar, the world's largest maker of construction equipment, was the best-performing component of the Dow. It gained 3 5/8, to 49 3/16.
General Motors, the No. 1 auto maker, was up 9/16, to 83 1/8, and Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum company, rose 7/8, to 41 3/8.
Not all technology stocks suffered yesterday. Microsoft climbed 1 5/8, to 151 3/4; Cisco Systems gained 1 5/8, to 99 7/16, and Lucent Technologies rose 1 5/16, to 102 7/8.
Many big Internet stocks also did well. Yahoo gained 6 5/8, to 160 1/8, and Amazon.com rose 4 7/8, to 133.

HEADLINE: A Winner And New Era Are Declared In Nigeria

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, March 1

 BODY:
Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, who was officially declared Nigeria's next president today, pledged to foster democracy in a country where years of corrupt military misrule have squandered vast oil wealth and restricted the freedom of one in six Africans. 
 Final results in the presidential elections on Saturday showed the retired general winning a decisive victory, with 63 percent of the popular vote. But his rival, Olu Falae, seized on reports of fraud and irregularities to dispute the results, although he did not say how far he would take his challenge.
The outcome appeared to have been accepted by a nation weary from 16 years of uninterrupted dictatorships and nine convulsive months that, at times, threatened to irreparably widen the ethnic, religious and regional fissures in Africa's most populous land. Lagos -- a base for Mr. Falae and a city that has often expressed its political displeasure with dramatic violence -- was quiet as night fell.
Significantly for General Obasanjo -- who will inherit a country on the verge of economic collapse, with the price of oil plummeting to generational lows -- the United States, Britain and France issued statements welcoming the election's outcome. Oil companies from the three countries have billions of dollars invested in Nigeria.
The vote now holds the promise of democratization for the country's 108 million citizens, who make up a sixth of the continent's population.
"Election is not the end of democracy," the President-elect told reporters in Abuja, the capital. "Democracy is a process. Election is just one important event in the process, and democracy under my own leadership will continue."
The election was peaceful but marred by what international observers described as serious fraud and irregularities including ballot box stuffing and inflated results in some regions. They said irregularities occurred on both sides.
Most observers described the problems as not significant enough to change the outcome, given the wide margin of victory. Former President Jimmy Carter, however, wrote to the independent commission overseeing the elections that because of the fraud, his team of observers could not "make an accurate judgment about the outcome."
General Obasanjo acknowledged irregularities, but called on Mr. Falae, a former Finance Minister, to accept the outcome for the sake of national unity. In a letter to the election commission, Mr. Falae urged it not to declare the results final. Mr. Falae did not say whether he would pursue his challenge. But there was little evidence that the outcome would generate the outrage necessary to give momentum to a formal challenge.
Lagos State gave Mr. Falae 88 percent of its votes and 12 percent to General Obasanjo, the most lopsided margin of the 36 states and the federal capital territory of Abuja. But even here, most people interviewed today said they were tired of political fighting.
"I am not happy about the results," said Larry Sule, 33, a banker, who shared the same birthplace, Abeokuta, as General Obasanjo, and who had voted for Mr. Falae. "But I think we should accept the results and allow Obasanjo to be sworn in in the name of the transition. If there is a prolonged dispute, going to the courts, the military might take it as an excuse to prolong their stay."
Lagos is dominated by the Yoruba, one of the three main ethnic groups in Nigeria, and both candidates are Yoruba, but because of his military past and his close ties to northerners, General Obasanjo is mistrusted by many Yoruba.
During a weeklong campaign, General Obasanjo presented himself as a safe bridge between a future civilian government and military rulers ever ready to seize back power. Mr. Falae sold himself as a clean break from the past.
According to the final results released today, General Obasanjo, the candidate for the People's Democratic Party, won 62.8 percent of the popular vote or 18.7 million votes. Mr. Falae, who was the joint candidate for two smaller parties, the All People's Party and the Alliance for Democracy, garnered 37.2 percent or 11.1 million votes. There were 53 million registered voters, though election officials suspected that only 40 million were genuine.
As expected, Mr. Falae swept the six southwest Yoruba states, but won only three others outside the region. General Obasanjo's party retained the dominance it had exhibited in recent elections for local, statewide and national assembly seats.
"I'm very happy about it," said Jeji Jatay, 88, a farmer near Abuja, which voted overwhelmingly for General Obasanjo. "I want an Obasanjo Government to help the poor and the farmers. By the grace of God, the Obasanjo Government will be a listening Government."

HEADLINE: Sales of Credit Card Accounts Are Hurting Many Consumers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
First there was the 5.9 percent teaser rate. When that expired, the interest rate on Tom Moore's PNC Bank credit card jumped to 14.4 percent. Finally it settled at 12.5 percent. Mr. Moore, an illustrator who lives in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, was satisfied.
But last week Mr. Moore was stunned to find that he was no longer a customer of the Pittsburgh-based bank but of a bank in Oklahoma he had never heard of. And his interest rate had been jacked up to 20.74 percent -- and 24.74 percent on cash advances. 
 "This is about the most odious business practice I've ever seen," complained Mr. Moore, who is 46.
Odious or not, tens of millions of Americans have been facing the same stark choice -- to take the new terms or leave them -- as the credit card business rapidly consolidates into fewer and larger hands. About 32 million accounts were sold last year, mainly by regional banks like PNC, Keycorp, First Maryland and First Union. That is more than four times as many as in 1996, according to R. K. Hammer, who runs a card industry advisory firm in Thousand Oaks, Calif. Because many people have multiple accounts, the sales involved some 20 million consumers. The figures do not include transfers resulting from mergers.
Mortgages and automotive loans are routinely bought and sold, but this has little impact on borrowers, since the rates cannot change. But the new owners of credit card business are free to impose whatever interest rate the traffic will bear, subject only to the handful of remaining state usury ceilings. They can also impose that rate on existing balances, shorten the time for making payments without interest charges, eliminate grace periods for payments received a few days late and raise penalties for late payment, now commonly as much as $29.
Big buyers have included Chase, which bought 3.5 million Bank of New York accounts last year, and Citibank, which bought AT&T's 14.5 million Universal Card accounts. Other buyers are Fleet Financial and Banc One, which owns First USA, as well as some little-known companies.
Citibank said there was "really no impact" yet on Universal Card customers.
Except for low teaser rates guaranteed for, say, six months, banks have no legal obligation to honor any rates card holders now pay, and have shown little inclination to do so. But while it is not unusual for rates to rise six or eight percentage points, they could also fall. "It's the natural time to examine the risk and reward of each," Mr. Hammer said, and the result "could be a repricing up or down." And even when rates stay the same, penalties and grace periods may change, sometimes to the consumer's benefit.
Still, Gerri Detweiler, a credit card specialist and consultant to Debt Counselors, called it "scandalous" that consumers can so easily fall prey to the wheeling and dealing of large institutions.
"If your mortgage or car loan were sold, your rate would stay the same," Ms. Detweiler said. "That's not the case with credit cards." When consumers see an account has been transferred, it is very important to read the fine print because of a high probability that the interest rate or some other terms have been changed.
With an estimated 3.5 billion credit card offers flooding Americans' mailboxes each year, card holders would have little trouble taking their business elsewhere. Often, by paying a fee, they are even able to transfer balances. But even though banks are required to notify card holders of a switch, they "anticipate that a lot of new customers won't pay attention," Ms. Detweiler said.
Mr. Moore, who said, "I've never had a credit problem," acknowledged that a month or two earlier he had received a mailing that might have included a notification of the higher rates but that he had not focused on it.
Credits cards once provided a lush business for regional banks like PNC, but many are fleeing it now, squeezed by the high costs of uncollectable debt and a rising number of consumers who pay monthly balances in full, depriving the bank of interest income. And the cost is rising for the increasingly sophisticated computer models that analyze customer use patterns.
David Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, an industry newsletter in Oxnard, Calif., says the industry's ever-more-sophisticated ability to analyze account data has helped it tailor new products and cut costs, savings ultimately shared with customers. "Never has there been a better time," he said, "to find the card that appeals to you."
But even at a time of unparalleled prosperity, there is no letup in the record number of Americans filing for bankruptcy, raising fears that a business downturn would send bad card debt soaring.
"The card business is really becoming a business of scale," said Warren G. Heller, research director at Veribanc Inc., a Wakefield, Mass., company that rates banks. "A lot of companies are recognizing this and throwing in the towel."
Some retailers are also making changes. For example, Ikea, the Swedish furniture company, retains its blue-and-yellow credit cards but switched the servicing of customer accounts to Citibank last year.
Mr. Moore, inquiring about the sale of his account, telephoned the new owner, Direct Merchants Bank in Tulsa. A service representative told him that his was one of a half-million PNC accounts transferred and that if he did not like the new terms he could close his account.
He promptly canceled his card, but must still pay the higher interest rate on his $848 balance, which he hopes to pay off soon. But if he had been running a balance too big to settle fairly quickly, he would have been forced, with only a few weeks' notice, to pay a much higher interest rate for some time unless he could transfer it to a new card.
"If you build up a substantial amount, you may not be able to pay it all," said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. He called it "gouging" when a credit card rate is raised sharply for no reason other than a business deal between large institutions.
Direct Merchants Bank belongs to the Metris Companies, a Minnesota-based marketer of consumer credit products, including credit card registration and extended warranties on appliances. It was once an arm of the Fingerhut Companies, a catalogue and telemarketing concern with which it still has some ties.
Metris is one of the more aggressive of several buyers of credit card portfolios being shed by banks, having acquired $1.6 billion worth in the last two years, half from PNC and the rest from the Cleveland-based Keycorp, Mercantile Bancorporation of St. Louis and Huntington Bancshares of Columbus, Ohio.
Metris charges interest rates on its cards ranging from 15.9 percent to 26.9 percent, depending mainly on how it judges creditworthiness.
"It's a price-for-risk philosophy" tailored to individual customers, said Alfred A. Galgano, a vice president, citing what he said are more than 150 combinations of rates and fees. He said the Metris system for judging risk was more refined than those of some banks it was buying credit accounts from, suggesting that at least some customers might find an advantage in being sold.
Mr. Galgano would not say how many former PNC customers, like Mr. Moore, refused to accept Metris's terms, only that there was a "fair amount of attrition," no more than expected. He also said some PNC customers were headed for higher rates even if there had been no transfer, either because of the end of an introductory rate or, say, a deteriorating pattern of payment.
Kevin Mukri, spokesman for the Comptroller of Currency, which enforces the notification process for national banks, said he knew of no serious violations by banks or of consumer complaints.
The biggest resistance tends to come from people who sometimes carry balances. Those who always pay their cards off immediately would never be levied the high rates. Those who never pay cards off tend to be so stretched that they may not qualify for better rates elsewhere.
Metris caters mainly to people of moderate income, which Mr. Galgano defined as those earning between $15,000 and $35,000 a year.
In PNC's eyes, Mr. Moore belonged to a group of customers it regarded as geographically incorrect for its business -- that is, beyond the limits of its physical operations. It announced in September an agreement to sell these to Metris, then decided just before Christmas to sell the rest of its credit card operation, 3.3 million accounts serviced in Wilmington, Del., to the Wilmington-based MBNA Corporation, the industry's No. 3.
The going rate that a bank will pay for a card account ranges from $50 to $180, depending on creditworthiness and use patterns.
Jonathan Williams, a spokesman for PNC, said that he knew nothing of how Metris was handling his bank's former customers and that the bank had no obligation to them. Asked specifically about Mr. Moore's contention that he had been delivered up to sharks, Mr. Williams said he "would disagree" with that characterization.
"It is not uncommon to sell a business that has accounts and at which point it now becomes the business of the successor," he said. "The customer by law has to be informed of any change in terms and has the option not to accept it."
Even as competition for creditworthy customers has put downward pressure on credit card rates, profit margins have withered by two-thirds in the last seven or eight years, said Allen W. Sanborn, president of RMA, a Philadelphia-based association of bank lenders. "Some customers you just can't make any money on," he said, even when card issuers raise late fees and other penalties to offset the effect of lower rates.
Mr. Hammer, the California analyst, figured that pretax returns to lenders on card balances had now fallen four straight years, to 2.5 percent in 1998 from 3.9 percent in 1994.
High fees themselves have now created a backlash, one reflected in Congressional efforts to curb abusive credit card terms. John LaFalce of New York, ranking Democrat on the House Banking Committee, plans to introduce legislation today covering various practices, like hidden rates and aggressive solicitations.
The measure would also give consumers hit with a higher interest rate the right to pay off balances at the earlier terms. "It's only simple fairness," said Gary Luczak, a spokesman for Mr. LaFalce.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Worldwide, Things Are Not Going Better for Coke

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
In a speech in Chicago last week, the chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company made references to several well-known films, including "Being There" and "From Here to Eternity," when describing his company's experience overseas.
He left out "Suddenly, Last Summer." 
 That's when Coca-Cola, long the paragon of successful American consumer-products companies, began to feel the effects of a global battering that is without recent parallel. Coke's sales volume has dropped in many countries, profit is flat or falling, and the company is trying to manage its way through more simultaneous crises abroad than at any time since the end of World War II.
Now, with the Brazilian economy in recession and threatening to affect those of other Latin American nations, Coca-Cola's damage control has moved into high gear.
This morning, Coke's chairman, M. Douglas Ivester, is scheduled to make a rare appearance at a consumer-products conference presented by Merrill Lynch for dozens of portfolio managers who hold the keys to billions of dollars in investment funds. Such appearances are usually delegated to others, like Coca-Cola's chief financial officer, James Chestnut.
Mr. Ivester, a 20-year company veteran and a principal mechanic behind the Coke machine, is expected to try to reassure investors at the Manhattan conference that the long-term outlook for Coca-Cola remains positive. After his scheduled remarks, he is to answer questions from those attending the "by invitation only" event.
His message may be a tough sell. Even though stock analysts acknowledge the organizational strength of Coca-Cola, they say that investors are looking for more short-term security than the company's shares can provide. Last week, several Wall Street analysts reduced their 1999 earnings forecasts for Coke to about $1.45 a share, down sharply from the $1.95 many had estimated before the company's fortunes began to slide in August. It is also about the same as Coke earned last year.
The stock price, which is down nearly 5 percent for the year, fell 18.75 cents yesterday to close at $63.6875 -- off sharply from last July's high of $88.9375.
Mr. Ivester, whose normal travel schedule borders on the frenetic, has been spending an unusual amount of time making the company's case to his business peers. Last Thursday, in the address to the Economic Club of Chicago, he spoke enthusiastically about Coke's prospects.
"I have to chuckle sometimes when I read that some analyst is fretting about our 'global exposure,' " Mr. Ivester told the group in his measured Georgia twang. "I hate to tell them, but that's the idea."
Capitalism, he went on to say in a speech that included the various movie analogies, "doesn't usually begin with steel mills or automobile plants."
"It begins with consumer goods," he said. "Even in developing countries, many people can afford a Coca-Cola."
Some analysts beg to differ, especially when it comes to Brazil, Coke's No. 3 market in case volume.
"Brazil is definitely a challenge for them in 1999," said Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, who is one of the few urging people to invest in Coke now. (Her rationale is that the time to buy Coke stock is when the company hits a rough patch.) "And they didn't have a great 1998," she conceded.
Many analysts expect volume in Brazil to fall 5 to 10 percent this year, particularly as people decide that they don't have the disposable income to shell out for pricey American soft drinks.
Because the currency has plummeted in value, even spectacular growth in Brazil would be diminished on the balance sheet. Bill Pecoriello, a stock analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, predicts that the drop in the Brazilian currency's value will reduce Coke's earnings more than the 6 percent he had originally forecast, given the rest of the global risk facing the company. In 1998, Coca-Cola reported, currency devaluation worldwide reduced earnings by 9 percent.
In addition, Mr. Pecoriello expects case volume in Brazil to fall 13 percent this quarter, far worse than the 3 percent decline in the fourth quarter of 1998. Global volume will grow by 4 to 5 percent, he predicts, down from the 6 percent growth recorded last year and well off the 7 to 8 percent growth target of Coca-Cola's management.
"If Coke doesn't adjust marketing spending for the volume shortfall, margins should come under additional pressure," Mr. Pecoriello wrote in a note to investors last week, referring to the company's worldwide operations. He rates Coca-Cola stock as "market perform," while Coke's chief rival, Pepsico, is rated "outperform," the highest ranking. And while he predicts that Coke's earnings for this year will come in at $1.46, he cautions, "There's still risk in our numbers."
Another analyst, Marc Cohen of Goldman, Sachs, said Brazil was one piece of what might be a very large problem for Coca-Cola. "I'm growing increasingly concerned that the growth rate of the company is slowing," he said, citing compound earnings-per-share growth just under 13 percent for the 1990's -- not the 15 percent the company has repeatedly promised.
In Colombia and Venezuela, volume is also in a downward spiral, off more than 16 percent in the fourth quarter. And Colombia shows signs of shrinking demand for soft drinks over all, said Laura D. Meizler, a Latin American beverage analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "Substitute products have been growing," she said, noting that malt drinks are among them.
The good news for Coke's shareholders is that a personal appearance by Mr. Ivester tends to have a soothing effect on the skeptical, who find comfort in his command of the business and his breadth of experience.
"One of the virtues of a 113-year-old company is that we've traveled over bumpy roads before," he declared in Chicago. "We have seen the movie before."
The bad news is that in many countries around the world -- in Japan, Russia, Germany, Colombia, Venezuela, South Africa, Brazil, to list just the big box-office names -- Coke's epic is only in the first reel.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Credit Card Consolidation Holds Some Surprises
Tens of millions of Americans have been surprised to find their credit card rates rising after their accounts are sold to other banks as the business rapidly consolidates into fewer and larger hands.
The new owners of credit card business are free to impose whatever interest rate the traffic will bear, subject only to the handful of remaining state usury ceilings. They can also impose that rate on existing balances, shorten the time for making payments without interest charges, eliminate grace periods for payments received a few days late and raise penalties for late payment. Page A1. 

Republic New York to Cut 560 Jobs
Republic New York, battered late last year by losses in volatile overseas markets, said that it planned to cut about 560 jobs as part of a broader reorganization aimed at refocusing the bank on global private banking and other niche businesses. C8.
 
Ford Hires Rival Executives
Two senior executives from DaimlerChrysler joined Ford Motor, the latest in a series of departures of executives from the former Chrysler Corporation since its November merger with Daimler-Benz. C8.
 
REIT to Change Its Structure
Patriot American Hospitality said that it had agreed to a financial bailout plan led by the investors Leon Black and Thomas Lee, that its chairman and chief executive had resigned and that it would convert from a real estate investment trust into a traditional corporation. The new chairman and chief executive will be James D. Carreker, above, who oversees Patriot's hotel operations and developed its Wyndham chain. C9.
 
Unity on Russian Debt Frays
The unity of a key group of Western banks holding $15 billion in defaulted, short-term Russian debt frayed after two of its members broke ranks to accept a Russian repayment package regarded as nearly worthless. C4.
 
Ralph Lauren to Buy Club Monaco
Polo Ralph Lauren, the retail company, said it would acquire Club Monaco, a Canadian-based retailer that sells designer lookalike casual apparel, for $52.5 million in cash, an 18 percent premium to Club Monaco's closing price on Friday. Shares of Polo Ralph Lauren declined 43.75 cents, to $19.50. C8.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Old-Timers Help Dallas Come of Age

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 1

 BODY:
The Dallas Stars are so old that "Remember the Alamo" is not merely a figurative expression. The veterans don't mind that the National Hockey League will expand to 30 teams in two years because they remember how hard it was for them to earn a job in the six-team league. When the Stars signed a free agent named Hull last summer, one of them said, "Bobby may have lost a step, but his slap shot will help us."
Derian Hatcher's father was in the locker room the other day. Derian is the Stars' 26-year-old captain but his dad did not look all that out of place among a few of Derian's teammates. In need of an extra defenseman, the Stars last week hired the 38-year-old Doug Lidster, a former Ranger who had retired last year. Stashing his gear into his locker after practice Saturday, Lidster looked around and said, "I fit right in." 
 When the Stars visit New York this week to play the Rangers on Tuesday and the Islanders on Thursday, they will bring the league's oldest roster, averaging more than 31 years of age. They also bring the league's best record and its biggest expectations. In 58 games, they are 38-11-9 and 7-1-1 in their last nine. Their longest losing streak has been two games. On the road, they are unbeaten in their last eight. Their goals against average is 2.00, lowest in the league.
"We might not have the fastest team, but we can match fast teams," Guy Carbonneau, who turns 39 this month, said earlier this season. "We might not have the strongest team, but we can play a physical game. We might not be the best at any one thing, but right now we're the best team."
When they played Detroit last spring in the Western Conference finals, the Red Wings beat them in six games, on their way to their second consecutive Stanley Cup championship. But it seemed to some as if the craftier team in decline won over the better team ascending. Apparently en route to their second consecutive Presidents' Trophy for best regular-season record, the Stars' biggest challenge might be to stay healthy and focused on the last quarter of the regular season until the post-season tournament begins in April.
"It's definitely tough when everyone in the room knows we are all looking forward for the playoffs to start," Hatcher said Sunday, just before the Stars beat the Los Angeles Kings by 1-0.
Mike Modano, the scoring leader with 65 points and the alternate captain, said: "We all have a picture of the big picture, to get back to the conference finals again. It was tough losing then, and the toughest part is waiting to get another crack at it."
Colorado, which won the cup in 1996, also wants another crack at it. The Avalanche made a trade with Calgary for Theoren Fleury, an energetic scoring wing. But Bob Gainey, the general manager of Dallas, said the Colorado trade would not create extra pressure on the Stars to make a similar move by the deadline of March 23.
"I don't think it forces our hand," Gainey said. "We're open to all kinds of opportunities. But there is a certain need for chemistry to work properly together."
Gainey, a former captain of the Canadiens, has built a roster filled with veterans. Two of them, Mike Keane, who arrived from the Rangers last spring, and Carbonneau, were also captains in Montreal. Pat Verbeek was a captain in Hartford. Brian Skrudland was a captain in Florida. Brett Hull, Bobby's 34-year-old son, was a captain in St. Louis. Carbonneau said: "If Bob makes a trade and the chemistry is not there anymore, he is the one who will have to pay for it. He's going to try to make the right deal, but he also knows that sometimes the best trade you make is the one you don't make."
And, sometimes, the best signings you make are free agents. They compose a quarter of the roster, including Hull, Verbeek, Shawn Chambers, Ed Belfour and Dave Reid. Although more than half the Stars are older than age 30, the nucleus of the team is composed of stars in their prime, such as Hatcher, Modano, Sergei Zubov, Jamie Langenbrunner and Jere Lehtinen, all between ages 23 and 28.
Common among both older and younger Stars are strong personalities, a challenge to Ken Hitchcock, a strong-willed coach who was still coaching junior teams in Kamloops, British Columbia, when many of his players were established in the N.H.L. "These people are set in their ways," Hitchcock said. "So many strong opinions. There is no coaching clinic for this."
In his four seasons with the team, Hitchcock has learned to listen. Because he is so demanding in games and in practices, his players demand off days and he allows them, at least five each month, he said. "Otherwise, I'm going to burn this group out," he said. The veterans and even the 20-somethings bang on his door, Hitchcock said, to give him free advice. "Yinning and yanging," is what Hitchcock calls their ongoing negotiations. But even the Stars have free-speech limits. When Hull joined the team last fall, he brought the reputation of being hockey's version of Charles Barkley, a talented man who sometimes says too much. Midway through the season, when Hull complained to reporters about his ice time, Hitchcock didn't have to respond.
According to Jim Lites, the team president, the veterans told Hull that such things were "not done here" and Hull stopped complaining.
Currently sidelined with a hamstring strain, Hull still leads the team in goals with 26, despite playing a more restrained system that includes defensive responsibilities. Craig Ludwig, a Stars defensemen, said: "Hully played a free-wheeling kind of game" in St. Louis before joining the Stars and "He probably didn't expect to have that many goals with this kind of a system." As for Hull's conversational skills, Ludwig said: "He never shuts up. That's his character. But at least he plays the way everybody else does." Ludwig, who turns 38 this month, is the other alternate captain. Hitchcock calls him and other veterans his "glue guys." The coach meets with the captains and team elders about twice a month, to discuss everybody's gripes. Belfour, the goalie, said: "I have some input, but, basically, I leave it up to the older guys. I don't feel like I'm one of the older guys." He's a mere pup of 33.
The best way to protect Belfour's goals-against average is to keep the puck at the other end of the ice, Hitchcock said. To accomplish this, he encourages his defensemen to join the attack, not off the rush but rather after the forwards take puck possession in the other end. He learned this, Hitchcock said, when the Stars lost to the Wings in the playoffs. "We decided after playing Detroit last year to stop playing scared," Hitchcock said. So far this season, they are 3-0 against the Wings. Describing the style of extended puck possession in the attack zone, Hull recently said: "It's almost like a football game. Whoever has time of possession longest is going to win." This does not go unappreciated in football country. "The whole game seems to fit with the Texas personality," Hitchcock said.
The Stars make their share of mistakes, but teammates cover up for each other, a common trait of good teams. They are able and willing to block shots and to hustle on the backcheck. Although they aren't heavily penalized, the Stars know how and when to play mean. In the opening minutes against Pittsburgh on Friday night, Verbeek barged through two checks and then exchanged swings with Penguins goalie Tom Barrasso and Ludwig dropped Stu Barnes with an elbow to the head. After both served their minor penalties, Verbeek scored to spark the Stars to a 6-4 victory.
"I got slashed, I got punched," Verbeek explained afterward, ice bags on each elbow, a few stitches in his upper lip. "I reacted."
Such scenes are enjoyed by a fan base that is growing in hockey sophistication in the sixth season since the team moved from Minnesota. In some ways, the Texas culture, with oil and cattle, is like that of Alberta, in Western Canada, where several stars come from. Hatcher, one of several Stars from the "Hockeytown" suburbs of Detroit, said "It seems like every other person I meet is from up north." Many migrated during the Rust Belt recession two decades ago, from states round the Great Lakes. Hitchcock said the transplanted Northerners "are all coaching youth hockey, watching it on TV and buying season tickets."
Sunday's sellout was the 26th in succession and a new, bigger arena will open in two years. Lites said some fans used to cheer when the team pulled its goalie for an extra attacker during a delayed penalty, thinking it was a novel way of attacking. They don't any more, but they do shout the word "Stars!" when it is heard in the lyrics of the national anthem. And they cheer a film clip on the video board before the start of the period in which Pee-Wee Herman sings "The stars at night are big and bright" and a chorus of people in cowboy hats respond with "Deep in the Heart of Texas!" Perhaps, by June, the Stars will give the audience a great deal more about which to hoot and holler.
