HEADLINE: No Medical Insurance Means Tough, and Creative, Choices

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Peggy Parraga, a part-time massage therapist from Queens, divides her life into two phases: the time when she and her family had health insurance, and now, when they do not.
Seven years ago, she had a baby at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx, which accepted her managed care plan, offered good prenatal care and even served her and her husband a celebratory champagne dinner. In 1996, pregnant again but uninsured, she could afford only a clinic at Elmhurst Hospital Center, and endured a chaotic and unpleasant delivery by a doctor she had never met before. 
 Mrs. Parraga said she used to be good about checkups for her family. Now, her husband, a draftsman whose employer stopped offering insurance several years ago, has aches and pains that he cannot afford to have checked. "It has really made a big difference in my life," she said.
To live without health insurance is to linger between denial and fear. It means ignoring the little pains and dealing with the unmanageable ones in a frantic way. It is knocking wood for good health while knowing that medical calamities can show up at the most inconvenient times.
Most of the uninsured cobble together an approach of avoiding care whenever possible and using hospital emergency rooms or pay-as-you-can clinics when it is not. They are a diverse group, from the chronically ill woman in Harlem who borrows her mother's medicine because she cannot afford her own, to a roofer in Yonkers who is fending off bill collectors, to a young Web site designer making about $65,000 a year who takes the calculated risk he will never have to see a doctor at all. Others choose their medical battles -- say, an annual mammogram -- and pay upfront.
For the most part, the uninsured are not the poorest of the poor, who tend to be covered by Medicaid, the Government health program for the indigent. Indeed, of the 43 million Americans without health insurance, 75 percent work at least part time, but are not offered insurance through an employer or cannot afford their contribution. (The rest tend to be students, children and early retirees.) And their numbers are swelling, as the price of insurance rises -- especially for small businesses -- and as more people move from welfare to jobs where there are few benefits.
Nationwide, 17.6 percent of people under 65 lack health insurance. In New York State, the figure is even higher -- 19.1 percent, or roughly 3 million people -- and their ranks are growing faster. In part, this is because New York has a large working population of illegal immigrants and a plethora of small entrepreneurial companies, like those in the new electronic media, that are too new and unstable to offer benefits. Further, New York is home to a disproportionate number of people who toil in the visual and performance arts, many of whom put together a living with part-time or freelance work without benefits. The state has about 1.5 million part-time workers, second only to California, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
Even Without Frills, Coverage Is Costly
For many of the uninsured, individual coverage can be prohibitively expensive, or too meager to be worth the cost. Those costs vary wildly: $100 a month for no-frills coverage to $400 a month and up for extensive benefits similar to an employer's package.
"I am wary of the monthly expense," said David Wickland, who works four days a week as an office temp and paints the rest of the week in his Brooklyn studio. "Anything that I could afford would basically be for just the most minimal ambulatory care. At $100 a month, I am unable to justify it. I don't go to doctors when there is an option not to go."
For the occasional emergency, going without coverage can work. Mr. Wickland, who earns roughly $33,000 a year, fell off a ladder recently and fractured his femur. He called several clinics until he was referred to the public Gouverneur Skilled Nursing Facility, Diagnostic and Treatment Center, where a long wait and confusing maze of transfers and paperwork finally resulted in care.
"It was really chaotic," he said. "People speaking several languages were running everywhere; it was very mixed up. I had to wait a couple hours in this waiting room, and it was strange to see that people were in a lot of pain waiting for hours."
For $80 and a card that would allow him to come back for a checkup, he considered himself a satisfied customer.
"I realized that if something like that came up I would have some place to go, and I was relieved it was available," he said. "But it also made me leery about going on without health insurance. There are certain things like teeth care, or a mole that should be looked at, and I just can't go."
For people with complicated or chronic health problems, this strategy often fails.
Thai Brooks at first blush seems to be the perfect candidate for scraping by without insurance. She is 27, lives with her mother in Harlem and works 35 hours a week with disabled people, netting about $1,200 a month. Checkups and annual dental appointments are within her financial reach, and she is happy that she no longer has to rely on Medicaid.
But her health problems are daunting: she has severe asthma, a defective heart valve, a chronic gastrointestinal disorder and anemia.
Under Medicaid, she would go to a medical office at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan for most of her ailments and for dental care, and took advantage of the hospital's cardiac care center.
But now, she must pay $74 per visit to Mount Sinai, a figure computed from a stack of pay stubs she took to a recent visit. Visiting the cardiac center is out of the question now, as are many drugs.
So she borrows asthma drugs from her mother and has taken to swallowing over-the-counter antidotes for her intestinal problems. ("It makes things bearable.") She hit her head recently and had to go to the emergency room. In trying to come up with $600 to pay for it, she has ignored a phone bill. "I like working," she said. "But it is frustrating because I cannot afford to get sick."
 
Mental Health Care Is Difficult to Get
Mental health problems, which need constant attention, get perhaps the shortest shrift. Yolanda Bako, who is 52, has worked as an off-track betting clerk for three years. She works 20 hours a week and until just recently was not eligible for insurance.
Her medical home is Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, a public hospital 12 blocks from her cramped apartment. The hospital offers a clinic with a sliding scale of fees, where she goes for everything from a sore throat to urinary tract infections to depression.
But getting good care for the latter has been the most problematic. She has taken 20 different antidepressants in the last few years, she said, and when she goes to Jacobi's psychiatric clinic, a different doctor sees her each time.
When she told one of them she felt suicidal, she was told to go to the hospital's in-patient unit, where she said she was kept for eight days and emerged without a diagnosis or plan. "I was the closest thing to a rational person there," she said.
Total bill: $14,000, none of which she could pay. Her bank account was impounded, and she has battled her way through hospital administrators and courts to sort out a payment plan, which she admits she has not always honored. "This is supposed to be the cheapest hospital around," she said. "I didn't understand how it could be so high."
Everyone interviewed said that in a pinch, the emergency room is the place to head for care. "They scold me," said Mrs. Parraga, who sometimes takes her children there when they have high fevers. "But I just can't sit home with a sick baby."
City hospital emergency rooms do not just offer a poor choice for those who seek to use them as doctors' offices, they are a severe drain on the system. When there are wages to garnish, as in the case of Ms. Bako, it can be done. But more often, care for the uninsured is written off as bad debt.
Dr. Luis R. Marcos, president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's 11 public hospitals, regularly cites the uninsured as the largest economic drain on his system. Of the city's uninsured population, 71 percent seek care through his hospitals and clinics.
"In a health care world that all the philosophers these days want to make into a competitive marketplace, these are nonpaying customers," said James R. Tallon Jr., president of the United Hospital Fund.
Gov. George E. Pataki recently vetoed a bill that sought to enrich the corporation's charity pools by $100 million, and he has said he is interested in earmarking only a small portion of the tobacco settlement money for the uninsured. In the meantime, those without insurance take services they are not equipped to pay for.
Stephen Baldwin sheepishly admits he is part of the problem. At 43, he stitches together a living of about $30,000 a year with writing and roofing. While repairing a roof last year, he got a bad splinter that became infected. He has yet to pay the $150 bill for a tetanus shot at a hospital in Yonkers, near his home. The bill has been turned over to a collection agency.
"I don't like to live like that," he said. "But I am not making a lot of money right now."
The lack of preventative care is largely viewed as one of the most serious medical issues affecting the poor. The stories are well known among policy makers, like the women who show up in the emergency room with horrible coughs and are diagnosed with advanced breast cancer.
But there is evidence that even people who can afford insurance and choose to forgo it are missing out on preventative care. Adam Coti, who is 30, estimates that he makes around $65,000 a year between his two jobs as a Web page designer and a free-lance circulation consultant, depending on how much work he gets.
He is tilting toward one of the fastest growing groups of uninsured Americans: households with annual incomes of $75,000 or more accounted for half the increase in the number of the uninsured last year, according to the Census Bureau.
Mr. Coti's logic works like this: he gets an ear infection each winter, which costs him roughly $150 after a clinic visit and a prescription. This is cheaper than the $250 in monthly premiums he was offered for a very basic insurance plan.
But his father died of colon cancer, which is often hereditary, easily diagnosed and curable if caught early with the recommended annual test. "My mother reminds me that I need to spend up to $1,000 for a general checkup," he said. "I don't believe in skimping on that. It has to be done. I want to make sure that 'one of these days' doesn't turn into next year."
His greatest fear is a catastrophe. "I am not looking for the best insurance in the world," Mr. Coti said. "I'll take a huge deductible. But one out of control cabdriver mad at his dispatcher hits the pedal, and I am in trouble. I go bike riding, and there are a couple steep hills where I live, and I think to myself, 'You don't have insurance.' "
 
An Unusual Solution Is Found in Mexico
Ellen Pearlman has come up with an unusual solution to the expense of health insurance: when it comes time to go the the doctor, she simply leaves the country. Ms. Pearlman, who works as an adjunct professor at Columbia University and does freelance computer work, has been uninsured since 1990.
Four years ago, she was on a writers' retreat in Merida, in the Yucatan region of Mexico, when she had a dental emergency. What she found was so fantastic, she said, she decided to come back. She has had dental work that would have cost $2,000 at home for $200, and blood tests for $10. She has received checkups and the like each of the six times she returned there, and twice went there just to get some minor surgery. The doctors are first rate, she said.
"I look forward to discovering other health care systems in other countries," she said. "Because I have no hope of availing myself of the care system in America."

Chart: "GETTING HELP: Small Programs Offer Medical Coverage to Employers and Individuals at a Discount"
 
Though there are no comprehensive programs that address the problems of the uninsured, some small programs have emerged that offer insurance to employers or individuals at discounted rates.
 
WHO -- Working Today
 
WHAT -- A comprehensive health plan for individuals that includes mental health benefits. Functions similar to a health maintenance organization but offers point-of-service options. The group is also forming a "portable insurance" project for freelance media workers that would enable them to take their benefits from job to job. Packages start at $255 a month.
 
CONTACT -- (212) 366-6066, Ext. 14, or www.WorkingToday.org on the Web.
 
WHO -- Small Business Health Insurance
 
WHAT -- An H.M.O. for businesses with under 50 employees in East Harlem and parts of Brooklyn and the Bronx, run by the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which requires patients to use certain public hospitals and their doctors. The program may expand to other neighborhoods at a later date.
 
CONTACT -- (212) 501-4442
 
WHO -- New York Health Purchasing Alliance
 
WHAT -- Under this program, to be offered later this year by the New York Business Group, employers with 2 to 50 employees will be able to buy insurance through a central office and offer each employee a choice of many plans. The company can subsidize the least expensive option, and the worker who wants a fancier plan can pay the difference.
 
CONTACT -- (212) 252-7440
 
In addition, individuals can also open medical savings accounts, which are health insurance plans with high deductibles that are paid for with money that is deposited into an account upfront.
At the end of the year, any money remaining in the account is carried over to the next year, and all contributions are deductible on Federal income tax returns. Ask your employer or accountant for details. (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT DEBATES RIGHTS AND TRADE WITH THE CHINESE

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Tuesday, March 2

 BODY:
Trying to infuse the troubled relationship between the United States and China with a new sense of direction, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke sternly today to the authorities here about human rights but also encouraged them to move forward on joining the organization that governs world trade.
Ms. Albright told President Jiang Zemin and other senior officials that the United States was disturbed by Beijing's crackdown on opposition groups and called on them to release a number of political prisoners. 
 Ms. Albright said at a news conference this morning that "in the last two days we've seen what a candid dialogue looks like" on human rights. One Administration officials said rights issues were "prominent but not dominant" during the visit.
Ms. Albright's visit came on the heels of the annual report by the United States Government that identifies countries with human rights problems, which was far more critical of China than last year's report.
At the same time, Ms. Albright made clear that the Administration was sticking to the approach it had developed, separating human rights from trade issues. "We determined some time ago that it was not a good idea to link human rights and trade," she said during the first day of her visit on Monday, "and that we actually make better progress in both when they are not linked." She emphasized the possibility of membership for China in the World Trade Organization, aides said.
Relations between Washington and Beijing strained by the roundup of dissidents, charges that China is trying to hone the accuracy of its missiles with American technology, and a growing trade deficit. Today Ms. Albright described relations as "neither the best of times nor the worst of times."
Still, the Administration has been eager to sound positive about China's chances of entering the trade organization.
Her comments about separating membership in the organization from China's human rights record marked the latest in a series of signals that Washington is sending in an effort to prompt the Chinese to make serious offers to open its markets.
But there are huge obstacles to an agreement. The Administration would have to win the backing of American business, which is split on the issue of exactly what markets China must open, and how fast.
Moreover, China wants assurances that Congress will drop the annual review of its "most favored nation" trade status -- which despite its name means the rights afforded to most American trading partners.
The review has brought an annual Congressional debate over the nature of the economic relationship between the two countries. Dropping it would require Congressional action. And even if the Administration separates China's entry into the trade group from human rights issues, it is highly unlikely that Congress will keep them separate.
China views membership in the World Trade Organization as a matter of national prestige, and the United States has a virtual veto over who can join the Geneva-based organization, the rule-maker and arbiter in world trade matters.
In return for membership, Washington has insisted that China provide a detailed schedule for opening its markets to foreign goods. But Chinese officials, facing a severe economic slowdown, are loath to allow international competitors to vie with outmoded state-owned enterprises that are laying off millions of workers.
Ms. Albright's visit is not likely to stop China's Communist Government from taking further action against dissidents. Late last week it detained one dissident and handed down an 18-month sentence in a labor camp to another without a trial.
A human rights group based in Hong Kong said on Monday that another dissident planned to form an independent political party. A recent effort to form such a party brought several arrests.
But the visit also came as other vexing problems with China surfaced, including the arrest last week of a Chinese citizen in California whom Federal agents charged with trying to obtain a component vital to missile guidance systems.
Publicly, at least, Chinese officials did not emphasize that or other security matters. Instead, they limited their public criticisms of the United States to its human rights stand.
Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan, with whom Ms. Albright spent most of her time, obliquely warned the United States not to submit a resolution criticizing China's human rights record at the annual meeting in Geneva this month of the United Nations Human Rights Commission. He said such "confrontation" would not solve the problem.
The Administration is in the midst of a heated internal debate about whether to go ahead with such a resolution, which is bound to antagonize the Chinese Government.
The State Department has characterized Ms. Albright's trip as a "business visit," intended to develop a system of regular meetings between the two countries.
It was the highest-level of a constellation of visits to Beijing in recent and coming days by American officials. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers was here last week, discussing China's beleaguered economy and its possible route to membership in the trade organization.
The United States is seeking Chinese membership because it would force Beijing to agree to a schedule of reductions in tariffs and trade barriers and would subject China to the rulings of the organization's court, which enforces trade rules. While reluctant to lower those barriers, the Chinese want to insure that other countries -- including the United States -- cannot discriminate against Chinese-made goods.
The Clinton Administration sees China's desire for membership as an opportunity for a tangible accomplishment that could move the relationship between the two countries forward. The United States is eager to close a deal in time for a scheduled visit by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Washington in early April.
An Administration official familiar with Washington's efforts to get China into the organization said it appeared that Mr. Zhu was serious about the talks and understood the benefits of membership.
The Administration has been contemplating some "imaginative transition" periods for China's entry so that the uncertain economy here, particularly some sectors including agriculture, would not be overwhelmed by the immediate lowering of tariffs, the official said.
In addition to human rights, the main complaint from China during Ms. Albright's talks was an American proposal for a missile defense system in Asia, Administration officials said. The Chinese have said that if such a system embraces Taiwan, its deployment will set off a new arms race and deeply harm Chinese-American relations. A Pentagon study released last week portrayed a growing threat to Taiwan from a buildup of missiles along the Chinese coast facing Taiwan.
Ms. Albright countered, according to her spokesman, James P. Rubin, that the system, which is in the design stage, was intended to protect American troops in the region from threats posed by ballistic missiles.
She told the Chinese that if they improved relations with Taiwan and stopped their missile buildup near the island, the enthusiasm in Washington for the theater missile defense system would probably wane.
The Chinese also brought up the Clinton Administration's cancellation last week of a satellite sale to China on the ground that the purchasing company had ties to the Chinese military.
An Administration official said the Chinese had expressed puzzlement, arguing that if the United States was interested in reversing its huge trade deficit with China, it should allow the Chinese to buy high-technology goods. The deficit, which reached an all-time high of $57 billion last year, is second only to the American trade deficit with Japan.
On a subject that increasingly concerns the Administration, Ms. Albright urged the Chinese to be more helpful in preventing North Korea, with whom China has diplomatic and military relations, from becoming a nuclear power.
An Administration official called the talks on that subject constructive, but another official said the Chinese were fairly coy about how much influence they could or would use with the North Koreans.

HEADLINE: U.N. Panel Urges Tribunal For Khmer Rouge Leaders

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
A United Nations panel has recommended that a new international tribunal be convened to try about a dozen senior Khmer Rouge officials on charges of crimes against humanity while they ruled Cambodia, according to diplomats and senior Administration officials.
Under the recommendation, a separate Cambodian truth commission would consider all other cases. 
 But in a sign of the growing tensions between China and the United States, the Chinese have told Administration officials who are lobbying for a tribunal that Beijing would veto the idea if it is brought before the United Nations Security Council, those officials said. The Khmer Rouge relied almost exclusively on Chinese support during their rule, which led to the deaths of nearly two million Cambodians from 1975 to 1979.
"China has always emphasized it defers to the domestic decision of Cambodia," said an Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The only way the Chinese will not veto this is if the Cambodian Government goes to the U.N. Security Council and asks for it."
The recommendation for a tribunal was given to the Cambodian Prime Minister, Hun Sen, last week, but will not officially be made public for several weeks, officials said.
In contradictory statements during the last two months, Mr. Hun Sen has alternately complained that the world is at least a decade late in condemning the Khmer Rouge, has given half-hearted support for an international tribunal and has questioned whether a trial would lead to new violence.
At the same time, Mr. Hun Sen has grown closer to China, signing five new agreements in Beijing last month that provide Cambodia with increased trade and economic benefits. In the same month, China's Foreign Minister, Tang Jiaxuan, said in Bangkok that Western nations, especially the United States, had come up with the idea of trying the Khmer Rouge, which he said was inappropriate because "these are internal problems of Cambodia" and should be decided only by the Cambodians.
"China has outmaneuvered the United States once again," said Stephen R. Heder, a professor of political science at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London and a Cambodian scholar.
"It's highly unlikely that Hun Sen can be turned around. He's been prepared to have a trial or not have a trial depending on the highest bid and China and its friends are willing to give him economic benefits, security guarantees and general diplomatic support that the United States can't offer."
The proposal does contain a way to circumvent a possible Chinese veto. The proposed International Criminal Tribunal for Cambodia could be put before the General Assembly for a vote, should it be blocked in the Security Council. But the five permanent members of the Council, including the United States, are wary of setting such a precedent.
Written by three outside experts, the proposal for a Cambodia tribunal includes innovations based on the experiences in the former Yugoslavia, Rwanda and South Africa, among other nations, according to officials. To set up the tribunal quickly and to save money, the offices of the tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda will be used. The trial of the top dozen or more officials would be held at the Hague, in Manila or in Canberra.
The truth commission, which was the idea of Thomas Hammaberg, the Secretary General's Special Representative on Human Rights in Cambodia, would be established in Cambodia and would allow Cambodians to have a full airing of what went on in one of this century's worst cases of mass murder.
"It's a good balance of the twin imperatives of justice and national reconciliation," said Craig Etcheson, program director of The International Monitor Institute and the former head of the Cambodian Documentation Center. "You establish a record through the tribunal and at the same time you allow Cambodians to feel that their suffering has been acknowledged and to find their way to reach social reconciliation within their community."
Mr. Hun Sen also said he is reluctant to approve a tribunal because world powers ignored his requests for nearly two decades to set up a Khmer Rouge trial, waiting until it suited their timetable.
From 1979 to 1991 Cambodia was hostage to the Asian cold war, and the United States, among other countries, refused to even officially acknowledge the mass killings for fear of upsetting China. Then, the Khmer Rouge signed a peace treaty and other countries worried about upsetting Cambodia's delicate recovery.
It was only in 1997 that a real push began, stimulated in part by Mr. Hun Sen and his then co-Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh. They petitioned the Secretary General that June asking "for the assistance of the United Nations and the international community in bringing to justice those persons responsible for the genocide and crimes against humanity during the rule of the Khmer Rouge from 1975 to 1979."
Pointing out that Cambodia did not have the "resources or the expertise" to conduct a trial, Mr. Hun Sen argued that "only in this way can this tragedy be brought to a full and final conclusion." Two weeks later, however, Mr. Hun Sen overthrew Prince Ranariddh and his ardor for a trial has since cooled.
There is little dispute over which Khmer Rouge leaders should be tried and whether there is sufficient evidence to convict them. At the top of the list is Nuon Chea, second to Pol Pot, the head of the regime who died last April, followed by Ta Mok and Khieu Samphan. Mr. Nuon Chea and Mr. Khieu Samphan turned themselves in to Mr. Hun Sen's Government in December and are living in a western Cambodian city with other Khmer Rouge defectors. Mr. Ta Mok is at large in the jungles of western Cambodia.
Cambodians fear that the long delay will prevent a trial from ever being held. According to a recent private poll cited by senior Administration officials, 80 percent of Cambodians favored an international tribunal. In a smaller survey done in 1997 by the Cambodian Documentation Center some 75 percent of Cambodians favored a trial.
While Secretary General Kofi Annan has yet to read the proposal, senior United Nations officials say he is worried about the precedent set by the arrest in Great Britain of General Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator.
"The Secretary General is listening to the Pinochet argument that it is better to bury the mistakes of the past, a senior United Nations official said.

HEADLINE: Doctors' Group Merges With a Larger Union

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The Doctors Council, a union representing 2,500 salaried doctors at New York City hospitals, announced yesterday that it was merging with the larger Service Employees International Union as part of a plan to accelerate efforts to unionize doctors nationwide.
Under the merger agreement, the Doctors Council -- most of whose members are post-residency attending physicians at the city's municipal hospitals -- will begin a campaign to unionize physicians in other states, helped by the larger union's pledge to spend $1 million a year on the effort. 
 Barry Liebowitz, president of the Doctors Council, said one priority would be to press for legislation in New York State and elsewhere that would make managed-care organizations liable if they overrule doctors' decisions and patients are hurt as a result.
At a news conference announcing the merger, Dr. Liebowitz and other union leaders said repeatedly that doctors' unions would fight as much to improve patient care as to increase doctors' wages and benefits.
"Medicine has been infected by a big-business mentality," said Dr. Liebowitz, a pediatrician. "Hospitals are merging and downsizing. Profit-driven managed-care companies and corporate administrators are dictating medical treatments to protect the bottom line. For the sake of our profession and for the sake of patients everywhere, this must stop."
With the merger, the Doctors Council becomes the third medical union in the Service Employees International Union, which now includes 15,000 doctors, making it the the nation's largest representative of doctors. The service employees union has created a new umbrella group, the National Doctors Alliance, comprising the Doctors Council, the Committee of Interns and Residents, and United Salaried Physicians and Dentists.
In 1997, the Committee of Interns and Residents, which is based in New York and represents 9,000 doctors, joined the service employees union, which has 1.3 million members, 600,000 of whom are in health care.
Andrew L. Stern, president of the service employees union, said it would make a big push to unionize not just interns and residents, but also salaried physicians. Doctors in private practice are usually considered independent contractors who are prohibited by law from bargaining collectively.
Labor leaders say many doctors are interested in unionization because they are angry about stagnating salaries and stepped-up restrictions imposed by hospitals and managed-care organizations.
"Nearly 50 percent of practicing physicians in the United States are now in salaried positions, making them eligible to join unions," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "They need unions because the upheaval in the health-care industry is affecting their work, just as it is affecting other health-care workers."
Dr. Liebowitz said the union would not rule out calling strikes. He said it would be hard to justify doctors' striking over economic issues, but he said a strike might be appropriate to prevent reduced quality of care -- closing a cardiology and neurology department to cut costs, for example.
"Sometimes it is better to strike than to allow patients to go into a substandard facility," he said.

HEADLINE: China Syndrome: Disputes Persist, Civility Rules

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 2

 BODY:
On her departure from China today, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright put the best face on the fractured United States-China relationship, saying it was mature enough to withstand sharp disagreements.
As she headed for Thailand for talks about that country's economy, she lauded the Chinese for the "depth and ease" of her discussions here, which were crammed into less than 48 hours. She emphasized that there would be no going back on the Clinton Administration's policy of broad engagement with China. 
 In short, she suggested, the United States has managed despite the rough bumps of the last few months to get beyond a relationship whose health depended primarily on one issue, whether human rights or trade or national security.
But in each of those areas, which were the hottest topics in the talks, Ms. Albright and her advisers acknowledged that they still faced significant obstacles in China and at home in Congress.
On human rights, Ms. Albright told the Chinese authorities that the recent arrests and long prison sentences imposed on members of a fledgling opposition party were a breach of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, not just an internal matter as the Chinese insist. From the American point of view, she said, the political stability that China values so highly cannot be bought at the price of freedom.
Fairly predictably, her advisers said, the Chinese rejected the arguments. But less predictably, a senior Administration official said, the Chinese did not "go through the roof" as they have in the past at the mention of human rights.
Further, the official said, slow progress is being made in persuading the Chinese to set up an information exchange on prisoners that would allow the American Embassy in Beijing to have regular contacts with the Chinese Foreign Ministry on the status of individual prisoners.
The Chinese were also told that the visit of the Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Washington in early April would present them with an opportunity to make a positive move on human rights.
To coincide with his visit, Ms. Albright suggested that the Chinese formally agree to one of the United Nations civil rights covenants they have signed but not yet ratified: the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights or the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.
Congress remains angry over China's human rights policies, and the recent arrests and sentences of opposition party members in China has heightened the antagonism.
In a sign of this renewed ire, the Senate unanimously adopted a resolution last week urging the Administration to condemn China at the annual meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva, which will begin at the end of this month.
One of Ms. Albright's tasks on this trip was to assess whether the Administration should introduce a resolution against the Chinese in Geneva and what effect it would have on the Chinese leadership, who have always interpreted such resolutions as highly negative acts.
By the end of Ms. Albright's talks, her advisers said, no decision was made on the touchy subject -- but they allowed that it was not a bad idea to keep the Chinese guessing.
In another area of discussion -- China's possible membership in the World Trade Organization, which governs global trade -- Ms. Albright came away somewhat heartened.
Her aides said that for the first time Mr. Zhu, who has major responsibility for the economy, appeared to understand the benefits of joining the trade organization, even as the Chinese economy was being shaken by slowing growth.
The Administration has hammered at the idea that opening the Chinese market for services, goods and agricultural products are likely to create job growth, not job loss as the Chinese have feared.
While the atmosphere for China's entering the trade organization has improved, officials said, the details of the concessions China is prepared to make for what the Administration insists must be a "commercially viable" agreement were far from clear.
China is now the fourth-ranked United States trading partner, and Washington argues that China is too big to leave outside the trade organization. The Americans believe that membership would force China to agree to a schedule for lowering tariffs and trade barriers and would subject China to the rulings of the group's court, which enforces trade rules.
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, is due in Beijing on Wednesday and will make a specific proposal that addresses the outstanding issues, a senior Administration official said. "After her visit we'll have to see where we are," the official said.
Although the Administration has for the moment made the trade organization its central focus in the relationship with China, there are major problems with gaining support from Congress for Chinese membership.
Various interest groups in Congress will be taking a close look at how the Administration negotiates requirements for market openings in areas like agriculture and telecommunications.
In addition, China has demanded that its agreement to join be tied to ending the annual vote in Congress on whether China should have "most favored nation" trading status, entitling it to the basic rights enjoyed by most United States trading partners.
It is not clear, several aides to Democratic senators said recently, that lawmakers will favor waiving the annual debate over the economic relationship between the two countries. At the very least, they said, senators will want to see improvement by China on human rights -- and, if not, a resolution in Geneva by the Administration -- in exchange for permanent trade status.
A specialist in China's economy, Nicholas R. Lardy, who is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said the Chinese were nervous about their prospects in Congress.
"The Administration has got only one carrot -- that is permanent trade status -- but the Chinese say, 'What if we don't get the vote in Congress?' " Mr. Lardy said. "The Chinese say, 'We've made all these concessions, but what do we get?' "
On United States national security interests, which have also riled Congress, Ms. Albright had to reply to some pointed complaints from the Chinese about Washington's intentions to deploy a missile defense shield in Asia. The Chinese view that plan, which could involve a protective shield around Taiwan, as a threat.
Ms. Albright's answer was equally pointed: "I replied that instead of worrying about a decision that has not been made to deploy defensive technologies that do not yet exist, China should focus its energies on the real source of the problem -- the proliferation of missiles," she said at a news conference today.
China should use its influence with North Korea to help restrain missile development there, she said. And China should work with Taiwan to reduce tensions so that the Chinese can reverse their recent buildup of missiles on the Chinese coast opposite Taiwan.
If missile threats from North Korea and China were not perceived to exist, then the need for a United States missile defense shield in Asia would diminish, she said.

HEADLINE: In America;
Working on Poverty

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Courage is a quality in short supply with politicians of any era, and especially now. So it seemed odd at lunch this week with Andrew Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to hear him insist, passionately and un-self-consciously, that now is the time to move on behalf of the perennial underdogs in our society -- the families living in squalor and hopelessness on Indian reservations, or in the economic and social wreckage that has defined Appalachia for decades, or in the worst of our inner cities, which continue to be dangerous and isolated crucibles of despair.
"We have real people in real pain that we have to attend to," said Mr. Cuomo, who toured the poverty-ridden coal mining regions of West Virginia last week. 
 With the U.S. economy humming, and with the budget deficit gone, there is an unprecedented opportunity to make investments that will bring training and real jobs to men and women for whom employment has been little more than a distant memory, or a dream.
"The economy is breaking all sorts of records," Mr. Cuomo said. "And because the economy is strong we want to say everything is good. A lot of things are good. Employment is up, crime is down, poverty is down, welfare is down. But at the same time we have a lot of significant problems."
He picked up a stack of large color photographs and spread them across a table. "The Dow Jones? They don't know from it," he said, pointing to individuals in the photos who have been so hounded for so long by poverty in the Mississippi Delta, on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota, on the South Side of Chicago, that they cannot imagine an economically viable future.
"This is a great economy, yes," said Mr. Cuomo. "But you go to Appalachia, it's just like it was 30 years ago. We've had some success with the cities, but over all the cities are not doing well. They are smaller, poorer, and the poverty is more concentrated than 20 years ago. You want to say the poverty rate has come down? Yes. But it's still one in five." He was referring to the fact that even in these most prosperous of times, one in five American children lives in poverty.
The 10 poorest counties in the U.S. are rural, and their poverty rates are staggering, in some cases higher than 60 percent.
The way to deal with these problems is to put people to work, said Mr. Cuomo. And because the economy is doing so well, the necessary investments should be made now. "You fix the hole in the roof when the sun is shining," he said, "not when it's raining."
The goal, said Mr. Cuomo, is to get businesses and jobs into poverty-stricken areas, or to get residents of depressed areas into jobs that are located elsewhere. "We have some new approaches to these problems that are designed to create jobs by stimulating the private market economy," said Mr. Cuomo. "It will require government action because the private market is not going to South Central Los Angeles without a subsidy. Period. So you have to say, 'If you go to South Central L.A., I'll give you a tax break.' That's Jack Kemp's enterprise zones. Or you say, 'If you hire a person from South Central, I'll subsidize their salary.' That's Charlie Rangel. We do both, but it has to be about either creating jobs or getting people into jobs."
In an era in which technological miracles have become commonplace, it is possible to get good jobs to the unlikeliest places. Mr. Cuomo recently asked a gathering of executives if their operations could function out of the Pine Ridge Reservation. Sure, he was told. For the right price, they could work anywhere.
Mr. Cuomo is trying to spread the word that there are many Americans living in squalor and with very little hope at a time when the nation is more prosperous than ever. He insists they can be helped to help themselves, and that it is in the national interest to offer that initial help.
"The President talks about untapped markets," Mr. Cuomo said. "Where do we still have the economic potential, the untapped markets where the economy can still grow? It's the very same areas that need the help. The high-unemployment areas. The high-poverty areas.
"We know how to do this. We have the resources. The excuses are gone."

HEADLINE: International Study on Water in Mideast Leads to a Warning

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, March 2

 BODY:
The drought this winter could be a portent of an even drier future unless Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians work together to conserve shared water resources, an international panel of scientists warned today.
With a population of 12 million in a region with as much rainfall as Phoenix, Ariz., water supplies "are barely sufficient to maintain a quality standard of living," said Gilbert F. White, a geographer from the University of Colorado who was chairman of a research group from the United States National Academy of Sciences and counterpart institutions from Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority. 
 In what was described as the first major study of the long-term outlook for water supplies between the eastern border of Jordan and the Mediterranean Coast of Israel, the report said even with strict management "the area's inhabitants will almost assuredly live under conditions of significant water stress in the near future."
Ancient underground aquifers are being drained dry, while scarce rains flow unused into desert gulches and rivers are diverted for water-intensive tropical agriculture, the researchers said. Watersheds cross political boundaries and can only be managed jointly, they said.
It is hardly news here that water is getting ever scarcer and the population steadily larger. Yet by drawing on data from disparate sources within and outside the region, the study provides what its authors believe is the first comprehensive analysis of regional patterns of water demands and supplies, while at the same time detailing feasible methods of conserving water and reducing consumption.
At least as significant as the content, participants said, was the political fact that this was the first serious study involving Jordanian, Israeli and Palestinian experts, all of whom urged their Governments to work together on recycling waste water, developing more efficient irrigation and using brackish water for industry and agriculture.
The unusual regional collaboration and the prestige of the Academy of Sciences should help assure that the study will guide the World Bank and other Western aid donors whose support is crucial to all three Governments, the authors said.
Left carefully unmentioned were the consequences of an regional battle over dwindling water resources. But the concern was implicit.
"This is a very dry region and a very tiny region, with an importance out of all proportion to its size," said David Policansky, staff director of the project.
The 225-page study, which took more than two years, is itself rather arid, scrupulously avoiding any hint of national bias or ideological advocacy, and concentrating on regional research rather than policy prescriptions.
"While we were aware of many proposals for managing water supplies in the study area and neighboring areas, we explicitly refrained from making recommendations about these specific programs and political policies," Mr. White said.
The scientists acknowledged that their hope was to galvanize policymakers into action and to remove the excuse that there is insufficient scientific information on which to base broad new water policies.
Members of the group met on Monday with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat. The Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities will be presenting its findings to the Israeli Government, and the Royal Scientific Society of Jordan is advising the Government in Amman about the research.
The principal scientific contribution of the panel, some suggested, was to collate and verify existing research from varied sources on regional industry, irrigation, meteorology and geology.
"There was a serious lack of regional information," Mr. Policansky said, pointing to a map of regional rainfall patterns that was drawn from different official sources and research institutes. "This is quite basic. But until we did it there was nothing like it."
The report stresses the limits of a landscape ranging from "sparse forest" to desert and "semidesert," cleaved by the "temperate steppe" of the Jordan Valley, itself increasingly dried out by upstream irrigation. In 40 years, all fresh water in the region should be reserved for household use, with treated waste water and saline water used to supply agriculture and industry, the researchers said.
As the largest and by far the most prosperous of the three, Israel accounts for most of the consumption, the study confirmed. At 344 cubic meters, its per capita water use in 1994 was almost four times that of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, at 93 cubic meters a person.
Palestinian officials and Israeli environmentalists often point critically to this disparity and to California-style watered lawns and capacious bathtubs that they consider irresponsibly profligate. Yet the study showed that Israel's use is only marginally greater than Jordan's. Jordan is poorer than the West Bank, yet consumed 244 cubic meters a person.
In Jordan and Israel, the thirstiest consumers are not households, but farms, out of all proportion to their share of the economy and workforce. In Israel, agriculture accounts for 3 percent of the gross domestic product and 57 percent of water consumption. The Jordanian agricultural sector contributes 6 percent of the G.D.P., but uses 72 percent of the water. In the less developed West Bank and Gaza Strip, agriculture absorbs about the same share of water, 64 percent, yet accounts for fully a third of the local economy.
The Israeli Foreign Minister, Ariel Sharon, has been promoting plans for Mediterranean desalting plants that could supply Gaza and Israeli coastal communities. But the study noted that desalting sea water was extremely expensive -- $1 or more for a cubic meter of potable water -- and would not usually be considered feasible in a region without cheap and abundant fuel supplies.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Reassuring Data and High Yields Help Treasury Prices Post Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose yesterday for only the second time in almost a week as market participants covered short positions after a benign report on new-home sales.
Also contributing to higher prices were the unwinding of positions in front of a large amount of corporate debt expected to be priced during the next few days and the attractive yields resulting from recent selloffs. 
 "Unlike existing-home sales, which rose to a record level in January, new-home sales fell modestly during the month," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "and while this was the second consecutive monthly decline, the sales pace is still at historically high levels and shows no definitive signs of slowing as of yet."
Although rising mortgage rates could dampen housing activity in the short term, he added, "keep in mind that housing is the leading edge of broad economic momentum, and the economy's rip-roaring advance is not likely to slacken significantly until a housing slowdown is under way."
He said a separate report that the Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose five-tenths of a percent in January did not suggest a slowdown in the economy.
Despite the market's recent swoon and concern about rapid economic growth and Federal Reserve intervention, Mr. Fine said the odds that the Federal Open Market Committee would raise interest rates at its March 30 meeting were slim but that there was a good chance that the committee could shift its stance in favor of higher rates in the future.
"Given the recent onslaught of strong economic data, the labor market data to be released this Friday could prove very instrumental in this decision," Mr. Fine said.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 24/32, to 94 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.61 percent, from 5.66 percent on Monday. The two-year note gained 3/32, to 99 24/32, to yield 5.13 percent, down from 5.18 percent the previous day.
The Treasury was an active seller of debt yesterday, selling $10 billion of new 52-week bills and $19 billion of 12-day cash management bills. The 12-day bills are used to meet the Treasury's short-term cash needs and are an addition to its regular schedule of debt sales.
The auction of 52-week bills went well, analysts said, thanks to the increase of nearly 30 basis points in yields since last month's auction. The bills were awarded at an average rate of 4.665 percent, with the number of bids the best since last September's auction. The rate of the 12-day cash management bill came in at 4.79 percent.
Elsewhere in the bond market, Colombia sold a five-year note that was priced to yield 11.587 percent, or 6.3 percentage points over the comparable Treasury issue. The issue was another indication that Brazil's devaluation of its currency in January has had much less fallout than feared.
This was the first bond that Colombia has sold since Russia devalued the ruble and defaulted on some bonds last August. The high yield attracted enough investors to raise the issue to $500 million from $400 million, said Rachel Hines, the managing director for Latin American capital markets at J. P. Morgan Securities, one of the joint lead underwriters on the issue.
Following are the results of yesterday's auctions of a 52-week Treasury bill and 12-day cash management bill:

HEADLINE: Hewlett Plans To Split in 2 In Revamping

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2

 BODY:
Responding to the ever-shifting fortunes of high-technology industries, the Hewlett-Packard Company, the cornerstone of California's Silicon Valley, announced today that it would split into two independent companies, one focusing on computers, printers and scanners, the other on electronic test equipment and medical technology products.
Wall Street greeted the move enthusiastically, sending Hewlett-Packard shares up $2.75 to close at $68.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Analysts said the split would allow Hewlett-Packard's computer and imaging businesses to compete more effectively with more focused companies that have lower cost structures, like the Dell Computer Corporation, Sun Microsystems Inc. and Lexmark International Group.
Although Hewlett-Packard's reputation was built on the quality of its test and measurement equipment -- not to mention its legendary founding in the iconic Palo Alto garage 60 years ago -- that business has been marked by higher overhead and slower growth than the company had realized in computers, printers and scanners.
"The company has been in too many businesses," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "H.P. has actually done surprisingly well through the years with a diversified business, but the time has come for this kind of step. I think it should be a shareholder-enriching event."
Hewlett-Packard has struggled to meet its own or analysts' estimates of revenue growth, although it beat earnings estimates in the most recent quarter through rigorous cost-cutting. Test and measurement, which also includes medical products like ultrasound, patient monitoring devices and heart defibrillators, had averaged better than 10 percent revenue growth over the last decade, but in the most recent fiscal year, growth dropped to 1 percent, because of the Asian economic crisis and a slowdown in the semiconductor business.
"We still have quite a collection of businesses under one roof, which have become increasingly divergent in terms of their business models, the way they go to market, and the customers they serve," Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's chairman, president and chief executive officer, said in a telephone interview.
After the split, the computer and imaging company will continue to be known as the Hewlett-Packard Company, while a new name will be chosen for the measurement company. Hewlett-Packard plans a public offering of 15 percent of the measurement company's outstanding shares by year-end, which would be the largest initial public offering in Silicon Valley history. The measurement business, including chemical-analysis and medical businesses, represented $7.6 billion of Hewlett-Packard's total revenue of $47.1 billion in the 1998 fiscal year.
"The focus we get from being separate will help our outbound message," Mr. Platt said. "What can you say about a company like H.P.?"
In contrast, he said, Sun Microsystems, a major competitor in large network server computers, "is out there with just one message."
"The complexity and confusion of having all these businesses under one roof outweigh the synergy of having them all together," he said.
Mr. Platt, 58, said he would remain chief executive until Hewlett-Packard's separation was completed. That is expected to take 12 to 18 months. A search for a successor is under way.
Aside from the printer business, where Hewlett-Packard has a commanding market share, the company has struggled to own any particular market segment the way Sun is identified with the Internet, Dell with personal computers or I.B.M. with large enterprise systems.
Analysts say that while Hewlett-Packard has credible offerings in all of those markets, it has lacked a coherent strategy to address any one of them. What is not clear is whether spinning off test and measurement will change that picture, they said.
"I actually think test and measurement is the crown jewel," said James Moore, chief executive of Geopartners Research in Cambridge, Mass. "Test and measurement is where the technology tends to be, where a lot of the talent tends to be. The problem is on the PC side. It was a great mistake for them to plunge so heavily into PC's. They and Compaq got into a price war, and what neither company understood was that Dell was hitting them in a blind spot."
Dell has grabbed market share from Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard with a combination of a direct sales model, which eliminates the overhead of dealers and distributors, and custom configuration, which allows it to sell machines at higher average prices.
Even so, Mr. Platt said the companies' business models were actually coming closer together. "Dell's out now very aggressively recruiting dealers and distributors to help them serve customers who prefer to be served that way," he said. "While we started out with very different multitier strategies, we are converging."
At $10.2 billion, revenues in Hewlett-Packard's computer business increased 3 percent over last year; in contrast Dell grew sales by 38 percent in the same period. At the same time, revenue from the measurement organization declined 11 percent, with test and measurement down 14 percent, chemical-analysis up 8 percent, and medical-products down 13 percent.
Mr. Platt said one quarter's results did not drive the decision to split the company, but he conceded that they might have been a factor. "If we'd had quite a wonderful year, maybe there would have been less urgency," he said.
Edward W. Barnholt, Hewlett-Packard's executive vice president and general manager of the measurement organization, has been named chief executive of the new company.
"We'll work very hard to be an $8 billion start-up that will compete very effectively with companies of all sizes," Mr. Barnholt said.
Whatever name is eventually chosen for the new company, he said, it will likely reflect the legacy of Hewlett-Packard. "We certainly want to build on the heritage of H.P.," he said. "We don't want to leave that equity behind."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Intervenes as Inflation Fear Sends Currency Down

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2

 BODY:
Weakened by uncertainty about revisions in the Government's agreement with the International Monetary Fund and growing fears of a rise in inflation, the Brazilian currency continued its slide to a record low against the dollar today, forcing the central bank to intervene for the fourth time in a week.
The currency, the real, dropped as low as 2.22 to the dollar before recovering somewhat and settling at 2.16 after the central bank stepped in. In New York, the real edged up to 2.10 to the dollar from 2.13 on Monday, after falling 8.6 percent in a week. 
 Since Brazil devalued its currency in mid-January, it has declined more than 40 percent, leading to sharp increases in prices of imported goods and forcing the Government to raise interest rates to levels that threaten to suffocate the economy.
The immediate cause of the sharp drop in the real's value over the last two days was the need for Brazilian companies to pay obligations to foreign creditors. The lenders, because of their continued concerns about the economic crisis here, have been unwilling to roll over about $2 billion in bonds and other payments due this month, and Brazilian debtors have been forced to scramble to obtain dollars. "This is not really a run against the real," Paulo Ferraz, president of Banco Bozano Simonsen, said today. "This is a specific demand for payments of Eurobonds, and once it is met, I would hope the dollar will begin to fall."
But market analysts said other factors, chiefly a sharp rise in the rate of inflation, traditionally the Brazilian economy's great worry, have also played a role in the decline of the real this week. By official calculation, prices rose 3.61 percent last month, more than double the 1.79 percent recorded during all of 1998.
Inflation, which as recently as five years ago had been running above 1,000 percent annually, is expected to increase further in March and April, as January's devaluation makes the price of everything from medicine to wheat more expensive. As a result, interest rates, which already stand at a punishing annual rate of 41 percent, may soon be running behind inflation, increasing the likelihood they will have to be raised more.
That, in turn, has exacerbated fear that the recession brought on by the collapse of the real will be longer and deeper than the Government is willing to acknowledge. Hence, the anxiety about the precise terms of the new targets for spending cuts and taxes contained in the revised agreement being negotiated with the I.M.F. -- something made necessary after President Fernando Henrique Cardoso abandoned the defense of the real in mid-January.
When the decision to allow the real to float freely on the foreign-exchange markets was announced then, the Government indicated that it would no longer intervene to prop up the currency. The central bank reversed course once the real passed the symbolic level of 2 to the dollar, but has acted inconsistently in recent days, encouraging speculators to mount attacks on the currency.
"Above all, what is needed is a more active posture by the economic team, especially the president of the central bank," said Carlos Kawall, chief economist for Citibank. "Absent a more vigorous role as regards exchange policy and other initiatives, the market will continue" reacting unfavorably.
The real's recent decline has come despite a statement on Monday by Michel Camdessus, managing director of the I.M.F., that good news would soon result from the negotiations with Brazil. The market "was anticipating a quicker freeing up" of I.M.F. money and a return of bank credit "than we are seeing now," Mr. Kawall said.
In the meantime, impatience with the I.M.F. and the deep spending cuts required as part of its $41.5 billion aid package is growing. Some of Mr. Cardoso's closest political allies have joined in the chorus of complaints, spreading concern that the Brazilian Congress may not agree to some of the I.M.F.'s demands.
"We understand that the Government needs to go to the I.M.F.," Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, the president of the Brazilian Senate and Mr. Cardoso's most powerful political associate, said last week. "But that doesn't mean the I.M.F. can interfere in national problems, above all to create difficulties for the poorest sectors in Brazil."
Arminio Fraga, president-designate of the central bank, has been having acrimonious confirmation hearings in Brasilia. Opposition senators have interrogated him mostly about his ties to the financier George Soros, his previous employer. But some questions have elicited indications that he intends to move ahead with an austerity program.
"Monetary policy in the next few months will necessarily have to be characterized by a restrictive slant so long as the transitory effects of the devaluation have not disappeared," Mr. Fraga said on Friday. He warned that "the next few months are going to be difficult," with unemployment likely to rise and businesses to go bankrupt.

HEADLINE: Earnings Top Expectations At Two Large Retailers

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Dayton Hudson Corporation, two large retailers, reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were higher than expected, aided by the economy's strength, which spurred sales of home goods and clothing.
Federated, the department-store company whose chains include Macy's, Bloomingdale's and Burdines, said net income rose 7.7 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, which ended Jan. 30. Dayton Hudson said operating earnings jumped 27 percent as sales rose at its Target discount chain and rebounded at its Mervyn's midprice department stores. Net income rose 19 percent. 
 Record employment and rising wages left consumers flush with cash to buy brand-name goods at bargain prices during the holiday season at Target and other discount chains. And a late burst of holiday shopping and demand for marked-down clothes in January increased sales at department stores.
"It's a good sales environment for both companies because the consumer is really driving this economy," said Timothy Ghriskey, senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation, which owns shares in both retailers.
Profits received a further boost from the retailers' efforts to hold down inventory and operating costs, offsetting the price cuts that were needed to spur sales of coats, sweaters and other winter clothing during the holiday season.
At Federated, which is based in Cincinnati, net income in the quarter rose to $408 million, or $1.88 a share, from $379 million, or $1.66 a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected a result of $1.82 a share, and Federated's shares gained $1.4375, to $40.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
Revenue grew 2.9 percent, to $5.21 billion from $5.06 billion, aided by a 4.1 percent increase in sales at stores open at least a year.
Dayton Hudson's profit from operations rose to $453 million, or 97 cents a share, from $356 million, or 76 cents a share. The results exceeded forecasts by 7 cents a share. The Minneapolis-based company's shares closed down $2.25, to $61.875 on the Big Board.
Gains and charges related to a change in the company's income tax rate, the hiring of an outside company to handle data center operations and the redemption of long-term debt resulted in net income of $423 million, or 90 cents a share. There were no gains or charges a year ago.
Revenue rose 13 percent, to $10.1 billion from $8.95 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 6.1 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCIES;
The Euro Falls, And Some Find Economic Fault

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 2

 BODY:
In the two months since the European single currency was introduced, pretty much the only direction it has moved is down.
From a buoyant and technically smooth start-up on Jan. 4, the euro has steadily slipped against the United States dollar. An initial exchange rate of $1.17 is now around $1.09. 
 The decline has surprised most experts and puzzled the overseers of the new currency at the European Central Bank. It could also strain relations with the United States, where Government officials now loudly complain that Europe has to do more to stimulate world growth. A weak euro makes that harder, because it increases the price of imported goods and diminishes European demand for them.
The euro's troubles reflect a series of economic and political developments that have taken the shine off Europe and its new currency. Economic growth has sharply slowed, particularly here in Germany, while the United States has defied expectations with an unrelenting pace of torrid growth.
Some experts and political leaders also warn that the financial markets may have been unnerved by recent squabbling among European political leaders over monetary policy, farm subsidies and budget cuts. "You can't get around the fact that the euro is the economic component of a blueprint for political unification," said Graham Bishop, an adviser on the single currency to Salomon Smith Barney. "If you see disarray at the heart of the political process, that ought to make people nervous."
Many economists argue that the euro will regain its initial strength later this year, though perhaps not before it sinks a little further. But many also concede that their predictions two months ago were simply wrong. "I had to change my view fairly quickly," said Ravi Bulchandani, chief currency strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in London. Like many others, Mr. Bulchandani had expected the euro to climb from its starting price of $1.17. Now he predicts that it could sink to $1.05 before it strengthens.
Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, suggested in January that he would be comfortable if the euro traded between $1.14 and $1.19. When it dropped below $1.14, Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged that he was "puzzled," but he did not signal any policy change.
Economists say the euro's decline largely reflects the sharp contrast between American and European growth rates. Industrial production across the 11-nation euro zone declined two-tenths of a percent in December, the European Commission said in data released on Monday.
By comparison, the Commerce Department said Friday that fourth-quarter growth in the United States increased at an annualized 6.1 percent, the fastest in nearly 15 years.
European sluggishness has been notable in Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro zone's total economy. Just today, the German Chambers of Industry and Commerce said that companies now expect the economy to grow only 1.5 percent this year, down from 2.8 percent in 1998. The German central bank has already estimated that the economy declined four-tenths of a percent in December. "There are clouds spreading over the German economy and the sunshine has disappeared," said Franz Schoser, the chambers' managing director.
In Italy, Europe's third-largest economy, things are worse. The Government said on Monday that economic growth last year was only 1.4 percent, far short of its projections.
At the same time, economic expansion has made the United States a magnet for foreign money, increased the demand for dollars and reduced that for euro investments.
"If you look at the two economies," said Stefan Schneider, chief European economist for Banque Paribas, "they just seem to be going in opposite directions."
Europe's uncertain prospects have aggravated the running battle between some left-leaning political leaders and the conservative monetarists at the European Central Bank.
Finance Minister Oskar Lafontaine of Germany continues to press the bank for reduced interest rates, which would help stimulate European economies with increased lending but could further weaken the euro by reducing the value of investments denominated in the currency.
Some currency traders thought the bank would soon give in, and some economists say that the expectation of lower rates probably helped push down the euro in recent weeks.
But Mr. Duisenberg and other members of the central bank's board made it clear this week that they would not change course at their next meeting on Thursday. "We think the interest rate should stay where it is now," Mr. Duisenberg said in an interview with the Spanish newspaper El Mundo, and several of his colleagues have since echoed those views.
Bank officials note that parts of Europe are still growing at a pace they consider reasonable. France is more buoyant than Germany, and economists say it can still grow by more than 2 percent this year. Spain, Portugal, Ireland and the Netherlands are all growing much faster than that.
Indeed, some analysts say German political leaders appear at odds with their French colleagues. Both Governments are now controlled by left-of-center parties, but French leaders have refrained from actively criticizing the central bank.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Electronic Serial Numbers Raise Privacy Concerns
From computers to cellular phones to home electronics, everyday devices and software programs are increasingly embedding telltale identifying numbers that enable them to interact. That trend is generating a dispute pitting security interests and convenience against privacy concerns.
Privacy groups argue that the merger of computers and the Internet has brought the specter of a new surveillance society. But a growing alliance of computer industry executives, engineers, law enforcement officials and scholars contend that absolute anonymity is not only increasingly difficult to obtain technically but is also a potential threat to democratic order because of the possibility of electronic crime and terrorism. "You already have zero privacy -- get over it," Scott McNealy, the chairman and chief executive of Sun Microsystems, said recently. Page A1. 

Since Birth, Euro Has Fizzled
In the two months since the European single currency was introduced, pretty much the only direction it has moved is down. The decline has surprised most experts and puzzled the overseers of the new currency at the European Central Bank. A1.
 
Car Sales Strong in February
Major auto makers reported record sales for February. Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler both said sales rose 8 percent. American Honda said sales rose 14 percent. C2.
 
Sony Introduces Playstation II
Making what could be a quantum leap in the march to wed consumer electronics to computers and the Internet, Sony introduced the widely anticipated second generation of its hit Playstation video-game console. C4.
 
Broadcaster Wants to Try Banking
Pat Robertson, the religious broadcaster, wants to go into the banking business. He and the Bank of Scotland applied for a charter to operate a new national bank that will not have any branches but will instead deal with customers by telephone and mail. C5.
 
Retail Giants Post Good Profits
The retail giants Federated Department Stores and Dayton Hudson reported quarterly profits that beat forecasts, aided by the economy's strength, which spurred sales of home goods and clothing. Shares of Federated gained $1.4375, to $40.0625, while Dayton Hudson fell $2.25, to $61.875. C7.
 
Computer Shares Pull Stocks Down
Stocks ended lower, led by Intel and 3Com, on concern that waning demand and increased competition will hurt profits in the computer industry. Nasdaq fell 36.15 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2,259.03. The Dow industrials fell 27.17 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 9,297.61. The S.& P. 500 declined 10.66 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 1,225.50. C8.
 
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 24/32, to 94 26/32. Its yield fell to 5.61 percent, from 5.66 percent on Monday. C8.
