HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: He's Got the Moves Off Court, Too;
St. John's Point Guard Conquers a Road Fraught With Danger

BYLINE: By JUDY BATTISTA 

 BODY:
Erick Barkley and Tyrone Grant, their low voices spiked with bravado, had a conversation recently that turned civic pride on its head -- debating which one of them came from the worse Brooklyn neighborhood. Grant -- from Brownsville, "a few blocks from Mike Tyson," he noted -- brought the debate to a quick conclusion when he conceded that Barkley's was "the worst neighborhood in the world."
"It was either be a drug dealer or play basketball," Barkley said in perhaps an overstatement about the Farragut Houses in Fort Greene. "You took one side of the road or the other." 
 Shirley Barkley can still look out her apartment window at Farragut and see the concrete court below where her small son took his first underhand shots when he was 6 and began to make that choice.
Barkley was terrible; "I was an ant," he said. But basketball led him on a circuitous course fraught with the perils of the urban ghetto, a course he managed to navigate from childhood games against Stephon Marbury to a key role in the elevation of St. John's to a top 10 ranking this season. From the chaos rose the consummately controlled, reticent fulcrum of St. John's offense, a freshman who will be on display this week in the Big East Conference tournament, which begins today at Madison Square Garden.
Good point guards, St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis said, give teams the chance to win every night. St. John's has been in every game.
"If it wasn't for Erick, we wouldn't be in the top 10," said Grant, the senior center. "He's made all of us better. His decision-making has been perfect."
His decision-making off the court has been nearly as good. Barkley was born in 1978 and grew up during the crack scourge, when one early mentor used to hear gunshots and gang fights as he escorted young Erick home from the gym. Shirley Barkley, an evangelist, did not want Erick, the youngest of nine children, in the projects then, and still tries to dissuade him from visiting there.
"It was drug-infested," she said. "You couldn't help it. I never had any problems with Erick, though. He was always a good kid."
Barkley was the beneficiary of what now looks like the smooth exchanges of a practiced relay team: a handoff from mother, to church league coach, to high school, to concerned friends to a fortuitous trip out of town to improve his grades, to college.
It was not so smooth, of course. When Erick was still in high school, Shirley Barkley left her son behind with friends and went to Georgia, a move she made to get away from the neighborhood, her son said. And Barkley struggled so much academically in high school that there were doubts he would be eligible to play for St. John's this season.
But the inner city has forged that most legendary of New York athletes -- the playground point guard -- and Barkley figured out that he could steal the moves from the good ones like Marbury and still avoid the pitfalls that swallowed other street phenoms.
"Basketball was his salvation," said Bob Oliva, Barkley's coach at Christ the King High School in Queens. "I've never coached a player who had such a one-track mind. Erick's social life was going to the gym and playing basketball. It was his outlet."
Joe Francis knew that from the first time Barkley showed up for a St. Ann's Catholic Youth Organization practice. Barkley was about 6 then, and very small. Francis, a dean at Xaverian High School, has a picture of Barkley standing next to a water fountain; the fountain is taller than Barkley.
"I was practicing with the basketball team, with a bunch of older guys maybe 14 years old," Francis said. "He said, 'I want to be an N.B.A. player.' I go into this thing about hard work and dedication. He said he was right-handed. I said, put the ball in your left hand and just dribble around the court. This was about 5:30. I lost track of this little guy going around the court. At 9, I'm kicking everybody out of the gym and I notice the little guy still going. I said, 'Why didn't you stop and go home?' He said, 'You never told me to.' "
Francis became one of the people Shirley Barkley relied on to rescue her son. He shooed away the gang members when they tried to woo a 12-year-old Barkley, and Francis' gym became the haven for Barkley and the place where the first glimmers of his basketball future became clear.
He once scored 20 points in a half during a 12-and-under tournament, when Barkley encountered Marbury at a Christmas tournament in Coney Island. Barkley was 9 and Marbury was 11. The final score was 54-48.
"His team had 48 and Steph had 44," Barkley said. "We won the game and I was the m.v.p. I will never forget that game."
By the time he got to Christ the King, Barkley was already a standout player -- Oliva said he was the most controlled freshman he had seen -- and the team won the Catholic league championship in Barkley's sophomore season.
The personal turning point came before Erick's senior year, when Shirley Barkley moved to Georgia. Mother and son agreed that Erick would stay in New York and then go to prep school to straighten out his grades.
Francis talked to the family of Craig (Speedy) Claxton, Barkley's close friend, who is now Hofstra's point guard. Yvette and Steve Claxton run a quiet household where the television is off and the schoolwork is done. They have seven children, the oldest of whom is about to graduate from medical school. When Barkley moved to the Claxtons' home in Hempstead, on Long Island, it was his first brush with the dynamics and discipline of a middle-class family.
"He saw that people could live better, so that's the way he chose to go," Shirley Barkley said.
Craig Claxton said: "When he moved in with me, it was a nice neighborhood, and he didn't have a choice about getting into trouble. My father drove my sister to school every day, so he had to go. It's tough on you if you don't have somebody looking after you telling you to go. They treated him like another part of family. I think he was more friendly and easier to get along with afterwards. Living with my parents, it opened him up to people."
Barkley is now so quiet and composed that an on-court flare-up between him and Ron Artest during a game against Connecticut in January was shocking. But in high school, Barkley displayed a fiery temperament, and he was ejected from a diocesan championship game for scuffling with an opponent.
"I was uncoachable," Barkley said. "I had a bad attitude. I didn't listen. At Christ the King, I would mumble something under my breath if things didn't go my way. I'd point my finger at somebody else. My temper was so quick."
That changed when Barkley got to Maine Central Institute in remote Pittsfield, a prep school powerhouse Barkley attended to improve his grades. He got the test score he needed, and with the change in scenery came a change in style. His coach, Max Good, told him that the innate New York suspiciousness and street-tough attitude would have to go.
"When Erick came to visit he said, 'Coach, let me use your car.' " Good said. "I tossed him the keys. I don't think he really wanted the car; he wanted my trust. His host parents said he hardly left the driveway. When I gave it to him it had an eighth of a tank of gas. When I got it back, it was full. I think he learned to trust people here."
As his personal life settled down, so, too, did his game. The temper faded and so did the flashy plays. Barkley had seen prodigies whose games were so full of juking and thread-the-needle passes that colleges spent two years changing their style. Why, he wondered, shouldn't he just develop a stripped-down game from the start?
"I never used to settle for the easy play," Barkley said. "At Maine, I was watching a lot of games. I really liked John Stockton's game a lot. One move, and he'd go right by them. Being flashy doesn't get you anywhere. Being a fundamental point guard gets you places."
St. John's is going places with him. Barkley's minimalism -- crisp passes and simple moves -- has enabled him to play four games this season with no turnovers, and seven games with just one. He has 74 steals. He is the point guard St. John's didn't have during the Felipe Lopez era. Last season, St. John's two point guards, Tarik Turner and Collin Charles, turned the ball over 113 times and made 169 assists. Barkley has 62 turnovers and 133 assists.
"He not only has the candy," Jarvis said, "he knows when to give it out."
Coach Jim Calhoun of Connecticut said: "He's allowed that team to have other guys do things. But he's the guy who gets them into spots where they need to be."
St. John's is where it needs to be, a likely third seed when the national tournament brackets are announced Sunday. Shirley Barkley is back in town for a while, too, to see her son finish his season. The latest handoff has been made. Barkley is taking St. John's to the top level.
"The first couple of games, I was nervous and I tried to make everybody feel I was perfect," Barkley said. "Once I got that out of my head, it's worked out. I guess I've got a game."

HEADLINE: January New Home Sales Slowed From Record Levels

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell more than expected in January as harsh winter weather stalled buying in the Midwest. Even so, January's pace of sales was the third strongest ever.
In a separate report, the Conference Board, based in New York, said today that its index of leading economic indicators rose five-tenths of a percent in January, the fourth consecutive monthly increase and a sign that the economy is moving into a ninth year of expansion with plenty of momentum. 
 New single-family home sales fell 5 percent in January, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 918,000 units, the Commerce Department said. While the sales fell short of analysts' forecasts of a 971,000 pace, the monthly total was surpassed only by those in December and November, when new houses sold at a record annual rate of one million.
Also, January was the 38th consecutive month that the new-home sales rate exceeded 700,000 units, the longest such string on record.
"A peaking housing market doesn't mean the economy is slowing," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., who expects sales to rebound in February. "The surge in sales will insure strong retail sales of household durables for many months to come."
A panel of forecasters from the National Association for Business Economics concurs. Almost 80 percent of the 248 economists surveyed said they thought the current expansion would become the longest on record in February 2000.
This year, the business group expects the economy to grow 3 percent, slower than the 3.9 percent of 1998 but faster than earlier forecasts of 2.1 percent late last year. The group also expects the Consumer Price Index to rise 2 percent in 1999 after rising 1.9 percent last year, and the unemployment rate to increase to an average 4.5 percent this year from the current 29-year low of 4.3 percent.
For all of last year, home sales totaled a record 887,000, compared with 804,000 in 1997. Last year's new- home sales beat the record of 819,000 set in 1977. A new-home sale is recorded when a buyer signs a contract or puts down a deposit to buy a dwelling.
The median price of new homes rose 3.8 percent in January, to a record $157,000 from $151,300 in December. The price increase probably was a reflection of the sales strength in the West, "where houses cost considerably more than in the Midwest and South," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
Higher interest rates are a potential negative for home sales, however. The average weekly 30-year mortgage rate in January was 6.79 percent, up from December's 6.72 percent, according to weekly statistics compiled by Freddie Mac. For the week ended Friday, the 30-year rate rose to 6.89 percent, the highest since mid-November.

HEADLINE: Major Auto Makers Report Record Sales

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 2

 BODY:
Most major auto makers, including the Ford Motor Company, DaimlerChrysler A.G. and American Honda, reported record sales for February.
"Since the end of the General Motors strike in August, the industry has had an incredible run of monthly records," said David Healy, an auto analyst for Burnham Securities in New York. "The reasons are the usual suspects. Car prices are reasonable, if not declining. Employment levels and consumer confidence are very high. Used-car prices are strong, making trade-ins worth more and causing people to buy new cars instead of used ones." 
 At Ford, sales of Ford, Mercury, Lincoln and Jaguar cars and trucks rose 8 percent, to 319,340 vehicles, from February 1998, surpassing the previous February sales record set in 1996.
DaimlerChrysler reported sales of Dodge, Jeep, Chrysler and Plymouth cars and trucks totaling 215,450 units, also up 8 percent over a year ago and beating the previous record set 1996. Mercedes-Benz posted slightly lower sales in February from a year ago.
Ford's sales rose on the strength of trucks, most notably the full-size Ford F-Series and compact Ranger pickup trucks as well as sport utility vehicles like the Ford Explorer and Expedition. Ford's total truck sales climbed 20 percent, to 193,779 vehicles. F-Series sales rose 27 percent, breaking the previous monthly sales record set in 1978; Ranger sales rose 46 percent for the best February since 1978. Combined sales of the Explorer and Expedition set new records, and the redesigned Ford Windstar and Mercury Villager minivans also posted increases.
Ford's car sales, however, dropped to 125,561 vehicles, down 6 percent from a year ago, because of lower sales to daily rental fleets, Ford said. Excluding fleet sales, retail car sales rose 12 percent, the company said. Sales of the redesigned Ford Mustang and Mercury Cougar were higher, but sales of Ford's high-volume Taurus fell. A redesigned Taurus will be displayed at the New York auto show in April and put on the market in the fall.
At DaimlerChrysler, truck sales rose 7 percent, to 145,436 vehicles, setting a new record for the sixth month in a row. Sales of sport utilities led by the Jeep Grand Cherokee and Dodge Durango and minivans, especially the Dodge Caravan, contributed to the increase. The automaker's car sales rose 9 percent, to 70,014 vehicles.
Honda also reported record February sales for its Honda and Acura brands. Its car and truck sales totaled 81,910 units, up 14 percent from a year ago. Honda's new Odyssey minivan and redesigned Acura TL entry-level luxury car had triple-digit gains.
Volkswagen reported its best February in 18 years; Audi had the best February since 1986. Volvo, Subaru and Kia also reported higher sales.
Auto makers said the continued upswing would likely carry through to spring, typically the strongest season of the year, with March sales already coming in strong.
"There is very little doubt that March sales will be higher than a year ago," said Robert Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service, in a statement. "After that, the mountain is going to get a little steeper because the sales rate in the second quarter of 1998 was very fast. Still, momentum is on the side of a strong U.S. economy and confident U.S. consumers."
Indeed, Mr. Healy of Burnham Securities said he was uneasy with the industry selling significantly above recent levels. When the rest of the auto companies, including the General Motors Corporation, report sales Wednesday, Mr. Healy said he expected the seasonally adjusted rate would be at a lofty 16.7 million for cars and light trucks.
"It seems too good to last, but I don't see anything to spoil it," he said. "Every month I raise my forecast, and I suppose I'll keep raising it."
Auto makers are also increasing their forecasts for this year's vehicle sales. DaimlerChrysler's early February forecast put car and total truck sales for 1999 at 15.6 million vehicles. "We've increased the forecast every month for the last three months, and I wouldn't be surprised if March gets off on a good foot and the forecast ticks up a little more," said Jamie Jameson, vice president for sales and marketing operations at DaimlerChrysler.

HEADLINE: Budget's Reliance On Social Security Is Under Scrutiny

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Republican leaders began today to explore publicly ways to end the longstanding practice of using Social Security money for other purposes -- but not necessarily right away.
Needing money to pay for tax cuts and additional spending, House and Senate leaders discussed allowing Congress to dip into Social Security funds for the next several years but then walling off the retirement system's money from the rest of the Federal budget. 
 The idea of weaning the Congress from reliance on Social Security's money has more support among House leaders than among their counterparts in the Senate, many of whom favor putting the retirement system's funds off-limits immediately, Republicans said.
Removing Social Security from the budget equation entirely, though, has repeatedly proved politically impossible. Backers of the gradual approach say theirs is the only realistic way of imposing a new fiscal discipline on Congress and the White House, while still giving Republicans the wiggle room they need to propose the tax cuts and spending increases that they hope will be the centerpiece of their electoral strategy in 2000.
Although the proposal's prospects remain unclear, Republican leaders say they will have to decide soon because the question of using Social Security will go a long way toward shaping their tax and spending plans.
The House plan for gradually taking Social Security out of the budget was detailed today in legislation introduced by Representatives Wally Herger, Republican of California, and David Minge, Democrat of Minnesota, who is among his party's most fiscally conservative members.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said the plan, though gradual, would be "a remarkable accomplishment, certainly far superior" to past efforts to keep Congress from mingling Social Security's money with general revenue.
But because it would leave their party exposed to attacks by Democrats that they are endangering Social Security, Republicans said they wanted to see how much bipartisan support the gradual approach might attract before making a decision on how to proceed. Democrats have rallied around President Clinton's proposal to address the same problem by reserving 62 percent of total budget surpluses over the next 15 years for Social Security.
The debate illustrated the difficulties Republicans are having reconciling their desire for new spending and tax cuts with their efforts to shore up Social Security and retain their claim to fiscal responsibility. And it brought to life the complex politics of the post-deficit world in Washington, where Democrats and Republicans each vow to be more austere than the other even as they confront the likelihood of huge and growing surpluses in the next decade.
Although the plan won support from a handful of moderate to conservative House Democrats, it drew criticism from others, including the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
"While the general theory of taking Social Security monies out of circulation is a worthy goal, to the extent we understand their bill it's not an approach we would support," said Laura Nichols, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gephardt.
For most of the last 30 years, the Federal Government ran deficits even after spending the revenue generated by Social Security along with general revenues. Under the accounting used by the Government, the Federal budget moved from deficit to surplus last year, and is projected to remain in surplus for years to come.
But last year's surplus of $70 billion was the result of a $99 billion surplus in Social Security more than offsetting a $29 billion deficit in the Government's operating budget. Projections suggest that the Government will run an operating deficit this year and next year, and then run operating surpluses.
President Clinton's proposed budget for next year leaves the entire surplus untouched, but only by proposing tax increases and using budget maneuvers that Republicans have already rejected.
If adopted, the gradual approach to taking Social Security out of the budget could make it easier in the short run for both parties to pay for new spending they have proposed for the military and education, among other programs, and could provide Republicans with additional flexibility in financing the big tax cut that they envision as the centerpiece of their legislative agenda.
In the long run, the idea would be to make the money generated by Social Security sacrosanct, thereby making it easier for the Government to pay all promised benefits in the coming decades as the population ages. But by allowing some of the money to be spent for the next few years, the gradual approach would put Congress in the position of explicitly endorsing its longstanding practice of papering over the country's remaining fiscal problems.
The more austere proposal favored by many Senate Republicans -- to wall off Social Security immediately and completely -- would insulate the party from Democratic attacks over spending Social Security's money, but would complicate the task of drafting a budget containing spending increases and tax cuts.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, is leading the effort to leave Social Security untouched. But Mr. Armey said after today's meeting that the differences were narrowing and that he expected a compromise soon.
Mr. Armey said even a phased-in approach to removing Social Security from the budget would preserve more of the retirement system's money than Mr. Clinton's plan. Mr. Herger and Mr. Minge said their bill would reserve $1.69 trillion for Social Security in the next decade, while the President's plan would reserve $1.59 trillion.
Walling off Social Security would reduce the national debt, which most economists say would make it easier for the Government to pay baby boomers their retirement benefits. But both parties agree that reducing the debt alone does not fully address Social Security's problems.
The House plan for gradually taking Social Security out of the budget would separate out from the Federal budget the money earmarked for Social Security, but do it over three years in a way that would leave $89 billion in play for tax cuts or spending over the next two years.
For the coming fiscal year, the plan would wall off all $80 billion of the excess Social Security payroll taxes, but leave $51 billion in interest payments from Social Security's reserves. In the next fiscal year, the plan would wall off all the excess payroll taxes and half the interest payments, leaving a projected $38 billion for Congress to play with.
In the third year, all money derived from Social Security, both payroll taxes and interest, would be taken off the Government's books for purposes of spending and tax cuts.
In a letter to Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Mr. Herger and Mr. Minge said they did not intend their bill to provide cover for "a final raid on the Social Security Trust Fund" for either tax cuts or spending increases.
But the practical effect of their plan would be precisely to allow the money left on the table to be used for tax cuts or spending increases. Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, has generally supported the approach as he seeks to put together a tax and spending blueprint for next year.

HEADLINE: Congress Hears Status of Year 2000 Solutions

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
American industry and the government are generally winning the race to fix year 2000 computer glitches by year's end, but the problem is likely to cause widespread civil unrest and economic disruption abroad, a Senate panel reported today.
With 304 days to go, most Federal agencies, utilities and big companies are solving computer flaws that could spew faulty data or worse, the panel said. But its 160-page report warned that the nation's health care industry "lags significantly" in redressing the problem, as do millions of small businesses, and scores of state and local governments. 
 More chilling are the findings abroad. Global communications, financial systems, air transportation, and oil supplies could be interrupted for days or weeks. Important allies like Japan, Mexico and Germany are nine months to two years behind schedule.
In a closed briefing at the Capitol, senators heard that computer failures in Russia could blind early-warning radar and lead to false alarms of nuclear attacks. Soviet-built nuclear reactors in Russia and Eastern Europe could shut down. And there is a chance that terrorists will try to exploit the chaos.
"In this country we will have a bump in the road but it will not be crippling," said Senator Robert F. Bennett, a Utah Republican who heads the Special Committee on the Year 2000 Computer Problem. At midday, he briefed his colleagues on national security risks.
"Internationally, we think the chances of difficulty are much higher," Mr. Bennett said.
The Senate, in its quest to resume a regular legislative agenda, took the unusual step of devoting its entire day to aspects of the year 2000 problem.
The Senate voted 99 to 0 this morning, to authorize the Government to guarantee loans to small businesses to fix computer problems.
This afternoon, the Senate voted 92 to 6 to extend the panel's work through February 2000, and approved its $800,000 budget.
Moreover, the House and Senate are considering bipartisan bills that would limit litigation, lawyers' fees and damage awards related to the problem. Lloyd's of London has projected that global legal costs could reach $1 trillion.
An unlikely coalition of insurers, high-technology companies, and large and small businesses support the legislation, which is opposed by consumer groups, trial lawyers and the Clinton Administration.
Republican leaders in Congress have put the bills on the fast track, making consideration by both houses likely in the coming weeks.
As 2000 approaches, experts around the world are concerned about computer crashes that might occur if software, written to recognize the year by the last two digits, mistakes 2000 for 1900.
The Senate panel and the Administration use the same analogy to describe the problem's domestic impact: a bad snowstorm that disrupts daily life for a few days at most.
Senator Gordon H. Smith, an Oregon Republican, said: Prepare but do not panic. Set aside some extra canned goods and bottled water, but do not stockpile.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is the committee's vice chairman, said, "We have tried to discount what I call the Y2K survivalist mentality."
Indeed, the Gartner Group, a research and consulting firm, has estimated that only 10 percent of any computer failures in the United States are expected to last more than three days. And the panel gave relatively high marks to the nation's utilities, telecommunications, financial and transportation areas.
But the report, the most comprehensive assessment of the year 2000 problem, singled out the nation's 6,000 hospitals, 50,000 nursing homes and 800,000 doctor offices for criticism. About 80 percent of doctors' offices and 50 percent of small- to medium-sized businesses have failed to take action, the report said.
The problem is more serious abroad, the senators said, because foreign governments either do not have the resources, the political will or the interest to deal with the problem, which could hamper everything from credit-card transactions to utilities.
Many nations are looking to the United States for help. Today, John A. Koskinen, President Clinton's year 2000 czar, was in the Philippines to discuss ways to avert breakdowns with 30 Asian-Pacific countries.
The Pentagon sent a delegation to Moscow last month to meet with Russian technical experts and lay the groundwork for a plan to have Russian specialists sit with their American counterparts this New Year's Eve in a joint missile-warning center in Colorado.

HEADLINE: In New Hampshire, Buchanan Rides Again

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., March 2

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan, who in two previous Presidential forays fashioned himself the icon of the disaffected worker and the iconoclast of the Republican Party, is back for a third run.
"Mount up and ride to the sound of the guns," Mr. Buchanan ordered his loyalists today in announcing his latest bid for the Presidency and offering up his familiar platform: for restoring America's "lost sovereignty," for trade protection, for a moratorium on immigration and for "the rights of the innocent unborn." 
 Added to his populist stew was a repudiation of President Clinton, who, he said, has desecrated the White House by using it "to shake down corporate executives, to lie with abandon to the American people," and by turning it into "a place to exploit women." It is time, he said, "to call down the curtain on the sorry soap opera in the White House."
Mr. Buchanan's candidacy, which became abruptly evident when he took a leave from his role as co-host of the CNN television program "Crossfire" just a week ago, is widely perceived as more of a vanity run or even a mischief run than a serious campaign for the White House. Friends say he was bored with his television job, and even fervent supporters say he has little chance of becoming President.
But there is no denying the passion in his crusade against those he calls the elite global economists. And analysts say Mr. Buchanan, who won the 1996 New Hampshire primary, has the ability to shake up a Republican field crowded with lower-wattage conservatives who have been unable to distinguish themselves from one another.
"He will have a dramatic impact on the second- and third-tier candidates who are trying to carve out a niche on the right," said David Carney, a venerable New Hampshire Republican strategist who is not affiliated with any Presidential campaign. "He may peter out, but between now and Labor Day he will be the 800-pound gorilla in that half of the party and will drive these other guys crazy trying to figure out how to deal with him."
Greg Mueller, his communications chief in 1992 and 1996, said Mr. Buchanan seemed driven by a preoccupation with economic dislocation and believed it was an issue that no other candidate in either party was addressing.
"That's a cause and a mission that he's taken upon himself," Mr. Mueller said. "He believes that the Republican Party must identify with those working-class issues to rebuild the Reagan coalition to take back the White House."
Still, the populist pitch to the downtrodden worker may have less resonance in an economy that has now been expanding for eight years, and it is unclear whether the 60-year-old Mr. Buchanan can recapture the romanticism and the early momentum of his previous campaigns.
The candidate made today's announcement here in the state where he achieved his greatest electoral vindication: his 1996 triumph over Bob Dole, the party's eventual nominee, following a drive in which Mr. Buchanan conjured up the image of peasants "coming over the hills" with pitchforks and overthrowing the establishment.
New Hampshire's rough-hewn individualists have always been good to Mr. Buchanan, giving him 37 percent of the primary vote in 1992. George Bush won New Hampshire that year, but Mr. Buchanan's strong showing was a searing indictment of the incumbent President, who went on to lose to Mr. Clinton.
But the event today lacked the kind of full-dress, media-savvy theatrics that Buchanan watchers have come to expect. The usually spontaneous candidate, well practiced on his feet, read his speech to about 200 people at a sterile, low-ceiling conference center here. There was no music, no warm-up act, no grand entrance, no sense that something historic or even new was happening. Only one man came with a pitchfork, a smoothly carved work of art that was actually crafted in Germany, an unintended illustration of Mr. Buchanan's message that foreign-made goods are flooding the American market.
Except for his wife, Shelley, Mr. Buchanan has no entourage, no spokesmen, no consultants, no advance team. In part, that is the nature of his latest insurgent candidacy. But it also reflects the fact that his 1996 aides are working for other candidates this year. Mr. Mueller, for example, plans to sign up with Steve Forbes. Perhaps the biggest absence is that of Bay Buchanan, Mr. Buchanan's sister, who served as the central strategist in his previous campaigns. This year she plans to keep her job as a commentator at MSNBC.
Mr. Buchanan plays down the need for such aides.
"We find the big entourages cost you an awful lot of money," and "then you run out of money," he said in a brief interview as he stepped off a commercial flight at the airport here. "You don't need all this in the early days. These consultants, I used to know them when they were all kids. They weren't that bright then!"
At his announcement speech here, he was preaching to the converted. The single pitchfork-toting supporter, Craig Henne, a lumber salesman from Eliott, Me., said that when he heard that Mr. Buchanan was running again, he "dusted off" his old Buchanan bumper stickers from the last time around.
Mr. Henne said that even if Mr. Buchanan's campaign "amounts to nothing," he wanted to show his support for a man who says what he thinks and believes what he says.
At a rally with 1,300 people on Monday in the gritty steel town of Weirton, W.Va., Mr. Buchanan demonstrated something important: that he could conceivably win over support from those who had not voted for him before. Weirton is a heavily Democratic town where the steel mill, stricken by the "dumping" of cheap foreign imports, has become a cause celebre of Mr. Buchanan.
"He's the one well-known person who is taking an interest in what is happening to us," said Janet Stagani, a 55-year-old Democrat who works as a bookkeeper for the steelworkers' union. "If he's willing to take a stand regardless of the outcome, then I can support him regardless of the outcome. I'll see what my choices are down the road. But right now I want to give him a vote of confidence."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Arkansas Roots, New York Panache;
Clintons Seem Suited to Local Political and Social Scenes

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
They cause traffic jams of epic proportions. They hold so many Manhattan fund-raisers that even their Democratic allies complain. They have endorsed policies that have infuriated labor unions, hospital officials, advocates for the poor, immigrants and, oh yes, Republicans.
So why is it that Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton seem so popular in New York? 
 That is a question many New Yorkers may be asking themselves these days as they watch Mrs. Clinton's very public exploration of whether to run for the United States Senate from New York next year.
They may also be pondering the question as they sit in midtown traffic waiting for Mrs. Clinton's motorcade to pass today and tomorrow. The First Lady is in town to deliver speeches before the Women's Leadership Forum and the United Nations, meet with local Democratic supporters and tour public schools in Queens and Manhattan.
In many ways, the idea that New Yorkers would embrace a former governor of Arkansas and his Illinois-born wife still seems a bit improbable. Neither has lived or worked in New York, and except for occasional excursions to Manhattan or the Hamptons, they have not even vacationed here much. Most of their visits have been to campaign or to raise money. And they have feuded with a host of local officials, including the Democratic senior Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who is retiring next year.
Yet their connection to New York is strong for a range of reasons, including their deep base of support among major Democratic voting groups, the large number of New Yorkers in their inner circle, distrust of their conservative opponents and the sense among some people that they radiate New York-style panache and sophistication.
A consensus of New York pollsters say both Clintons' ratings tend to be several points higher in New York State than nationwide. Mr. Clinton's job approval ratings in New York have been hovering in the 60 percent range for more than a year now. And recent polls show Mrs. Clinton scoring between 60 and 70 percent favorable ratings statewide.
Voters seem to respect her even in traditionally Republican strongholds in the suburbs and upstate.
"New Yorkers like the Clintons," said John Zogby, a pollster from Utica. "Period."
The clearest reason is that New York is a Democratic state -- registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by a ratio of 3 to 2 -- and the Clintons, despite their many scandals, have been the most successful national Democratic politicians in a generation.
But it is more than that, political analysts assert. New York, they say, has higher concentrations of the voting groups that are the Clintons' most ardent supporters nationwide: professional women, homosexuals, Jews and black and Hispanic residents. "These are groups that are important to the Democratic Party nationally," said Philip Friedman, a Democratic public relations consultant in New York. "But they are absolutely central to the New York State Democratic Party."
Not all of those groups were big fans of the Clintons during the early years of the Administration. But through politics and policies, the Clintons have won them over. Many Irish-Americans, a major New York voting bloc that is no longer reliably Democratic, like Mr. Clinton for his role in helping to broker peace in Northern Ireland. Jewish-Americans have come to view the Administration as a stalwart defender of Israel.
And a preponderance of blacks view Mr. Clinton as not only sympathetic to their concerns about racism, but also extraordinarily in tune with their culture, black politicians and intellectuals say.
"Bill Clinton is functionally an African-American politician," said Manning Marable, director of African-American Studies at Columbia University, noting that the President gets higher approval ratings among blacks than many black officials.
But will the Administration, and Mr. Clinton's, high job ratings, rub off on Mrs. Clinton if she runs for the Senate? Mr. Marable says yes. "There is a general perception that she is to his left," he said. "And that is just fine. Because ideologically, black politics is social democratic. There is a deep belief in state intervention to redress social problems."
The same may not be true with other groups. Mrs. Clinton may be less trusted by Jews because of her open support for a Palestinian state. Wall Street barons who like the Administration's economic policies may be uncomfortable with Mrs. Clinton's more expansive view of government. Centrist Democrats and Republicans may view her as too liberal on crime or social issues.
"She is identified ideologically with the left," said Mitchell Moss, the director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "That helps her in New York City, and it mobilizes her core constituency. But New York State has not been electing liberals for a long time."
Republicans and some pollsters also say that the moment Mrs. Clinton becomes a candidate, her poll numbers will drop as she is pressured to explain her positions in detail and demonstrate her understanding of New York, a place where she has never lived. State law requires only that she be a resident as of Election Day next year to seek the Senate seat.
"She might have trouble showing she knows the differences between Detroit and Schenectady," said Adam Goodman, a Republican media consultant who worked on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's 1997 re-election campaign. Mr. Giuliani is also considering running for the Senate next year.
Politics aside, the Clintons clearly have a social affinity for the city, one that many New Yorkers relish. There was the whirlwind birthday party for their daughter, Chelsea, a couple of years ago, complete with stops at performances on Broadway.
And the visits to the Hamptons, featuring the omnipresent shoulder-rubbing with society and Hollywood types. After all, even places as chic as the Hamptons and as sophisticate-minded as Manhattan like the validation conferred by a visit from the First Family.
What amazes some analysts is the fact that the Clintons have received such loyal support from core Democratic groups despite having taken positions that have angered those groups on numerous issues.
Many blacks objected vehemently to the 1994 crime bill that expanded the Federal death penalty and established mandatory sentences for many crimes. Black and immigrant politicians in New York were also furious with the President for signing the sweeping welfare bill in 1996 that sharply curtailed benefits.
New York hospital officials perennially fight proposed Administration cuts in health care spending. Most labor unions hated the North American Free Trade Act, which the President championed. Gay-rights advocates were deeply disappointed in 1996 when he signed legislation allowing states to outlaw same-sex marriages.
But what has helped the Clintons overcome anger with their positions on certain issues has been an even greater antipathy among New Yorkers toward the First Couple's opponents, many political analysts say.
"The Republican revolution of '94 and '95 really just scared the hell out of New Yorkers, including moderate Republicans," Mr. Zogby said.
Mr. Marable said, "Even though African-Americans have had many criticisms of this Administration, from the crime bill to the welfare bill, on balance, in the era of the Contract With America, in the era of the Christian Coalition, in the period of attacks on affirmative action, Clinton looks almost like a positive good rather than a necessary evil."
The Clintons' enemies may have helped them on another issue: impeachment, which appears to have solidified Mr. Clinton's support in New York and raised Mrs. Clinton's favorable ratings, analysts say. The First Lady has long been popular among professional women. But her stoic, steadfast defense of her husband last year won her additional support among more traditional, conservative women, pollsters say.
"I think the year softened her image," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. "People can, in different ways, identify with the trauma she's gone through."
Judith Hope, chairwoman of the New York State Democratic Party, said Mrs. Clinton should therefore benefit in a race against Mr. Giuliani.
"I think New Yorkers see her as the personification of the new woman in transition," Ms. Hope said. "That she has juggled a child, a job and a loss of personal privacy with such style and grace really inspires women."
But while many people like Mrs. Clinton for standing by the President, a smaller but still substantial number of people seem to dislike her for exactly the same reason.
The Marist poll picked up on that paradox in the answers it received from respondents to the question: Why do you like Hillary Clinton more, or less, than you did two years ago? Many who said they liked her more used words like strong, dignified and poised to describe Mrs. Clinton's handling of the Monica Lewinsky scandal. But many who said they liked her less described her as weak, opportunistic or dishonest for sticking by her husband.
Some analysts say Mrs. Clinton may benefit from the competition between New York City, a place she professes to love, and Washington, a town she seems to despise. Many New York politicians assert that their hometown is more sophisticated than the nation's capital, more drawn to independent women, less upset by sexual scandals.
For that reason, Manhattan might be the ideal place for both Clintons to settle after he leaves office, whether she runs for the Senate or not.
"New Yorkers love people who live near the margins," said Mr. Moss, the N.Y.U. political scientist. "The very qualities that make people like Billy Martin or Joe Namath helps explain why they like the Clintons. New Yorkers like risk takers."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
State's Jobless Rate Is Lowest Since 1989

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The state's revised unemployment rate for 1998 was 4.6 percent, the lowest it has been since 1989, and well below the 1997 rate of 5.1 percent, officials said yesterday.
The revised rate, which takes into account data such as employers' wage reports, was two-tenths of a point below the preliminary annual figure of 4.8 percent released in January, said Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the State Labor Department. The national unemployment rate for 1998 was 4.5 percent. In terms of employment growth, New Jersey had a net gain of 66,000 jobs in 1998 from the year before, Mr. Smith said. 
 The state's January unemployment figure remained at 4.4 percent, the same as December's and the lowest monthly rate since 1990, Mr. Smith said. The national unemployment rate for the month was also lower than the state's, at 4.3 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
All Three MajorIndicators Turn Down in Late Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower yesterday, led by Intel and 3Com on concern that waning demand and increased competition will hurt profits in the computer and networking industries.
"People got overly optimistic about personal computer sales in the first quarter," said Bruce Simon, chief investment officer of the Glenmede Trust Company, which oversees $15 billion in Philadelphia. Recent warnings about slower growth at Compaq Computer and Dell Computer "caused people to ratchet down their expectations to a more reasonable level," he said. 
 The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 36.15 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2,259.03. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 27.17 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 9,297.61. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 10.66 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 1,225.50. 3Com slid the most on the index. All three market measures surrendered gains in late trading. Declining stocks outnumbered advancers on the New York Stock Exchange 15 to 14.
Intel, the most active issue, fell 7 1/4, to 109 13/16, bringing its losses in the last five trading days to 18 percent. Jonathan Joseph, an analyst at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, downgraded the world's largest computer-chip maker to "hold" from "buy," citing weak processor demand, sluggish earnings growth, a slow transition to the Pentium III chip and order cancellations. Yesterday, a Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette analyst also downgraded Intel.
Other semiconductor makers fell. Texas Instruments fell 5 3/4, to 86 1/2, and Micron Technology dropped 3 1/4, to 54 1/4.
3Com was halted after it fell 3 11/16, or 12 percent, to 27, on concern that the No. 2 networking company's fiscal third-quarter profit may lag behind forecasts because of price cuts and steeper competition.
Hewlett-Packard rose 2 3/4, to 68 5/8, after the company said it would separate its computer and printing business from its medical devices and electronic testing equipment. It will also replace its chief executive, Lewis Platt, when the transformation is completed by mid-2000.
Shares of airlines and consumer-products makers gained on optimism a strong economy will lift profits. Airline stocks rose after Glenn Engel, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, raised the industry group to "moderate outperform" from "market weight."
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, rose 3 9/16, to 65 9/16. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 1 3/4, to 57 7/8. Delta Air Lines gained 2 11/16, to 65 5/8, and Southwest Airlines climbed 1 1/4, to 31 3/8.
A report on Monday that personal income and spending rose more than expected in January added to confidence that consumers are continuing to spend freely.
Whirlpool climbed 2 3/4, to 43 3/4, after the world's top maker of large appliances said it expected double-digit increases in earnings for the first quarter and full year. The company also said it would buy back as much as $250 million in stock.
Xylan jumped 8 13/16, to 35 3/4, after Alcatel of France agreed to buy it for $2 billion. Alcatel, Europe's No. 2 phone-equipment maker, already owns 6 percent of the maker of networking equipment and is buying the rest to bolster its business of linking computers to phone networks and the Internet. The $37-a-share offer is a 37 percent premium to the close on Monday.
Auto stocks declined even as February car and truck sales exceeded estimates for a third straight month, amid concern that the Federal Reserve could raise interest rates if consumers keep buying at this pace.
"These are blowout numbers," said David Garrity, an analyst with GVA Research L.L.C. "Assuming General Motors comes in at or slightly below expectations, this will be an annual rate of 16.8 million units. Sales this strong could tempt the Federal Reserve to take action."
Ford Motor fell 1 1/4, to 57 1/8, and General Motors lost 7/16, to 82 11/16.

An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Wednesday, about the stock market, referred incorrectly to an earnings forecast that preceded a 6.7 percent rise in Whirlpool Corporation shares. HEADLINE: GAME THEORY;
Cheating Death Has Never Been Easier

BYLINE: By J. C. Herz; E-mail address: Herz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
CHEATING is big business in video games. To Interact, the company that manufactures Game Shark "enhancement devices," it's worth $40 million a year.
Interact is the fifth-largest video game company in America. It makes no free-standing hardware. It doesn't publish a single software title. It has, however, sold two million pieces of plastic and silicon that plug into the back of a Sony Playstation or the cartridge slot of a Nintendo 64 to give the player invincibility, extra weapons, superpowers and access to hidden areas and bonus levels. If you want to fight the boss on the 17th level (and brag about it in the schoolyard), you don't have to invest 30 hours to master the game. Just plug in a Game Shark, which contains hundreds of cheat codes for all the hottest games in one package. 
 From a technological standpoint, cheat codes are nothing new. The factory that manufactures Game Sharks, in Manchester, England, was cranking out similar devices for the Commodore Amiga in 1979. A device called the Game Genie turbocharged thousands of eight-bit Nintendo consoles in the 1980's.
Game Shark's cheat codes function on the same principle as its predecessors. But it can do what early devices could not because the world of consumer electronics has changed radically.
The biggest difference can be summed up in two words: cheap memory. As any PC owner knows, the price of computer memory has taken a nose dive since the 1980's. Back then, it was much too expensive to put memory chips in a game peripheral, so there was no room to store codes. If you wanted to use a cheat code on your Nintendo machine with a Game Genie, you had to enter it manually every time you played, and the device could handle only one code at a time.
The Game Shark comes with hundreds of codes and a user-friendly software interface because four-megabyte memory chips cost $8. Cheap memory is what made beepers and cellular phones and Tamagotchis economically viable, and it makes the Game Shark a more robust and profitable device.
Cheap memory also makes stored information a more important part of the experience. People buy a Game Shark for the cheat codes stored on it, not for the raw device. Essentially, Interact is an information vendor. So the information has to be current. "Previous manufacturers of cheat devices treated them like toys," said Todd Hays, Interact's chief executive. "They made them as cheaply as possible, in one big batch, and shipped them all at Christmas.
"We decided that just wasn't going to work -- you've got to be able to promote these things year-round. So we invested in a help line, an 800 number for codes, a 900 number for really advanced codes. We invented Web site support. And we always ship very fresh product -- we treat it like a loaf of bread. If there's a hot new game coming out tomorrow, the Game Sharks we're shipping today will have a whole new fresh stash of codes."
Generating those codes involves a squad of full-time hackers who crank video games through high-powered computers and software algorithms. "On a television," Mr. Hayes said, "all you can see is the result of the programming. What we see is a million lines of actual code, and we have seasoned hackers that go through and look for aberrations.
"Our hacking stations are hooked up to a logic analyzer, and we've written software for it -- find all locations in the game where life equals zero. Boom, at the end of the game, and here and here and here -- these are all the places where you might die. Then you go and look at the code, and you might find a way you can avoid that place.
"We find all sorts of things. We even find things that the software company never meant for you to see, places you can't get to from normal game play. Sometimes developers put things in there, like the Tiger Woods game that Electronic Arts published -- there were some lines of code buried in there that produced a pretty offensive scene from 'South Park.' Electronic Arts found out about it and recalled the product.
"It's rare for something like that to get past quality control, but it happens -- a lot of these programmers are so creative and so artistic, and they're cooped up in these little rooms, and it's a challenge for them to get something past their boss. It's an anti-Establishment, rebel thing to do -- let's see if the bug police can find it."
In that sense, the hardware hackers at Interact are the ultimate gamers, uncovering everything that is meant to be found, as well as a few things that are meant to stay buried. Software, by its very nature, is a palimpsest -- there are always layers that no one is supposed to see. A piece of hardware loaded with cheat codes is a lens that reveals those layers.
The larger question is whether the use of this device qualifies as cheating. What a Game Shark allows you to do is have more extensive access, at your discretion, to the software you already own. In game play, that is called cheating. But if you buy a book and skip to page 200, or rent a movie and fast forward to your favorite scene, does that count as cheating? If you're doing scientific research and discover a technique that yields vast quantities of high-quality information at blinding speed, does that qualify as cheating?
If the object is to gain knowledge of a system, which is the ultimate object of any computer game, then what separates cheating from learning? And if using a Game Shark isn't cheating, then what is?
"I don't know," Mr. Hayes said. "That's a good question. I suppose if you changed the game code itself. Like, there's another company that makes devices, and their claim to fame most recently was a nude Lara Croft code for Tomb Raider. We went in and investigated this, and it turned out that there was no nude Lara Croft in the game, that what they'd actually done was take skin tone from other parts of the game and paste it over her bathing suit so that she looked nude. But she was never actually nude. And they are currently being sued by Eidos, the publisher, for intellectual property infringement. If something's buried in the game, I'll unbury it. But I'm not going to make something up or interfere with the integrity of the code."
In a medium subject to infinite manipulation, outright fabrication is still a no-no. Cheating may be ill defined, but it's fairly easy to spot an outright lie. Look for the topless virtual celebrity, then check for neck seams.
Game Shark, by Interact; for Sony Playstation and Nintendo 64, $49.99; for Game Boy, $29.99.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
France Playing Catch-Up In the Arts?

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Delacroix, Cezanne, Manet, Monet, Matisse . . . and, and? While people around the world are lining up to see French masters, not to mention expatriates like van Gogh and Picasso who spent most of their careers in France, the country's contemporary artists are not exactly carrying on the tradition.
Germany can boast of international art stars like Gerhard Richter, Anselm Kiefer and Sigmar Polke. Britain can take pride in Lucian Freud and young Brit Pack artists like Damien Hirst and Rachel Whiteread. And the United States has Jasper Johns, Richard Serra, Bruce Nauman, Elizabeth Murray, Cindy Sherman and many more. 
 But France? "We have Arman, but he is of a different generation," said Pierre Buhler, the French cultural counselor in New York. "And Christian Boltanski. Annette Messager and Sophie Calle have had some success here. You know Kiefer is now working in France. But we will not appropriate him."
The situation is galling to a nation ever eager to proclaim its cultural superiority.
The French Government, in inimitable dirigiste fashion, is now trying to intervene. If all goes as planned next fall, dozens of galleries, contemporary art centers, museums and art schools on the West Coast will participate in "Cote Ouest: A Season of French Contemporary Art." The promotional material for the event, which was planned by the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, says it is "the biggest initiative to date to promote foreign art in the United States."
To pull it off, France had to dangle a few enticements. Through itsembassy in the United States and the Association Francaise d'Action Artistique, a Government-financed agency, it paid for American museum and gallery curators to visit France to view the available art. It offered subsidies to art centers that agreed to show work in the United States. It promised to bring French artists to the United States as well for workshops and lectures.
Etant Donnes, a French-American Fund for Contemporary Art, volunteered to help museums find American corporate and foundation sponsors for exhibitions. The principal benefactors of Etant Donnes, aside from the Florence Gould Foundation in New York, are all French: Air France, Banque Nationale de Paris and the Government.
When everything is added up, Government and private support for "Cote Ouest" may exceed $1 million. Which is not extraordinary. In 1998 French Government agencies spent about $500,000 promoting their contemporary artists in the United States even though nothing big like "Cote Ouest" was on the agenda.
Other countries, including Britain, promote their artists too. But Mr. Buhler said that "no other country has such a comprehensive approach. Other countries do one thing and then wait 10 years to do something else. Ours is ongoing."
French artists lag nonetheless, the magazine L'Express observed last fall in an article about New York's rule over the art world. Michael Kimmelman, the chief art critic of The New York Times, was among the experts interviewed by the magazine. "For the visual arts, France is now considered to be the rear guard among the great European nations," he said. Though it was the center of the art world until World War II, he added, "France pretty much dropped off the map" by the 1960's and 70's.
Mr. Buhler brushed off such talk. "It's possible that our artists are not known enough and were not marketed or did not market themselves enough," he said.
Some Americans agree. Shoshana Wayne, who owns a gallery in Santa Monica, Calif., and who intends to participate in "Cote Ouest," cited the publicity coups by France's rivals. "There is very good work being done in France right now," she said, "but the galleries, the museums, the collectors and the Government are not creating a scene the way they do in London."
But many more experts say the reasons for France's decline in artistic standing run deeper. Some cite a dearth of French collectors of contemporary art and France's failure over the years to generate the wealth that begets new collectors (in contrast to the stronger economies and healthy collecting ranks in Britain and Germany). Others say that French artists suffer because they shun the commercial system that creates "hot" art stars. It is also possible that French art is simply in a fallow period.
 
Blaming The Bureaucracy
Other experts say that France's arts bureaucracy, which gives generous grants and even helps artists find studios, has stifled rather than fostered creativity. "We have the impression of an institutionalized system, where creativity is sustained by the state," Mr. Kimmelman told L'Express. "And this induces a certain complacency."
Possibly at the risk of reinforcing such impressions, then, France is organizing "Cote Ouest." "We in the embassy and in the A.F.A.A. decided to go as big as we could," Mr. Buhler said. They invited West Coast curators and dealers to Paris to visit museums, galleries and artists and subsidized the trips. "About 10 went, possibly more," Mr. Buhler said. Thomas Collins, an associate curator at the Henry Art Gallery of the University of Washington, for example, spent a week and a half in France last fall, visiting about 18 studios, about 10 art centers and several galleries.
Then, Mr. Buhler said: "The whole thing snowballed, and now we have such demand. It's unprecedented to have an exhibition stretch over so many miles." Come October, he hopes, 12 museums, 5 universities, 9 alternative spaces, 3 public art projects, 19 galleries and an art fair will take part in "Cote Ouest."
The list of participating institutions is, however, a work in progress, and there appears to be a little hype as well as hope in the project.
The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, for example, is on the list and did send a curator to Paris to research French artists, courtesy of the event's French sponsors. But the museum will not take part. Kathleen S. Bartels, the museum's associate director, said that the research was not complete and added that a fall show "didn't fit in our schedule."
Officials at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art said that its schedule for October through January was also fully booked by the time the French approached them, although the museum is cited in the organizers' news release as a definite participant.
Robert A. Sobieszek, the photography curator at the museum, explained the discrepancy. In a history of photographic portraiture that he has been working on for 30 years, he is including French items, from 1830's daguerreotypes to current work of Orlan, a woman who alters her appearance through numerous plastic surgery operations and then photographs herself. "I already had some French stuff in it, but I haven't changed the show," he said.
Not that there was no temptation: "If I did a whole project," Mr. Sobieszek said, "they offered me up to $20,000, and they said they would bring the artist out."
 
Criterion of Success Is Hard to Define
The Portland Art Museum in Oregon cannot join in either. "I'm disappointed that we can't participate," said Kathryn Kanjo, the contemporary art curator. "But because we are expanding, our exhibition space is sorely limited. We knew all along that if we did participate, it would have to be in an extragallery way, outside museum walls."
But there are a number of participants. Mr. Collins, curator of the Henry Art Gallery, said that the gallery would show works by Gilles Barbier. In San Francisco, the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts plans to exhibit sketches and sculptures by Jean-Michel Othoniel, and Camera Work will show photos by Stephane Couturier. Several commercial galleries are planning exhibits.
Ms. Wayne, the gallery owner in Santa Monica, said: "I thought this was a great opportunity. I can't talk about the money, but that's not the reason I'd do it."
At this point it is hard to determine whether "Cote Ouest" will succeed or what criteria should applyin judging it. "From a P.R. standpoint, it couldn't fail to gain attention," Mr. Collins said. "And I'm looking forward to seeing a lot of these exhibits." He thinks he will show more French artists in the future now that he is familiar with their work.
Still, other art experts doubt that "Cote Ouest" will change attitudes toward French art. "Given the efficiency of communications today, works of art of interest and quality float to the surface of public perception pretty quickly, internationally and nationally," said Lucy Mitchell-Innes, a dealer and the former head of Sotheby's contemporary art department in New York.
"A good artist gets shows in New York with ease today, and Paris is not some forgotten, out of the way place," she said. "One really has to look at what's being made there."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Retreat AFifth Time In Seven Days

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The price of United States bonds fell yesterday for the fifth time in seven days as the General Motors Corporation reported stronger-than-expected February car sales, the latest sign that the economy is booming.
The price on the benchmark 30-year bond dropped 1 4/32 , to 93 23/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose 8 basis points, to 5.69 percent, from 5.61 percent on Tuesday. The yield has risen more than one-half of a percentage point so far this year as reports on jobs, manufacturing and consumer confidence have shown a robust economy.
Investors fret that too much growth will lead to faster inflation and will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later in the year, have driven down the price.
"The worst is not over," said Eric Cheung of the Wilmington Trust Corporation in Wilmington, Del. "There's no question about it -- it all comes back to the economy."
Yields on two-year notes, the most actively traded Treasuries, rose 4 basis points, to 5.17 percent.
Corporate bond sales also drew demand away from Treasuries, traders said. Fannie Mae, the largest provider of United States home mortgage financing, sold $3 billion of three-year notes.
And this trend could continue. The AT&T Corporation is expected to sell several billion dollars of debt in coming days. Lucent Technologies Inc., Pepsi-Cola Bottling Group and the Charter Communications Corporation are all planning sales of $1 billion or more in the weeks ahead.
Bonds fell yesterday as G.M. said that United States sales of North American-built cars and light trucks rose 18 percent, to 382,261 in February, beating estimates of a 6.4 percent increase. "That was important, and bonds fell right after the release," said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed income at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company in New York.
With 19 of 24 auto makers reporting through yesterday, February sales were 11 percent ahead of the comparable month a year earlier.
Bonds also fell as the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of nonmanufacturing business activity rose for the second consecutive month to 57 in February from 54 in January. The report measures activity at service providers, farms and other companies.
The report is a sign that first-quarter economic growth "is closer to 3.8 percent rather than 3 percent," said Christopher Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York.
That kind of growth may lead the Fed to raise interest rates later in the year. Market indicators, such as futures on eurodollars, or dollars held by banks outside the United States, reflect trader expectations for an increase.
The approach of tomorrow's jobs report also has investors concerned about the economy's strength.
The report will probably show that the economy added about 243,000 nonfarm jobs last month, according to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. The unemployment rate is expected to hold at 4.3 percent, the lowest in nearly three decades.
"The market is going to be on the defensive" before the release, said Rob McCool, a trader at First Chicago Capital Markets Inc.
To be sure, low inflation makes bonds attractive to some. Inflation in 1998 ran at its slowest pace in 12 years.

HEADLINE: New York's Job Growth in '98 Was Best Since '84, State Says

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Companies in New York State added jobs in 1998 at the fastest pace since 1984, and the number of jobs in the private sector continued to grow in January, the State Department of Labor announced yesterday.
Private sector jobs grew by 2.3 percent last year, to 6.8 million, and 1,000 more jobs were added in January, according to the Labor Department's newly revised figures. The figures are adjusted for seasonal factors; without such adjustments, the number of jobs would have fallen in January, as they do every year after the holiday season. 
 Unemployment in the state fell to 5.2 percent in January from 5.4 percent in December, mostly because the jobless rate in New York City fell to 7.6 percent from 8 percent, adjusted for seasonal factors. In the rest of the state, unemployment remained flat at 3.8 percent, compared with a national average of 4.3 percent.
The Pataki administration used yesterday's news to argue that the upstate economy was pulling out of the long slump that began in the early 1990's. Growth upstate has lagged growth in New York City, where a booming securities market has helped spark an economic surge.
"While the rate of growth downstate has been higher, the number of jobs upstate is now at a record high," said Stephen Kagann, chief economist to Gov. George E. Pataki.
Jobs in manufacturing continued to fall in the year ended January, but the declines were relatively minimal in industries that make things like industrial equipment and other so-called durable goods. The biggest drops in manufacturing were in businesses that are concentrated downstate, like the printing and garment industries, which lost 6,900 jobs.
Service industries continued to boom, adding more than 100,000 jobs. Growth was especially strong in motion pictures, business services and engineering, according to the Labor Department figures. Jobs in retailing and construction also jumped in the last year.
Binghamton tied with New York City as the metropolitan area with the fastest job growth in the 12 months ending in January, according to state figures. In both places, the number of jobs grew by 2.4 percent. For the entire state, the number of jobs grew by 1.9 percent.
New York now ranks about 20th among the states in terms of job growth, Mr. Kagann said. In 1992 and 1993, the state hovered in last place among the states, because it was still losing jobs while other states were growing, he said.
Despite the fast growth of jobs in the city, the unemployment rate in the five boroughs remains high. The jobless rate in the Bronx is 9.7 percent; in Brooklyn, 9.6 percent; in Queens, 7.1 percent; in Manhattan, 6.9 percent, and in Staten Island, 7.1 percent.
The highest unemployment in the state is in Hamilton County in the Adirondacks, where the jobless rate was 15.2 percent in January.

HEADLINE: Iran's Impulse for Change

 BODY:
The power of democracy is altering Iran. Unofficial results from municipal elections show that Iranians overwhelmingly supported moderate politicians associated with President Mohammad Khatami. The voting mirrored the presidential election that swept Mr. Khatami to power two years ago. Though conservative clerics remain the paramount rulers of Iran, Iranians are clearly impatient to lift religious repression and transform their country.
Iran's Constitution, adopted after Ayatollah Khomeini's 1979 Islamic revolution, provides for local elections, but none were held for two decades. Mr. Khatami called last Friday's vote hoping to create a more decentralized civil society that could support his agenda of political and social change. His gamble apparently paid off. The winners included liberal clerics like Abdollah Nouri, a Khatami ally who was forced out of the national Cabinet last year by clerical conservatives and who has now been elected to the Teheran city council. The high turnout that carried many moderate candidates to victory may now embolden Mr. Khatami to take further conciliatory steps toward America. 
 Washington would benefit greatly from the development of a more moderate and internationally responsible Iran, and should do what it can to encourage change. While continuing to support exchanges by sports teams and cultural groups, the Clinton Administration should begin to ease trade restrictions against Iran in ways that would have the most impact on ordinary Iranians.
The White House rightly insists that normal relations cannot be completely restored until Iran stops trying to build nuclear and other unconventional weapons, severs its links with terrorism and accepts peacemaking efforts between Israeli and Arab leaders. Iran has distanced itself from terror and now concedes the Palestinians' right to make peace with Israel. If further steps can be taken, the Mideast will be a safer place and Iran may resume its traditional role as a regional counterweight to Iraq.
Specifically, the White House should approve a request by an American trading company, pending since last year, to sell three million tons of grain and 400,000 tons of sugar requested by the Iranian Government. President Clinton also ought to ease restrictions on American imports of Iranian carpets, leaving in place only measures to discourage the exploitation of child labor. Neither step requires Congressional action. American food sales would make it easier for the Khatami Government to subsidize the diet of families hurt by collapsed world oil prices. Permitting carpet imports would allow the creation of many new Iranian jobs. Iran's people have once again voted for change. America should welcome their democratic choice and extend new opportunities for friendship.

HEADLINE: Report Says Buyers Can Choose Clean Cars or Clean Factories

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
For environmentalists in the market for a new car, the choice is not an easy one.
According to the Council on Economic Priorities, an environmental group based in New York, car buyers face a rock-and-a-hard-place choice: They can buy cars that were made in nonpolluting plants or cars that run clean themselves, but they cannot do both. 
 In a report released yesterday, the council lauds the fuel efficiency, and thus environmental cleanliness, of the Honda Civic and Mitsubishi Mirage. But it criticizes Honda of America Manufacturing and Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America for the high levels of pollutants spewing out of the Ohio and Illinois plants where the cars are made.
It cites the Chrysler Jeep Grand Cherokee as a gas guzzler, even when compared with other sport utility vehicles. But it praises the Toledo, Ohio, plant where the Cherokee is made as one of the cleanest around.
"Some of the most polluting cars are made at the least-polluting facilities, while the clean cars are coming out of dirty plants," said Romi Chin Gottfrid, an environmental research associate at the council.
None of the plants mentioned in the study are flagrant violators of state or Federal environmental regulations. A spokeswoman for the Environmental Protection Agency, while acknowledging the "irony that sometimes clean products come from dirty facilities," indicated that the agency was not particularly incensed by the study.
Ms. Gottfrid responded, "Regulators should be holding these companies to a higher standard."
Not surprisingly, none of the companies are apologizing. "We've taken pro-active action to minimize environmental impact," said a Mitsubishi spokeswoman, who added that "the council's data is incomplete." Ron Lietzke, a spokesman for Honda of America, said that Honda's four Ohio plants were recently certified as environmentally sound by the International Organization for Standardization in Geneva. "We have continuous, active efforts going to reduce our emissions, waste and use of natural resources," he said.
DaimlerChrysler A.G., which makes the Jeep Grand Cherokee, meanwhile, is focusing on the praise. "We're very pleased that our employees' efforts to address environmental performance have been recognized," said Sonja Bultynck, an environmental spokeswoman.
And about that nagging fuel efficiency problem? "Well, the 1999 Cherokee is 7 percent more fuel efficient than the 1998 model," she said.
