HEADLINE: Should We Cut Social Security Loose?

BYLINE: By Charles J. Zwick and Peter A. Lewis; Charles J. Zwick and Peter A. Lewis were, respectively, director and assistant director of the United States Bureau of the Budget (now the Office of Management and Budget) under President Lyndon Johnson.

 BODY:
Two conservative members of Congress -- Representative Wally Herger, a California Republican, and Representative David Minge, a Minnesota Democrat -- have introduced a bill that would separate Social Security from the rest of the Federal budget. Their rationale sounds persuasive enough on the surface: to protect future retirees by preventing Social Security's current surpluses from being absorbed into other parts of the budget.
But a little history is in order. The move would mean reversing a carefully considered decision made 30 years ago. 
 Until 1968 there were three Federal budgets: an administrative budget, a cash budget and a trust fund budget, which included Social Security. These budgets were consolidated on the recommendation of a bipartisan commission appointed by President Lyndon Johnson. The commission's reasoning was that the operations of the Federal Government must be viewed in total to correctly measure their impact on the economy.
Of course, the commission recognized that it was not beyond the ability of economists to add up three different numbers. But the public and the press, it realized, usually latch onto just one.
Now, as then, failing to include Social Security with the rest of the budget would create a distorted understanding of the state of the nation's finances. Public debate -- and Congressional debate -- would become confused as different factions argued from different sets of numbers to make political (but not necessarily reliable) points.
The separation of the Social Security budget was a relic of President Franklin Roosevelt's original conception of the program, which was that it was simply an insurance plan rather than a concrete recognition of the Government's obligation to senior citizens. But ever since the 1930's, it is along the latter lines that Social Security has developed.
Separate budgets make sense only if one believes that Social Security and other trust funds handled by the Government are essentially private-sector operations or have no impact on the rest of the economy. But Social Security is based on involuntary collections by the Government. It's hard to equate these payments with the kinds of retirement plans offered by Merck or Microsoft.
Taking Social Security out of the overall budget would make that budget look worse now, because Congress taps into Social Security funds to pay for other programs. If conservatives are still hoping to seek a tax cut, citing the current Government surplus, why would they want to weaken their case by making the budget appear less flush? That's what would happen if they stripped away the Social Security trust fund. This effect would not appear to be consistent with conservative priorities.
A more plausible explanation is that the proposal is part of a continuing effort to privatize Social Security. The inclusion of Social Security in the unified Federal budget presupposes that Social Security is a Government program -- in other words, a Government obligation.
Taking Social Security out of the unified budget would be a victory -- albeit a small one -- for those who would remove the obligations for Social Security from the Government. And it would make intelligent public debate on the economy more difficult -- as the Presidential commission recognized 30 years ago.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares End Day Mixed, With the Dow Falling by 21.73

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday after slumping technology shares rallied in the final hour, pulling the major market gauges up with them.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.73 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 9,275.88, after rising as much as 40 points and shedding as much as 86 before trimming its losses in the final 30 minutes. 
 Broader indexes, which are more heavily stocked by technology shares, were lower most of the day but crossed into positive territory late in the session. The Nasdaq composite index ended up 6.17 points, or nearly three-tenths of a percent, to 2,265.20, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.20 points, or nearly two-tenths of a percent, to 1,227.70. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies fell 2.48 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 391.95.
Computer stocks dropped after 3Com, which sells Internet data, voice and video systems, said on Tuesday that its third-quarter operating earnings would be far below analysts' expectations because of an unexpected slowdown in sales to businesses in the United States and Latin America. 3Com fell 2 3/8, to 24 5/8, in Nasdaq trading after dropping from 27 in after-hours trading on Tuesday.
3Com's statement came after similar warnings of soft sales from Compaq Computer and Micron Electronics, a unit of Micron Technology.
Technology stocks tried to weather the storm early but ran out of steam by early afternoon. Still, some companies had gains. After 3Com, the most active stocks were Intel, up 4 7/8, to 114 11/16 ; Compaq, up 1 15/16 , to 33 7/8; Dell Computer, up 2 7/8, to 80 15/16 , and Microsoft, up 1 1/16 , to 149 5/8.
Stocks were pushed lower by the bond market, where prices sank after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of nonmanufacturing activity rose to 57 percent in February from 54 percent in January. But the group's index of nonmanufacturing prices eased, to 46.5 percent from 47 percent.
"The specific problem, short term, is the bond market and rising yields," said Larry Wachtel, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. With stock prices so high, "it's very hard to justify these valuations when interest rates are rising."
Meanwhile, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, restated his reservations about President Clinton's proposal to invest a significant portion of the nation's Social Security trust fund in the stock market.
Addressing a Congressional subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan said such a plan could encourage investments for political reasons in companies that are not well run or discourage investments in companies that could earn the best return for future retirees.
Investing Social Security money in the stock market could also lead to higher overall interest rates and curb economic growth, while doing "little or nothing" to make sure the retirement needs of the next century are met, Mr. Greenspan said.
His remarks ruffled a market that was already poised to continue a selloff of technology shares while no other sector has stepped forward to lead the market higher, said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter in New York. "This market is locked in a trading range," Mr. Bleier said. "You are in the process of building some very serious negative sentiment, far more negative than we've seen in several months."
Declining issues led advancers by 16 to 13 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was moderately heavy.

HEADLINE: A Haughty Blast From Communism's Past

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, March 3

 BODY:
On his first vacation as Italy's Prime Minister, Massimo D'Alema took his family on a private visit to New York over Christmas. His children wanted to see the Broadway musical "Cats" and F. A. O. Schwarz. Mr. D'Alema, a former Communist, wanted to see what the world's leading superpower has to offer, so he also went to eat at the TriBeCa Grill, the trendy downtown restaurant.
"It was nothing special," he said with a shrug. He then explained that there are only three cuisines in the world: French, Italian and Chinese. Italy, he said, was most important because it had given civilization its first real "proletarian dish," pizza. Pressed, Mr. D'Alema conceded that he had eaten well at one place in New York, Asia de Cuba a Cuban-Chinese restaurant in midtown. 
 Mr. D'Alema, who will turn 50 in April, became the first former Communist to lead a Western European Government in October, and he underlines the word "former." But even in small talk he retains a trace of 1970's left-wing hauteur.
When he holds his first official meeting with President Clinton in Washington on Friday, Government officials and ordinary Americans will get a first-hand look at a Prime Minister who is fiercely intelligent, confident and direct. Mr. D'Alema is also cold and quite free of easy charm. As he himself recently confessed to a television talk show host, "As a child, I was antipatico," using an Italian word that means displeasing.
Like Socialist leaders now in power in Germany, France and England, Mr. D'Alema has distanced himself from the most ideological extremes of his party and recast himself as a moderate. So far, his economic and foreign policies have mirrored those of his predecessor, Romano Prodi, a centrist. Mostly, Mr. D'Alema differs from the affable Mr. Prodi in background and personality. Mr. D'Alema's churlish assessment of American cuisine, delivered during an informal chat with foreign journalists in January, may have also been colored by his mood at that moment. At the time, the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan was in Italy and seeking political asylum there.
Mr. D'Alema was under intense pressure from Turkey and the United States to turn him over for trial in Turkey. The Ocalan affair was his first real foreign policy test as Prime Minister, and also his first taste of how the United States can squeeze an ally.
Mr. D'Alema refused to extradite Mr. Ocalan on the ground that Italian law forbids the extradition of prisoners to countries with death penalties. The United States reacted harshly at first, then backed off publicly and switched to nagging private diplomacy. Turkey threatened economic boycotts and worse.
Mr. D'Alema, who is sympathetic to the Kurdish cause, initially suggested Italy might grant Mr. Ocalan political asylum. The United States, Turkey and his many political opponents at home bludgeoned him for it, and Mr. D'Alema began searching for other solutions.
Germany, which feared a blowup within its large Turkish and Kurdish minorities, refused to take him, even though Germany had outstanding warrants for his arrest. Hopes for an international trial dried up under Turkey's opposition.
Italy finally asked Mr. Ocalan to leave in mid-January, and he ended up under Greek protection in Kenya. Turkish commandos captured him there, and he is now in a Turkish prison awaiting trial.
Mr. D'Alema, who sought a principled approach but eventually had to bow to realpolitik, views the episode as a learning experience -- but for the United States and Europe, not for himself.
"If we defend the rights of the Albanians in Kosovo, and rightly so, then I think we have to also defend the rights of the Kurdish minority," he said in an interview in his office last week. He said he would raise the issue of Kurdish rights with Mr. Clinton. "We cannot split up Turkey, but there are other national issues there which must be addressed by the West, by the United States and Europe together," he said.
But foreign policy is not the most urgent problem on the Prime Minister's agenda. Mr. D'Alema, who came into office pledging to reduce Italy's unemployment rate, which in some areas of the south is about 23 percent, is facing many hurdles. Italy's economy in 1998 showed the slowest growth rate in Europe: 1.4 percent instead of the 2.5 percent goal the Prodi Government set when Italy agreed to adopt the new European currency, the euro.
Mr. D'Alema has made it his mission to reform the chaotic and chronically unstable Italian electoral system and create a two-party system. He faces opposition from the conservative right wing, and even his allies are not exactly on board. This month, Mr. Prodi created his own center-left party, which is likely to further splinter the left.
Mr. D'Alema is the first Italian Prime Minister to hold weekly news conferences. Yet his relationship with the Italian press is not exactly cozy. One of his closest aides, Fabrizio Rondolino, his media adviser, was forced to resign last month after steamy accounts surfaced of Mr. Rondolino's newly published erotic novel. Mr. D'Alema accepted his resignation but also attacked the "vulgarity" of the Italian media. Italian newspaper columnists paint Mr. D'Alema as arrogant and remote, but they have also attacked him for recent appearances on popular television shows intended to warm up his image.
Mr. D'Alema says the media assaults are the result of his unstinting honesty. "Perhaps mistakenly, I have always said what I thought," he explained.
But Mr. D'Alema is also heavily scrutinized for his Communist past. His parents were Communists and his father was a high-ranking party official. As a child, Mr. D'Alema was sent to Soviet summer camp at Artek, the Soviet union's most prestigious international "pioneer" camp on the Black Sea.
He mostly spoke French to fellow campers, he recalled. "At the time, it was the international language of choice." (Mr. D'Alema now studies English during his lunch breaks, in an effort to improve his communication skills at NATO meetings and summits of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations).
He was the head of the Young Communist League in the 1970's, and edited l'Unita, the Communist Party newspaper, from 1988 to 1990. In 1991, against the backdrop of the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Italian Communists splintered, and Mr. D'Alema left to form a non-Marxist party, Democrats of the Left. Since then, he has often denounced the mistakes of Communism, but he gets irritated when Italian journalists harp on his own.
"Many of these gentlemen were to my left, advocating armed insurrection," he said. "My past is also their past."
Mr. D'Alema, whose trip will be his fourth to the United States, said he is not anti-American, but he acknowledged that he sees the United States through the eyes of a left-wing European intellectual. And that includes a dim view of American popular culture.
"I am a Benigni fan," he said, referring to Italian director and actor Roberto Benigni, whose Holocaust comedy, "Life Is Beautiful," won seven Academy Award nominations this year.
"Naturally, I hope that this time, the Americans will not betray our hopes and expectations," Mr. D'Alema said, referring to Oscar night later this month. But he added that his own expectations were confounded by the film's popularity with ordinary Americans. "I never would have imagined it," he said. "It improved my image of the United States, the fact that this film could be successful there, because it is a film that forces one to think."

HEADLINE: Thais Show Albright the Fruits of American Aid: Meaningful Jobs and Legal Crops

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: CHIANG MAI, Thailand, March 3

 BODY:
Madeleine K. Albright put a human face on foreign policy today, listening to a group of young Thai women explain how American aid money had helped turn them away from drugs and prostitution and toward meaningful jobs.
It was unusual for an American Secretary of State to be sitting at a table with rural women one-third her age in an out-of-the-way town in northern Thailand. Proudly, Ms. Albright acknowledged as much. 
 "I'm doing things secretaries of state didn't do," she told the women, some in the ornate dress and headgear of the hill-tribe people. "Partially because they interest me but more importantly because they are new elements of American foreign policy." In the United States, she said, "combating drugs is a job for the Secretary of State."
Ms. Albright met with trainees from the New Life Center and Thai Women of Tomorrow to highlight what money from the United States Agency for International Development can do.
The programs, which Hillary Rodham Clinton visited two years ago, claim success in educating and then giving vocational training to girls who have been rescued from opium-addicted parents, or from brothels and drug dens.
Ms. Albright arrived in Thailand primarily to support the Government in its painful path of economic reform after the financial crash in 1997. The Thai economy is still shrinking, but Clinton Administration officials said the worst appeared to be over.
But before meetings in Bangkok, Ms. Albright wanted to show the importance of dealing with the social side of the financial crisis.
In rural Thailand, young women are expected to become the breadwinners for elderly parents and relatives. Without jobs, they become vulnerable targets for traffickers in women and prostitution rings.
One of the women at the round-table session with Ms. Albright, Chanpen Promsen, 21, told how after finishing school she had stayed at home looking after her family.
A former teacher got in touch with her and suggested she go to Bangkok for six months of vocational training under the Women for Tomorrow program, Ms. Promsen said, and is now employed as a garment worker. "I'm making money and can support my family," Ms. Promsen said.
Earlier today, Ms. Albright took a 20-minute drive through tropical vegetation of banana and bamboo trees to the village of Nong Hoi, where the Thai royal family has been helping farmers grow fruit and vegetables instead of opium. The Thai Government has made substantial progress in eliminating opium-growing in northern Thailand, which is part of the area known as the Golden Triangle.
Ms. Albright went out of her way to praise the Thais for curbing opium growing by the introduction of crop substitution.
"This is in marked contrast to the country of Burma, where they are not doing the kinds of things you are doing," she said. In the last two years, she said, Washington has contributed $1.3 million to the crop substitution program.
"Here we are saying no to narcotics and yes to vegetables," said Ms. Albright.
Local farmers who used to earn the equivalent of $100 a year from opium now earn about $1,200, he said.
"That's stunning," Ms. Albright said. "It's not as though they are losing money; they are making money."

HEADLINE: Kingstown Journal;
An Outpost in the Banana and Marijuana Wars

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent and the Grenadines

 BODY:
When American troops helped destroy more than one million marijuana plants in December in the rugged northern regions of this island, growers were outraged. They protested on radio and in front of Government offices. They appealed to business and political leaders. They even started a petition drive to ask President Clinton for damages.
"The Americans are not showing any real concern for our economic and social development," said Junior Cottle, chairman of a group of marijuana growers who described himself as "representative of the ganja man." 
 Mr. Cottle said he did not grow marijuana but did smoke it.
Marijuana is not legal here. But its production in the remote mountains has, American officials said, taken off in recent years, making St. Vincent the second largest grower in the Caribbean, after Jamaica.
Growers said they were turning to the crop to deal with an unemployment rate that is officially 20 percent but that many people here say is far higher.
The animosity directed at the United States comes from two directions. Residents have a feeling that Washington has abandoned this corner of the world, now that the cold war is over and it no longer sees a Communist threat in the Caribbean.
There is also a marked hostility against Mr. Clinton for waging war with Europe over banana trade preferences, the legitimate backbone of the economy.
The nub of the dispute is that Europe unfairly favors bananas grown by its former colonies, including this onetime British outpost, where English is spoken and cricket is a favorite sport. The preference discriminates against American companies that produce bananas, the United States says.
Officials here say removing the import protections would deal an economic catastrophe to countries that have little capacity to grow anything else and whose bananas are costly to grow. Some Government and business leaders say the United States risks undermining its anti-drug efforts in the region if banana growers turn to drugs -- not just marijuana, but also trafficking in Colombian heroin and cocaine as alternatives.
At the very least, some Caribbean experts note, the banana issue is creating such deep resentment that it may compromise the willingness of Caribbean countries to continue cooperating in anti-drug efforts.
"When Caricom countries meet in July, I think you'll see a bold statement of resistance," said Ivelaw Griffith, a Caribbean expert at Florida International University in Miami. Caricom is the Caribbean Community, the regional economic association.
Marijuana growers here are seeking to anger the public against further eradication while exploring an agenda that includes promoting marijuana for medicinal purposes and pushing for job creation in fishing and nonbanana agriculture.
The president of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Martin Barnard, said of the United States' stance: "People don't understand it. They're saying, 'What more can they do to us?' "
Prime Minister James F. Mitchell, who asked for the mission in December, refused to see the farmers, telling them in a terse letter in November that his Government was "firmly opposed to the illegal drug trade."
Mr. Mitchell said in an interview that he would like to see even more American assistance to curb marijuana cultivation and the heroin and cocaine trafficking through the Caribbean. But he said he regarded the friend in drug control as a foe on the banana front.
"We have a property-owner democracy, and that's what's been threatened, our quality of life," he said.
American trade officials said that they did not want to hurt Caribbean banana producers and that there were ways to protect them like subsidies to bring down banana prices.
At the University of Miami in February, the Clinton Administration director of drug policy, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, declined to comment on the banana problem, calling it "a complex issue." But General McCaffrey said he did not accept the argument that "it's either this or drugs."
"Nobody turns to marijuana or opium or cocaine production as a survival mechanism," he said. "They turn to that because you can make more money."
But drug riches are not readily apparent at the house of a 39-year-old banana farmer who also grows marijuana and identified himself only as Nebo. He lives in the northeastern town of Georgetown, an hour's drive from here, in an unpainted concrete-block shell with two bedrooms and a family of seven.
As the sweet smell of marijuana wafted in from somewhere around the house, Nebo said his 10,000 marijuana plants yielded an income that was at least 10 times the revenue from his three acres of bananas. Nebo said he had no reason to grow bananas anymore except that "it's in the culture."
"It's been in my family," he said. "I just keep doing it. 'Right now I'm taking my income from ganja to support the banana crop. Ganja has been beneficial to me. It's paid for my house, schooling, food, the bills."
Another banana grower in Georgetown, Iris Walker, said she and her husband would never resort to drugs. But she said marijuana farmers should be accepted as a necessary evil, underscoring the feelings of many residents.
"It's illegal," Ms. Walker said. "But if some people don't do it, they don't have bread for the children."
She called the Americans "selfish."
Government officials said they were trying hard to diversify the economy to reduce the reliance on the banana crop, which is recovering from a slump caused by bad weather and low prices.
Tourism in St. Vincent and the Grenadines earns three times as much as bananas. But officials say that the agricultural dollar goes longer because it is spent locally and that no industry can yet replace bananas in importance.
Marijuana growers and their supporters say they stand ready to help.
"We're ready to be part of the process," Mr. Cottle said. "The fact that we come out and talk illustrates the magnitude of the problem."

HEADLINE: Democrats and Republicans Rally on Issues

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Under a campaign-style blue banner, President Clinton rallied today with Congressional Democrats to show party unity on a legislative agenda that would reserve more than three-quarters of Federal budget surpluses for Social Security and Medicare.
The event was an effort by Democrats to frame the agenda for the 106th Congress, while the Republicans were still seeking their own consensus on legislation. 
 Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore received standing ovations from Democrats who protected the President from impeachment but wanted to censure him for "shameful, reckless and indefensible" behavior. Mr. Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, who recently gave up plans to challenge him for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000, even hugged.
With the impeachment process over, Democrats and Republicans have quickly become enmeshed in battles over issues like education and how to apportion surpluses for tax cutting, spending and the long-term solvency of Social Security and Medicare.
Looking to inoculate themselves against a Democratic assault on the issue of Social Security, the Republican leaders of Congress have been working on a budget plan to reserve Social Security only for the popular retirement program.
Mr. Clinton praised Republicans for agreeing to reserve billions of dollars for Social Security, but said another 15 percent of the surplus should be put aside for Medicare, a stand the Democrats hope will allow them to frame the Republican tax-cutting plans as a raid on the Federal health care program for the elderly.
"There are still strong differences in our approach," the President said in an ornate room in the Library of Congress, "and we must resolve them in a way that benefits the American people."
Under a frieze of warriors carrying their dead, Mr. Clinton spoke of the Democratic origins of the Great Society programs for the elderly.
"If we do these things -- saving Social Security, saving Medicare, empowering more Americans to save for their own retirement," he said, "we will fulfill our historic challenge to meet the difficulties and the opportunities of the aging of America in a way that provides a stronger economy and more stable families for our children."
House Republicans countered with a rally led by the majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas. The crowd shouted "ka-ching" -- to imitate the sound of an I.R.S. cash register -- as Mr. Armey recited all the ways that a family is taxed.
Representative Rick Lazio, Republican of Long Island, called the surplus the "overcharge" and said that tax cuts allow a family to save money "for a new home, or money for ballet lessons for your daughter or shots for the new puppy."
Mr. Armey said Republicans had agreed with Mr. Clinton to set aside 62 percent of projected budget surpluses to fix Social Security, making the real debate over whether to use the rest of the surplus to cut taxes or increase Government spending.
"When the choice is seen that way," Mr. Armey said, "the American people overwhelmingly come out on the side of cutting taxes."
But with the party feuding over which taxes to cut, the Republicans did not showcase any particular tax cut. Instead they announced plans for town hall meetings nationwide to promote tax relief.
At the Democratic rally, Senate Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said that a Republican proposal for a 10 percent tax cut would give people who earn $800,000 an annual tax cut of $20,000 while families who earn $38,000 or less would save 27 cents a day.
"We believe America's families deserve better than 27 cents a day," he said and moved on to other Democratic agenda items like education and health care. "They deserve good schools for their children. If they are sick, they deserve whatever treatment their doctor says they need."
The Democrats today also called for raising the minimum wage, putting 50,000 more police on the streets, and for tax credits devoted to retirement savings, child care and long-term health care.
The competing rallies showed that for all the recent talk of bipartisanship both parties are on a campaign footing -- not a good sign for legislative achievement. A sign of the mood of Democrats on Capitol Hill was that the most enthusiastic and spontaneous applause came not for Mr. Clinton or Mr. Gore, but when Mr. Daschle introduced Mr. Gephardt as "the next Speaker of the House."
Mr. Gephardt urged Democrats to work with Republicans, and said: "We will be judged by our progress, our action, our accomplishment, not by our words."
But other Democrats made clear that they would be happy to bludgeon the Republicans if they block the Democratic agenda.
"If they reject all of it, they provide the foundation for the 2000 elections," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the chairman of the Senate Democratic campaign. And Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island, who heads the House campaign effort, said, "We are going to have to continue to identify Republicans as the party that has put off the important business of this country for the past year."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Banking legislation puts fiscal heavyweights in rival corners.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
A CONTINUING spat between Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, over modernizing bank regulations threatens to bury legislation that comes before House and Senate committees today. They agree that laws from the 1930's and 1950's that keep banks out of the securities and insurance markets should be scrapped. But they disagree how banks should be structured to handle their new responsibilities.
Mr. Rubin, with the support of most economists, looks as if he will get most of what he wants from the House. Mr. Greenspan, drawing powerful support from past and present Fed officials, may win in the Senate. Indeed, the Administration yesterday threatened to veto the proposal by Phil Gramm, chairman of the Senate banking committee. The risk is that Congress will be deadlocked, forcing the economy to operate under Depression-era rules for at least a few more years. 
 The nation's laws prohibit commercial banks from underwriting insurance and securities or engaging in most commercial activities. Nearly everyone agrees that most of these prohibitions should be scrapped. The idea is that banks could be allowed to offer customers a single, convenient and low-cost place to bank, invest and buy insurance.
Mr. Greenspan would require banks to affiliate with securities and insurance firms under the joint ownership of a bank holding company. He would not allow banks to provide financial services directly or through wholly owned subsidiaries. Under the Greenspan plan, bank holding companies would rule the market. By the way, Mr. Greenspan's Fed regulates bank holding companies.
Mr. Rubin would allow banks to avoid the complicated and costly burden of setting up holding companies and instead create wholly owned, but separately incorporated, subsidiaries. In this arrangement, banks could become financial giants. By the way, Mr. Rubin's Treasury regulates banks.
To almost anyone outside the Beltway, the distinction between affiliates and subsidiaries appears arcane. Suspicions are heightened by the strong aroma of a turf war. But there is more to this dispute than petty jealously.
The Fed points out that subsidiaries are dangerous because their losses would directly eat into the financial reserves of the parent bank. That leaves the bank financially vulnerable. The Fed worries that transfers between parent banks and their subsidiaries could grow excessively large because the money would still be owned by the bank and would not, therefore, spook creditors.
But the Fed is hard pressed to point to independent economists who share its fears. George Benston of Emory University says that the Rubin plan -- and the bipartisan bill proposed by James Leach and John LaFalce, the chairman and ranking minority member, respectively, of the House banking committee that embraces many of Mr. Rubin's demands -- "gives Mr. Greenspan all the protections that he needs."
Under the bill, banks could offer securities underwriting through a subsidiary. But participating banks would be required to hold an extra layer of capital reserves. And none of the dollars that the bank invests in its subsidiary could be counted toward its capital requirement. In other words, if the subsidiary went bankrupt and the parent bank lost its entire investment, the bank would still be left with more capital than is normally required. Second, the amount of money that the bank would be allowed to send to its subsidiary would be limited to the amount the bank would be allowed to send to an affiliate of a holding company.
Mr. Benston's point, like Mr. Rubin's, is that affiliates and subsidiaries are largely equivalent under the House proposal.
But Mr. Greenspan makes a second criticism of the House plan. Banks, he points out, can borrow money more cheaply than other firms because of various Government-provided favors. The Government insures money deposited by the bank's customers. The Government provides loans to banks in times of distress. And the Government guarantees the system that provides for rapid processing of deposits and payments. Mr. Greenspan worries that banks will pass the financial benefit of these implicit Federal subsidies to their subsidiaries, thereby distorting competition in the market for financial services.
But Mr. Benston dismisses these arguments, as well. "The subsidy Mr. Greenspan points to may not exist, but it is almost surely small. Along with the Federal insurance come layers of expensive regulations. Besides, the benefit of the subsidy, if it exists, can be passed along to affiliates about as easily as subsidiaries. And, banks have little incentive to pass along subsidies to affiliates or subsidiaries."
The Fed appears to fear that securities underwriting and other financial services are so inherently nuclear that they can blow open holes in the parent bank's capital before regulators have time to react. But, Mr. Benston points out, "Derivatives can blow up faster than stock and bond purchases. Underwriting poses no special risk."
But there is another argument that may explain the Fed's animus toward subsidiaries. If banks prefer Mr. Rubin's model to the Fed's, bank holding companies will shrivel, leaving the Fed little to regulate. Over time, Fed officials fear, their regulatory expertise will also shrivel. Fed officials believe regulatory expertise is integral to the Fed's ability to do its other job: setting monetary policy.
There are other contentious issues, including Senator Gramm's threat to undermine the rules that compel banks to lend in poor neighborhoods. But the major dispute is over bank structure. It might seem obvious that the impact on the economy of Depression-era bank rules is large. But the presumption may well be wrong. Regulators have chipped away at the regulatory shackles, finding loopholes by which to approve, for example, a merger that brought Citibank and Salomon Smith Barney together. A legislative fix may not be all that important. Mr. Leach says his bill will deliver a "psychological boost" to the financial services sector, especially to firms serving midsize business. Perhaps. But Mr. Leach cites testimony that the economywide benefits might be only a few billion dollars a year.
"There is always good reason to throw out silly rules," Mr. Benston said, "but don't expect bank reform to pack much of a wallop."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Deal Protects Maine Woods From Development

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 3

 BODY:
Great swaths of the Maine woods with a combined area larger than Rhode Island would be protected forever from development under a $28 million plan announced today and thought to encompass more territory than any other such deal.
Gov. Angus King of Maine said in Augusta that the plan would include more than 2,000 miles of shoreline on streams and rivers, more than 85 lakes or ponds, and nesting areas for bald eagles and peregrine falcons. 
 "This is probably the biggest day for Maine out-of-doors since Governor Baxter first saw Mount Katahdin," Mr. King said, referring to the 1920's Governor, Percival Baxter, who personally bought and donated Baxter State Park, a widely beloved wilderness area crowned by Mount Katahdin in northern Maine.
Under the agreement, a family of longtime Maine landowners, the Pingrees, would provide a conservation easement on the land by selling the development rights on 754,673 acres to a private nonprofit group, the New England Forestry Foundation. The family can continue limited industrial logging and the public will still have recreational access, although there are no plans to transform the land into a park. They have no immediate plans to develop the land.
The foundation, which is 55 years old and promotes sustainable forestry, is still raising the money for the purchase and has two years to amass it.
Governor King, who announced the agreement, said it was probably the largest conservation easement deal on private forest land.
On a roll of recent victories in their efforts to preserve Northeastern forest land, environmentalists praised the Pingree agreement as a significant step toward saving more of the Northern Forest, the 26 million acres of woods from Maine to New York.
"It's the soul-satisfying sound of another big piece of the Northern Forest puzzle clicking into place," said Bob Perschel, chairman of the Northern Forest Alliance, a coalition of 35 groups.
The deal came at a moment of exceptionally hot debate over what Maine should do about its 17 million acres of woods, a discussion prompted by land sales last year of giant paper company holdings that amounted to about 15 percent of the state.
Conservationists scored their most recent Maine triumph in mid-December, when the Nature Conservancy, an international group, announced that it would pay $35 million to buy 185,000 acres of International Paper Company land in northern Maine. Not far away, a week earlier, conservationists cheered an even bigger landmark preservation purchase: 300,000 acres of forest land in New York, Vermont and New Hampshire from the Champion International paper company for $76 million.
But at the same time, environmentalists in Maine have complained loudly that the state is not prepared to protect more of the millions of acres coming up for sale as global economic forces lead paper companies to shift their assets. The environmentalists called for the state to find the money and the will to buy more land to protect it, and warned that at least one big land purchaser was known for sub-dividing and building on wilderness parcels.
In a state where love for the forest gets as prosaic as moose meat in the freezer and as poetic as Henry David Thoreau's paeans to the Maine Woods, the heightened discussion has been enough to move the state Legislature to put the issue on the front burner in its current session. It is considering a variety of proposals, including one from Governor King for a $50-million bond issue for land purchases and ranging to more than $100 million. Any such bond issue would have to come before voters in November.
Legislative leaders say there seems to be enough consensus that at least a $50-million bond issue has a good chance of passing. In public debate, however, contention remains on issues ranging from just how much land should be bought to whether it should remain working forest or be protected from logging. But today's announcement seemed to please virtually all camps.
"It's a win-win," said Abby Holman, executive director of the Maine Forest Products Council, a trade association for the wood and paper industry. "You're actually able to provide for a conservation easement and reduce the threat of development in pristine areas, and secure the future of the timber industry."
At the other end of the forest spectrum, Jonathan Carter, executive director of the Forest Ecology Network and an advocate of maximizing wilderness areas, also praised the deal as a great step, though he added: "It's important that we realize that conservation easements are not wilderness restoration. Hopefully, now we've got it out of development's hands, we can now move forward and create a wilderness park."
That -- creation of a wilderness park -- was the kind of total stop to logging achieved this week by defenders of Headwaters, the old-growth redwood forest owned by a lumber company in Northern California. But in the East, where most forests are privately owned, unlike their publicly owned Western counterparts, just reducing logging and stopping development can seem to environmentalists like progress.
Injecting a note of skepticism into all the celebration, Mr. Carter pointed out that the Pingrees, who are known as the most environmentally punctilious of Maine's large landowners, would receive $30 million for abstaining from developing land that they may have had no intention of developing anyway.
"If you can continue to do what you've always done and someone will give you $30 million, who will say no?" Mr. Carter asked.
But Governor King countered that the Pingrees, who are now in their seventh generation of holding land first assembled in 1840, were showing unusual vision in putting a permanent ban on developing their land.
"This is forever," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
British Halt Cuts in a Key Rate, Driving Pound Up Against Euro

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 3

 BODY:
The Bank of England brought five months of monetary easing to an end today, deciding to leave its key short-term lending rate unchanged at 5.5 percent. The decision helped send the pound to a record high against the euro.
The central bank's monetary policy committee announced the decision without elaboration. Economists said it was probably responding to recent data suggesting that a slowdown in British economic growth appeared to be ending. 
 There was little reaction in the London stock market, where the decision to leave interest rates unchanged had been expected. But the currency market was quick to bid up the pound on speculation that British interest rates would become more attractive compared with rates elsewhere. Higher rates tend to make a currency worth more; lower rates tend to stimulate the economy by making loans more affordable.
The pound hit a record high of 67.25 pence against the euro, the single European currency introduced two months ago. It gained nearly a cent against the dollar here, rising to $1.6225, before retreating to $1.6134 in New York.
Britain's central bank had reduced the short-term securities repurchase rate five successive times from October through February, which brought it to the current 5.50 percent level from 7.50 percent.
But a British industry lobbyist said rates were too high and should be cut further. "Inflationary pressures remain flat and with prospects for economic recovery still fragile, a significant cut was both workable and necessary," said Ian Peters, deputy director general of the British Chambers of Commerce.
He said rates needed to move in line with those in the 11-nation euro zone, where they are at 3 percent. Two other non-euro nations cut key rates this week -- Norway earlier today and Denmark on Monday. The European Central Bank is to hold a rate meeting on Thursday; there is no expectation it will reduce rates.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hong Kong Plans Shifts in Reserves

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 3

 BODY:
Hong Kong said today that it would change the way it managed $118 billion of reserves, increasing the amount of United States dollars and equities in the portfolio and taking more risk in search of better returns.
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the de facto central bank, will cut the percentage of bonds in its Exchange Fund to 80 percent from 90 percent, and will double the ratio of equities to 20 percent. The United States dollar will account for 80 percent, an increase at the expense of European currencies and yen. 
 The changes reflect the way government reserves and pension funds are being managed, economists and treasurers said. Even the most conservative institutions are switching more money into equities as stocks have continued to outperform bonds.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bonds Rally, Driving Yield To New Lows In Japan

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, March 4

 BODY:
Japanese bonds rallied today, driving the yield of the benchmark issue to its lowest in more than two months as expectations grew that the central bank would extend its efforts to guide down short-term interest rates.
The Bank of Japan, after pushing the overnight lending rate close to zero on Wednesday, is considering lowering other short-term rates such as yields on certificates of deposit. 
 The move "will make it easier for investors to buy long-term bonds by raising funds in the money market," said Michiya Seki, a trader at the New Japan Securities Company.
The benchmark No. 203 bond rose 1.105, or 511 yen per 50,000 yen bond, to 101.904, pushing the yield down 125 basis points, to 1.565 percent. It earlier touched 1.555 percent, the lowest intraday level since Dec. 22. It was the lowest close since Dec. 21.
The benchmark yield has fallen 37 basis points in the last five days as the central bank drove down short-term interest rates in an effort to end the recession and bring down bond yields. The yield is still up from a record low of 0.695 percent on Oct. 7.
Kazuo Ueda, a member of the Bank of Japan's policy board, said that lowering yields of certificates of deposit and other money market instruments could be another option to ease monetary policy.
The unsecured overnight loan rate between banks, which is equivalent to the United States Federal funds rate, hit a record low two-hundredths of a percent on Wednesday. As money market traders charge two-hundredths of a percent commission for brokering overnight loans, the interest rate effectively fell to zero, traders said. The rate fell after the Bank of Japan pumped 400 billion yen ($3.3 billion) into the banking system, adding to a 1.26 trillion yen initial daily surplus, signaling its commitment to bringing short-term rates down and expanding money supply.
Meanwhile, the central bank is sticking to its resolve not to underwrite Government bonds, a move that some politicians want the bank to take in order to absorb a glut in the debt market and cap a rise in long-term interest rates.

HEADLINE: With a Job, Without a Home;
Low-Wage Workers Turn to Shelters to Bridge the Gap

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Kenneth Lindo walks with bond traders and bankers through the gleaming lobbies of Wall Street during the day, his canvas messenger's bag heavy with checks and stock certificates from the longest bull market in memory. But at night, he beds down at the 30th Street Men's Shelter in Manhattan, rolling his winter jacket in the sheet under his head.
Until January, Mr. Lindo had a pillow to call his own, in a Harlem room that cost $20 a day on his $5.50-an-hour pay -- almost 70 percent of his take-home income. At the shelter, he does without. 
 "I got to get there earlier than 5 P.M. to get a pillow," explained Mr. Lindo, 44, as he loped through deliveries in the financial district, where he has worked on and off near the minimum wage since he was 18.
Mr. Lindo's double life illustrates a larger paradox. The booming economy has provided employment for more low-wage workers like him, but by driving up rents, has made it harder for them to cover the cost of housing, sending some to the city shelter system to bridge the gap.
And the system they encounter is in the midst of re-evaluating the role work should have for its shelter residents.
Recent court rulings cleared the way for the city to require parents in family shelters to work for the city in exchange for their beds, and the Giuliani administration is arguing for the same authority in shelters for single adults. But how such a system would work remains unclear.
Would residents with pay from private-sector jobs still qualify for shelter beds? Might they, like shelter residents in Philadelphia, have to turn over a percentage of their earnings to sleep there?
Simply getting a steady bed in a shelter has become more difficult for many poor people who work but cannot find affordable housing. More than 69 percent of the city's 7,570 shelter beds are now operated under contracts by private, nonprofit agencies, many in programs geared to substance abusers or the mentally ill.
"So many of the specialized beds have been developed with a therapeutic or rehabilitation approach that there are very few beds available for men who are working and simply need a roof over their heads until they can get housing," said Steven Banks, director of the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Rights Project.
This winter, according to records compiled in New York by the Legal Aid Society, full-time stock clerks, short-order cooks and messengers were among several hundred homeless men who were shuttled through the shelter system's overnight circuit. They often waited past midnight at the 30th Street Shelter intake center near Bellevue Hospital Center, records show, then were bused to one-night bed assignments in other shelters throughout the city that they had to vacate by 5 or 6 A.M.
Mr. Lindo, the messenger, for example, spent 19 nights at different shelters before landing his current bed in the Bellevue shelter, one of the coveted "assessment beds" that serve as a gateway to a steady assignment.
Susan Wiviott, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Homeless Services, said that the recent overflow was temporary, caused mainly by seasonal demand. Like most cities, New York does not compile statistics on the number of people who are employed when they enter the shelter system, she said, but she estimated it as "very minimal."
But for these working homeless, the nightly routine of long waits, broken sleep and early morning ouster from unfamiliar beds can threaten their ability to keep a job.
Derek Wall-Carty, who works a mix of day and evening shifts as a cook for the Houlihan's restaurant chain in Garden City, on Long Island, was on the overnight circuit last month, and described the trial of keeping up private-sector work while depending on a rotating shelter bed. "It was six days of hell," Mr. Wall-Carty said, "and for three of them I didn't sleep at all."
The day he was housed at the Wards Island shelter, it took him two and a half hours by bus, subway and Long Island Rail Road to get to his 9 A.M. shift, after he had waited for a bed the whole night, he said.
Another day, he was bused to the Kingsborough shelter in Brooklyn at noon between two night shifts, he said, but the door manager told him he had to choose between going to work or having a bed when he returned.
Even when a caseworker at the Wards Island shelter agreed to reserve him a bed for his return from another night shift, the trip from Long Island left him stranded at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue at 1 A.M., because buses to Wards Island were no longer running.
He walked across the Triborough Bridge, he said, losing his way on Randalls Island and arriving at the shelter at 4 A.M. to find his bed gone after all.
"I refuse to lose my job because of a setback," Mr. Wall-Carty said, adding that he turned to the shelters on Jan. 20 after the woman who had rented him a room in her Bedford-Stuyvesant house for $70 a week objected to his work hours.
Mr. Wall-Carty, 21, who studied hotel and restaurant management at New York City Technical College for two years, now shares a room with 13 other men at Pamoja House, a 200-bed employment-oriented shelter operated by the Black Veterans for Social Justice in a city armory in Brooklyn. The program lasts up to six months, and he says he hopes it leads to an affordable apartment.
Although there are differences in shelter admission policies around the country and a lack of consistent data collection, other areas also report unexpected increases in the number of working adults living in shelters.
In Columbus, Ohio, 20 percent of the homeless families sheltered in 1998 reported income from jobs, up from 8 percent in 1994, said Matt White, research director for the Community Shelter Board, which allocates public and private money to the shelters.
In Orange County, Fla., a survey last year by the Homeless Services Network found that 53 percent of shelter residents there were employed, up from 36 percent when the same survey was done five years earlier.
While many people think of typical adult shelter users as chronically homeless derelicts or the mentally ill, a majority of those who entered the New York City system between 1988 and 1995 -- nearly 60,000 men out of a sample of 73,293 -- left within two months and did not return, or came back only briefly, over the next three years, according to an analysis by Dennis P. Culhane, an associate professor of social welfare policy at the University of Pennsylvania.
Residents in this group were not without problems, Mr. Culhane's analysis showed: about a third came with histories of substance abuse. But many, he said, were working people coping with crises of poverty.
One example is Damon Revells, 39, who was a cook for Norman's Jerk Chicken in Jamaica, Queens, when he became homeless in December. Mr. Revells, recently divorced, said that when his child support payments left him behind in the rent, his landlord locked him out.
After days of shuttling between temporary beds in different shelters, he said that he was so exhausted and emotionally drained, he dozed off on the job and burned the soup. He was laid off soon after.
"This thing could just become this grinding machine," he said in a recent telephone interview from a shelter on Wards Island, where he has been assigned a steady bed and is now looking for a new job.
"People for whom the economy has really made life good have trouble understanding why these people can't make it," said Mary Ann Gleason, the executive director of the National Coalition for the Homeless in Washington. "But there's an inverse relationship between a strong economy and the affordability of housing. You have this direct rise in housing cost in proportion to what the market will bear, but we haven't increased the minimum wage."
Tony Proscio, former deputy commissioner for the New York City Department of Homeless Services and now a consultant on urban development, said there was another reason why the current robust economy might cause more of the working poor to end up in shelters: employers hard-pressed to fill jobs without swelling labor costs have hired workers passed over in a weaker economy, including some with criminal records or histories of substance abuse that put them at greater risk of losing their housing.
Mr. Lindo, a divorced Army veteran who graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx in 1973, puts himself in that category. He spent six days in a detoxification program in early January at the suggestion of the private shelter he called when he first lost his room.
"Your life catches up with you sometimes," he said, describing a 1995 drug conviction for which he is still on probation, credit card debt from Christmas three years ago, and traffic tickets from a stint as a taxi driver.
He says he is trying to pay off the fines so he can drive a cab again. Meanwhile, he is back to being a Wall Street messenger. He starts and ends his shift in Jersey City, where the messenger service that employs him runs a mail room under contract to a prominent investment bank. Mr. Lindo asked that the companies not be named.
"They might not like it," he said, "that I'm living in a shelter."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Disney andHong Kong Confirm Talks on a Theme Park

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Confirming weeks of breathless rumors, Hong Kong and the Walt Disney Company said yesterday that they were in early negotiations about building a theme park in the former British colony.
It would be the second Asia-based theme park for the entertainment company and would mark a major expansion of Disney's dealings with China, which regained sovereignty over Hong Kong 19 months ago. 
 Sir Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's financial secretary, said Disney and the Hong Kong government had reached a "common understanding" about building a park in Hong Kong. He said they would now begin "intensive negotiations" and hoped to make a final decision by the end of June. If a definitive agreement is reached, Sir Donald said the first phase of a Hong Kong Disneyland could be completed by 2005.
Besides its parks in Orlando, Fla., and Anaheim, Calif., Disney operates theme parks in suburban Paris and outside Tokyo.
The mere whisper of Disney's interest has generated giddy excitement in Hong Kong, which has been racked by recession and a steep drop in tourism in the aftermath of Asia's financial crises and the British-Chinese agreement that converted Hong Kong into a special autonomous region of China.
Some people in Hong Kong have come to view a Disney park almost as a pot of gold. Even as he confirmed the negotiations, Sir Donald felt obliged to temper public expectations.
"I am fully aware of, and indeed share, the public's excitement at the prospect of seeing Mickey and his friends in Hong Kong," Sir Donald said in his annual budget address in the former colony. "However, I must caution that while we have made the first important steps, there is still much ground to cover. Much hard negotiating lies ahead."
Disney, which is based in Burbank, Calif., confirmed through a spokesman that it was in preliminary discussions about building a theme park resort in Hong Kong but declined to elaborate.
The chairman of Disney, Michael D. Eisner, had said in the latest annual report that Disney would likely build a park in China in the coming years, and speculation grew that Hong Kong and Shanghai were preferred locations.
Regardless of where in China a Disney park is built, the negotiations themselves are persuasive evidence that Disney's fortunes in the world's most populous country are improving after a three-year chill. China's film market was closed to Disney movies after the company's 1996 release of "Kundun," a film about the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, who is considered a political enemy by Beijing. But in February, in an early sign of a thaw, China approved the release of the Disney animated hit about the Chinese heroine "Mulan," which opened in theaters there last week.
Before Disney committed to Hong Kong, it would need to agree on the price of the land for a theme park. Indeed, Ian Perkin, the chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce, said: "I'd say the chances of this are less than 50-50. If you look at the cost of land in Hong Kong, I'm not sure Disney is willing to pay."
Sir Donald said the government and the company envisioned building the park on reclaimed land north of Lantau Island, not far from the new Hong Kong International Airport.
The airport, which is also built on reclaimed land, cost $20 billion, an amount that included the vast network of bridges, tunnels, highways and railways that connect the airport to central Hong Kong. Some of that infrastructure could presumably serve a new Disneyland as well. But the cost of another enormous reclamation project could easily reach billions of dollars.
One person with knowledge of the talks between Hong Kong and Disney said the company had initially proposed that the government give Disney the land. No matter how much Hong Kong wants to lure Disney, analysts said it could not accede to such a deal.
Sir Donald said a theme park would generate thousands of new jobs at a time when Hong Kong is suffering from record unemployment. He said the park would also protect the territory's status as a tourist destination in Asia.
Mr. Perkin agreed that a Disney theme park would be a potent growth engine for Hong Kong. But because such a project would require years of planning before construction started -- let alone the gates opened -- he said it should not be viewed as a panacea for Hong Kong's current problems.
In addition to the Disney project, Sir Donald announced that the government would build a giant industrial park for technology companies. The $2 billion project, called Cyberport, will be financed partly by the government and partly by the Pacific Century Group, a real estate and technology company controlled by Richard Li, the son of Hong Kong's most prominent tycoon, Li Ka-shing.
Sir Donald also forecast that Hong Kong's gross domestic product would grow five-tenths of 1 percent in 1999, after plummeting 5.1 percent last year. Mr. Perkin said even that modest goal would be hard to achieve.
For all the caveats, the prospect of a Disney park has been a tonic to a city sorely in need of good news. The shares of Hong Kong property developers have soared in recent days as the Disney rumors percolated. Analysts said the value of real estate near the park would rise significantly. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Disney shares rose 31.25 cents, to $34.50.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: NETANYAHU ON PULLOUT
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would consider "the possibility of a unilateral withdrawal" from Lebanon if "accompanied by necessary security measures." He rejected a suggestion by Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon that May elections be postponed in order to form a unity government dedicated to a pullout. Both men's remarks followed a campaign promise by the Labor Party candidate, Ehud Barak, to withdraw troops within a year if elected Prime Minister. Deborah Sontag (NYT) 

ISRAEL: POLICE QUESTION SHARON
The police interrogated Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon on the suspicion that he might have bribed a former general to give false testimony on his behalf in a libel case. Mr. Sharon's lawyer, Yaakov Weinroth, strongly denies that there was either any act of bribery or any false testimony. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
JORDAN: EMBASSY IN KUWAIT REOPENED
Jordan reopened its embassy in Kuwait, ending a break between the two Arab countries that began during the 1990-91 Persian Gulf crisis. Jordan, unlike several Arab states, did not join the U.S.-led alliance against Iraq in the gulf war, and many Kuwaitis feel that Jordan favored Iraq after Baghdad's 1990 invasion. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: 2 GROUPS BARRED
Two Protestant militia groups opposed to the Northern Ireland peace accord have been banned by the British Government, Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam said, because of their continuing involvement in sectarian violence. The Orange Volunteers and the Red Hand Defenders are fiercely pro-British groups that have carried out bomb attacks on Catholic nationalists. (Reuters)
 
GIBRALTAR: BRITAIN BACKS VOTING RIGHTS
Britain will seek voting rights for Gibraltar in European Parliament elections, risking a new dispute with Spain, which contests British rule over the territory. The European Court of Human Rights ruled last month that excluding Gibraltar from voting for candidates to the 626-member parliament was a breach of human rights. (Reuters)
 
RUSSIA: FAR APART ON I.M.F. DEAL
Russia and the International Monetary Fund are still far apart on an economic accord, and the I.M.F. must not bend its rules too far as it decides whether to start handing over cash again, Michael Mussa, the fund's chief economist, said. He told reporters that the Government of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov was reversing some policies accepted by his predecessors. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
JAPAN: BACKING FOR CONTRACEPTIVE PILLS
A Health Ministry committee approved the sale of birth control pills, bringing Japan closer to the general sale of the pill almost four decades after its first use in the West. The pill could be available by the end of the year. The shift came after women's groups protested the ministry's decision in January to approve the male impotence drug Viagra after deliberating just six months. Approval of the pill has taken nine years. (AP)
 
CHINA: CALL FOR TIANANMEN INQUIRY
As the 10th anniversary of the June 4 killings by the military around Tiananmen Square approaches, victims and their families have renewed calls for the Government to re-evaluate the incident. The group wants to clarify who ordered soldiers to move against the demonstrators, and a new compensation law for the victims, whom they number in the tens of thousands. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)
 
CAMBODIA: HUN SEN BACKS TRUTH PANEL
Prime Minister Hun Sen says he favors a truth commission to deal with atrocities committed by the Khmer Rouge, but warned in a letter to the U.N. that a trial of the group's leaders could cause "panic." His letter came a day after U.N. legal experts recommended the formation of an international tribunal outside Cambodia to try senior Khmer Rouge leaders and a truth commission inside Cambodia to deal with lower-level perpetrators of the 1975-79 killings. (AP)
 
PHILIPPINES: GRAFT TRIAL FOR MRS. MARCOS
Imelda E. Marcos suffered a major legal setback when a court ordered that she be prosecuted on five cases of graft. Prosecutors have accused her of setting up four foundations to conceal $350 million in Swiss bank accounts from 1978 to 1984. With interest, the deposits now amount to more than $500 million, Philippine officials say. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
ZIMBABWE: NEWSMEN ALLOWED TO LEAVE
Over the objections of the Government, a judge has allowed two journalists who say they were tortured by soldiers to go to Britain for medical treatment. Mark Chavunduka, editor of The Standard, and a Standard reporter, Ray Choto, were detained after the paper reported a suspected coup attempt. They said they were beaten and given electric shocks before being released. (AP)
 
SOUTH AFRICA: AIDS DRUG REJECTED
Health Minister Nkosazana Zuma reaffirmed that the Government would not pay for AZT for pregnant women to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus to their babies. Some foreign researchers are so incensed at the decision that they are trying to embarrass her by revoking her invitation to next year's World AIDS Conference, to be held in South Africa. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
BRAZIL: NEW HEAD OF CENTRAL BANK
After four days of rancorous debate, the Senate approved the appointment of Arminio Fraga, until recently an aide to the financier George Soros, as president of the central bank. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: WORKER EXCHANGE PROPOSED
Labor Minister Jose Antonio Gonzalez said Mexico would like to "carefully analyze" with U.S. officials the possibility of developing the "regulated interchange" of workers by the two countries. Sam Dillon (NYT)

HEADLINE: MIFFED AT EUROPE, U.S. RAISES TARIFFS FOR LUXURY GOODS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The United States heated up two politically contentious trade disputes with Europe today, slapping 100 percent tariffs on $520 million in European products and threatening to ban Europe's supersonic pride, the Concorde, from landing in the United States.
The tariffs imposed by the Clinton Administration on goods such as Louis Vuitton handbags, Parma ham, pecorino cheese and Scottish cashmere sweaters, which essentially double their price and make it much harder for European exporters to sell them in this country, are part of a six-year battle over trade in bananas. 
 The threat to ban the Concorde is in a bill passed overwhelmingly in the House of Representatives today, in retaliation for a European ruling that would ban many older American airplanes from landing in Europe. American officials say Europe's restriction is designed to promote the sale of new engines and aircraft made by European manufacturers.
But both battles are really about the enormous tensions that have erupted between the United States and a Europe newly unified by a common currency. On both continents, politicians are feeling the heat from slowing exports, and fear a slowdown in economic growth later this year. And Washington and the European Union find themselves unable to resolve seemingly ordinary economic disputes, with each accusing the other of defying the World Trade Organization, the four-year-old court of international trade.
The court has stepped in to arbitrate the banana dispute, which involves European limits on imports, and has become the battleground over other politically sensitive issues, including Europe's ban on imported beef from cattle raised with hormones.
The arguments have resulted in some of the nastiest trans-Atlantic bickering in years. This afternoon, American officials said they hoped the imposition of the 100 percent tariffs on European luxury goods -- with the exceptions of wine and Mercedes Benz cars -- would "freeze trade" in those items and compel the Europeans to negotiate. In response, Europe's top trade official, Sir Leon Brittan, called the American action "unacceptable and unlawful."
Oddly, the underlying dispute seems relatively trivial. "It's hard to believe," one American official mused today, "that we got to this by arguing over bananas."
The trade fight with Europe has become a major issue at the White House, with President Clinton becoming directly involved in some of the negotiations, most recently with French President Jacques Chirac. But the economic impact is relatively modest: The United States imported $176.3 billion in goods from nations in the European Union last year, meaning that today's sanctions apply to one-quarter of 1 percent of goods imported from Europe.
But in trade, as in politics, symbolism counts for more than statistics. And the symbolism of today's actions are clear: The United States is showing that it intends to retaliate if it believes Europe is manipulating trade rules to keep out competition.
The airplane battle, like the beef-hormone dispute, is a prime example of how one continent's environmental and health regulations are another continent's trade barrier.
The European Parliament recently passed legislation banning the takeoff or landing of older airplanes even if their engines have been retrofitted with devices called "hush kits" that reduce airplane noise. European officials say the planes still are too loud.
Rep. James Oberstar, a Minnesota Democrat who sponsored the measure to ban the Concorde flights, calls the rule "a thinly veiled attempt to give a competitive advantage" to the European aircraft and engine makers.
There are only 12 Concorde aircraft now flying, with regularly scheduled flights between Kennedy International Airport in New York and London and Paris. .
Both airlines today called for the United States and Europe to settle their differences at the World Trade Organization.
That may yet happen. But clearly the House action was intended to give the Clinton administration more leverage in their talks.
The banana dispute is steeped in American politics: While the Government is acting on behalf of the Dole Food Company and Chiquita Brands International, neither company grows or picks bananas in the United States. Almost all of their bananas are grown in Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Nicaragua.
Europe has imposed an enormously complex banana quota system that limits the import of Latin American bananas, to benefit former European colonies, many in the Caribbean. The trade court has struck down the quota system several times. In each case, American officials charge, Europe made minor modifications to the rules that essentially kept the trade barrier in place.
So in December the Administration warned it was preparing to retaliate, publishing a list of goods that would be doubled in price for a total of $520 million -- the amount that United States banana companies say they've lost because of Europe's restrictions. Ambassador Peter Scher, who heads up agricultural talks for the United States Trade Representative's office, said that the "real issue is whether Europe is prepared to obey the W.T.O.'s rulings."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
It's Tax Time: for Some, Gorilla Hunting Season

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE GREEDY HAND
How Taxes Drive Americans Crazy and What to Do About It
By Amity Schlaes
255 pages. Random House. $22.95.
"To tax and to please, no more than to love and to be wise, is not given to men," wrote Edmund Burke in 1774. Nor, he might have added, is it often given to humans to write about taxes and be stimulating. Yet in "The Greedy Hand: How Taxes Drive Americans Crazy and What to Do About It," Amity Schlaes not only manages to keep you wide awake, she also sets your blood to boiling. 
 She does so by citing particularly egregious examples of how our current Rube Goldberg machine of a tax code sometimes works. She tells, for instance, of a New York City couple who lost their 29-year-old son, an investment banker, in the crash of Pan Am's Flight 103 in Lockerbie, Scotland, and were dunned by the Internal Revenue Service for $6 million in back taxes on the settlement the I.R.S. estimated they would receive, even before the amount of that settlement was determined.
She tells of another couple who bought a house in East Dorset, Vt., because of the area's outstanding schools, only to learn that the state's supreme court had ruled that the local school-financing system was unconstitutional, that it would no longer be all right for one school district to spend more money on its students than another, and that henceforth local real estate money was to be sent to the state capital so that it could be given out equitably.
She writes that Tax Freedom Day -- which is what a Washington-based think tank called the Tax Foundation names the day on which the average American has finally paid off his total annual burden of Federal, state and local taxes -- fell in 1998 on May 10, "the latest day in history."
What Ms. Schlaes is getting at with these illustrations is not exactly subtle. She is talking about estate taxes, real-estate taxes and social-security taxes, and the point she is making is that the present American tax system is greedy, intrusive, unpredictable and meddling. And the Internal Revenue Service in administering this system acts with all the restraint and subtlety of a 500-pound gorilla on amphetamines.
Elsewhere, Ms. Schlaes details other alleged excesses of what Thomas Paine in "The Rights of Man" described as "the greedy hand of government thrusting itself into every corner and crevice of industry, and grasping the spoil of the multitude." In a chapter called "Your Clothes," she describes shopping for tax-free apparel at the Mall of America in Minneapolis-St. Paul as an example of the lengths to which people will go to escape sales taxes.
In "Your Work," she argues that the present Social Security System is "indeed and truly a Ponzi scheme," or a ruse in which money from one generation flows into the pockets of another until there are simply not enough people to pay. In "Your Marriage," she explains how two conflicting goals, "equality for the poor" and "equality for women," have combined to produce a result whereby married people pay higher taxes than a comparably earning single man and woman.
In "Your House," she argues apropos of the home-mortgage deduction that if real estate did not "enjoy a huge advantage over other investments, our economy would grow more efficiently overall." In "Your Baby," she laments how the cost and difficulty of hiring proper child care is actually causing couples to give up having additional children. In "Your Success," she insists that the progressive income tax does more harm than good and fails to fulfill its stated purpose of taxing the truly rich. And in "Your Retirement," she describes how the Social Security system has the effect of idling and infantilizing older people even as the economy demands more workers and people are living longer, more active lives.
How does the book propose to solve these myriad ills, which add up to such an indictment of our tax system that by the end you are almost ready to accept the flat tax proposed by the House majority leader, Dick Armey? Or the single tax once dreamed up by Henry George. Or even a system based on cowrie shells or maybe bubble gum. Encouragingly, Ms. Schlaes, a member of The Wall Street Journal's editorial board, concludes that "our impasse, in fact, contains the outline of its own solution, if only we allow ourselves to look at it clearly."
What "our long struggle with Paine's greedy hand" tells us, she writes, is that "taxes have to be "visible," "simple," "for revenue" (as opposed to for the purpose of steering behavior), and "lower." She goes on: "We don't have to load extra taxes on the rich"; "It's time to privatize Social Security"; "Local is good," ("The Federal government cannot solve everything"), and "We must lock in change." By this last she means simply that we ought to clear out the present "underbrush," and "put through lower, simpler rates that apply to all in a consistent manner" and that we ought to pass a constitutional amendment "that calls for limiting Federal taxes, including Social Security, to 25 percent of our income, or even a lower share."
She concludes that "luck is on our side. Today the nation is actually in a better position to undertake a tax reform than at any point in living memory. . . . Today we have no deficit and no cold war." We need only look to our own history of resisting taxes for "the path to follow."
Now there may be any number of details about which to quarrel with Ms. Schlaes. For instance, she fails to prove her case that all progressive systems inevitably fail to tax the rich proportionally, and she leaves one to suspect that the real reason the rich gain the benefit of loopholes is not because "progressivity" is flawed but simply because the rich have more power. And many will question her larger assumptions that the welfare state has proved itself useless and that an untrammeled free market will not create its own systemic problems.
Still, by criticizing our present tax code so concretely, Ms. Schlaes has provided a thoughtful overview of the system's many contradictions and inequities. Even if you don't always agree with her conclusions, she defines the debate over what we ought to do and gets you thinking constructively about the problems she identifies.
