HEADLINE: Night Court Joins the Theater That Is New York

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The hour was closing in on midnight. A detachment of ruddy-faced German tourists emerged from the metal detectors in the Criminal Courts building in lower Manhattan, took a sharp left and headed down the empty marble corridor toward the city's least likely international attraction, night court.
Tentatively, they filed into Room 130. They entered like spelunkers, wide-eyed and hushed amid the cavernous courtroom's disconcerting fluorescence. Wrestling off ski jackets, they settled into several rows of dark wooden benches, looking eager, alert and utterly out of place. 
 The court stenographer squinted at them, then shrugged.
"It looks like they came off a tour bus or something," she muttered.
"I'm telling you, this is in the tour books," said Judge Ruth Pickholz, who was presiding that night. "They should have been here the night of the escape."
Manhattan makes its name on superlatives, so maybe it should come as no surprise that in the only borough with 24-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week arraignments, the 5:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. shift at arraignment court at 100 Centre Street near Chinatown is both a tourist attraction and an occasional cheap date.
This is, after all, post-O. J. Simpson America. Who is not interested in sidebar conferences and orders to show cause? With criminal lawyers serving as hosts of television talk shows and Judge Judy becoming a celebrity, courtrooms are becoming a daytime-television cliche. Night court, meanwhile, is the real thing.
Like much in Manhattan, night court is real-life theater. It is the criminal-justice equivalent of a ringside seat at emergency-room admissions. It is mostly pantomime, robbed of its dialogue by bad acoustics, but it offers the curious visitor a hard look at a sad slice of New York life.
Hour after hour, the door to the holding pens behind the courtroom bangs open and shut. Men and women with smudged faces and sleep-flattened hair slouch before the judge. Charges are barked out: heroin possession, fare-beating, possession of stolen property. Lawyers argue in shorthand; the judge sets bail.
Once in a while, something startling breaks the rhythm. Denied bail, a defendant dares the court officers to force him to return to the pens. Or as had happened in Judge Pickholz's courtroom earlier that week, a man leaps the rail and tries to bolt, only to be caught in the corridor and charged with escape.
"I consider arraignments the E.R. of the court system," said Judge Pickholz, a former lawyer with the New York Legal Aid Society and former corruption prosecutor for the city. "We triage. Some cases need a Band-Aid. Some of them need major surgery."
Every day, hundreds of people are arrested in Manhattan. Under state law, the city has 24 hours to get them arraigned before a judge, who will hear arguments from a prosecutor and usually a court-appointed defense lawyer on, among other things, how high to set bail.
Time was, people used to languish in jail for days, unarraigned. Then in 1990, the Legal Aid Society went to the state Supreme Court and argued that the city was violating a law requiring arraignment "without delay." In April of that year, a judge agreed and set the limit at 24 hours.
These days, the arrest-to-arraignment time is usually less than that. But a visitor to night court may be struck by the tension between the pressure to deal quickly with the flow of "bodies," in law-enforcement parlance, and the countervailing impulse to treat the "bodies" as something more.
 
'Cans of Tuna Fish'
Not everyone finds the balance satisfactory.
"The system believes in processing our clients, kind of like cans of tuna fish," said Stephen P. Pokart, a Legal Aid lawyer who has worked in night court often since 1980. "They don't recognize them as humans. They are species as paperwork, species as statistic, the species defendant."
Standing on the western rim of Chinatown, the vast Criminal Courts building is an awesome place. "Where law ends there tyranny begins," reads the inscription on one wall. Homeless men can be seen bedding down along the sidewalk, while litter swirls in windy eddies near the entrance.
Room 130 is the bigger of the two arraignment courtrooms, a room so archetypal that Barbra Streisand replicated it for her 1987 movie "Nuts." The cracks in the benches appear in places to have been spackled with now petrified chewing gum; even tourists look pallid under the 11 overhead lights.
A low rail divides the room -- public on one end, lawyers and accused on the other. There is an interview booth for lawyers and clients, reminiscent of a confessional. Up near the ceiling, there are eight tall, rectangular windows, their Venetian blinds in varying degrees of disarray.
Judge John Walsh, a former police inspector who oversees arraignments throughout the city, recalls watching from the bench some years ago as a pigeon flew into the courtroom through an open window, circled the room as if according to long habit, then came blithely to rest in an indoor nest.
"You see what's on that screen?" he asked a visitor one afternoon, pointing out a mysterious constellation of small white globs on an out-of-use video monitor that had come to rest on top of the interview booth.
"Spitballs," he said.
 
A Revolving Cast
The cast of characters at night court is shifting yet somehow constant. Criminal- and civil-court judges are assigned in rotating five-night shifts. The lawyers cycle in and out, too. Only the court officers are regulars, a tight-knit group with a shared social life outside of court.
As for the accused, they have a certain superficial sameness. If they look as if they slept in their clothes, they did. They appear weary and bedraggled; some are sick. Told to keep their coats with them, many stand before the judge in down jackets, as though expecting snow.
Some stare at their feet, hands behind their backs. Some list to one side, looking warily at the judge. Some chortle in disbelief at the prosecutor's account. Some are mentally ill; many are indigent. Some are in withdrawal; a few are diabetics in danger of insulin shock.
"We have a great deal of trouble getting credibility with our clients, for all sorts of socio-economic and other reasons," said Mr. Pokart, 58, who joined the Legal Aid Society, a nonprofit agency that provides representation for indigent defendants, after graduating from Harvard Law School, then getting a degree in theater directing and running soldier shows in Vietnam.
"Clients often ask us, 'Are you a paid lawyer?' " he said. "You can make a joke and say, 'No, I do this for the fun of it.' So they smile, maybe. But they think of us as not paid lawyers because they're not paying us."
"So, we're not 'paid lawyers,' " he continued. "Generally we're white and they're not. We're well dressed and they're not. We're educated and they're not. We're out of jail and they're in there." Furthermore, he said, many of them have been badly represented by incompetent lawyers before. He added, "So there is a great deal of mistrust."
Each arraignment tends to follow a pattern. A defendant is brought into the courtroom through the door leading to the holding cells and is deposited on one of several wooden benches. There he is left to wait with maybe a dozen other men and women, their backs to the public, until a court officer calls his case.
 
Building Drama
Cases are announced in a loud, barely intelligible rush of terminology. The defendant takes his place next to his lawyer, whom he met minutes earlier in an interview booth adjoining the pens. The prosecutor asks that bail be at a certain level; the defense wants it lower.
If the defendant's mother is in the courtroom, she is pointed out -- an indication that the accused might be counted on to come back to court. The defense lawyer might talk about the client's job, if he has one, or his medical condition, if he has one, and how he will suffer if held in jail.
"Our job is to help them as lawyers," said Mr. Pokart, who once tossed a client's glass eye to a judge while making the case that the client could not keep it clean in jail. "If they're locked up at arraignment, helping them as a lawyer means to get them out of jail."
Then comes the judge's turn.
He or she skims a sheaf of papers: a one-page complaint; the defendant's rap sheet; a brief report on where he lives, how long he has lived there, whether he works, where he works, and a bail recommendation from the private agency that the city uses to prepare such reports and recommend bail.
The judge then has a minute or two to set bail. Maybe three.
"If they're not decisive, they had better become decisive very quickly," said Judge Walsh, who retired as a police officer, was sworn in as a judge and hit night court all in the same week. "You have to make decisions and there's no second call, no let-me-think or what-do-you-think? You're the one."
What is more, the decisions are hard and the judge has little information to go on. "I've never had something bad happen," Judge Pickholz said. "That's every judge's nightmare. That's the one thing you don't want to be responsible for -- having somebody get hurt because of something you've done."
 
Intermission
The pressure lifts briefly when the court breaks for dinner around 9 P.M. It is a segregated ritual: Judges gravitate to Forlini's, a nearby Italian restaurant, defense lawyers to Chinatown, court officers to their desks. When they return, many are fighting exhaustion.
Other tasks punctuate the night. Some defendants, charged with misdemeanors, plead guilty and must be sentenced. Sometimes orders of protection and search warrants need to be signed. Often, there are defendants with drug problems that jail will not help and who have no other place to go.
"You have to get yourself some help," Judge Pickholz told a woman, who was 41 but looked 60, limping toward the bench to be arraigned on yet another misdemeanor drug charge. "Do you know that? Because you're going to end up in jail or dead on the street."
The woman nodded blankly. A tourist dozing in the second row snapped awake. It was well past midnight. The defense lawyer and the prosecutor huddled with the judge. "She's a lost soul," the judge said quietly. "If you want to help get her into a program, I'm not going to keep her in jail."
Though the woman had a record, the prosecutor agreed to reduce the charge from a misdemeanor to a lesser category called a violation. That way, the woman could plead guilty and not be charged with violating her probation. Maybe she would even get help.
The judge thanked him.
"There's a place for D.A.'s like you," she said.
He answered, "I hope they send me there soon."
 
Where to Watch
For those who have an appetite for courtroom drama but who cannot face leaving the living room sofa, the current television season offers plenty of alternatives to a trip to night court. There's always Court TV, which televises real cases in real courtrooms. Then there is a flourishing genre of courtroom drama more akin to soap opera. The best known is "Judge Judy," with Judge Judith A. Sheindlin presiding, which now outstrips "Oprah" and "Jerry Springer" in the daytime ratings. But there are a half-dozen others, and counting, offering a full range of posturing plaintiffs, cranky judges and speedy justice -- all in the tidy space between commercials. Here is a sampling of courtroom shows on television and when they are broadcast in the New York region:
 
"JUDGE JOE BROWN" -- 3 P.M. weekdays on Channel 9.
 
"JUDGE JUDY," with Judith A. Sheindlin, a former New York Family Court judge -- 4 and 4:30 P.M. weekdays on Channel 2.
 
"JUDGE AND JURY," with former Judge Burton Katz -- 1 P.M. weekdays on MSNBC cable network.
 
"JUDGE MILLS LANE" -- noon weekdays on Channel 11.
 
"JUDGE WAPNER'S ANIMAL COURT," with retired Judge Joseph A. Wapner. Hears disputes on veterinary malpractice, grooming disasters and other matters involving pets. 11:30 A.M. daily; 2:30 and 7 P.M. weekdays, and 9 P.M. on Tuesdays on Animal Planet cable network.
 
"THE PEOPLE'S COURT," with former Mayor Edward I. Koch -- 4 P.M. weekdays on Channel 4.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES;
Competition For Cliff Notes

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, March 4

 BODY:
Neither a borrower nor a lender be. . . . whateverrrrrrr!
Shakespeare has always enjoyed at least modest popularity in Hollywood, with one movie studio or another taking a crack at his plays in the form of faithful revivals or loose interpretations. 
 But rarely has there been as big a rush as this year, when audiences will get a chance to see works ranging from "Titus Andronicus," one of Shakespeare's least-known plays, to yet another modernization of "The Taming of the Shrew," this time called "10 Things I Hate About You," set in a high school and geared toward teen-agers.
Six Shakespearean productions are scheduled to hit theaters within the next year, three of them starring Julia Stiles (above) and all hoping to take advantage of the popularity of "Shakespeare in Love," a romantic fantasy that has little to do with the writer's plays or life but has received 13 Academy Award nominations.
Yet nearly everyone in Hollywood considers Shakespeare a box office liability, at least if audiences get the impression they will have to listen to long, opaque soliloquies in antiquated English.
"The trick is how do we overcome it, because there is audience resistance," said Mark Gill, president of the West Coast operations of Miramax Films, the Disney unit that is distributing three of the new Shakespeare movies. "The more contemporary they are, the better the chance they have."
Gil Junger, the director of "10 Things I Hate About You," said he had also been skeptical at first. "My immediate reaction was, a teen-ager is just not going to be interested," said Mr. Junger, until now a director for television, including the episode in which Ellen DeGeneres declared she was a lesbian on her sitcom, "Ellen."
"I just didn't want to do a Shakespeare movie because of the commercial concerns," he said. "But then I read the script and I thought it was a great story. Then I said, 'Of course, it's a great story. It's Shakespeare.' "
The film is scheduled to be released on March 31. In May, it will be followed by "A Midsummer Night's Dream," starring Calista Flockhart, Kevin Kline and Michelle Pfeiffer. A version of "Othello," also set in a high school and called "O," again with Ms. Stiles, is scheduled for an October release.
Late in the year there will be "Titus Andronicus," directed by Julie Taymor and starring Anthony Hopkins and Jessica Lange.
A contemporary version of "Hamlet" set in New York, starring Ethan Hawke, Bill Murray and Ms. Stiles, is expected early next year. That will be followed by a new version of "Love's Labour's Lost," with Kenneth Branagh, Alicia Silverstone and Nathan Lane, set in the 1930's and made with music by Cole Porter, George Gershwin and Jerome Kern.
"It all goes in cycles," Mr. Junger said. "This may be over in a year."
 
A Jackboot to Art
Art, it is often said, transcends politics. "The Harmonists" is a cautionary tale about the risks of believing too much in that old saw.
"The Harmonists," which opens next Friday, is a German movie about an extremely successful group of a cappella singers of the 1930's. Its members, like many Germans of the day, believe that while the Nazis may break a few windows and even a few laws, they will not interfere with the popular arts. The film, which has been quite successful in Germany, examines how wrong they were.
It is based on the true story of the Comedian Harmonists, who were modeled on the American group the Revellers. A play, "Band in Berlin," that is also based on their experiences, opens in New York on Sunday.
The German group was formed in 1927 by Harry Frommermann, a young man in love with music and eager to capture the upbeat sassiness of the day. There were six members, three of them Jewish. The movie ends with the group's forced dissolution in 1934, all shocked by the Nazis' belligerence yet still unaware of the extent of their evil.
The movie has in fact drawn some criticism for not heavily emphasizing the Holocaust, said Heino Ferch (left), a German actor who plays Roman Cycowski, a Jewish opera singer from Poland who was one of the band members.
Mr. Ferch, a former gymnast and acrobat, said the movie, while ending on a note of foreboding, gives no direct hint of the Holocaust. As a result, he said, some people suggested that the movie pulled its punches.
Buthe said that one of the film's strengths was showing how people only slowly woke up to the Nazis' real agenda.
"It wasn't necessary in a movie like this to go hard on the Holocaust itself," Mr. Ferch said. "It goes deeper in your heart, I think, because you can see how these people reacted and their denial. They were Jews, but they thought they were so popular, no one would attack them."
The Nazis later began a crackdown on what they called Jewish art or degenerate art, banishing or killing artists in many fields.
But the movie keeps its gaze tightly focused on the hopes, dreams and personal lives of the Comedian Harmonists.
In one striking scene, Mr. Ferch's character says he will marry his girlfriend only if she converts to Judaism. She does, and the wedding scene, shot in a synagogue in Prague, is a joyous occasion filled with music and dancing, a stark counterpoint to the fate of the group and millions of Jews across Europe.
 
Dimming Star Power
S. Abraham Ravid, a business professor at Rutgers University and New York University, has produced a fairly dense academic paper whose conclusions are supported with entries like "mean of dependent variable," "adjusted R-squared" and "F-statistic."
The paper might not be of much interest outside academia except that it appears to disprove several cherished theories about what makes a movie profitable.
Examining a random sampling of nearly 200 movies, Mr. Ravid said he found that lower-budget movies tended to be more profitable than big-budget pictures, though they often generated less revenue; movies with unknowns or lesser-known actors tended to be more profitable than star-driven films; there was no statistical correlation between the strength of reviews and profitability, but there was a relationship between the number of reviews, no matter how positive, and profitability, and the strongest correlation for profitability was a G or PG rating.
Sequels, he adds, tend to be more profitable than the average film.
Mr. Ravid, a lifelong film buff and a former radio journalist in Israel, said the conclusions in his paper, "Information, Blockbusters and Stars: A Study of the Film Industry," which is to appear in The Journal of Business later this year, surprised him. He said he had undertaken the study to understand the business rationale of paying top dollar for Hollywood stars.
"I wanted to know why would you hire an expensive star right up front for a movie," he said.
The figures contradicted much of the Hollywood wisdom regarding star power, he said. They also conflicted with some recent studies that have purported to show that stars like Mel Gibson and Michelle Pfeiffer (left) have been the biggest profit generators.
Among the reasons his study countered popular wisdom, he said, was that he focused on the profitability of movies, not just their box office revenues. In examining data on older movies, he also adjusted revenue and profit for inflation, so that valid comparisons with could be made with current movies.
"I was actually very much rooting for the stars in my analysis," Mr. Ravid said. "Once I saw which way the results were going, I tried several different definitions of a star, and I was wondering why it wasn't working out. But stars are not what they seem to be. They often bring in higher revenues, but the profitability is smaller."
Why would the studios persist in paying up to $20 million to get a major star in a movie if such films rarely generate big returns?
"I can only speculate, but in an atmosphere of great uncertainty, people try to play it safe," Mr. Ravid said. "They can say everyone else is doing it. That's my best interpretation."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Picasso's Ceramics: Seriously Casual

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
You should have fun with the exhibition of Picasso's ceramic work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Picasso certainly seems to have enjoyed carving this particular notch in his cane of art conquests. That he did so during one of the happiest periods of his life may partly account for the unclouded lightness of these charming figures, wittily decorated plates, casseroles, pitchers, masks and glazed-tile paintings. Perhaps the second-class status traditionally accorded ceramics had a relaxing effect, contributing to the air of genius on holiday, veering in and out of focus, that permeates this show.
The best pieces are utterly transparent. They reduce Picasso's transforming genius to its most basic, accessible components; present his favorite subjects in a medium that seem to fuse painting, sculpture and drawing into a single, fluid process, and reveal another side of his easy familiarity with different artistic periods and styles. The less successful works parody those styles to the brink of kitsch and confirm the careless bravado that Picasso could almost always summon: even on automatic pilot he produced things that were at least Picassos and sometimes only that. And they reiterate his reflexive obsession with the female form. When is a vessel just a vessel? Almost never. 
 By the late 1940's, Picasso was withdrawing from the pressures of Paris and spending more and more time in the south of France, enjoying a brief period of family life with his young mistress, Francoise Gilot. In 1947 they had a son, Claude, and in 1949, a daughter, Paloma. Also in 1947, Picasso began to work at Madoura, the pottery factory of Georges and Suzanne Ramie in Vallauris, near Antibes. Blessed with ground that yielded excellent clay, Vallauris had been an important ceramics-producing center from Roman times to the 1920's, when metal cooking vessels began to replace the traditional earthenware. The Ramies extended the invitation to Picasso partly in the hope that his presence would help revive the town's depressed economy, which it did.
Soon Picasso was spending his summers and more and more of his winters at Galloise, a villa above Vallauris, renting an old perfume factory there as a sculpture studio and, for a decade, even producing linoleum-cut posters for the town's small summer ceramics festival. (They line the reading room in the Met exhibition and have the same offhand liveliness as the ceramics.) His involvement with ceramics, which was most intense during the late 1940's, eventually resulted in more than 3,000 objects that form the only patch of terra incognito remaining on the well-charted continent of his art. It is noteworthy that after his death, every art object in his estate was photographed except the ceramic works, which he owned in abundance. First exhibited around 1950, they were dismissed by influential potters like Bernard Leach in England and viewed with embarrassment by the art world.
"Picasso: Painter and Sculptor in Clay" affords the first extensive look at Picasso's ceramics while refraining from burdening them with undue claims. The show was seen last fall at the Royal Academy in London, where it was organized by a curatorial team that included Claude Picasso and Bernard Ruiz-Picasso, the artist's grandson. Other curators were Norman Rosenthal and Simonetta Fraquelli of the Royal Academy, and Marilyn McCully, a London-based Picasso scholar.
Showcased in the exhibition's opening gallery are works that hint at the range of styles, forms and subjects to come, as well as some of the ups and downs. On view are a large pitcher painted with robust flowers and a serpent in ultramarine and black; a tall, curving vase that Picasso converted into a female torso by adding a bright yellow bikini so crisply Minimal it might have been painted by Alex Katz; a jolly mask that suggests some kind of high-class touristware, and a bright green plate presenting a ceramic fish, fork and lemon slice, a cliche worn thin by the Surrealists and later thinner still by Robert Arneson.
Also here is a bare-to-the-waist draped figure, a little Venus de Milo with arms. And of course there is the artist himself, shown in Attic-style black silhouette on a green and white pitcher, painting and (on the other side) sculpturing from the nude model. In one of the show's better moments of tossed-off brilliance, the throat of the pitcher doubles as clerestory studio windows through which birds and treetops are visible. Such depictive finesse becomes excessive later in the show, in a group of elliptical platters and small bowls whose curves recreate that most macho of Picasso motifs, the bullring, with almost cloying accuracy.
The show has been beautifully installed by William S. Lieberman, the chairman of 20th-century art at the Met and a veteran of many Picasso shows. Happily, nearly everything can be seen in the round. Unhappily, some interesting pieces were not lent to the New York stop, including some early dabblings in ceramics dating from the late 1920's, in which Picasso painted images onto vases made by Jean van Dongen, the brother of the painter Kees van Dongen. Other works were simply trimmed from the display, among them a singularly rugged hybrid sculpture (1950-51) that consists of an earthenware vase embedded in a larger, cruder pitcher made of cast plaster.
At first, Picasso merely added glazed images and decorations to traditional plates thrown on the wheel by the potters at Madoura. Or he cleverly reshaped vases fresh off the potter's wheel, adding a few dents, dots, dashes and wavy black lines to create a woman in a billowing Fortunyesque gown, for example.
But he also began designing zoomorphic pieces, made of combinations of thrown forms that were often innovative departures from ancient jugs and amphoras. These include the reclining kid goat in the show's second gallery, and the man and woman mounted on a bull and a horse. The extended necks of these vessels, with curving arms attached, double as the human figures. The images of these animals are split and splayed ingeniously onto tilted bullet-shaped volumes -- one more round in the continual contest between two- and three-dimensional forms that began with the two-eyed profiles of "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon."
And naturally, Picasso began to rove through history, creating amusing fragments that parody the black and red vases of Classical Greece or depict arcadian fauns and flute players who began to re-enter his art in the 1920's. Most convincing in this category are the regal women inspired by Hellenistic Tanagra figures, who are shown draped in patterned robes.
The rims of certain plates have wonderful details, even when their central images fail to impress: decorative borders suggestive of French peasant pottery, or colored confetti that seems lifted from his own pointillist-flavored Cubist works of the late teens. And of course there are images of Francoise: on one plate she's depicted sentimentally as a doe-eyed beauty, on its neighbor in crude childish scribbles of red and blue punctuated by a sharp-pointed nose. Next to this, her face appears again, this time carved into a mask with powerful volumes and startled eyes. After 1954, there are portraits of Jacqueline Roche, the saleswoman Picasso met in the Remies' workshop, who became his companion and, in 1961, his wife.
While not overburdening Picasso's ceramics with claims of greatness, the exhibition and its catalogue, which includes essays by Claude Picasso, Bernard Ruiz-Picasso and Ms. McCully, also stops short of putting them in an appropriate historical context. But that's fine for now. This show opens new territory. A land-rush of research homesteaders will undoubtedly follow.
One hopes that future scholars will reintegrate Picasso's ceramics into his work as a whole and consider it in relation to the work of his contemporaries in the fields of both art and craft. Some of the ceramic pieces were cast in bronze, but only one example is included here, the gracefully streamlined "Centaur," from 1947-48, which carries a tiny water jug on his back.
How do Picasso's efforts in clay compare with Matisse's sojourn in the applied arts, which resulted in the chapel at nearby Vence? And what was their effect on ceramic art? Despite Bernard Leach's dismissal, a new book on 20th-century English craft by Tanya Harrod states that in the early 1950's, a younger generation of English potters found Picasso's ceramics liberating in their improvisatory high-spiritedness, their modernity and their disdain of function, qualities that provided alternatives to Leach's emphasis on Asian ceramic traditions.
Most interesting of all will be a consideration of their relationship to the work from Picasso's last decade, when his involvement with ceramics decreased and he turned to painting and printmaking, often working in bouts of feverish productivity. Mr. Lieberman has included two of Picasso's late paintings from the Met's collection in the exhibition's final gallery, creating a fascinating coda. Their blending colors and fluid forms could well have been influenced by both the unpredictable melting of glazes in the Madoura kilns and the abandon with which Picasso applied them. It is interesting to think that these untroubled ceramic pieces, intimating a pastoral idyll beneath an eternal Mediterranean sun, might have helped set the stage for the desperate turmoil of the late paintings, which often convey a portrait of the artist staring death in the face and working against the clock.
"Picasso: Painter and Sculptor in Clay" is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, through June 6.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 4; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2256 words

HEADLINE: THEATER GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.
+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth last weekend for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.
++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for performances last Friday night only.
 
Broadway
 
* "DEATH OF A SALESMAN." In the harrowing half-century anniversary revival of Arthur Miller's masterwork, you walk right into the mind of its decimated hero, played with majestic, unnerving transparency by Brian Dennehy. Robert Falls's shadow-shrouded, powerhouse staging never looks down on Mr. Miller's deluded Brooklyn dreamer or looks ennoblingly up to him as a martyr to a success-driven country. Instead, it demands that you experience Willy's suffering without sociological distance, that you surrender to the sense of one man's pain. Yes, there's no avoiding the clunky speechifying and symbolism. But this interpretation is, above all, committed to the work's tragic, conflicted familial love story. Even as it expertly conjures Willy's grimly distorted worldview, the production lets us see clearly his effect on those around him. Led superbly by Elizabeth Franz, who redefines the role of Linda Loman, and Kevin Anderson, as Willy's rudderless elder son, those people express, in highly personalized portraits, the genuine pity and terror given more abstract voice by the choruses of Greek tragedy. (3:00). O'Neill, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $40 to $65; $25 rush tickets may be available the day of show (Ben Brantley). 

*+ "ELECTRA." The foul deeds of "Electra" may have been recorded nearly two and a half millenniums ago, but in this masterly modern-dress version, they are as raw as the lead item off the police blotter. The portrait of a family convulsed by violence and betrayal is so potent and harrowing, it leaves you dazed and weirdly giddy. A daughter plots murder; a mother is butchered; a son is up to his elbows in blood. And you couldn't be more delighted. With the astounding Zoe Wanamaker in the title role, giving the proverbial performance of her career, this "Electra" is the most significant restaging of a classic on Broadway since the revisionist "Doll's House" with Janet McTeer. It's a provocative evening that re-acquaints you with the potent, unprocessed power of Greek drama; you're swept along by the narrative, majestic in its directness and simplicity (1:30). Barrymore, 243 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $35 and $60; student rush tickets available on day of show, $20 (Peter Marks).
 
*+ "NOT ABOUT NIGHTINGALES." Tennessee Williams was 27 and living miserably with his parents when he created this fascinatingly conflicted melodrama, which is only now making its New York debut and has been given a superb Anglo-American production under the direction of Trevor Nunn. "It may be very good or very bad," the young Williams wrote in his journal. "I don't know." It is, in fact, both. The brutal story of a prison hunger strike, "Nightingales" follows the formulas of gritty, behind-bars potboilers from the 1930's. Yet like the play's restive prisoners its author twists and turns within the self-imposed confines of his generic plot, breaking through with an agonized lyricism and empathy for people in cages that's all his own. Led strongly by Corin Redgrave, as an evil warden, and Finbar Lynch, as a self-taught intellectual inmate, the sterling cast matches Williams's compassion with unconditional commitment. And every production detail melds to create an airless universe sapped of color and hope, a world in which death is just one step away and madness even closer (3:00). Circle in the Square, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $60 and $65 (Brantley).
 
*+ "SIDE MAN." In its depiction of a young man struggling to remain the glue in the troubled marriage of his vacant, trumpet-playing father and unbalanced, alcoholic mother, this lovely play has an abiding power. But if you go to "Side Man" expecting tour de force portrayals or actorly pyrotechnics, you're liable to feel as if you've walked into the wrong neighborhood. Go instead for the more refined pleasures of Warren Leight's offbeat story and his true-to-life, as opposed to larger-than-life, characters. The production, directed by Michael Mayer, is a mirror of its Roundabout incarnation, with one important exception: the addition to the cast of the movie actor Christian Slater in the central role of the play's put-upon son and narrator. He delivers a performance that is courageously economical (2:30). Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $25 to $60; student rush, $20 (Marks).
 
Off Broadway
 
* "BEAUTIFUL THING." The generosity of spirit abundantly evident in Jonathan Harvey's script, and the well-matched, down-to-earth performances by Matt Stinton and Daniel Eric Gold are the principal assets of this endearing, lopsided smile of a British comedy about a boy who falls for the boy next door. The production is not without shortcomings, particularly in the attempt to render realistically, a la Mike Leigh, a slice of London life among the hard-pressed and depressed. Yet despite some distractions, "Beautiful Thing" is worth your attention, because even when Gary Griffin's direction falters, Mr. Harvey's characters hold their own. The offbeat love story unfolds so authoritatively, and in such sweet fits and funny starts, that you quickly grow comfortable in the young men's world. And more than that, the young men at the center of the story are teen-agers you're happy to root for (2:00). Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $45 and $47.50 (Marks).
 
++ "CAPTAINS COURAGEOUS." A very dull cruise. Despite a pleasingly uncomplicated performance by Treat Williams as a simple Portuguese fisherman who pulls a spoiled rich boy (Brandon Espinoza) out of the sea, this musical version of the Rudyard Kipling story never picks up much speed. For all its handsome rigging, for all the muscular chanteys and wistful sailing songs by the songwriting team of Frederick Freyer and Patrick Cook, the show itself is rather static and pale; it lacks the sense of momentum and profusion of color that should develop naturally in a musical drama that rides the swells of the Atlantic. The lusty men of the fishing trawler, posed in choirlike formations, sing of their love of the adventure of going to sea, but nothing that happens onstage makes us believe this is so (2:15). Manhattan Theater Club, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 4 P.M. Tickets: $60 (Marks).
 
++ "FAR EAST." A. R. Gurney's uneven but very poignant account of a young American naval officer, Sparky Watts (Michael Hayden) seeking to find (or lose) himself in the Japan of the 1950's. For Mr. Gurney as well as his alter ego Sparky, "Far East" represents a serious bid for escape from the world that has defined him: that of the well-bred WASP. The playwright tries hard to extend his reach, to find in Sparky's coming of age a mirror for America's rediscovering itself after World War II. It's too large a burden for this comedy's slender, gracefully sloped shoulders. Yet what is good here, especially the scenes portraying Sparky's ambivalent friendship with an officer's wife (played to perfection by Lisa Emery), is as good as anything Mr. Gurney has written. Under Daniel Sullivan's first-rate direction the production is a welcome reminder of the appeal of its author's gliding dialogue and structural elegance as well as of the troubled, rueful heart that informs all of Mr. Gurney's work (2:00). Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $55 (Brantley).
 
* "THE HOTHOUSE." Pinter for Pinterphobes. This fractured, little-seen farce from 1958, here given an exemplary production by the Atlantic Theater Company, suggests that the ever enigmatic Harold Pinter could have flourished as a member of Monty Python or "Beyond the Fringe." "The Hothouse" applies the rhythms of old vaudeville routines to the darker complexities of the modern world, in this case represented by a state-run convalescent home. The play has some ham-fisted (and unnecessary) detours into apocalyptic darkness, but like the best of Pinter, it reminds of just how surreal our own everyday reality is, and in doing so, it is criminally good fun. The director Karen Kohlhaas brings the discipline of a military drill to the evening's sublimely unseemly goings-on. And every member of the ensemble, headed by Larry Bryggman as the ultimate clueless man in charge, creates a distinctly individual comic construct while clicking right into the overall Swiss-watch precision (2:00). Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 7 P.M. Tickets: $35 and $40; student rush $10 (Brantley).
 
"THE MINEOLA TWINS." Playing both title roles in this political cartoon of a play by Paula Vogel, the wonderful Swoosie Kurtz gets to show off the highly refined comic exaggeration that first made her name in the New York theater. As the buxom, right-wing Myrna and the flat-chested, left-wing Myra, Ms. Kurtz scores personal, devilish points off familiar archetypes, and what she does with a simple straitjacket is a marvel. Unfortunately, as these characters squabble through four decades of American life, they are never much more than the sums of their slogans and fashion accessories. The production itself, with the resourceful Joe Mantello directing a stylish supporting cast, is first-rate, a sort of pop hymn to the transforming powers of theater. But in manipulating cultural cliches, Ms. Vogel (of the far superior "How I Learned To Drive") usually fails to transcend them, with jokes at least as old as the first season of "Saturday Night Live" (2:15). Laura Pels, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street, (212) 719-1300. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 7:30 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2:30 and 7:30 P.M.; Sundays at 2:30 P.M. Tickets: $55 (Brantley).
 
*+ "THE MYSTERY OF IRMA VEP." Far and away the funniest two hours unfolding anywhere on a New York stage. The revival of Charles Ludlam's 1984 hit, played with a consummate sense of comic timing by that old Ridiculous Theatrical Company hand Everett Quinton and a bright newcomer, Stephen DeRosa, is just about all one could hope for in outrageous Gothic spoofing that incorporates such dainty devices as leering Egyptian mummies, blood-soaked oil portraits and bald men in billowing gowns. Mr. Quinton is priceless as both the insecure lady of the manor and a double-dealing tour guide to the pyramids who turns "sarcophagus" into the most hilarious word in the English-Egyptian dictionary. Mr. DeRosa is splendid as everything from an embittered maid to a swaggering lord of the manor. The quick-change routines alone are worth the trip (2:00). Westside Theater, 407 West 43d Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.; Saturdays at 7 and 10 P.M.; Sundays at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $49.50 (Marks).
 
Long-Running: Broadway
 
Here are summaries of Ben Brantley's and Peter Marks's reviews:
 
*+ "LES MISERABLES." Like a faded fresco lovingly restored, the refurbished version of this Broadway warhorse has regained many of its original colors. Chief among the new assets are excellent cast additions. Still, as in the early days, you barely crack a smile in three hours of gorgeous harmony and pageantry (3:15). Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $15 to $75.
 
+ "MISS SAIGON." Age has both mellowed and invigorated this show. The staging is as sure and crisp as ever; the second-act evacuation scene remains a stunner (2:30). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200. Mondays through Saturdays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays also at 2 P.M. Tickets: $15 to $75.
 
+ "TITANIC." Going under without Leonardo or Celine and, for that matter, without tears. This is the hit musical blueprint of the legendary maritime disaster, a good-looking, cool and efficient piece of narrative that perversely fails to capitalize on its two obvious trump cards, sentimentality and suspense (2:35). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4100. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $45 to $80; $20, for students and the elderly, available on the day of the show at the box office.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Climbed 7.6% In February

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Retailers' sales at stores open at least a year rose 7.6 percent in February, more than expected, as shoppers snapped up basic household goods at discounters like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and new spring fashions at clothing chains like Gap Inc., according to a report released yesterday.
The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi's report for sales at stores open at least a year, a standard industry measure, beat its forecast of a 5.5 percent increase. Wal-Mart's sales rose 10.3 percent, topping the industry leader's plan for a 5 percent to 7 percent gain. Sales rose 12 percent at Gap, whose chains also include Old Navy. 
 Retail sales have exceeded estimates five months in a row as the strong economy, low unemployment and rising wages leave shoppers confident and flush with cash. Spending is expected to stay robust through the first half of the year, analysts said.
"This is a gangbusters economy supported by consumer spending," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo in Minneapolis. "Some retailers are having problems keeping merchandise on the shelves."
Electronics and appliance chains saw strong sales of big-ticket items such as DVD players, satellite televisions and wireless phones. Same-store sales rose 11 percent at the Best Buy Company, the biggest chain, and at the Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack. Circuit City Group said strong sales, including a 12 percent rise last month, would help it exceed fiscal fourth-quarter profit estimates.
February's sales beat the 5.4 percent gain in the month a year ago and was the biggest for the month since 1992, said the Bank of Tokyo, whose sales index includes 83 companies. February is the smallest month of the year for retail sales, according to the National Retail Federation. Same-store sales are a key indicator of a retailer's business because they exclude new, renovated and closed stores.
Wal-Mart's sales gain was its second double-digit increase this year. The Kmart Corporation, the No. 2 discount retailer in the United States, reported a higher-than-expected 5.8 percent increase.
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, whose Target discount chain accounts for about two-thirds of its revenue, said same-store sales rose 8.3 percent.
Among the apparel chains, sales rose 13 percent at the Limited Inc., the biggest specialty clothing retailer, with chains including the Limited and Express. The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation's sales rose 21.4 percent on demand for women's career clothing. Talbots Inc.'s sales fell 7.1 percent, largely because the women's clothing retailer had fewer inventory markdowns to draw shoppers than a year earlier, analysts said.
Shoppers largely overlooked mid-price department stores for the brand names at the more expensive department stores, bargains at the discount chains or clothing styles at specialty chains.
The J. C. Penney Company's department-store sales declined four-tenths of a percent, while Sears, Roebuck & Company's rose eight-tenths of a percent.
Department stores that fared well include Federated Department Stores Inc. and the May Department Stores Company.
Federated, which owns Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other chains, said sales rose 1 percent. Sales at May, which runs the Lord & Taylor, Foley's, Filene's and Hecht's stores, increased 3.7 percent.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

(Source: Goldman, Sachs, based on company reports)

HEADLINE: U.S. Calls China Trade Talks 'Productive'

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 4

 BODY:
After two days of meetings, China and the United States have "made important progress" in defining terms for China to join the World Trade Organization, said the United States' senior trade official. But the official cautioned that there were still significant differences between the countries and "a number of issues remained to be addressed."
"The Chinese Government has exhibited a very serious attitude and strength of purpose that has helped to make this week particularly productive," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, who said that she had met for over two hours with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. 
 Despite the many caveats, Ms. Barshefsky's remarks were by far the most optimistic assessment in many months of China's chances of joining the W.T.O., the Geneva-based organization that sets the rules for international trade. She said that her chief negotiators would remain in the Chinese capital to work on a more detailed plan, although she refused to elaborate on areas of concern.
China has long sought entry into the organization, but on the more lenient conditions offered to third-world countries. The United States has countered that China's economy is too large to be classed among the world's poorest nations.
Just three months ago, Chinese and American officials were saying that membership in the organization was a dead issue this year, convinced that China's current economic slowdown would make it impossible for the country to open its markets to the extent required for membership.
But the prospect of more stringent trade organization entrance requirements in the future, as well as the need for an image-lift before Prime Minister Zhu's visit to Washington next month, have rekindled interest in a deal. Today, Chinese officials seemed determined to make a run at membership in the organization, whatever the short-term economic pains.
Ms. Barshefsky said that two or three months ago, Chinese officials suddenly "indicated that they wished to re-engage in earnest" -- a request that has been followed by a series of negotiations, culminating in Ms. Barshefsky's visit to Beijing this week, "at the request of the Chinese Government."
Some experts say the new enthusiasm is related to the fact that Taiwan, which China regards as a breakaway province, is itself concluding membership negotiations. But a stronger impetus seems to be that the trade organization is expected to redraw the membership requirements this fall at a meeting in Seattle, and many believe that entrance requirements will get stiffer at that time.
"If China doesn't become a member before the Seattle meeting later this year, the issue will drag on for years," said Ji Chongwei, a senior researcher in the central Government's Development and Research Center. "I personally think it is hopeful that China can reach an agreement with the U.S. in the near future."
The need to mend fences before Mr. Zhu's visit to the United States next month has also put pressure on both sides.
The collegial relationship that the United States and China built up through early 1998, culminating with President Clinton's visit last summer, has been deteriorating since late last year, bruised by Beijing's renewed crackdown on political dissidents and other issues.
Although Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright took great pains to promote cordial engagement when she visited here this week, the two sides have exchanged harsh words over human rights, defense policy and technology exchanges in recent months.
In Beijing and Washington, there is hope that progress toward China joining the organization would patch up the facade if not the substance the relationship.
"Both China and the U.S. hope to make some breakthroughs on bilateral relations during Zhu Rongji's visit," said Xue Ning, a researcher at the World Trade Organization Shanghai Research Center, a Chinese Government research agency. "There won't be progress on issues like Taiwan, human rights, Tibet or religious belief. So to make the visit look good, both sides have the incentive to reach some agreement on W.T.O."
It is hard to imagine what kind of deal could emerge or what trade barriers the Chinese would be willing to drop at a time when many factories are idle and laying off millions of workers.
They have until now been extremely reluctant to significantly lower import duties, or to allow foreign companies to operate in such potentially lucrative sectors as insurance, banking and telecommunications.
A 100 percent import duty on foreign cars has insured that middle-class Chinese generally buy tinny domestic models. Many major Western banks and insurers have set up offices in China in the hope that the service sector would soon open, but their representatives now sit idle.
If tariffs were lowered and market access improved, "Chinese companies will lose some share" of the market, Mr. Xue said. But there are potential benefits as well, like greater access to Western markets at a time when China's exports to countries like Japan and Thailand have dried up with the Asian financial crisis.
Many experts say they believe that any deal would have to involve a timetable for the gradual lowering of tariffs and opening of markets over a period of years.
"If this is done overnight, many Chinese industrial sectors won't be able to handle it, since China's state-owned enterprises still have a lot of problems" said Mr. Ji. "This can only be done step by step."
Even if negotiators from the two sides can agree on terms, it remains to be seen if the United States Congress will go along.
Congress, which submits China's most-favored-nation trade status to an annual review, would have to vote to change that practice in order for China to be accepted into the W.T.O, since the organization's 134 members are automatically granted that status.
And at a time when the Senate is criticizing China's human-rights record, Congress will certainly require, at the very least, a solid deal.
"The W.T.O. package will be scrutinized -- it must be real, it must be tangible," Ms. Barshefsky said, adding, "Accession will only occur on commercially viable terms."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Computer IssuesRejuvenated, With Dow Up 191.52

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After weeks of sour news on technology stocks, the sector received a boost yesterday when I.B.M. announced that it had won a $16 billion order from Dell Computer for parts like disk drives and displays.
That news gave the broader market a lift after more than a week of a general slide. But despite the 2 percent jump in the Dow Jones industrial average and the 1.5 percent surge in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the market is still locked in the trading range it has been in since January. 
 "We are stuck in a trading range because we had prices get well ahead of earnings," said Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "Values are stretched so far it will be difficult for the market to make any headway unless interest rates go down."
So far this year, long-term interest rates have jumped more than half a percentage point despite the lowest inflation, according to some measures, in more than 40 years. The reason for the rise has been the refusal of the economy to slow down and the growing concern among investors that the Federal Reserve will have to raise rates to rein in growth.
With today's jobs report for February, investors will get a new indication of how strong the economy still is and, in turn, a signal on whether interest rates will keep rising. The consensus estimate for nonfarm payroll job growth is 245,000.
If the jobs report is stronger than expected, that will probably send interest rates higher. That should put more pressure on stocks because higher rates make their valuations more expensive. But investors, at least for a day, may decide that stronger economic growth will produce enough of a pop in earnings to overcome this drag.
The Dow rose 191.52 points, to 9,467.40. It is 176 points below the record it hit in January and is up only 1.4 percent since last July, when last year's selloff began. The S.& P. 500 climbed 18.94 points, to 1,246.64, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 27.69 points, or 1.22 percent, to 2,292.89. The Russell index of smaller-company stocks finished up 2.07 points at 394.02. While the three other major indexes are up slightly for the year, the Russell is off 6.6 percent.
While the I.B.M. announcement helped lift the broad market, its effect on technology shares was less than might have been expected. And that is because investors continue to have doubts about the outlook after a series of announcements of earnings and sales shortfalls from the likes of Dell, Micron Technology, Compaq Computer and 3Com.
Mr. Cliggott said that a report released yesterday showing that factory orders increased 1.7 percent in January, to a seasonally adjusted $349.6 billion, indicated that the growth trend for semiconductors was still healthy. But the data also showed that the growth rate for the personal computer and telecommunications sectors was slowing, he said.
Shares of I.B.M. finished the day up 4 1/4, to 171. But it was well off its high of 177. Intel rose as high as 117 7/8 in early trading but fell in the afternoon, finishing down 1 5/16, to 113 3/8.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Move Little As Investors Await Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were little changed yesterday, as anxious investors awaited the release of the Government's monthly jobs data today.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32 , to 93 21/32 . Its yield was unchanged at 5.69 percent yesterday. 
 One manager said market participants feared that a number above 250,000 new jobs could scare away many investors and cause the yield on the long bond to rise to last summer's levels, heightening speculation that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates later this year to combat inflation.
But things could go the other way if today's number shows that fewer jobs were added to the economy in February, setting the stage for a rally in the bond market.
A surge in the economy during the first two months of the year has caused credit markets to reassess future monetary policy. And a diminishing flow of flight-to-quality buying has reversed some of the premium priced into bonds.
Though economic fundamentals appear to have turned against bonds, higher rates have also attracted some investors away from equity markets in favor of bonds.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "The fear in the market is really being driven by the seemingly ever- declining weekly initial unemployment claims."
Yesterday, according to the Labor Department, initial claims for state jobless benefits fell by 8,000 in the week ended last Saturday to a seasonally adjusted 286,000. The four-week average of 290,750 is the lowest average in a decade. It was 287,500 on Feb. 24, 1989.
Mr. Donne said the consensus for today's number was about 245,000 jobs created in February, with a range from 200,000 to 300,000. If today's number is under 250,000, he said, the long bond could rally down to a yield of 5.60 percent, but would have trouble declining further without more encouraging news.
"Comments by the Fed chairman recently have pretty much indicated that the central bank is not worried about the liquidity problem of last fall, which was caused by the hedge fund debacles when overseas markets fumbled," Mr. Donne said. "But what they are worried about is an overheated economy and high stock market evaluation."
How much the Fed might do at this month's Federal Open Market Committee meeting on March 30 has already been priced into the market, Mr. Donne said. "The answer is quite a lot," he said.
Some market participants like Mr. Donne say that rates at these levels are high enough to slow the economy.

Europe's Rates Stay Same
 FRANKFURT, March 4 (Bloomberg News) -- The European Central Bank left its interest rates unchanged today, resisting political pressure for a reduction.
As expected, the bank maintained its refinancing rate, a short-term benchmark for the 11-nation euro zone, at 3 percent until its next meeting on March 18. It left its floor deposit rate unchanged at 2 percent and its ceiling marginal-lending rate at 4.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Microsoft to Sell Business Internet Software

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
Projecting a vision of a world in which most buying and selling takes place between machines, the Microsoft Corporation yesterday announced its electronic commerce strategy, a range of software products and services designed to automate business.
Although Microsoft has generally been perceived to be trailing in Internet commerce systems, the company yesterday offered Biztalk, a new language, or a set of conventions, that it said would help draw together disparate business practices and electronic commerce technologies via the Internet. 
 "The Internet is the ultimate market," said William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman and chief executive. "It's great news for businesses because they can reach out to more customers than ever before."
The new approach will offer businesses the ability to configure electronic systems for retail or business-to-business commerce in a "Lego block" approach, Microsoft executives said.
But they did not announce specific product availability dates or prices, saying only that they would be available shortly after the company's much-delayed Windows 2000 operating system, the successor to Windows NT, which is scheduled to be released before the end of the year.
Microsoft also announced Commerce Server version 3.0, a software program designed for Windows 2000.
As part of its new initiative, Microsoft also announced a variety of new business partnerships and the acquisition of Comparenet, a comparison-shopping Web site that it intends to integrate into its MSN Web portal.
Microsoft is trying to turn MSN into a marketplace by offering services that will make it easier for small businesses to build an on-line store.
Industry analysts said that although Microsoft was late and trailed competitors like I.B.M. in the electronic commerce space, the software company's new strategy appeared to be a systematic approach.
"They're definitely late; it's a me-too strategy compared to companies like Yahoo and America Online," said Michael Putnam, a business and technology analyst at Forrester Research Inc., a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass.
He added that the strategy was a good one but suggested that Microsoft might run into resistance from competitors and from its own customers and business partners in its attempt to evangelize a broad standard with the Biztalk language.
"I don't think Biztalk is a good thing," he said. "Standards are critical for the growth of Internet commerce, but this is like General Motors making the traffic rules."
Microsoft executives predicted yesterday that the accelerating pace of electronic commerce would shortly begin to transform some products that have been sold as physical objects into digital information.
Speaking in defense of what he has called "friction free capitalism," Mr. Gates said that products like music and books would increasingly be purchased in electronic form.
"A lot of products that today are in physical form will become digital," he said.
Industry analysts were skeptical that Microsoft would be able to achieve meaningful dominance in electronic commerce markets, because it will have difficulty harnessing broadly used Internet standards to its proprietary software.
The company has chosen to build its Biztalk "framework" around an industry Web standard known as XML, which is being used to connect data bases to the Internet.
"If they're not using industry-standard XML, they're out of luck," said Kimball Brown, a computer industry analyst at Dataquest, a San Jose, Calif., market research firm. "Microsoft is going to have to play by industry rules."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Increases a Key Interest Rate to 45%

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4

 BODY:
The Brazilian central bank raised its benchmark interest rate today to 45 percent and granted its new president expanded powers to adjust rates in an effort to head off a surge of inflation and to stabilize the country's battered currency.
The monetary authority's actions were the first to be taken under Arminio Fraga, a former aide to the financier George Soros. Mr. Fraga was confirmed on Wednesday as central bank president by the Brazilian Senate after an acrimonious debate. At a news conference in Brasilia this afternoon, Mr. Fraga promised a vigorous response to the country's financial crisis, saying his administration would be "pro-active, not reactive." 
 The interest rate increase, from 39 percent, helped steady the Brazilian currency, the real, in trading today. The real has declined in value against the dollar by more than 40 percent since mid-January. After hitting an all-time low of 2.22 to the dollar on Tuesday, the real recovered strongly, closing at 2.07 to the dollar, up 3.9 percent from Wednesday. The stock market also reacted favorably, grateful for any indication that the Government was taking the offensive. Sao Paulo's Bovespa exchange rose 3.9 percent.
In remarks to reporters after announcing the interest rate increase, Mr. Fraga made it clear that his primary goal was to stem the sharp rise in consumer prices brought on by the devaluation of the real. "The exchange rate is important, but what will determine our success or not is the rate of inflation," he said.
With the real under siege, the central bank earlier this week announced, apparently at Mr. Fraga's behest, that banks' compulsory deposit requirements would be raised to 26.5 percent as of Friday and 30 percent later this month. The monetary authority said it was taking that step "to dry up liquidity" and "relieve pressure on the real."
In raising interest rates, Mr. Fraga was adhering to advice profferred by the International Monetary Fund. At a news conference in Washington on Wednesday, the fund's chief economist, Michael Mussa, said that while he hoped Brazilian "interest rates will end up this year substantially lower" than they did in 1998, "if the real continues to depreciate, they will probably need to push up interest rates further."
But not all analysts agree with that approach. In an interview with the Globo News cable channel on Wednesday, Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University professor who has served as an adviser to several emerging countries, argued that Brazil should immediately cut the interest rate to 20 percent in an effort to create jobs and slow the increase of its mounting internal deficit.

HEADLINE: U.S. Starts Push to Salvage Kosovo Talks

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is unleashing what it hopes will be a speedy diplomatic offensive to salvage the Kosovo peace proposal in an effort to avoid a reprise of the last inconclusive round of talks.
The goal was to have a deal ready to sign by March 15, said officials, But they said if that proved too ambitious they hoped at least to have the ethnic Albanians' agreement pinned down by the time the talks are scheduled to resume next week in France and to know exactly where the main impediment to a settlement, the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, stood. 
So far, Mr. Milosevic has stood on the sidelines in Belgrade, building his forces in and around Kosovo and watching as the threat of NATO air strikes against him subsided after the earlier talks in Rambouillet, France. But tonight he put up his first obstacle to the new American offensive.
The Administration has enlisted former Senator Bob Dole, a champion of the ethnic Albanian cause, to go to Kosovo to try to persuade the ethnic Albanians to agree to the settlement that they balked at signing more than a week ago in Rambouillet. Mr. Milosevic has, however, denied Mr. Dole a visa to enter Yugoslavia. He planned instead to have his meetings with ethnic Albanian leaders in Skopje, the Macedonian capital.
Waiting in the wings was a special envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, who, officials said, was asked by the Administration this week to take the settlement, after the ethnic Albanians have signed it, to Mr. Milosevic for approval. The Yugoslav leader has continued to object strenuously to the main element of the plan, deploying 28,000 NATO-led peacekeepers, including 4,000 American soldiers, in Kosovo.
Despite the renewed efforts, the Administration appeared less than certain that the strategy would fall into place.
The plan to tackle Mr. Milosevic as soon as possible cannot get off the ground until agreement is won from the ethnic Albanians, who proved at Rambouillet to be unpredictable.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright indicated the uncertainties tonight after arriving in Indonesia at the end of a three-country trip in Asia.
"We'll have to see whether this process will be successful this time," Ms. Albright said of Mr. Dole's mission at a news conference here. Of the ethnic Albanians, she said, "I don't know when they are going to sign is the answer."
On her first visit to Indonesia as Secretary of State, Ms. Albright has traveled here to encourage the Indonesians to hold free and fair elections on June 7. The first multiparty elections since 1955 occur as Indonesia, the country worst hit by the Asian financial crisis, is undergoing economic and ethnic turmoil.
Hours before Ms. Albright arrived, students who are calling for President B. J. Habibie to resign clashed with baton-wielding police officers in downtown Jakarta.
As Ms. Albright traveled from China to Thailand and now here, Kosovo has remained high on her agenda. It appeared quite likely that if Mr. Dole was successful in his mission that Ms. Albright would change her plans and fly to Brussels to meet him and the Supreme Commander of NATO, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, over the weekend.
Mr. Holbrooke's plans had not been decided, Ms. Albright said tonight.
The Serbian newspaper that is tightly controlled by Mr. Milosevic, Politika, said today that Mr. Holbrooke would arrive in Belgrade "within days."
The likelihood of a swift success by Mr. Dole was cast into doubt by Mr. Milosevic's actions. In the last several weeks his troops have been blocking the borders with Macedonia, which will make it difficult for the ethnic Albanian leaders to slip out of Kosovo.
After the setback at Rambouillet, where the ethnic Albanians rebuffed Ms. Albright and General Clark, the Administration began its concerted campaign to win them over and to work as much as possible before the talks resumed.
Instead of holding the talks at a French air base in Normandy, a situation that could lead to another set of rambling Rambouillet-like negotiations, the Administration was trying to persuade the French to hold the talks in Paris.
The deputy national security adviser, James Steinberg, met the eight-member board of the National Albanian American Council on Wednesday. According to the executive director of the council, Ilir Zherka, that was an effort to insure that the council used its influence to have the leaders of the guerrilla movement in Kosovo sign the agreement.
A main concern of the ethnic Albanians, Mr. Zherka said, was that Mr. Milosevic would be given the opportunity to wring concessions out of the peace plan after the ethnic Albanians had signed it.
Mr. Steinberg reassured the group that if Mr. Milosevic demanded concessions, the ethnic Albanians would have to give their approval or the peace plan would be dead, Mr. Zherka said. "If the Albanians say no to changes, then that's the end of it," Mr. Zherka quoted Mr. Steinberg as having said.
Mr. Dole sought a commitment from Ms. Albright that if he won an agreement from the ethnic Albanians that the plan would not be subject to the whims of Mr. Milosevic, according to Mira Baratta, a senior adviser to Mr. Dole.
In a telephone conversation with this morning, Ms. Albright told Mr. Dole that there could be no "material" changes to the peace plan by Mr. Milosevic, Ms. Baratta said.
Mr. Dole, who has been sympathetic to the ethnic Albanians since visiting Kosovo in 1990 and seeing the Serbian repression there, will be accompanied by a senior State Department official, Jim O'Brien, and a general from the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Ms. Baratta said.
Mr. O'Brien, a lawyer who has been involved in the fine print of the peace proposal, will be taking with him a document ready for signing. The proposal calls for a three-year interim period of autonomy for Kosovo, now a province of Serbia, and for the withdrawal of Serbian forces and the demilitarization of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army.
Mr. Dole plans to meet the leadership of the guerrilla movement, as well as civilian leaders who represent a broad spectrum in Kosovo. Mr. Dole would meet Hashim Thaci, the leader of the ethnic Albanian delegation at Rambouillet who, the Kosovo Liberation Army announced this week, would be the prime minister of an unofficial provisional government.
Mr. Thaci was the holdout at Rambouillet, refusing to sign the peace proposal, apparently because it did not include a referendum on independence after three years. A referendum, which is anathema to Mr. Milosevic, would undoubtedly result in an overwhelming victory for supporters of independence.
"Senator Dole would like the plan signed as soon as possible, because the delay is taking the pressure off Milosevic," Ms. Baratta said. "It's his intention to walk away with the signatures."
As an inducement to sign the plan, the Administration invited members of the Kosovo Liberation Army to go to Washington next week for talks on how the United States could establish relations with the little-understood group.

HEADLINE: Pataki and Giuliani Pick Hudson River Park Board Members

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed board members yesterday to govern a new park to be built along the Hudson River, ending a six-month delay that park advocates feared was jeopardizing the park's progress.
The appointments mean that the Hudson River Trust will automatically come into existence in 30 days. It will be responsible for the planning, design, construction, operation and continuing maintenance of the four-and-a-half-mile Hudson River Park, which will stretch from Battery Park City to 59th Street and will include piers, an esplanade with a bicycle trail and extensive landscaping. 
 "This park is the most important open space project for New York City since the creation of Central Park," the Governor said.
Park advocates had been increasingly critical of Mr. Pataki for delaying his appointments despite his strong backing of the park during his re-election campaign. The law defining and protecting the new park was passed in June, but the Governor waited until September to sign it. And he waited until yesterday to name board members, a delay that his staff has insisted was necessary to find the best candidates.
Park advocates have complained that the delay meant sacrificing cost savings that could have come from constructing the park simultaneously with the reconstruction of the adjacent highway, Route 9A. They have also said that a strong voice from the park board is needed in numerous land-use decisions all along the park.
"Now, we can move forward, and we need to move forward promptly," said Albert K. Butzel, chairman of the Hudson River Park Alliance, a coalition of 35 environmental and civic groups in favor of the park.
The Governor appointed James A. Ortenzio, who has been serving as chairman of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, as the chairman of the new panel. The Mayor and the Governor will alternate in filling the top post. Mr. Ortenzio, a major fund-raiser for both Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani, owns the Long Island Beef Company in Greenwich Village directly opposite the park.
The Mayor appointed Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and Planning, to be vice chairman. Mr. Levine, whose experience includes working as a labor negotiator for Major League Baseball, has been shepherding planning in City Hall for the park.
Mayor Giuliani said the park would "bring a world-class waterfront park to the neighborhoods on the West Side and to millions of New Yorkers."
The Governor's other appointments to the board included Theodore Roosevelt 4th, a managing director of Lehman Brothers who is active in environmental organizations and enjoys kayaking on the Hudson. The others were Diane Taylor, a former gubernatorial aide who is now vice president of Keyspan Energy, and two current officials in his administration, John P. Cahill, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, and Bernadette Castro, the State Parks Commissioner.
The Mayor's other appointments were Georgette Mosbacher, a top Republican fund-raiser; Richard Schwartz, a former mayoral adviser and parks official; Joseph B. Rose, Planning Commissioner, and Henry J. Stern, Parks Commissioner.
Earlier, the Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, announced that her three appointments would be Franz S. Leichter, the former State Senator who fought for years for the park's creation, and two longtime advocates for the park, Madelyn Wils and Julie Nadel.
In an interview, Mr. Ortenzio denied that there had been a significant break in the momentum and expressed doubt that savings could have been achieved by proceeding with the road and the park simultaneously. He said this could have spawned enormous traffic jams. "And, really, the new highway is going quite nicely," he said.
He also promised to run a cost-efficient operation, perhaps even using an old bus or construction trailer for the trust's offices. "Keep it cheap, keep it clean," he said. "No big staff, no high expenses."
