HEADLINE: With Its Deal for Level One, Intel Seeks New Area of Growth

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., March 4

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation agreed today to buy Level One Communications Inc. for $2.11 billion in stock as it pushes into the fast-growing market for chips used in networking equipment.
Each share of Level One stock is to be exchanged for 0.43 share of Intel stock. That values Level One at $48.75 a share, an 80 percent premium to today's closing price of $27.125. Intel will issue 18.6 million shares for the purchase. 
 Buying Level One gives Intel products for a part of the semiconductor industry that has been growing faster than its traditional processor market, which is slowing along with personal computer sales. Intel's shares have fallen 16 percent in the last week and a half amid concern about sluggish personal computer sales and increasing competition from a rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc.
"With the core PC market slowing, they need to look for other growth opportunities," said Ashok Kumar, an analyst at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, who rates Intel a strong buy.
In the next three years, sales of communications chips are expected to rise twice as fast as sales of microprocessors, which provide most of Intel's revenue, according to the market researcher Dataquest Inc.
Level One's chips, which have built-in communications features, are used by most large network-equipment makers to reduce the cost of their products.
Intel has been building more communications features into its chips and sells its own networking products.Those products now contribute less than 10 percent of the company's $26 billion in annual revenue, though the company said it would look for more networking purchases.
"We're continuing to look for other acquisition candidates," said Craig R. Barrett, Intel's chief executive.
The purchase of Level One, which is based in Sacramento, Calif., comes after Intel agreed to buy the Shiva Corporation, an Internet-equipment maker, for $185 million in October.
Level One and Intel already work together in a partnership formed last summer. The two are developing chips for controllers that send data over corporate networks using high-speed copper wiring. The first products from that partnership are not expected until late 1999 or early 2000.
Mark Christensen, vice president of Intel's networking unit, said that the company had no plans to sell networking products to large corporations or phone companies and would instead focus on equipment for small businesses.
Level One gets about 60 percent of its revenue from the repeaters, transceivers and other chips used in so-called Ethernet switches, the most widely used equipment for linking PC's to corporate networks. The remainder comes from chips used in equipment for high-speed Internet access.
Because Level One and Intel both make chips used in PC connector cards, the combined company "will have overlap issues in some product areas," said Ken Pearlman, an analyst at CIBC Oppenheimer.
Some Level One chips are used by top networking companies like Cisco Systems Inc. and the 3Com Corporation in low-cost equipment that competes with Intel's networking equipment.
Still, Robert S. Pepper, Level One's president and chief executive, said the purchase would not affect the company's original equipment manufacturer agreements with Cisco, 3Com and others.
Shares of Intel fell $1.3125, to $113.375. Level One fell $5.25, to $27.125, before trading was halted. The announcement was made after the close of regular trading.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Up Nearly 200 Points As I.B.M. Lifts Stocks
After weeks of sour news on technology stocks, the sector received a boost when I.B.M. announced that it had won a $16 billion order from Dell Computer for parts like disk drives and displays. Despite the increase, the market is still locked in the trading range it has been in since January. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 191.52 points, or 2 percent, to 9,467.40. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.94 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,246.64, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 27.69 points, to 2,292.89. In the bond market, Treasury securities were little changed. Page C6.
 
Funds Grumble About Olivetti Bid
Olivetti has yet to begin its formal $60 billion bid for Telecom Italia, but large British and American investment funds are complaining that as the biggest shareholders in the target company they may be getting a bad deal. C4.
 
Retail Sales Increase 7.6%
Retailers' sales at stores open at least a year rose 7.6 percent in February, more than expected, as shoppers snapped up basic household goods at discounters like Wal-Mart Stores and new spring fashions at clothing chains like Gap. Among the apparel chains, Ann Taylor Stores posted a sales increase of 21.4 percent, lifting its shares $2.75, to $41.75. C2.
 
Bank Legislation Seems in Trouble
House and Senate committees took action on sharply conflicting bills to eliminate Depression-era barriers between banks, securities firms and insurance companies, reducing the chances that Congress will pass major banking legislation this year. C4.
 
Microsoft Breakup Proposed
The nation's largest software-industry trade group has warned the Government not to impose sanctions on Microsoft that could "fracture" Windows' role as an industry standard if the company loses its antitrust suit. But a report by the group recommends that the Government consider breaking up Microsoft as a cure for what the report regards as the lack of competition in the software industry. C2.
 
Microsoft announced its electronic commerce strategy, which includes software and services designed to automate business. C2.
 
Intel to Buy Chip Maker Level One
Intel agreed to buy Level One Communications for $2.2 billion in stock as it pushes into the fast-growing market for chips used in networking equipment. C18.
 
Brazil Raises Interest Rate
The Brazilian central bank raised its benchmark interest rate to 45 percent and granted its new president expanded powers to adjust rates in the future to head off inflation and stabilize the country's battered currency. C4.
 
Rare Coins Go Back to Turkey
The investor William I. Koch handed a trove of ancient Greek coins to the Turkish Government. Officials said the coins, which were issued around 465 B.C. and which Mr. Koch bought more than a decade ago, had been illegally removed from their country. C4.
 
Miller Lite Campaign Halted
Miller Brewing is making an abrupt about-face by ending a campaign for the flagging Miller Lite beer brand that attempted to appeal to younger consumers with offbeat entertainment. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.

HEADLINE: Building Fame for $15 a Head;
For the Hip-Hop Set, the Local Celebrity Is the Barber

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
His name is on the lips of the hip-hop set in Sunset Park. The teen-agers in the baggy pants and Michelin Man jackets up and down Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn know Pedro Quinones, though not as Pedro Quinones. They know him as Casper, the sultan of the shape-up, the master of the Number One Fade, the quick answer to the bad hair day.
He is only 19, not yet finished with high school, but he seems to understand that hype is as important as haircuts for his chosen profession. His nickname is emblazoned across the windshield of his 1990 Oldsmobile. The clients who walk down the steps into his gritty Fourth Avenue shop, Casper's Cuts, are greeted by a floor-to-ceiling painting of Casper's cherubic face, a tribute courtesy of a customer from Canada known as Virus. 
 "Casper is the man!" proclaimed Andre Padilla, 18, a patron who came from Staten Island on Wednesday afternoon, one of a stream of teen-agers passing through the shop, some of them from Queens or distant points in Brooklyn, all of them coming just to place their heads in Casper's chubby hands.
Few loyalties are more sacred than the one between customer and stylist. In Manhattan, where money and vanity flow in equally deep streams, hairstylists have been vaulted to celebrity status by their female clientele, and charge the fees to prove it. Frederic Fekkai, the decade's premier celebrity stylist, charges upward of $300 for haircuts at his salon on East 57th Street. Clients at the John Sahag salon on Madison Avenue pay $275 just so a stylist will blow their hair dry in a way that creates the straight, sleek look.
But for men -- whose stylists are no longer just barbers -- the same cults of celebrity extend beyond the salons of Manhattan, even if the prices and the glamour do not. Ask the teen-agers gathered in Casper's ground-level shop if their barber has a rival, and they will scoff at the suggestion.
Customers interviewed in Brooklyn neighborhoods like Bay Ridge, Fort Greene and Sunset Park profess equal loyalty to their barbers. Some customers will follow a stylist from shop to shop for years. Others carry their stylists' beeper numbers. Some barbers make house calls for less than $30. Usually, the price of a cut is about $15 or less.
Loyalty, however, does not always extend to the relationships between stylists and their shops. Last week, a barber in Queens, Manuel Heredia, was shot to death inside his shop. The police said he had been arguing with barbers at a new shop that had lured away two of his employees. The owner of the rival shop and another man have been charged with second-degree murder.
How could such a violent end come between two men in such a genteel business? The murder did shock many barbers, but the root of the problem did not.
"It didn't surprise me with the fact that it was competitive and there was a beef between them," said Jose Nunez, a stylist with his own following at New York Style in Bay Ridge. "They did the same kinds of hairstyles and had the same types of customers. That doesn't surprise me at all."
Like rock musicians who begin their careers by playing in a garage, many barbers begin as teen-agers hacking away on cousins, siblings and friends, developing a following they often take with them when they move to a real shop after earning a license. With so many heads in New York City in need of grooming, barbers often enjoy the sort of low unemployment and ego gratification that brings a transience to the trade.
Whether because of spats over personality or money, or even a fit of artistic pique, many barbers say they are not at all fearful of changing locales.
"We're more like free agents," said Bert Calderon, 26, who works with Mr. Nunez in Bay Ridge, his fourth shop in about five years. "But we're unrestricted. As long as we're happy, and you don't get on our nerves, we're all good."
David Jenkins, 32, owns Legends II, a Fort Greene barber shop directly across Fulton Street from another barber shop, Barber's World. Sitting in the shop was Tom Colman, 54, who regularly travels from Manhattan because he trusts the way Mr. Jenkins cuts his fade hairstyle, shaving it close to the skin on the sides and letting it rise to a neat platform of hair on top.
With such loyal customers, Mr. Jenkins said there is plenty of business for all shops. But to stay competitive, he makes house calls for certain customers. He said he is careful when he hires younger barbers. He scouts barbering schools for new talent, keeping abreast of the latest styles, and he tries to find barbers who seem responsible and willing to stay put, knowing that they may not.
"Each barber is his own business," said Mr. Jenkins, who rents chairs to barbers for $150 a week.
The relationship between shop owners, usually older barbers trained to cut with scissors, and younger stylists, who build followings by shaving haircuts like fades with a razor and electric clippers, is mutually dependent, if delicate and often prickly. Margarito Flores, 59, owns two barber shops in Sunset Park and has been in business for 30 years. Aware that the young stylists bring in the young clients, Mr. Flores said he hires them. But rather than hire just one, he said he hires three -- to protect himself.
"There would probably be a problem if I lost all three at once," he said through a translator, Ruben Carrero, 27, who as it turns out has been coming to Mr. Flores for 20 years.
Sal Mannino, the owner of Astor Place on 77th Street in Bay Ridge, once hired Mr. Nunez. Now, Mr. Nunez works around the corner at New York Style. No hard feelings, Mr. Mannino said. Barbering, he said, is about talent and charisma. "They know only one haircut," he said. "The skin fade. That's it. So to me, that's not threatening."
Perhaps it is not surprising that anyone who earns a living scraping a razor across another man's neck must not only inspire confidence, but also have it. "If you're good," Mr. Calderon said, "you don't have to worry about competition. Once somebody sits down in my chair, it's rare they don't come back."
But Mr. Calderon's ego is not so inflated that he is blind to the betrayals of the profession. He said he once left a shop for a week, thinking it was temporarily closed, only to discover that the shop owner was stealing his clients. Now, he keeps a Rolodex of his clients beside his bottles of mousse, and he also sends out Christmas cards.
Working at the next chair, Mr. Nunez, 22, bent over a customer, shaving a fade with the languid confidence of a man fully aware of his own worth. He said he could recall several fistfights between competing stylists, though never a homicide like the one in Queens. Talent, he says, is the best form of occupational insurance.
"I've got kids who go to college as far away as North Carolina," Mr. Nunez said. "They won't get their hair cut until they come back home."
There are, of course, men who walk into whatever barber shop is nearby and make an appointment with whichever barber is available.
Not Vic Perez. He arrived Wednesday afternoon at Casper's Cuts. He had already gotten a "shape-up," the barbering equivalent of a tuneup, from his regular barber, Steven.
Mr. Perez, 21, said he gets one shape-up and one haircut every week for a total of $22. He will not leave Steven, not even for Casper, but he stopped in because he described himself as a "barber shop hopper," eager to listen to or start the chatter famous at barber shops.
Mr. Perez described his current haircut as a "pretty thug" look, meaning that he can dress it up or dress it down. If he goes on a date, he might get a Caesar, a stylish, modulated look. "Having your hair is like an attitude," he said. "Your hair shows who you are."
In the middle of the chatter, Casper works without talking or lifting his eyes from his work. His sidekick, Angelo Rivera, 16, takes customers in the second chair. Mr. Rivera said he used to cut hair at home, punching a hole in a garbage bag and using it as a cape to keep hair off the floor and the customer. Casper charges $8, and he says his clients include tow truck drivers and police officers. He is saving money, planning for the day when he can buy a building, maybe even a beauty supply business. He wants to be the shop owner and the stylist, like Frederic Fekkai, even if he has never heard of him.
"People see me as young. They think I'm a drug dealer," he said, attributing the attitudes mostly to his souped-up car. "They just assume the worst. They assume I got the money the wrong way."
But he admits that he likes the attention that comes to him because of his barbering. When he goes to the local McDonald's, children whisper his name. Cars stop in front of his shop, and drivers shout hellos.
"Yeah," Casper said, "I like the attention. It feels good. It's better than nobody knowing me."

HEADLINE: Unstable Autocracies in Central Asia

 BODY:
A series of car bombs recently exploded at the Government's headquarters in Uzbekistan's capital, Tashkent, killing 16 people. They narrowly missed the country's leader, Islam Karimov -- a sign that the stability provided by the dictators of Central Asia and the Caucasus can be quickly upended.
Since the breakup of the Soviet Union, stability has been the West's primary goal for these countries. The region borders such trouble spots as Afghanistan and Iran. It is also sitting on bountiful oil and gas reserves. While the United States has criticized the local leaders for their autocratic ways, it has treated them as partners, on the theory that their rule provides a stable climate for oil and gas investment. But the attempt on Mr. Karimov, and the failing health of President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan, are reminders that autocratic rule could give way to instability when the dictators die. 
 Most of the leaders in the region have focused all politics around loyalty to themselves and blocked the development of political institutions. There are few serious political parties, parliaments or courts and no mechanisms for a peaceful transition of power. The most democracy is found in Georgia and Kyrgyzstan, and the least in Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, the most populous nation.
Many of the leaders encourage potentially volatile clan politics. Under Soviet rule, Central Asian republics were tightly controlled by Communist leaders appointed by Moscow -- many of whom are now their nations' presidents. They once relied on a network of local state farm and provincial bosses. Today these same men head territorial mafias that control jobs and government benefits. Virtually all Central Asia's strongmen favor a particular mafia or clan -- crucial in countries where such ties determine who gets rich.
Repression of religion is another practice that could cause future unrest. In Uzbekistan, the independent practice of Islam is banned, and President Karimov has closed hundreds of mosques in the last year. The crackdown on Islam has politicized the expression of religion and turned it into an outlet for protest against poverty and corruption.
While all the dictators claim to welcome foreign investment, most will not institute market reforms or anti-corruption measures that might stimulate economic growth. Mr. Karimov, for example, has lost foreign investment and International Monetary Fund loans because he continues to control access to hard currency. He does so to reward friends by allowing them to buy foreign currency cheaply, which they can then resell for huge profits. Instead of building stability through economic growth and the construction of political institutions, Central Asia's dictators count on smothering dissent. That kind of artificial, temporary stability often ends in explosive unrest.

HEADLINE: Where's the Outrage Over Taxes?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire (column, March 1) is wrong when he asserts that Social Security is not helped by keeping part of the surplus for Social Security instead of cutting taxes. He notes that the Social Security Trust Fund lends its money to the Treasury. But if there were a tax cut instead, the trust fund would have less to lend to the Treasury, and the Treasury would need to borrow more from the public. If the public lends more to the Treasury, it invests less in stocks, bonds and deposits, resulting in less investment and lower economic growth. 
 In the future, when Social Security needs more money, the trust fund has the return on its additional assets and the possibility of selling bonds back to the Treasury. Compared with a tax cut, this does not hurt the Treasury.
 
PETER DIAMOND
Lexington, Mass., March 2, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS' PLAN WOULD KEEP MONEY IN SOCIAL SECURITY

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
The Republican leaders of Congress agreed today on the broad outlines of a budget plan that they said would immediately wall off Social Security funds so that they could not be used to pay for tax cuts or new Government spending.
The budget framework for fiscal year 2000, hammered out in days of closed-door meetings among senior House and Senate Republicans, would adhere to the stringent spending limits enacted in the balanced-budget agreement reached two years ago by President Clinton and Congress. And it would provide for a relatively small tax cut in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 that would grow to a cut of as much as $800 billion over the next decade. 
 "We think we have a package that is historic," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee. "For the first time we are making the argument that Government should not take any of the money that comes in for our senior citizens."
The outline represents the Republicans' effort to avoid the feuding and disarray of last year and sets the stage for a battle with Mr. Clinton over fiscal policy in an age of windfall surpluses.
The Republicans' plan is also intended to protect them from charges by Mr. Clinton and Democrats that they would use Social Security money to finance tax cuts for the wealthy. In fact Republicans hope that their plan will prove an impediment to Democrats, leaving them open to accusations that they are raiding Social Security if they want to increase domestic spending.
But the plan will force Republicans to give up their hopes of enacting a large tax cut before the 2000 election year. While the numbers for the budget outline were still being assembled, Republicans said the tax cut in the 2000 fiscal year would be about $10 billion to $15 billion.
The budget agreement will also require the House and Senate Republicans to make billions of dollars in spending cuts to stay within the budget limits set in 1997.
This will not be easy. For years money brought into the Government through Social Security taxes has been used to mask the true size of the Federal deficit and to pay for spending programs unrelated to retirement.
In the 2000 fiscal year, for example, the Congressional Budget Office has projected a surplus of $133 billion. But if Social Security funds are subtracted from the totals, the Government will actually have a deficit of $5 billion.
Mr. Kasich and Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, acknowledged that they still had to sell the blueprint to their rank and file. Some moderates could oppose the cuts in domestic spending the plan would necessitate. The two men hope to report the budget plan out of their committees later this month.
The White House tonight signaled that simply setting aside Social Security money would not be enough to satisfy Mr. Clinton. "Their plan still is nearly $700 billion short for Medicare," said Gene Sperling, the senior White House economic adviser. "And it's not clear whether they extend the life of Social Security a single day, or how they could put together a budget that would not lead to significant reductions in areas like education, environment and health care."
The Republicans countered that they were actually doing more to safeguard Social Security than Mr. Clinton's proposals would. Mr. Domenici cited a study by the Congressional Budget Office that said the President's budget would save only 58 percent of next year's Social Security surplus.
"He's running around saying he's the one saving Social Security," Mr. Domenici said. "If saving the trust fund and not spending it is the test, we're 100 percent pure, and he's 58 percent pure."
The Republican agreement today came as the party's Congressional leaders made a determined effort to avoid the mistakes of last year, when Mr. Clinton first proposed that surpluses be set aside to ensure the solvency of the Social Security trust fund for the baby boom generation.
His stand left Republicans divided over whether to save the surplus or enact large tax cuts. The House and Senate never enacted an agreed-upon budget plan.
The result was that President Clinton won increases in education spending and other domestic spending in a last-minute spending bill just before the election. Republicans lost any leverage because they were afraid of being accused once again of provoking a shutdown of the Government.
The move to wall off Social Security funds immediately was promoted by Mr. Domenici, who wanted to blunt any charges by Democrats that Republicans were raiding the popular Federal retirement program. Under the plan the Social Security surplus -- expected to reach 1.8 trillion over the next decade -- can be used for debt reduction or else for an eventual Social Security overhaul. To spend the surpluses any other way would require 60 votes in the Senate.
The proposal was initially resisted by Mr. Kasich, who had wanted to phase in such a plan over several years, in order to be able to dip into the surplus for a little bit longer. That would have made it easier for Republicans to craft a large tax cut as the centerpiece of an election year agenda.
But Republicans said that Mr. Kasich was ultimately pleased with the decision to stay within the budget limits set in the balanced budget law, despite pressure for more spending. And he took satisfaction in the Senate's agreement to a phased-in tax cut.
Republicans said their plan would also live within next year's spending limit of about $550 billion for discretionary spending in domestic and military programs. They said they would accomplish this while also raising military spending. Even if programs are frozen at this year's levels, Congress will still have to make savings of about $15 billion because of inflation. And that is before increases in military and education spending, which both parties want, are taken into account. There was no suggestion today where in the budget members of either party would turn to make cuts.
Mr. Kasich and Mr. Domenici did not say what kind of tax cut the Republicans would enact and the budget resolution is usually silent on that question, leaving it up to Congress' tax-writing committees to decide that later in the year. Republicans are deeply divided over whether to pursue an across-the-board, 10-percent tax cut, whether to enact tax credits for various social purposes, or whether to pursue other tax reductions, like a cut in the so-called marriage penalty.
One option that might make it easier for Republicans to stay within the budget caps, several Republicans said, would be for them to enact a tax cut, like a reduction in the capital gains tax, which they say could initially bring in more Government revenue by spurring economic activity.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Jim Crow Past Haunts a Life Lived in Exile

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
PEGGY KING JORDE has lived and worked in New York City for the last 18 years, but a piece of her heart has stayed in her hometown of Albany.
That's Albany, Ga., mind you, not the place up the Hudson. In that corner of southwestern Georgia, some will tell you that they're from Ahl-BEN-ny. Not Ms. King Jorde, who has been Yankeefied enough to pronounce it the same as anyone else from these parts. 
 "There is so much of myself that's still rooted in Albany," said Ms. King Jorde, who directs the Federal Government's African Burial Ground project in lower Manhattan. "I do consider myself a Southerner. It's a culture I'm very proud of."
But her pride does not extend to racially charged features of that culture, which have caused her family great pain since the late 1950's, when Jim Crow ruled the South and Ms. King Jorde's father, C. B. King, led the nascent civil rights movement in Ahl-BEN-ny. This tale, though, is really about her uncle, Preston King, who teaches political philosophy at Lancaster University in northern England.
For nearly four decades, Preston King has lived abroad, unwilling to come back for fear of being arrested on an old criminal conviction that he and others consider racially based. But he turned 63 this week, and sees time slipping away. He would like, however briefly, to go home again.
This is, admittedly, more a story about Georgia than New York, but some New Yorkers are key figures in an appeal to Washington to make Mr. King's return possible. Besides his niece, they include Elizabeth Holtzman, the former Congresswoman and Brooklyn District Attorney, who is a longtime friend of the King family. Last month, she met with the Deputy Attorney General of the United States, Eric H. Holder Jr., to see what could be done.
"I know he's sympathetic to us," Ms. Holtzman said. "But being sympathetic is one thing, and doing something is another." Thus far, the Justice Department has promised only to re-examine the case, which runs like this:
In the mid-1950's, the draft board in Albany approved a student deferment so that Mr. King could pursue a master's degree at the London School of Economics. Board letters to him began, "Dear Sir." It was all done by mail -- quite routine.
BUT one day in 1958, back from London, Mr. King called on the board in person. That's when the clerk there saw he was black. From then on, the letters were addressed "Dear Preston." To Mr. King it was about the same as being called "boy." He refused to respond.
"This had to do with keeping black people under control," he said by phone from Lancaster, an English accent poking through every vowel. "Understand my perspective. The board is entirely white. Everything around you is segregated by law. It's part of the air you breathe. And the cherry on the cake is this disrespect shown to people who bear the status of otherness."
While not "dying to serve in the Army," he was prepared to go, he said. All he wanted was to be called "Mister." That did not happen.
Mr. King lost his deferment, and was ordered in those pre-Vietnam War days to report for his Army physical. After he kept ignoring "Dear Preston" letters, he was charged with draft evasion, convicted in Federal court in 1961 and sentenced to 18 months in prison. Rather than go to jail, he jumped bail and fled the country.
"It would have been an absurdity to surrender," he said. "It doesn't have any sensible bite to me. It doesn't have any moral bite."
After studying and teaching in Africa and in Australia (he now has Australian citizenship), Mr. King settled in Lancaster in 1986. He has made a good life for himself in England. His daughter, Oona, is a member of Parliament. But Georgia keeps beckoning. There are nieces and nephews to see, and family graves to visit.
Beyond New York voices like those of Ms. King Jorde and Ms. Holtzman, the chorus for laying old Southern ghosts to rest is growing. Television networks have done stories. The Albany City Commission passed a resolution urging a Presidential pardon or amnesty to "correct a travesty of justice." Even the Federal judge who sentenced Mr. King, William A. Bootle, now 96 and long retired, has said that a white man would not have been put on trial.
To Mr. King, it is up to the Government to wipe the race slate clean. "If you want to expunge the past," he said, "then you must reverse one of the consequences of that past."

HEADLINE: El Al at a Turning Point;
A Mirror of Israel's Divisions Prepares to Go 49% Public

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr.

DATELINE: LOD, Israel, Feb. 26

 BODY:
As airline employees cheered, the shiny Boeing 737, a blue Star of David freshly emblazoned on its tail, touched down at Ben Gurion International Airport here, the first of eight new Boeing jets that El Al, the Israeli international flag carrier, is acquiring this year.
This $600 million fleet upgrade, the biggest aircraft investment in El Al's history, is the most visible and costly part of a campaign to prepare the airline to sell stock to private investors as early as April. With a redesigned logo, chic new uniforms and an income statement modestly in the black after recurring state-subsidized losses, El Al is trying hard to become what Tom Schick, executive vice president at Boeing, called in a visit here "a new, aggressive and customer-focused airline." 
 Like Israel itself, El Al is 50 years old, proud of a pioneering past and a proven ability to survive, even thrive, in adversity. Also like Israel, the airline must cope with deep divisions, both political and cultural, as it strives to compete as an equal in the world market, without compromising its security or special national identity.
Private ownership and private management are the keys to El Al's economic future, its executives say, taking their cue from dozens of other state airlines that have been converted into commercial enterprises in recent years. But El Al Israel Airlines Ltd. is no ordinary airline, and selling it is no ordinary marketing challenge.
Its history as a terrorist target has made it perhaps the most security-conscious carrier in the world. Every flight has its own undercover armed guard. Nearly every pilot is a former Israeli Air Force officer. At home and abroad, baggage inspections and pre-flight security checks are carried out in deadly earnest, with the company's own state-of-the-art equipment and specially trained personnel. Aircraft like the new 737's are fitted at company hangars with classified Israeli security hardware.
All this adds $70 million to $100 million a year to operating costs, El Al officials say. That is a daunting sum for a company that generates about $1.2 billion in annual revenues. Under state ownership, about two-thirds of this expense has been absorbed by Israeli security agencies, but the Government and El Al management are now debating how these costs should be shared, and calculated, once El Al is no longer wholly owned by the Government.
"This comes with a price tag," said Joseph Ciechanover, the chairman of El Al, "and the costs and the responsibility for the costs must be stated clearly, up front, in the prospectus."
Then there is the Sabbath.
As is the case with the rest of its planes, El Al cannot fly its expensive new Boeing jetliners from Friday evening to Saturday night, or on eight other sundown-to-sundown Jewish holidays. The Sabbath restriction was imposed in 1982 when the rightist government of Menachem Begin wrested control of the ailing company from its union. The company was restructured as the designated national carrier, with a pared-down work force and a guaranteed monopoly on international air freight and scheduled passenger flights.
Keeping its fleet grounded on the Sabbath costs the company some $36 million yearly in potential net earnings, according to a study conducted for El Al three years ago by the Boston Consulting Group. That is a make-or-break figure for a company that posted losses of $83 million in 1996 and $4 million in 1997, before turning a profit in 1998 that was estimated at $25 million.
"The Sabbath is more than 24 hours," Mr. Ciechanover said in an interview at the company's utilitarian headquarters at Ben Gurion airport. "Take our flights to New York. We fly overnight Thursday, land early Friday morning and stay there on the ground until late Saturday night. That is 20 percent of our workweek.
"This is a Jewish state," he continued, "and it is understandably important to many people that the designated national carrier be respectful of the Sabbath. But the cost is very high."
Part of that cost is an inability to compete at all in critical weekend tourist traffic. In a society with a six-day workweek, flights on Friday nights or Saturdays are the first preference of the secular vacationer. Foreign airlines now offer more than 80 regularly scheduled international flights to and from Ben Gurion on Saturday alone. Small private domestic airlines, not bound by Sabbath strictures, do a busy weekend resort trade.
The Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, having promised to privatize the airline when it came to power two and a half years ago, is now scrambling to sell 49 percent of the company on the Tel Aviv stock exchange before the next national elections on May 17. But some officials say the sale, which analysts estimate will set a market value for the airline of as much as $250 million, may be delayed until after an expected runoff election on June 1 for Prime Minister.
The Government has backed away from longstanding plans favored by management to sell majority control to private investors, including a big international airline as a strategic partner. The Netanyahu Government also shelved plans to put El Al's initial stock offering on the market in the United States.
"I am very much for floating shares abroad," Mr. Ciechanover said. "Markets in New York would be better than Tel Aviv at evaluating an airline company. But it's better to get this process going. Once it starts, it won't stop."
Other disputes, though, must still be resolved before the stock offering can proceed. The Government and El Al's board are squabbling over how to divide the $100 million or more they expect to reap from the stock sale. The airline, unsurprisingly, thinks it should keep the money, while the Government says the earnings should go to the public treasury.
There is also disagreement with the union about how much of the stock will be offered at a discount to El Al workers. The Government wants to limit it to 10 percent; employees want more.
The most sensitive question, of course, is how much leeway private management will have over what has been considered an invaluable public asset.
Many of El Al's far-flung international routes were established more for strategic than commercial reasons, as Israel sought to expand transportation and diplomatic links in defiance of terrorist threats and Arab-led boycotts.
Its fleet still serves as a kind of civilian air reserve, on call to be pressed into service in times of war or national emergency.
Its passenger aircraft are commandeered for airlifts, often in situations of great risk. For example, El Al flew thousands of Ethiopian Jews to Israel in just 24 hours in 1991, when Addis Ababa was aflame with civil war. And special El Al night flights bringing hundreds of thousands of immigrants from the former Soviet Union continued throughout the Persian Gulf war, even as Iraq was lobbing missiles at Israel and other airlines suspended flights to the region. "We were flying around the clock," said Nachman Klieman, the El Al spokesman. "It took quite a toll."
Would a privatized El Al remain available for such patriotic duties? Management says yes, but not on the same essentially cost-free terms. And it would expect other private airlines here to do the same.
In addition, El Al cargo planes routinely haul classified materiel for the Defense Ministry and other state agencies. After an El Al 747 carrying chemicals ordered by a top-secret Government research lab crashed in October 1992 after takeoff from Amsterdam's airport and killed 43 people, the airline said little for almost five years amid contentions that the shipment was intended for the manufacture of nerve gas -- and the cause of health problems reported by residents of the neighborhood where the plane fell.
El Al officials, saying the airline is fully insured against any potential liability from local Dutch lawsuits. have since acknowledged that the plane was carrying dimethyl methyphosphonate, which can be used in making the nerve gas Sarin. Israeli officials said it was destined for use in tests of gas mask filters.
El Al's privatization was officially endorsed in 1995 by a Labor government, which received union blessing to divest itself of a majority of its holdings. When Mr. Netanyahu became Prime Minister in 1996, the Government promised to make the sale a centerpiece of a broader privatization program. In 1997, a commission recommended a 100 percent divestiture, while El Al's management assiduously courted American Airlines as a potential equity partner.
Yet concern among Orthodox Jews that private owners would overturn the ban on flights during the Sabbath -- known in Hebrew as Shabbat -- led the Government to cap the planned stock sale at 49 percent. No single investor will be entitled to buy more than 5 percent of the company, discouraging many prospective foreign buyers.
"It is not easy to sell El Al, especially because of the problem of Shabbat," said Moshe Leon, Mr. Netanyahu's chief economic adviser. "But it must be done, and it will be done."
Without a change in the Sabbath policy, the financial turnaround that was achieved last year could prove ephemeral, El Al officials say. Most of El Al's 1998 profit margin came from record-low fuel prices and unexpected local savings from the devaluation of the shekel last fall. The company is braced for more competition from foreign airlines -- Continental is inaugurating daily service here from Newark in August -- and from domestic cargo carriers, which are petitioning for regular international air freight routes.
In response, El Al's union has taken the Government to court to block air cargo competition unless El Al is allowed to fly freight on the Sabbath as well. With cargo accounting for a quarter of El Al's revenue, the loss of the freight monopoly coupled with the continued Sabbath restriction could doom the company, the union argues.
"That is the complexity of this country, where religion gets mixed up with the state," said Michael Kovachi, the chief El Al union representative. "What Hamas and El Fatah didn't manage to do, the religious have done, lowering the flags on the tails of our planes."
The decision to deregulate the air cargo business is now in the hands of Transportation Minister Shaul Yahalom. As a leader of the small National Religious Party, he must balance the demands of his devout Orthodox constituency against his avowed free-market beliefs.
Mr. Yahalom accuses El Al of "hiding behind its workers" in the lawsuit and trying "to torpedo moves that are aimed only at creating true competition and lowering prices for the benefit of the public." But he has continued delaying an expected ruling in favor of freight deregulation.
A paradox in the court battle is that a private local company, Cargo Air Lines, is already flying as many as seven freight flights out of Israel every Sabbath -- using leased El Al planes with moonlighting El Al crews. In an arrangement winked at by the Government since 1982, these Friday and Saturday freight flights help amortize the costs of El Al's equipment while insuring that cut flowers and perishable produce reach weekend markets in Europe.
El Al's local competitors have joined the call for the Sabbath ban to be lifted, but only as part of a broader deregulation of the industry. "El Al must be released from this limitation if they want to privatize," said Michael Weinstein, the chief executive officer of Aeroel, an Israeli company that runs foreign charter flights on Fridays and Saturdays.
"The market will adjust itself," Mr. Weinstein said. "El Al will continue to be the leader, because of its routes, but it may cut back on flights that are not so profitable. Competition will make El Al better."

HEADLINE: Budget Politics Is Delaying Relief for Central America

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Nearly $1 billion in emergency aid to storm-stricken Central Americans ran afoul of partisan budget politics in the House and Senate today, dooming any chance that President Clinton could deliver the relief package when he visits the region next week.
Republicans in both houses were willing to approve the aid, but only on conditions the President would find unacceptable -- cutting an equal amount from programs like food stamps and welfare assistance. The House Republicans disregarded pleas from their new Speaker that they go along with Mr. Clinton's plans without causing problems. 
 "It seems that the Republican majority is looking more to play politics with some of the issues than in providing the very needed aid," said the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, who denounced the proposed cuts.
The Senate Appropriations Committee unanimously approved $1.9 billion in new spending, which included $956 million to help countries like Honduras and Nicaragua rebuild after they were devastated by storms last fall. It also contained $100 million in aid to Jordan and $285 million in assistance for American farmers and ranchers hurt by the economic turmoil in Asia.
Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, said the offsetting cuts came from programs that received extra money last fall, which would not all be spent this year. But he acknowledged that the cuts were politically sensitive and might not survive a White House veto or negotiations with the House.
Mr. Stevens and the Republican leadership are under strong pressure from fiscal conservatives to stay under the self-imposed spending caps, and not skirt the restrictions by giving the spending emergency status as Congress often does in providing aid for natural disasters.
In another jab at the Administration, the committee approved by voice vote an amendment from Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, that would bar the Federal Government from recouping any settlement proceeds the states have negotiated with the tobacco industry.
The White House's five-year budget projections assume that the Federal Government would receive $18.9 billion from the tobacco settlements. Despite today's vote, the committee was sharply divided, foreshadowing a fierce floor battle.
Across the Capitol, a meeting of the House Appropriations Committee was canceled today after Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, also under pressure from budget hawks as well as top lieutenants like Tom DeLay and Dick Armey, both of Texas, ordered the panel to find offsetting cuts in its budget to pay for the Central American aid.
Mr. DeLay and Mr. Armey, taken aback by the Senate seizing the traditional House role of demanding fiscal responsibility, also expressed anger that the Government was willing to send millions to storm victims in Latin American and the Caribbean, but shortchange American farmers.
The House action dealt a setback to Mr. Hastert, who expected to benefit along with Mr. Clinton from quick action on the emergency foreign assistance. Mr. Hastert had not originally sought offsetting cuts for that aid, although lawmakers had done so for the assistance to Jordan.
"The simple fact is, a lot of our members want to be fiscally responsible," said John P. Feehery, Mr. Hastert's spokesman.
The about-face illustrates the problems Republicans face as they run into self-imposed budget restraints despite large projected surpluses. It also shows the challenges Mr. Hastert confronts in dealing with a six-vote House majority and rumblings that Mr. DeLay, the minority whip, is calling the shots.
Democrats seized on the Republicans' decisions to portray a Republican Party insensitive to the needs of the poor in this country and abroad.
"I find it puzzling that the offsets suggested by some of our Republican colleagues would cut food stamps and welfare assistance for the needy in this country to pay for assistance for the needy in Honduras," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.
But all of the committee Democrats voted for the bill, accepting Mr. Stevens' explanation, as did Tom Harkin of Iowa, or vowing to fight the cuts on the Senate floor or in House-Senate conference committee, as did Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota.
The proposed cuts from the current budget include $262 million in food stamps, and $70 million in climate change and international environmental programs. The bill also included $80 million to provide new detention centers for Central American immigrants fleeing their storm-ravaged countries. To pay for most of this, the committee cut $65 million from border enforcement naturalization programs.
To win Democratic support, Mr. Stevens added $130 million in agricultural aid to the original bill, and created a new program for the steel industry that would guarantee up to $1 billion in emergency loans.

PUB-DATE: March 5, 1999

SECTION: EDUCATION

LENGTH: 2015 words

HEADLINE: Justice: A Man's Title and His 'Guiding Light'

BYLINE: ALISON ZIMBALIST


HIGHLIGHT: In this lesson, students reflect on the life of retired Justice Henry A. Blackmun, investigating major court decisions he influenced and understanding the impact of his voice in the Supreme Court on our society today. 

 BODY:
Overview of Lesson Plan: In this lesson, students reflect on the life of retired Justice Henry A. Blackmun, investigating major court decisions he influenced and understanding the impact of his voice in the Supreme Court on our society today.
Author(s):
Alison Zimbalist, The New York Times Learning Network
Suggested Time Allowance: 45 minutes
Objectives:
Students will: 
1. Define "justice" and discuss the role of justice systems in societies. 
2. Review and evaluate the role of the Supreme Court in the American legal system. 
3. Examine the influence of Justice Henry A. Blackmun through reading and discussing his obituary, "Retired Justice Blackmun, Author of Roe v. Wade Abortion Ruling, Dead at 90." 
4. Examine a Supreme Court case influenced by Judge Blackmun's voice as a justice.
Resources / Materials:
-student journals 
-pens/ pencils 
-Civics textbooks and other similar resources for investigation of the Supreme Court 
-copies of "Retired Justice Blackmun, Author of Roe v. Wade Abortion Ruling, Dead at 90" (one per student) 
-computers with Internet access
Activities / Procedures:
1. WARM-UP/DO NOW: In their journals, students respond to the following questions (written on the board prior to class): What does "justice" mean? What is the role of the justice system in American society (or any other society)? 

2. Discuss and evaluate the role of the Supreme Court in the American legal system. How do cases reach the Supreme Court? How are decisions made? How are the Justices of the Supreme Court chosen? Students may use civics textbooks or other similar resources to help them answer these questions if students have not yet thoroughly studied the Supreme Court. Students then brainstorm qualifications for serving as a Justice of the Supreme Court, and the teacher records their ideas on the board. 

3. Read the article "Retired Justice Blackmun, Author of Roe v. Wade Abortion Ruling, Dead at 90." In a discussion, students summarize the article and identify key aspects of Justice Blackmun's background, career, and tenure on the Supreme Court. What were some of the major court cases in which he was involved, and how did he side on each? What effect did his decisions have on his career as a judge and of others' perceptions of him? What insight do quotations from Justice Blackmun's colleagues offer about his life? What information about his upbringing and other personal information provide in understanding Justice Blackmun's character? Examine some of the quotations quoted from Justice Blackmun in the article, and discuss whether or not you agree. 

4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: Individually or in small groups, students conduct research of a Supreme Court decision in which Justice Henry Blackmun was involved. As Justice Blackmun served on the Supreme Court for 24 years, thus participating in an enormous number of cases, it may be easiest to have students research cases that Justice Blackmun authored in some way. The Oyez Project at Northwestern University is an excellent resource for easy searching and understanding of these court cases. Tell students to go to (http://oyez.nwu.edu/justices/justices.cgi?justice_id=98&page=cases) for a list of cases in the Oyez database in which Justice Blackmun participated. Students will see that some of the links to cases indicate Blackmun's authorship. When a link is chosen, students will see basic information about the case (docket number, subjects, dates, and other information) and will be able to choose from the following links to further resources for information: 
--Abstract: Briefly and basically presents Facts of the Case, Question Presented, and Conclusion. 
--Justices: Detailed biographies of all Supreme Court justices who sat on the case. 
--Oral Argument: On Real Player audio (some written text provided in some cases) 
--Written Opinions of the Court: A Link to FindLaw's Web page on the case, which provides the full text of the case. 
In their research, students should answer the following questions: 
a. What were the major issues of the case? 
b. What arguments were presented during the case? 
c. Who were the parties involved, and why was this brought before the Supreme Court? 
d. What was the final decision? 
e. If you were a member of the Court, how would you have voted on the issue, and why? 
f. What do you think is the significance of this case in American society today? Students should present their research findings to the class, either through oral presentation or by creating a poster to be displayed in the classroom.
Further Questions for Discussion:
--What is the basic procedure for determining cases that will come before the U.S. Supreme Court? 
--What Constitutional basis is there for the procedures of the Supreme Court? 
--Why does the Supreme Court sometimes reverse its own decisions? 
--How does the Supreme Court affect the lives of Americans? 
--What is the relationship of justice to American society as a whole?
Evaluation / Assessment:
Students will be evaluated based on written journal response, participation in classroom discussion, and thorough research of a Supreme Court case heard by Justice Blackmun.
Vocabulary:
status quo, liberal, tenure, terminate, consensus, prohibitions, divisive, ominous, coalesced, plurality, arbitrary, rationality, consistency, dissenting, rejoinder, conservatives, paradoxically, happenstance, nonpartisan, nonideological, diverged, brutality, antic, corollary, emancipation
Extension Activities:
1. Create a time-line of Justice Blackmun's life, including his education, occupations, important Supreme Court decisions, and family information. 

2. Research current Supreme Court justices and the important cases which they significantly influenced (current justices: William H. Rehnquist, John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter, Clarence Thomas, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Stephen G. Breyer). 

3. Create a flow chart of how a court case (either a general case or a specific one) goes through the process of being heard in front of the Supreme Court. 

4. "Retry" one of the court cases researched in class. How would each student vote on this issue if he or she were a member of the Supreme Court? What information about American society can be determined by reviewing the case? (Particularly, what does this case tell us about society at the time in which the case was tried? Has anything changed?) 

5. Debate the underlying issues often tried in Supreme Court cases, supporting your views with examples of historic cases (possible issues to examine: freedom of religion, freedom of speech, search and seizure, privacy and personal autonomy, race discrimination, federalism, rights of the accused, due process). 

6. Diagram your state's judicial system and where it intersects with the federal court system. What is the difference between a case in federal court and a case in state court?
Interdisciplinary Connections:
Foreign Language- Find Web sites written in the language of study that discuss the court process or specific court cases. Translate and discuss the information. 

Global History- Research the supreme court or highest court systems in other countries (particularly Germany, Canada, Australia, Japan, Switzerland, Great Britain, and the Soviet Union) and compare them to the United States Supreme Court. 

Journalism- Write a news article about a newsworthy Supreme Court decision as if you are reporting from the court. 

Mathematics- Design, distribute, analyze and graph a poll about what people view as the most significant Supreme Court decision in their lifetimes. 

Teaching with The Times- Read several obituaries from The New York Times. What similarities do they share, and why?
Other Information on the Web:
The Federal Judiciary Homepage (http://www.uscourts.gov) provides extensive information about and links to the U.S. court system, publications and directories, news, and the Federal Judiciary Channel. 

FindLaw (http://www.findlaw.com/casecode/supreme.html) is a searchable database of Supreme Court decisions since 1893. 

The Oyez Project at Northwestern University's U.S. Supreme Court Multimedia Database (http://oyez.nwu.edu) is a searchable database of Supreme Court cases, biographies of justices, and a virtual tour of the Supreme Court building.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 3; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1556 words

HEADLINE: Testing the Limits of Tolerance as Cultures Mix;
Does Freedom Mean Accepting Rituals That Repel the West?

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
In Maine, a refugee from Afghanistan was seen kissing the penis of his baby boy, a traditional expression of love by this father. To his neighbors and the police, it was child abuse, and his son was taken away. In Seattle, a hospital tried to invent a harmless female circumcision procedure to satisfy conservative Somali parents wanting to keep an African practice alive in their community. The idea got buried in criticism from an outraged public.
How do democratic, pluralistic societies like the United States, based on religious and cultural tolerance, respond to customs and rituals that may be repellent to the majority? As new groups of immigrants from Asia and Africa are added to the demographic mix in the United States, Canada and Europe, balancing cultural variety with mainstream values is becoming more and more tricky. 
 Many Americans confront the issue of whether any branch of government should have the power to intervene in the most intimate details of family life.
"I think we are torn," said Richard A. Shweder, an anthropologist at the University of Chicago and a leading advocate of the broadest tolerance for cultural differences. "It's a great dilemma right now that's coming up again about how we're going to deal with diversity in the United States and what it means to be an American."
Anthropologists have waded deeply into this debate, which is increasingly engaging scholars across academia, as well as social workers, lawyers and judges who deal with new cultural dimensions in immigration and asylum. Some, like Mr. Shweder, argue for fundamental changes in American laws, if necessary, to accommodate almost any practice accepted as valid in a radically different society if it can be demonstrated to have some social or cultural good.
For example, although Mr. Shweder and others would strongly oppose importing such practices as India's immolation of widows, they defend other controversial practices, including the common African ritual that opponents call female genital mutilation, which usually involves removing the clitoris at a minimum. They say that it is no more harmful than male circumcision and should be accommodated, not deemed criminal, as it now is in the United States and several European countries. At the Harvard Law School, Martha Minow, a professor who specializes in family and school issues, said that intolerance often arises when the behavior of immigrants seems to be "nonmodern, nonscientific and nonrational." She cites as an example the practice of "coining" among Cambodians, where hot objects may be pressed on a child's forehead or back as cures for various maladies, leaving alarming welts that for teachers and social workers set off warnings of child abuse.
Americans are more than happy to accept new immigrants when their traditions seem to reinforce mainstream ideals. There are few cultural critics of the family values, work ethic or dedication to education found among many East Asians, for example.
But going more than halfway to tolerate what look like disturbing cultural practices unsettles some historians, aid experts, economists and others with experience in developing societies. Such relativism, they say, undermines the very notion of progress. What's more, it raises the question of how far acceptance can go before there is no core American culture, no shared values, left.
Many years of living in a variety of cultures, said Urban Jonsson, a Swede who directs the United Nations Children's Fund, Unicef, in sub-Saharan Africa, has led him to conclude that there is "a global moral minimum," which he has heard articulated by Asian Buddhists and African thinkers as well as by Western human rights advocates.
"There is a nonethnocentric global morality," he said, and scholars would be better occupied looking for it rather than denying it. "I am upset by the anthropological interest in mystifying what we have already demystified. All cultures have their bad and good things."
Murder was a legitimate form of expression in Europe centuries ago when honor was involved, Mr. Jonsson points out. Those days may be gone in most places, but in Afghanistan, a wronged family may demand the death penalty and carry it out themselves with official blessing. Does that restore it to respectability in the 21st century?
Scholars like Mr. Shweder are wary of attempts to catalogue "good" and "bad" societies or practices. Working with the Social Science Research Council in New York and supported by the Russell Sage Foundation, he helped form a group of about 15 legal and cultural experts to investigate how American law affects ethnic customs among African, Asian, Caribbean and Latin American immigrants.
A statement of purpose written by the working group, headed by Mr. Shweder and Ms. Minow, says that it intends to explore how to react to "official attempts to force compliance with the cultural and legal norms of American middle class life."
"Despite our pluralistic ideals, something very much like a cultural un-American activities list seems to have begun circulating among powerful representatives and enforcers of mainstream culture," the group says in its statement. "Among the ethnic minority activities at risk of being dubbed 'un-American' are the use of disciplinary techniques such as shaming and physical punishment, parent/child co-sleeping arrangements, rituals of group identity and ceremonies of initiation involving scarification, piercing and genital alterations, arranged marriage, polygamy, the segregation of gender roles, bilingualism and foreign language use and many more."
Some sociologists and anthropologists on this behavioral frontier argue that American laws and welfare services have often left immigrants terrified of the intrusive power of government. The Afghan father in Maine who lost his son to the social services, backed by a lower court, did not prevail until the matter reached the state Supreme Court, which researched the family's cultural heritage and decided in its favor -- while making clear that this was an exceptional case, not a precedent.
Spanking, puberty rites, animal sacrifices, enforced dress codes, leaving children unattended at home and sometimes the use of narcotics have all been portrayed as acceptable cultural practices. But who can claim to be culturally beyond the prevailing laws and why?
Ms. Minow said that issues of cultural practice were appearing in more law school curriculums as Americans experience the largest wave of immigration since the 1880-1920 era. "Immigration is now becoming a mainstream subject," she said. "There is also definitely a revival of interest in law schools in religion," including a study of the relation of beliefs to social practices and legal constraints.
Some of the leading thinkers in this debate will discuss the issue at a conference at Harvard in April on the relationship between culture and progress. "If you believe that there is such a thing as a successful society and an unsuccessful society," said Lawrence Harrison, a conference panelist, "then you have to draw some conclusions about what makes for a better society."
Mr. Harrison, who wrote "Underdevelopment as a State of Mind" (Harvard) and "Who Prospers?" (Basic Books), said he believed there were universal yearnings for "progress" and that to refrain from judging every practice out there ignored those aspirations.
Paradoxically, while some Americans want judgment-free considerations of immigrants' practices and traditional rituals in the countries they come from, asylum seekers from those same countries are turning up at American airports begging to escape from tribal rites in the name of human rights. Immigration lawyers and judges are thus drawn into a debate that is less and less theoretical.
Mr. Jonsson of Unicef, whose wife is from Tanzania, says he has had to confront cultural relativism every day for years in the third world. He is outraged by suggestions that the industrial nations should be asked to bend their laws and social norms, especially on the genital cutting of girls, which Unicef opposes.
He labels those who would condemn many in the third world to practices they may desperately want to avoid as "immoral and unscientific." In their academic towers, Mr. Jonsson said, cultural relativists become "partners of the tormentors."
Jessica Neuwirth, an international lawyer who is director of Equality Now, a New York-based organization aiding women's groups in the developing world and immigrant women in this country, asks why the practices that cultural relativists want to condone so often involve women: how they dress, what they own, where they go, how their bodies can be used.
"Culture is male-patrolled in the way that it is created and transmitted," she said. "People who control culture tend to be the people in power, and who constitutes that group is important. Until we can break through that, we can't take the measure of what is really representative."
Other voices are often not being heard or are silenced. "People forget that inside every culture, there is a whole spectrum of ideas and values," she said. "There may be women in another culture who defend the practice of female genital mutilation, but in the same culture there will be women who oppose the practice. And men, too."

LENGTH: 951 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Counterfeiters Competing For Golf Equipment Market

BYLINE: By DENNIS BLANK

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., March 5

 BODY:
Within hours after the Taylor Made Golf Company introduced its new $300 Fire Sole driver at the recent Professional Golfers' Merchandise Show here, counterfeiters were hustling their own versions for less than half that price at the same trade show.
That was just one example of a brazen and widespread underground in counterfeit golf equipment, a market that has been estimated at up to $4 billion a year, more than the entire $2.5 billion legitimate golf-equipment industry. 
 Also flooding the market are knock-offs, or imitations that do not try to pass for the real thing but might violate patent protections. The line between counterfeits and knockoffs can be blurry, but both are definitely having an economic impact on sales for an industry already in a slump. Despite an increase in the number of people golfing, sales this year are expected to be flat at best and possibly down as much as 10 percent.
"The problem is definitely getting worse," said George Abbott, managing director of the International Anti-Counterfeiting Coalition in Washington. Thomas Cove, vice president for governmental relations at the Sports Goods Manufacturers Association, said: "Counterfeiting chases the money. It is a criminal syndicate."
The Professional Golfers' Association declined to comment, but one lawyer said that knock-offs and counterfeits were being sold openly at the association's most recent trade show.
"It has a huge effect on the industry," said the lawyer, Timothy L. Epp, who represents Taylor Made, based in Carlsbad, Calif. "But we really don't know the size of this underground. I don't think we can ever stop the knock-off business."
The size of the problem is open to debate. While the United States Customs Service puts it at $4 billion annually, Mr. Cove says that estimate is far too high. He estimates the total United States sales of all counterfeit sports equipment, including apparel, at just $2 billion annually, compared with $60 billion in wholesale revenues from legitimate sales.
Taylor Made has won several judgments against Taiwan manufacturers. But, Mr. Epp said, the copyright infringements are costing the company sales and damaging its good will.
"These knock-offs and counterfeit goods are often misrepresented to unsuspecting consumers to be exactly the same as genuine Taylor Made products," he said.
Law enforcement is cracking down. At the end of the recent Professional Golfers' Association show, Customs agents arrested 12 people, including four Taiwan nationals, in Houston, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Savannah, Ga. The arrests concluded a two-year investigation that resulted in more than 300 seizures of phony golf clubs with an estimated total value of $6 million. By comparison, seizures by Customs in 1997 at ports like Los Angeles and San Francisco netted an estimated total of $1.1 million in counterfeit golf-club parts coming in from Asia.
The 12 men have all been arraigned in Federal courts on charges of trafficking in counterfeit goods, which carry sentences of up to 10 years in prison and $2 million in fines.
Customs said its agents had infiltrated the underground network and discovered that most of the counterfeit components were made in Vietnam, China, Taiwan and Thailand. Once in this country, the clubs are sold to distributors, who do business in hotel rooms and on the Internet.
One Web site that industry lawyers say is a particular cause for concern is Chip Shot Golf, which sells what it calls "Callaway wood lookalikes" for $139.99, far below the Callaway Golf Company's Biggest Big Bertha, which can retail for more than $500. Chip Shot Golf declined to comment.
Callaway Golf, the leading manufacturer of golf equipment, has more than two dozen civil actions pending in the courts and has put pressure on the authorities in Taiwan to arrest offenders. More than 110,000 counterfeit clubs have been seized there in raids on manufacturers.
"It is a brazen and reckless move to copy the technological innovations of others and blatantly infringe on patents granted -- a move that we cannot and will not allow to go unchallenged," said Steve McCracken, a lawyer for Callaway.
Last year, Taiwan authorities arrested Lin Ping-Chun, the owner of Lin Kou Golf near Taipei, who had already served a six-month sentence for counterfeiting violations. Tung Uei Industries in Taichung City was also raided, with the police arresting some company officials and confiscating an estimated $65,000 worth of counterfeit Callaway clubs.
"We will continue to wage the war against counterfeiters of our products because such activities hurt consumers, our retail accounts, as well as employees and shareholders," said Ely Callaway, the company's president.
Callaway's lawyers say Jason Tse Lung Lin, through a company called Impression Golf, capitalized on the popularity of Callaway clubs by using names like "Big Brothers" and "Big Bursar" and a logo virtually identical to Big Bertha's. Callaway was granted an injunction to put Impression Golf out of business.
One Customs agent, Joseph Henderson, said undercover agents infiltrated the network of Asian golf equipment makers and set themselves up as importers for two of them after making purchases. He said that he does not think organized crime is involved, but that these Asian companies "are organized like any other business in terms of marketing, distributing and shipping."
Mr. Abbott of the International Anti-Counterfeiting Coalition said it was difficult to compare losses resulting from counterfeiting with legitimate sales, because counterfeiting does not constitute theft of an actual product.
"It's often hard to tell who is robbing you," Mr. Abbott said.

HEADLINE: Debt of Consumers Climbed in January

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers increased at a faster pace in January as all categories of debt increased, Federal Reserve figures released today showed.
Borrowing rose by $14.7 billion, to $1.316 trillion, in January, after a revised increase of $3.1 billion in December. 
 Consumer credit rose at a 13.5 percent annual rate during January, up from the 2.9 percent pace in December. It was the biggest increase in more than a year, the Fed said.
 "We don't think consumer borrowing is going to scale back" this year, because unemployment is low and incomes are rising, Gary Thayer, an economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said before the report was released. In addition, Mr. Thayer said, low inflation gives consumers more buying power.
Revolving loans outstanding, which include credit card debt, rose by $5.7 billion in January, up from a $3.9 billion increase in December. Auto loans rose $6.5 billion, up from $4.4 billion. Other types of installment loans rose by $2.5 billion, after falling $5.2 billion in December.
Economists watch the Fed's credit report because it helps them gauge consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic output. The report does not, however, track loans secured by real estate, like home equity loans.
With the economy expanding and unemployment close to a 30-year low, consumers have been spending money at the fastest pace in 14 years. Some of that spending, of course, has been financed by credit cards and other loans, and some economists caution that consumers may be taking on too much debt, especially if the economy sours.
