HEADLINE: An Oxford Historian Whose Vox Is Populi

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: WINDSOR, England, March 1

 BODY:
Niall Ferguson likes to joke that he became a historian by default. "At Oxford, I discovered that I couldn't be a politician, I wouldn't make a terribly good journalist, I was a very poor double bass player and I was an absolutely appalling actor," he said. "I came to realize that what made me happy was to sit in a library reading about dead people."
His choice of A. J. P. Taylor as a role model, however, suggests he was not exactly yearning for seclusion. "Alan Taylor was the first historian I had ever heard of as a schoolboy," he recalled, "and I had heard of him because his books were commercially successful and he did television, newspapers and radio." At the age of 20, then, even before graduating from Oxford, Mr. Ferguson had understood it was possible to be both a respected academic and something of a public figure. 
 What perhaps the soft-spoken Glaswegian did not imagine was that he would achieve this double-billing -- "The Intelligent Populist," as The Spectator weekly magazine has called him -- so early in his career.
Now, just weeks before his 35th birthday, he is a Fellow of Jesus College, Oxford, and author of an appropriately learned tome, "Paper and Iron: Hamburg Business and German Politics in the Era of Inflation, 1897-1927," published by Cambridge University Press. But he is also the most talked-about British historian of his generation, thanks to frequent newspaper articles and interviews on television and radio, along with two new books aimed at nonacademic readers.
"The World's Banker: The History of the House of Rothschild," published as a single 1,309-page book in Britain by Weidenfeld & Nicholson, has been split into two volumes in the United States, with the first 608-page volume, "The House of Rothschild: Money's Prophets," issued by Viking in December. Mr. Ferguson's other new book, "The Pity of War," about World War I, which appeared in Britain in November under Penguin's Allen Lane imprint, will be published by Basic Books in the United States next month.
Eager to have the books read, Mr. Ferguson (who pronounces his first name NEEL) chose to publish them with commercial houses, which helped assure him a large number of reviews -- almost all excellent -- as well as a fresh flurry of press interviews.
The books in themselves also stirred debate since both present what historians would consider new discoveries (for example, that Nathan Rothschild was almost bankrupted by Napoleon's defeat at Waterloo or that Scottish soldiers in World War I routinely killed their German prisoners of war).
For Mr. Ferguson, though, the main difference between, say, his German inflation book and "The Pity of War" lies in their presentation. "Cambridge University Press will produce a book that is intimidating to read, the print is small, the footnotes are on the page," he explained. "Penguin will produce a book which has pictures, good charts, looks nice, and then they will market it. But if you look at the texts of the two books, it's not that big a shift."
Mr. Ferguson knows he is risking the disapproval of his academic peers when he reaches out to the general public. "I think it is a minus in the eyes of the majority of academics, who are deeply suspicious of 'media dons' as a phenomenon," he said, sipping mineral water in a hotel in the shadow of Windsor Castle.
Yet he insists that he is continuing an old tradition. "The idea of the academic as somebody who is dedicated purely to scholarly activities, who will address only an inner priesthood who speak the higher jargon, is a very modern idea," he said. "I think that, for a modern historian, engagement with the media is terribly good for you."
In fact, by his own admission, Mr. Ferguson specialized in economic history and German history because he felt expertise in these areas might serve him well outside the academic world. But he also believes that knowledge of history can enrich debates about contemporary affairs, whether the topic happens to be post-cold-war Europe, the Bosnian conflict or even whether the stock market bubble is about to burst.
Since the late 1980's, then, he has embraced journalism. "Zola said that journalism is the anvil on which everyone should bash their prose into shape," he noted, adding that aggressive editing of his early work taught him to write more clearly. And he answers his academic critics by challenging them to expound and defend their views in public. "It is much harder to convince television viewers than your students," he said.
Mr. Ferguson actually looks the part of a "media don." He cuts a dashing figure, with his tousled hair, fresh good looks and dapper clothes (he wears the corduroy suit of an intellectual and the "power" suspenders of a banker), while his marriage to Sue Douglas, a former editor of The Sunday Express, keeps him close to the world of journalism. But he is also not short of opinions he is ready to share.
His political foes call him a right-wing historian or, more generously, an intellectual conservative, although he describes himself as a liberal fundamentalist. Either way, he seems to be a product of Britain under Thatcherism: he believes strongly in the market and in individualism and is opposed to government intervention in the economy. Recently he spoke out against Britain's joining the new European currency, the euro, although he claims to be "a very European person culturally."
As a Scot, he has raised eyebrows by criticizing Britain's Labor Government over its efforts to increase Scotland's autonomy by creation of a Scottish Parliament. "There's huge hypocrisy about Scottish nationalism," he said. "Their nationalism starts and stops at the entrance to sports stadiums. In reality, all the talk of independence is just a strategy to get more money out of the Treasury."
And yet he insists that he is skeptical about ideologies. "I think being a historian is a terribly good cure for ideological rigor," he said with a laugh, "because it's very hard to see any ideology withstand the experience of 200 years of modern history."
Thus, if Mr. Ferguson had to name an underlying belief, it might be old-fashioned research, like the four years he spent working on his doctorate on German inflation. His massive history of the Rothschilds, which covers the period from 1780 to 1918, was the result of five years' work financed partly by a research fellowship from the British branch of the Rothschilds, who also arranged for him to become the first outsider to gain access to the family's archives. "The Pity of War," originally inspired by his grandfather's stint on the Western Front, also involved extensive research, which led him to go against the conventional historical tide and conclude that World War I could have been averted. This prompted some critics to tag the book "revisionist."
This week, he was in Windsor working in the castle's Royal Archives in preparation for his next book, a history of the Saxe-Coburg family, which supplied much of the 19th century's European royalty (including Prince Albert, Queen Victoria's consort). On a year's sabbatical from Oxford, Mr. Ferguson is also spending time at the Bank of England working on a long-term study of the bond market.
Meanwhile, he has been teaching modern history at Oxford as well as working on other books, including "Virtual History: Alternatives and Counterfactuals," a collection of essays about the "what ifs" of history.
"Virtual history" stands at the center of his approach to the past. Specifically, by examining the uncertainties, dilemmas and options of history -- for instance, "Would World War II have occurred without Hitler?" -- he challenges the inevitability of history and the supremacy of ideologies.
"I began to realize we have a fundamental problem with historical philosophy," he said. "Some people just don't think the past could be any different. And that leads to the belief that history repeats itself. I think there's nothing more dangerous than people who exercise the power of prophecy on the basis of a deterministic theory of history. As Alan Taylor said, all we can learn from history is how to make new mistakes."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Lowers Rates Again, And for Banks It's a Big Zero

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 5

 BODY:
Japan's central bank pushed overnight interest rates to the unprecedented level of effectively zero this week in one of its boldest attempts yet to invigorate the economy -- basically allowing Japanese banks to borrow free.
The Bank of Japan's move, which partly contributed today to a 5 percent surge in the Japanese stock market, represents a gamble that banks will use this borrowed money to increase their own lending to businesses and individuals. The hope is that such a move will stimulate spending and generate a recovery in the world's second-largest economy, which is stuck in the worst recession since World War II. 
 Lending rates in the overnight money market, a critical part of the banking system, have been well below 1 percent for a while -- a sign of how fragile both the weakly capitalized banks and the economy have become over the last few years.
Last month the Bank of Japan announced it would bring the rate down to 0.15 percent. This week the central bank poured between the equivalent of $10 billion to $15 billion each day into the market, and the rates fell to 0.04 percent, then to 0.03 percent, then to 0.02 percent, then to 0.01 percent on Thursday. Today, the rate settled at 0.02 percent, or just one-fiftieth of one percentage point.
That means the rate is less than one two- hundredths the comparable level in the United States. At such a rate, a bank could borrow $1 million overnight and pay just 27 cents in interest the next day.
Nobody, including officials at the Bank of Japan, is sure whether the astonishingly low rates will work. There are also significant hazards -- a mass flight of capital as investors seek higher returns in investments overseas, for example, or a plunge in the value of the yen. Indeed, the yen fell to a three-month low of 123.72 to the dollar in Tokyo today, and some forecasters now say it could weaken to 130 fairly soon and far further later this year.
The biggest risk is that even with such low borrowing costs, the Bank of Japan may still not be able to coax banks to borrow and use that cheaper money to expand lending to companies throughout the country. A critical problem now is that banks have been so absorbed in treating their mountains of bad debt that they have been simply unwilling to make new loans and have even been cutting their lending.
"This is still a trial period," said Kazuo Momma, an official at the Bank of Japan. "It takes time to evaluate what is happening in the market."
For today, at least, the market liked it. Encouraged by the central bank's moves this week, as well as a formal application for public money by the nation's biggest banks, investors sent stocks rallying in the biggest one-day surge this year. That pushed the benchmark Nikkei 225 share average up 710.55 points, to 14,894, its highest level since December.
The Bank of Japan's moves also brought down long-term bond rates, which last month were triple the level of October. The Government is trying to expand the economy with more spending, and this has spooked investors who had dumped bonds and sent their yields soaring. Higher yields can choke an economic recovery by raising long-term borrowing costs.
The yield on the 10-year Japanese Government bond, a benchmark for long-term rates, fell to 1.57 percent today, a three-month low.
The Bank of Japan was able to reduce overnight lending rates by flooding the overnight money market with funds. The $230 billion market is the lifeblood of the banking system and is a commonly used tool for banks and other financial institutions to borrow and lend short-term cash.
"It's amazing," said Akihiko Yokoyama, a fixed-income analyst at J. P. Morgan in Tokyo. "Can you imagine who would lend out money at zero percent?"
The answer seems to be: fewer and fewer lenders. And that could emerge as a problem. Insurance companies and investment trust funds no longer want to park their money there, and are putting it into regular bank deposit accounts or into longer-term money markets, such as one-month or three-month maturities.
Bank of Japan officials are suggesting that they may next try to lower interest rates in the money markets for one-month or three-month borrowings. But that could ultimately lead to capital flight, as investors move money abroad for higher returns.
"It's definitely a problem at the moment," said Clifford J. Shaw, president of Mercury Asset Management Japan Ltd. "Having rates at zero has all sorts of implications."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Nuclear Power Elite;
A Small Circle of Companies Seeks Control of Reactors

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

DATELINE: PLYMOUTH, Mass.

 BODY:
FOR SALE: Five buildings on 1,600 acres of woodland. Cape Cod Bay vu. 26 years old. Original owner. Good condition.
 The property that was put on the market last summer was a nuclear plant -- the Pilgrim Nuclear Power Station here -- and that alone might have made it a tough sell. 
 For one, nuclear energy has been very unpopular since the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island. And the opening of electricity markets in states like Massachusetts adds to the financial risks of running a nuclear plant: the costs of plant shutdowns, for instance, can no longer be passed along, with the blessing of regulators, to customers. And the operator no longer has a monopoly.
For these reasons, Pilgrim's owner, the Boston Edison Company, said that if a buyer could not be found, the plant would be shut and decommissioned sooner rather than later. For Plymouth, a town of nearly 50,000 and the home of Plymouth Rock, the loss of its biggest employer would have been a huge blow.
So the 670 managers and employees of the Pilgrim plant were understandably nervous when teams of executives from other utility companies toured the plant to see if they wanted to make a bid. The floors and walls of the plant glistened; the telephones were even polished by hand. Some of the maintenance and operating workers wore ties and dress shirts for a time.
"Until a buyer was found, you did not know what the future held," recalled Frank Clifford, a service reactor operator at Pilgrim.
While the offers did not exactly pour in, two bids were eventually made for the plant. The Entergy Corporation, a huge utility based in New Orleans, was the winner with an $80 million bid. It was just the second sale of a nuclear plant in the United States.
It's a buyers' market, but the fact that there is a market at all in nuclear plants is a sign of how deregulation is reshaping the power industry. Entergy and companies like the Peco Energy Company and Dominion Resources are in the forefront of a group of bargain basement shoppers who see remaining value in nuclear energy. Instead of spending hundreds of millions of dollars or more to build a new power plant capable of generating the same amount of electricity, they are able to buy older nuclear plants for tens of millions -- a mere fraction of their book value. (The last reactor to be built in the United States was ordered in 1973.)
These companies, which own more than one nuclear plant, say they have developed the skill and size to run nuclear plants more efficiently. The possibility of costly operating shutdowns does not frighten them, they say, because they will have the expertise, manpower and equipment available should a problem arise.
And the price is so cheap that it pays to deal with the generally higher costs of operating nuclear power plants compared with that of running other electricity sources.
Nuclear plants in newly open markets like Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New Jersey are particularly attractive. Under deregulation, a number of the utilities in those states are shrinking to become transmission companies. They will concentrate on the delivery of electricity and on servicing business and residential customers. Utilities like the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, for example, will buy power at the lowest price from pools where companies like Entergy, Dominion and Peco will sell power.
The buyers of nuclear plants contend they can thrive in such open markets. When the plants are run well, they can compete on price with low-cost plants that run on hydropower, coal and natural gas. And local nuclear plants are particularly attractive compared with power plants outside the region, which face more expensive transmission costs.
"People who are buying the nuclear plants are very smart," said Robert Rubin, a utility analyst with Bear, Stearns. Despite the image of nuclear power as an industry with no future, he said, it still has many years of life yet.
Entergy, which will have five nuclear plants once the Pilgrim acquisition closes, has identified nuclear generation as having tremendous potential.
Many utilities, however, especially those with only one nuclear plant, see only potential liabilities. At the same time, regulators in Massachusetts and elsewhere have been pushing utilities to dispose of their generation plants to help open the market to competition.
For those utilities that are transforming themselves into transmission companies, state regulators often make allowances for their nuclear plants because of the uncertainty over whether there would be buyers. But most utilities have not needed much prodding to sell.
Mr. Rubin estimates that 25 to 30 plants will soon be put on the market and will either change hands or be shut. In a decade, he predicted, most of the nation's 103 operating reactors will be owned by just a handful of companies.
In what may be the next such deal, the two units of the Nine Mile Point nuclear plant, which employs 1,350 workers, are up for sale. The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation of Syracuse owns one unit. A consortium of utilities, which includes Niagara Mohawk, owns the other. They are in negotiations with Amergen, a joint venture formed by Peco Energy, a utility based in Philadelphia, and British Energy of Edinburgh, one of Britain's largest generators of electricity.
The fate of the plant, on the shores of Lake Ontario, is causing apprehension in Scriba, N.Y., a town of about 8,000.
"Is the new owner going to be a good citizen in our community?" asked Norman Seiter, a lawyer for the town board of Scriba. The two units pay about 85 percent of the property taxes of the town and 39 percent of Oswego County's taxes. If the units are sold, as expected, for less than their book values, the town would be under pressure to reduce the plant's valuation sharply, causing property tax revenues from the operations to fall.
In July, Amergen was the buyer in the first nuclear plant sale in the United States, agreeing to acquire the functioning unit of Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania, the site of the nation's worst nuclear accident. The seller was GPU Inc., a utility that serves parts of New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Amergen has also received the exclusive right to negotiate an agreement to buy the Vermont Yankee Nuclear plant in Vernon, Vt., owned by a group of 13 New England utilities.
But not every nuclear plant put on the market will end up with a buyer. Some plants have been so ridden with problems or have such complex ownership and regulatory hurdles that they are likely to be decommissioned early because they cannot be counted on to offer reliable power at competitive prices.
Last year, GPU, for example, tried to sell its Oyster Creek plant, situated about 35 miles north of Atlantic City, but talks broke down, and it was going to be shut. Now, the sales of the Three Mile Island unit and the Pilgrim plant have encouraged GPU to make another effort to find a buyer for Oyster Creek.
Peco had looked at the Maine Yankee plant in Wiscasset, Me., but backed off. The plant will be shut for good.
The prospect of a permanent shutdown worries people in Scriba the most. "We want these plants to stay here and keep operating," Mr. Seiter said. If buyers are not found, he noted, "we will still have a nuclear site in our backyard with the waste being stored for some time."
As more nuclear plants come on the market or are decommissioned, similar concerns are likely to be felt by dozens of communities.
For Boston Edison, a subsidiary of BEC Energy, the decision that its one nuclear plant would not be a part of its future was made after a review two years ago. The utility decided that Pilgrim should be run by a company that had a number of such plants and could take advantage of economies of scale, said Carl Gustin, the senior vice president for corporate communications at Boston Edison.
"It was the best way for Pilgrim to keep operating in the future to have an owner committed to nuclear power," he said.
Entergy got a bargain, industry analysts say. Of its total bid of $80 million, $67 million was for nuclear fuel. This meant that in effect Entergy paid only $13 million for a plant whose book value is about $700 million. A trust fund of $466 million to offset the cost of decommissioning, whenever that should be needed, is also being passed along to Entergy.
The company bought the Pilgrim plant at a time it was running at 97 percent of its capacity and producing 670 megawatts of power -- enough to serve a small city.
But the plant has been troubled in the past. For a time, it had one of the worst operating records in the nation. In 1986, the plant was already under criticism from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission when it suffered two shutdowns because of equipment problems.
Pilgrim remained shut for two years while it underwent an extensive overhaul. Adm. Ralph G. Bird, an outside expert with a background in nuclear submarines, took charge and put in new management and tightened operations and safety procedures.
Entergy has succeeded in turning around other troubled plants. Two of its plants, Arkansas Nuclear One and River Bend in Louisiana had particularly poor operating records in the late 1980's. The plants, which had been operating at as low as 60 percent of capacity, have been operating at an 88 percent level recently.
"You are taking a risk when you assume these assets," Mike Bellamy, the vice president for operations at Pilgrim for Entergy Nuclear said. "If they are run well and you buy them at a good price, the opportunity is there to make a nice profit."
In Plymonth, the sale of Pilgrim Nuclear "has brought real mixed feelings," said Robert Bradley, the office manager at the Pilgrim Sands Motel, whose house overlooks the plant. "There have been times when people were real nervous and wanted it shut down. It has also been a real financial boon to the town."
Indeed, the plant was warmly greeted when it opened in 1972. Thousands of the town's residents, many of them Italian and Portuguese immigrants, had once worked for the Plymouth Cordage Company, the world's largest rope maker. There were also several textile mills. But nylon and other materials replaced the Plymouth-made ropes, which were made from hemp, and the last mill closed in the mid-1950's.
Entergy is not expected to make major changes at the plant, Mr. Bellamy of Pilgrim said, adding that earlier job cuts had left the plant with a lean and efficient work force.
Still, workers and managers may have to change their way of thinking in a newly competitive industry.
Employees had the attitude that "Mother Boston Edison will take care of me," said Cristine Maimaron, a manager and an important member of the marketing team that sold the plant. "It was hard to make the break."

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 648 words

HEADLINE: Trans-Atlantic Transitions

 BODY:
The United States and Europe are quarreling over bananas, airplanes and beef, working together to secure peace in Kosovo and tangling over the future of NATO. This improbable confluence of events reflects important changes taking place in trans-Atlantic relations. Perhaps more clearly than at any time since the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union, America and its European allies are confronting the economic frictions of globalization and adjusting to a world no longer shaped by the clash of ideologies.
Though there are new stresses in America's relations with Europe, there are also encouraging signs that Europe may emerge from this period prepared to take a greater role in maintaining security on the Continent. That would be healthy for both Europe and America. 
 The most promising evidence of this shift is the negotiations over Kosovo. European countries have shown themselves willing to take on more political and military responsibility than they did in Bosnia four years ago. France and Britain have been especially assertive. But the latest American effort to lock up a deal before the formal peace talks resume later this month in France suggests that Washington's leadership and leverage will not be easy to replace.
NATO is another arena of change. While the alliance is preparing to mark its 50th anniversary next month with the admission of three new members, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, all is not harmonious. There is vigorous and potentially divisive debate within NATO about the alliance's reliance on nuclear weapons and how it should react to threats from beyond Europe. These discussions are drawing new energy from a younger generation of European leaders, especially Germany's new Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, and Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair.
With Russia no longer a military threat and three of its former allies about to join NATO, the question of whether the alliance still needs to threaten nuclear retaliation against conventional attack deserves discussion, as Germany has suggested. Also, most European NATO members rightly bristle at some of Washington's more ambitious notions for enlisting NATO forces to defend common Western interests on distant battlefields.
Trade relations are in flux as well, primarily because of increased global competition. The rapid integration of world markets over the past decade, symbolized by new decision-making bodies like the World Trade Organization, is challenging the cozy protectionist policies Europe used during the cold-war years to shelter its companies and workers from risk.
Europe is now trying to tilt its market in favor of local banana importers, aircraft manufacturers and beef farmers and ward off cheaper American competition. Since open protectionism is no longer respectable, Europe cloaks its efforts with arguments about air pollution, dangerous beef hormones and the devastation that free trade in bananas would produce in former Caribbean colonies. While not entirely without merit, these arguments disguise the real motives of European governments and impede reasonable solutions. A trans-Atlantic trade war is in nobody's interest.
Europe and America may also be headed for troubles in other economic areas. The introduction of Europe's new currency, the euro, could force European governments into restrictive monetary policies that could retard needed economic growth, slowing America's own economy and worsening trade tensions. The European Union's slowness to admit members from Central and Eastern Europe is distorting the political and economic development of the entire Continent.
Further frictions are likely as America and Europe adjust their relationship to new circumstances. That is fine, as long as the problems are resolved constructively and not allowed to undermine the vital trans-Atlantic partnership.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Markets Rally Sharply as Economic Fears Fade

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Investors, who were braced for bad news from the February jobs report, got a pleasant surprise yesterday that helped push bond yields down sharply and stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average set a new high, rising 268.68 points, to 9,736.08 -- just 264 points from 10,000.
Instead of a jobs report reflecting surprisingly strong growth and threatening higher interest rates, investors got a more benign result. 
 On the plus side for stocks, the jobs data showed that the economy was still growing at a strong pace, which is good for those hoping for a rebound in corporate earnings. On the plus side for bonds, the data did not show that the economy was too strong, which would have heighten fears of an increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve later in the year.
Added to this was the fact that bond investors had probably become overly pessimistic about the possibility of an interest rate increase recently. So the pop in the bond market after the 8:30 A.M. release of the employment report was big, with the price of the 30-year bond jumping more than two points. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.54 percent in early trading from 5.69 percent on Thursday.
Stocks followed when they opened, with the Dow up 202 points, or 2 percent, in the first half-hour of trading.
The rally shows that investors are still willing to bet on stocks, even if it means choosing to ignore traditional signs of danger. These include a stock market that is markedly overvalued for the earnings it is offering and rising interest rates that can undermine earnings and attract money from stocks.
"All you needed to do was to halt this sharp rise in interest rates," said Thomas McManus, the equity strategist at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities. He said that the stronger-than-expected economy this year helped a "return of confidence in earnings that enabled the market to be resilient in the face of rising yields." Since February, long-term interest rates have jumped half a percentage point.
But the news is not good for all investors. The gains in the market, as they have been for some time, have been concentrated in the big-name, big-company stocks, from General Electric, which rose 3 3/16, to 103 11/16 yesterday, to Microsoft, which jumped 2 11/16, to 154 15/16.
The underperformance of the rest of the market can be seen in the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks. It is down 5.7 percent this year, while the Dow is up 6 percent.
In addition, 50 percent of the stocks trading on the New York Stock Exchange are 30 percent or more below their 52-week highs, according to Jeffrey M. Warantz, senior equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney.
Mr. Warantz has another barometer, called the laggards indicator; it shows that the last 12 months 73 percent of more than 5,500 common stocks rose 1.2 percent while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 19 percent.
"Many, many investors didn't come near that," he said, referring to the 19 percent, "because the market was incredibly narrow and only a few stocks produced those gains. And if investors are diversified, as they should be, their portfolios, chances are, underperformed the market in the last year."
And for all investors, the tension in the market between rising interest rates and the Federal Reserve, on one side, and the outlook for corporate earnings and the stock market, on the other, still remains. And if the economy continues to look too strong, fears of a rate increase by the Fed will intensify, despite yesterday's bond market rally.
Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Tucker Anthony, said that February's increase of 275,000 jobs certainly "was not weak." She is telling her clients that given the signs of a rebound in manufacturing, which was signaled in recent data from purchasing managers and January factory orders, she is thinking of raising her economic forecast for the year one percentage point, to 4 percent.
Many economists believe that kind of growth, which matches the pace of the last two years, will force the Fed to raise rates to slow the economy and ward off a rise in inflation.
But Ms. Camilli believes that interest rates will not go much higher. She contends that the threat of another global financial crisis and fears of disruptions because of Year 2000 computer glitches will keep the Fed from raising its interest-rate target. In addition, she expects the first three months of this year to be the strongest quarter of 1999, followed by a pretty sharp slowdown in the second quarter. She said this sign of slowing ought to keep interest rates from going much higher and predicted the peak for long-term rates would come this month or in April.
In late bond trading yesterday, the 30-year Treasury bond had given up some of its morning gains, with the price closing up 1 11/32, to 95, while the yield was down to 5.60 percent, from 5.69 percent on Thursday.
Traders said that another spark for the rally was a report in Business Week magazine that said Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, was not inclined to raise interest rates because of concern about another global financial crisis. In addition, the jobs data showed that there was only a tiny increase in wage pressures last month, another sign that inflation remains in check.
The price of futures contracts based on the Federal funds rate, which is the Federal Reserve's target interest rate, also rallied, showing that investors were less worried, at least yesterday, about a rate increase later this year.
Semiconductor, computer, phone, drug and financial stocks led the stock market higher. Intel rose 1 1/4, to 114 5/8; I.B.M. jumped 7 3/8, to 178 3/8; SBC Communications climbed 2 7/16, to 51 13/16; Merck rose 2 5/16, to 82 3/4, and American Express jumped 5 5/8, to 118 5/8.
The Dow, which rallied at the end of the day, to close up 2.84 percent for its first close ever over 9,700. For the week, the Dow rose 4.6 percent. The S.& P. 500 climbed 28.83, or 2.31 percent, to 1,275.47 and is just four points from its highest level, which was reached at the end of January. It rose 3 percent for the week. The Nasdaq composite index, which has many technology stocks, also rallied sharply at the end of the day to finish at 2,337.11, up 44.22, or 1.93 percent. Because of of its recent selloff, it is still 173 points, or 7.4 percent, from its record high. For the week, Nasdaq was up 2.1 percent.
The Russell 2000 index rose 3.99, or 1 percent, to 398.01, and was up 1.5 percent for the week.

HEADLINE: Albright, on Visit to Indonesia, Meets Detained Timor Leader

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 5

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met today with the East Timorese separatist leader, Xanana Gusmao, who was brought from house arrest in a downtown bungalow here to the Indonesian Foreign Ministry for the encounter.
Mr. Gusmao, 53, who was jailed by the Indonesians in 1992 and released from prison to a lighter form of detention last month, is seen by many as holding the key to a peaceful transition to independence in East Timor. 
 Ms. Albright's visit to Indonesia, the first by a senior American official since President Clinton's in 1994, was dominated by talks over how to prevent a repeat of the civil war in East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that Indonesia invaded in 1975 invaded and then annexed.
Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim country and the fourth most populous, has been hit hardest by the Asian economic crisis, with a steep drop in living standards and a continuing economic slump expected this year. Ethnic violence has risen sharply in many parts of the country.
President B. J. Habibie startled the United States and regional powers in Southeast Asia last month when he announced that he was prepared to grant East Timor autonomy, and if that was unsatisfactory to the population there, independence.
Ms. Albright listened to proposals from both Mr. Habibie and Mr. Gusmao about how the transition on East Timor, a desperately poor region of 800,000 people on the eastern edge of Indonesia, should be managed.
In a speech after her meetings, Ms. Albright said the United States favored an "international presence" in East Timor but was not specific about what kind. A senior official traveling with her said that such a presence could be from the region, the United Nations or both.
Most disturbing to the Administration is the recent arming, apparently by the Indonesian military, of people on East Timor who are in favor staying part of Indonesia.
Between 7,000 and 10,000 "pro-integration" people have been armed in recent weeks, according to some estimates, and Administration officials have expressed strong concern that the violence on East Timor will rise. More than 100,000 people are reported to have died in the fighting after Indonesia's occupation of the territory in 1975.
The Secretary told the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, that the Administration believed the arms were being provided by "elements" in the Indonesian military, a senior Administration official said. "We don't know if it's an authorized policy, but we know it's going on," the official said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strong Job Creation Shows The Economy Is Still Robust
Another big burst of job growth in February showed that the nation's economy was still on a roll while wage pressures remained subdued. Driven by booms in construction and consumer spending, employers added 275,000 new jobs to their payrolls. Since Thanksgiving, the economy has been adding jobs at the staggering pace of 3.2 million a year. Even so, the unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 4.4 percent.
The strong jobs creation figures touched off a rally in the stock market and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a new high of 9,736.08. Traders also drove long-term interest rates down. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined to 5.60 percent, from 5.69 percent Thursday. Page A1. 

Borrowing by consumers rose by $14.7 billion, to $1.316 trillion, in January. Consumer credit jumped at a 13.5 percent annual rate in January, up from 2.9 percent in December. C14.
 
Tough Times for Indonesian Banks
It is clear that nursing Indonesia's ruined economy back to health will not be easy. But efforts to overhaul the devastated banking system have discouraged even the most hardened realists, who say the postponement of a crucial step toward bank reform last week was a telling example of why the country will take so long to heal. C2.
 
Adelphia Buys Cable Operator
Adelphia Communications is buying Century Communications for $3.6 billion in a deal that will make Adelphia the nation's fifth-largest cable television system operator. The deal is the second cable purchase by Adelphia in less than a month. C14.
 
Alaskan Oil Spill's Legacy Lingers
When the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound after midnight on March 24, 1989, the ship's captain told the Coast Guard the supertanker was leaking oil. "We're going to be here for quite a while," the skipper, Joseph J. Hazelwood, reported by radio. Nearly 10 years after one of the nation's worst environmental disasters, the Exxon Valdez is in many ways still there. A1.
 
Republicans Offer a Budget Plan
A Republican budget proposal calls for ending the longstanding practice of spending money earmarked for the retirement system. Instead the legislators recommend setting the funds aside either for use in any plan to shore up the system's finances or to reduce the national debt. A9.
 
Furniture Maker Accepts Bid
Winsloew Furniture, which makes aluminum furniture for patios and offices, agreed to be acquired for about $223.5 million in cash by a management group led by its chairman. The $30-a-share offer represented a 12 percent premium over Winsloew's closing price on Thursday of $26.75. C3.
 
Counterfeits Pinch Golf Market
The market for counterfeit golf equipment has grown to $4 billion a year, more than the $2.5 billion legitimate golf-equipment industry. Store shelves are also flooded by knock-offs, imitations that do not try to pass for the real thing but might violate patent protections. Together, they are hurting sales in an already slumping industry. C2.
 
ABN Amro Moves Into Italy
ABN Amro Holding said it would buy 8.75 percent of Banca di Roma for about 660 million euros, or $715 million. Under the agreement, ABN Amro's longtime Italian partner, Banca Antoniana Popolare Veneta, would then bid for a Banca di Roma unit, Banca Nazionale dell'Agricoltura. Those two banks combined would rank among Italy's top 10. C2.

HEADLINE: New York Puts On a More Hospitable Face

BYLINE: By KATHERINE E. FINKELSTEIN 

 BODY:
New York City has often had a love-hate relationship with its tourists. Sure, their money fuels the economy, but they also crowd Manhattan streets and make it even tougher to get restaurant reservations. And while locals do offer directions to out-of-towners, albeit reluctantly, the city continues to be a daunting place for visitors to master.
Yesterday, the city took a step toward greater hospitality with the opening of a computerized visitor information center in midtown that is designed to help tourists navigate a maze of cultural offerings using state-of-the-art technology. It will let visitors purchase tickets to a multitude of events and get up-to-the-minute information on many of the city's cultural and recreational offerings. Its operator, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, calls it the most technologically advanced center of its kind in the world. 
 But the welcome mat is being rolled out only so far: In true New York fashion, the center will not have public restrooms. Nell Barrett, a spokeswoman for the Convention and Visitors Bureau, said space constraints would not allow anything but a single toilet for use by the staff members. The center occupies 2,200 square feet.
"Obviously, if someone is in dire need they can use it, but it's not being promoted," she said.
Despite its lack of comfort facilities, the center, at 810 Seventh Avenue at 53d Street, signifies that New York has finally caught up with other cities in trying to cater to its tourists, said Fran Reiter, president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau, a not-for-profit organization that relies on public-private ventures to promote the city's tourism industry.
"Previously, we have not served visitors as well as we might," she said. "We were so big and so exciting that we assumed we didn't have to sell the city so hard."
New York has more than enough reasons to be accommodating to its tourists. An estimated 35 million visitors will come to the city this year, representing an increase of 53 percent since 1991, according to the Convention and Visitors Bureau. These visitors will pump $14.5 billion into the city's economy, the bureau estimates.
The center, which cost $400,000 to set up, will be open 365 days a year and will be staffed from 8:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on weekdays and from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. on weekends by four clerks who speak a multitude of languages. Its three computerized information kiosks with touch screens allow visitors to find information on attractions like zoos, museums and avant-garde theater.
The center was built in partnership with American Express, Eastman Kodak and an Internet company, CitySearch. It replaces one at 2 Columbus Circle, which helped 250,000 tourists a year and closed in September 1997. While the old center offered "a lot of information," Ms. Barrett said, it had no "bells and whistles."
The new center is intended to market New York's offerings in the information age. The bureau plans to eventually install 17 more kiosks in heavily trafficked areas throughout the five boroughs, Ms. Reiter said. The machines are expected to sell tickets to attractions like the New York Hall of Science in Queens and the New York Skyride at the Empire State Building.
The kiosks may ultimately appear abroad, Ms. Reiter said. There are plans to install one in a tourist center in London that offers information about New York. "We need to be the most welcoming city and the most informative because we have this embarrassment of riches," Ms. Reiter said.
Yet the bureau's sentiments are apparently not universal. As Ms. Reiter unveiled a new street sign labeled Visitors' Way yesterday, a group of passers-by offered an opinion from the other end of the spectrum. "We don't like visitors," they yelled.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1183 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH STILL AT FAST PACE AS HIRING SURGES

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Another big burst of job growth in February showed that the United States economy was still on a roll while wage pressures remained remarkably subdued.
For bond and stock investors yesterday, that combination eased fears of inflation, setting off a wild celebration. Traders drove long-term interest rates down and the Dow Jones industrial average up, with the Dow gaining 2.8 percent, or 268.68 points, to close at a record 9,736.08. 
 Fueled by a boom in construction and consumer spending, American employers added 275,000 jobs to their payrolls, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Since Thanksgiving, the economy has been adding jobs at the staggering pace of 3.2 million a year.
"The economy isn't losing any steam," said Kenneth Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board, a private research organization. "It's going to be a very strong first half."
Despite that, the jobs report -- which also showed that the unemployment rate edged up an insignificant one-tenth of a percentage point, to 4.4 percent, and that hourly wages barely budged, rising a cent -- reassured Wall Street that the Federal Reserve would not feel compelled to raise interest rates soon.
"Remember the movie 'As Good as It Gets'?" asked Daniel Eagan, senior portfolio manager at Black Rock, a Philadelphia investment firm. "We are about as close to that as we can be."
But many economists said the euphoria on Wall Street was overdone. Richard Rippe, the chief economist at Prudential Securities, warned that the latest evidence did not settle the question of whether the Federal Reserve might need to act later this year to try to cool an overheated economy. "The labor market may not have gotten tighter last month," he said, "but we're still creating jobs at an unsustainable pace."
The bump in the unemployment rate, for example, does not necessarily mean that workers are getting easier to find. The Labor Department says that any change of less than two-tenths of a percentage points carries little if any significance. In February, the change reflected a sharp drop in employment as measured by the so-called household survey. But it is not unusual for the household survey -- on which the jobless rate is based -- to give a weaker reading than the more reliable employer survey of actual payroll changes, according to Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
In fact, employment growth in the household survey has lagged behind for several years. The survey asks individuals about employment among members of their household and uses a much smaller sample than the employer survey. It is also an extremely volatile survey, having shown a gain of more than 700,000 jobs in January, three times the increase in the payroll survey, but then showing a drop of 200,000 last month.
Wage pressures appeared to ease last month. Hourly wages of rank-and-file workers, after jumping by a nickel in January, moved up only a cent in February, to $13.04.
Yet outside of manufacturing -- which cut 50,000 jobs as industry remained under relentless cost pressure -- virtually every indicator of current and future job activity was flashing green.
Weekly jobless claims, for instance, have fallen steadily, with the measure now at a 10-year low. The Conference Board's help-wanted index, which measures demand for workers, jumped sharply in January. And the latest quarterly survey from Manpower Inc., a temporary-help company based in Milwaukee that regularly polls 16,000 employers, showed that 29 percent expected to expand payrolls this spring while just 6 percent foresaw cuts.
"We see no deterioration of hiring strength," said Mitchell Fromstein, the chief executive of Manpower.
While job growth this fast is a boon for workers, especially the youngest, the least educated and the lowest paid, it poses risks for the economy.
If the recent hot pace were to continue, unemployment would fall below 4 percent within months, and the economy would be back in territory not seen since the late 1960's, when demands for higher wages started to burst out into inflation after a long period of quiescence.
True, inflation -- instead of rising as many economists had predicted -- has declined even as unemployment has remained below 5 percent for well over a year. The question is whether it makes sense to extrapolate that pattern into the future.
Some researchers think the labor market is getting more efficient. "It looks like something might have changed," said Alan Krueger, a labor economist at Princeton University, who is studying whether the expanding role of temporary help may be enabling companies to attract scarce workers without pushing up the entire wage scale.
Others, like Robert Gordon at Northwestern University, contend that the nation has had some lucky breaks -- rock-bottom prices for oil and other commodities, a stronger dollar and cheaper imports -- that are bound to disappear when the rest of the world's financial woes ease.
Whatever the future, the juxtaposition of strength in the mammoth service economy that employs most Americans and the weakness in manufacturing has persisted since the Asian financial crisis erupted in the summer of 1997. The size of the industrial job cuts in February, however, was something of a surprise because there had been a flurry of other indicators suggesting that the pain there was diminishing.
Some of the cuts were in industries that have long been ailing: the garment industry lost another 15,000 jobs. Others were in seemingly healthy sectors, although the Labor Department warned that the decline of 8,000 in auto employment was probably a statistical fluke.
Factory workers were not the only ones getting the ax. With gasoline as low as 80 cents a gallon in parts of the country, another 10,000 or so oil workers were cut from rigs, probably to sign on to construction crews.
Building continued to boom despite a few signs that higher interest rates might be starting to dampen mortgage applications. With mild weather and strong demand for everything from housing to new shops, 72,000 workers joined construction payrolls in February, bringing the total added since Labor Day to more than a quarter-million.
The lines at cash registers help explain why retailers are struggling to hang on to workers they might have laid off during what in most years is the slower winter season. They added 123,000 workers, adjusted, as are all the figures, to take account of past seasonal variations. And business services have been soaking up workers, adding 40,000 new jobs in areas like computer processing and management consulting. Health care employment, which has been stagnating for a while, jumped, too, as home-care agencies added more nurses and aides.
Even though hourly earnings barely rose, the measure can show flukes because its coverage is limited to rank-and-file workers and its month-to-month changes are often dominated by fluctuations in the types of employees who happened to get hired that month. Still, the rise from a year ago was just 3.6 percent, a slowdown from last summer.

HEADLINE: Turning the Tables

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
In the initial skirmishes last year over how to allocate potentially huge Federal budget surpluses, President Clinton triumphed politically by casting himself as the prudent protector of Social Security against irresponsible Republican tax cutters.
Now Republican leaders have taken a shot at turning that dynamic on its head. Putting aside more than a year of squabbling among themselves, they presented a broad budget outline on Thursday that will almost certainly prove impossible to turn into detailed legislation but that gives the party a unified set of principles with which to face the White House. 
 At the heart of the Republican approach is a pledge to be even purer than Mr. Clinton when it comes to Social Security. The Republican plan would end the longstanding practice by Congress and successive Administrations of spending money earmarked for the retirement system, and instead would set it aside for use in any plan to shore up the system or to reduce the national debt.
By taking Social Security out of the equation, Republicans hope, they no longer have to worry that tax cuts will be portrayed as benefiting the wealthy at the expense of the elderly. At last, they say, they have a shot at neutralizing an issue that has played to the political advantage of Democrats since Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Social Security into law 64 years ago and that Mr. Clinton has used with particular skill.
"We've escaped from the box Bill Clinton built for us," a senior Republican aide said today.
Not likely. At least not completely.
The White House pivoted neatly today and turned the debate to whether Republicans were doing enough to make sure that Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and a political touchstone second only to Social Security, could weather the aging of the population. (There is plenty in their plan for Medicare, Republicans responded.)
Many of the biggest legislative battles are still ahead, especially the fight over whether Social Security should be remade to include private investment accounts, as most Republicans want.
Moreover, the Republican budget framework, however effective and appealing in the abstract, could face difficulties when it comes to putting it into the form of a budget resolution, the tax and spending guideline on which Congress plans to vote within six weeks.
The most pressing problem for Republicans is that their plan will require deep domestic cuts in order to live up to the party's pledge to stick to spending limits imposed by the 1997 budget deal. That is ground on which Republicans have fought several times and lost, badly, since they won control of Congress in 1994.
Belt-tightening makes sense to many Republicans as a negotiating position across the table from a President who has repeatedly outfoxed them to win financing for political and policy priorities. But there is limited enthusiasm within the party for wading back into an ideological battle over the size of government.
Moderate Republicans, who hold the key to passage of the party's legislation, are especially wary of such a fight. And Republicans on the appropriations committees, which have to pass specific spending bills, said the budget outline left them in an impossible situation, since they see no realistic way to remain within the spending caps while also accommodating calls from within their own party for increased spending on the military and education.
"Maybe there's some magic way to make it work," said one Republican aide to the House Appropriations Committee. "If so, we're eager to hear what it is."
The Republican plan would also make it difficult to enact a sizable tax cut for next year, a goal that only a month ago the party considered nonnegotiable. Taking Social Security revenues out of the budget equation will leave the Federal Government running a $5 billion deficit next year, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
There are various ways of paying for a moderate tax cut next year, including closing loopholes or cutting the tax rate on capital gains, a step that would paradoxically increase revenue for the first year or two as investors rushed to sell stocks that had appreciated in value. But Republicans said their secret weapon when it came to tax cuts was the economy, which continues to grow faster than expected and therefore to generate more tax revenue than the budget office has so far recognized.
Several Republicans said today that the party's leadership expected the projection of a deficit (not counting Social Security) for next year to be transformed into a sizable surplus by the time Congress turns to writing a tax bill this summer. Such a surplus, one House aide said, would provide enough money both to ease the pressure on the spending limits and to enact the first phase of what would grow to be a substantial tax cut over the next decade.
One thing that has become clear is that surplus politics could be just as bitter and complicated as deficit politics were. "G.O.P. Stops Clinton Raid on Social Security," proclaimed the headline on a news release today from Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee and a Presidential hopeful.
The more aggressive posture among Republicans was also evident in comments today by the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, who assailed the Administration for proposing to finance hurricane relief to Central America out of this year's surplus, all of which is accounted for by Social Security revenue.
"I will oppose any effort to steal the Social Security funds that rightly belong to our senior citizens," Mr. Lott said.
White House officials praised the Republicans for the broader agreement to save a big part of the surplus for Social Security. But Administration officials are confident of their ability to hold the fiscal high ground by concentrating their attacks on the vagueness of Republicans when it comes to providing new money for Medicare.
"It's hard to think of something that would be more irresponsible fiscal policy," said Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy director, than to commit all the projected surpluses "to other things when we know Medicare is running out of money in 2008."

China Stole U.S. Secrets For Its Bombs, Officials Say
China has made a leap in the development of nuclear weapons -- the miniaturization of its bombs -- by using nuclear secrets stolen from an American Government laboratory, Administration officials said. The espionage probably occurred in the mid-1980's, officials said, but it was not detected until 1995. Government investigators identified a suspect, an American scientist at the Los Alamos laboratory, where the first atomic bomb was developed. A1

Zhu Rongji, reporting on his first year as Prime Minister, told the annual session of the National People's Congress that despite the "grim environment at home and abroad," China would forge ahead with the overhaul of state industries and a streamlining of Government bureaucracy. Federal Court Strikes Law On Violence and Women
A 1994 law that allows rape victims to sue their attackers on grounds that their civil rights were violated was declared unconstitutional by a Federal appeals court in Virginia. Aftermath of an Oil Spill

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Price Paid Dairy Farmers Is Poised to Plummet

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Milk producers enjoying record high prices will experience a sharp drop in the next month, the largest change in one month in history, the Agriculture Department said today.
Consumers should begin to see a decline in the prices of milk, cheese, butter and other dairy products by midsummer, economists say. 
 The Agriculture Department said the basic milk price received by producers would drop to $10.27 per hundred pounds of milk from $16.27.
The largest month-to-month decline ever recorded was a $2.52 dip, said Chris Nubern, an economist with the National Milk Producers Federation.
The Government determines the price each month by surveying manufacturers about the price paid to producers and then announcing the figure as a guideline for the industry.
The coming drop is earlier than normal. Prices paid to producers usually fall in the summer when it is hotter and milk production declines.
The decrease is partly a result of increased production prompted by the record prices, Mr. Nubern said, adding, "We're in a market where a lot of milk is being produced, and that's driving prices down."
But milk producers will have a cushion, because Congress included $200 million for dairy producers in last year's emergency farm aid.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: Without a Cause

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is University Professor and Maurice B. Hexter Professor of Social and Economic Policy at Brandeis University.

 BODY:

THE SECRET LIVES OF CITIZENS
Pursuing the Promise of American Life.
By Thomas Geoghegan.
240 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $25.
TODAY'S young adults are the first generation born this century to have missed the passion of American liberalism. Previous generations witnessed the crusading muckrakers and suffragettes, the zeal of the New Dealers and of the labor leaders Sidney Hillman and John L. Lewis, the vigor of John and Robert Kennedy, the righteousness of Martin Luther King Jr. and the freedom riders, the ardor and agony of the Vietnam War protesters and the fervor of the women's rights movement. There were excesses and hypocrisies all along the way, but also a thundering insistence on broader democracy and a more inclusive prosperity. 
 Now, at the century's end, most liberals would be content to save Social Security, not exactly an issue that gets the blood flowing. In this era of the most conservative Democratic President of the century, political passions seem the exclusive province of the right, those who want to slash taxes and end affirmative action and abortions.
What happened? Thomas Geoghegan, a crafty writer who moonlights as a Chicago attorney, blames the hollowing of America's great Northern cities, which were once incubators of progressive politics, and the withering of the Federal Government, which once gave such a politics a national scope. In Geoghegan's view, the states have quietly sucked the energy out of both and substituted lowest-common-denominator governments more responsive to the rich and the wacky than to the blue collars and the underdogs.
Geoghegan does not actually make this argument in "The Secret Lives of Citizens." Instead, he circles it like a dog chasing a scent. His is a whimsical, personal journey that never quite gets anywhere but stops at a lot of interesting and oddball spots along the way. The trail begins and ends in Chicago. The city is shrinking, surrounded by ever-expanding suburbs run by faux governments (DuPage County to the west, transportation authorities, mosquito abatement districts, the Northeastern Illinois Planning Commission) that meet secretly in hotel conference rooms to decide things like where to locate new runways and tollways. Once seething with ethnic ward politics, Chicago has become dull and soulless, Geoghegan says, filling up with young corporate achievers who don't even know where the wards are.
What's worse, power has tilted toward the Sunbelt states. New baseball teams don't even bear the names of cities anymore -- they're Texas Rangers, Arizona Diamondbacks and Florida Marlins. The original sin, according to Geoghegan, was Franklin Roosevelt's failure to apply the New Deal to the South. The ploy enabled Roosevelt to get legislation through Congress, but it proved a long-term curse. The South had no labor unions or wage bargaining. "It was as if a hole had been punched in the bottom of the New Deal. The wages, the jobs could leak slowly into the South. . . . Drip, drip, at first. Then gushing, in a flood." After revenue sharing became the core of Richard Nixon's Southern strategy, the Sunbelt got the infrastructure it needed to attract Northern industry. As competition intensified, the South's population and share of the gross national product exploded. And places like Chicago began emptying out.
Devolution to the states is all the rage now in Washington, whose officials seem oblivious of the states' tradition of corruption and ineptitude. Geoghegan remarks that United States attorneys could exist simply to prosecute state governments. After all, the savings-and-loan scandal happened after the states took on responsibility to regulate the companies. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court is busy reviving the ghost of John C. Calhoun, who once claimed that states could nullify laws of Congress. But if the Calhounists were correct, Geoghegan asks, how could we have ever abolished slavery? It's not just Roosevelt who's under attack now; it's Lincoln. The progressive writer Herbert Croly had warned early on: if the states got stronger and Washington weaker, all the old evils would return -- inequality, stagnant wages and big business running the country.
What's a citizen to do? It's the serious question that lies at the heart of the book, but Geoghegan answers it ironically. Democratic Presidents used to give Americans things to do, he writes. Roosevelt told us to join a union, Kennedy asked us to join the Peace Corps, Johnson to go to the inner city and teach children. But Carter didn't say. And although Clinton urged us to volunteer, he was evasive. "Volunteer for what?" Geoghegan asks. "Join a militia in rural Michigan?" National Democrats haven't a clue what to do, other than raise campaign money. You can't even find out at a place like Harvard's Kennedy School, where it's "all microeconomics. Cost benefit. Deregulation. Getting prices right -- which usually implies, I have found, getting wages wrong." A young woman at the school sobs, "I came here because I wanted to help people, and now, now . . . now they say . . . I can't do anything!"
What's Geoghegan himself to do? His grandfather, we learn, was a popular county commissioner during the Depression. "It would take us half an hour to walk a block, people coming up to shake his hand," he boasts. But Geoghegan won't run for office ("the shame was: I'd never live like my grandfather"), and he never quite decides what else would be worth doing. He comes to Washington in the 1970's, an idealistic young lawyer (from his previous book, "Which Side Are You On?," we know he worked for a time with the unions); gets a job at the Energy Department, which turns out to be a big bumbling bureaucracy; moves back to Chicago and campaigns for Harold Washington, but once Washington becomes Mayor his program is blocked by a group of white aldermen.
Later, Geoghegan considers suing Chicago for failing to control an outbreak of tuberculosis but then realizes it won't end the poverty that lies at the root of the disease. He considers a public-interest lawsuit to challenge residential parking, but it won't help the poor either. He wants to prevent poor youngsters from working, but it's not practical. He fantasizes about becoming a teacher. He briefly volunteers to help poor kids get jobs as movie ushers. He ponders how to get speedier trials for jailed defendants but is told by a public defender that a brief stint in jail may not be so bad for them.
This is a sly and ultimately sad book, written more as a prose poem than a serious argument. Geoghegan's language is playful, as when he describes regional governments as "little asteroid bits" that "float around, with no clear boundaries," and sometimes purple ("Every city in America seems the same now, doesn't it? One half: Girls, in tennis whites, dawdling over cat calendars. The other half: Babies, in crack houses, sitting in feces"). The paragraphs often run no more than one or two sentences, personal reminiscence mixing with historical anecdote, dipping into complex themes and then out again, mood shifting from wistful nostalgia to dark comedy.
At the end, Geoghegan finds himself at an interracial, interfaith, urban-suburban rally on crime control. Afterward, he drives home with a friend who asks what the group is going to do. "I don't know," he answers. "But that's the problem, nobody knows what to do." Geoghegan liked the meeting anyway, because it brought people together. The conclave was a symbolic gesture, and he gives it a metaphorical shrug. What to do besides shrug? With liberal passions gone and Chicago hollowing out, the author never quite decides.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1836 words

HEADLINE: There Goes the Neighborhood

BYLINE: By D. J. R. Bruckner; D. J. R. Bruckner is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:

THROWIM WAY LEG
Tree-Kangaroos, Possums, and Penis Gourds -- On the Track of Unknown Mammals in Wildest New Guinea.
By Tim Flannery.
Illustrated. 326 pp. New York:
Atlantic Monthly Press. $25.
"IT is always slightly unnerving arriving at a new location" in New Guinea, Tim Flannery says. "You have no idea what the locals will be like or how you will be received." What an understatement! This man walked alone into a village for the first time and overheard three locals agreeing to kill him, and that is far from the most threatening situation he found himself in. The title of his book, "Throwim Way Leg," is pidgin for going on a journey. Flannery, a celebrated mammalogist and paleontologist at the Australian Museum in Sydney, made 15 long research excursions into New Guinea beginning in 1981, when he was 26; in a dozen years he identified at least 17 new species of mammals, and his "Mammals of New Guinea" (1990) is the standard scientific guide. But "Throwim Way Leg" is more than an account of his fieldwork. It is an enthralling introduction to the mountain people of New Guinea -- unimaginably remote, charming, cunning, cruel, subtle and appealing -- and to their magnificent land. Flannery is not always an eloquent writer, but his evocations of the New Guinean landscape carry you away. 
 About 12,000 years ago, when the ocean swallowed an ice-age land bridge between Australia and New Guinea, life on the island was cut off from the world. In a place with no pack animals, where walking is the only locomotion and passage in any direction requires scaling mountains rising from 5,000 to 15,000 feet, people became so isolated from one another that today almost 1,000 languages are used. Equatorial monsoons sweeping the mountains create alpine swamps in the clouds, and on such wet vertical terrain arable tracts and dwelling spaces are few and distant, so the islanders formed tribes in tiny villages, warring with one another for 500 generations. No common identity developed and there is no political history -- kingdoms, pyramids, common religion, shared culture, all that.
Early in this century the Netherlands claimed the western half of the island and Australia the eastern half. But they stuck to the coast. Only in the late 30's was much contact made with mountain people, the vast bulk of the population. Now the world is moving in. In 1963 Dutch New Guinea became Irian Jaya, a province of Indonesia, and in 1975 the Australian territory became a nation, Papua New Guinea. There are still almost no roads on the island, and none across it; but small airstrips multiply, and international companies operate gold and copper mines. So the tribesmen are moving in a lifetime from the Neolithic period into the global Westernized economy.
Flannery's intimacy with them was necessary: to find unknown species of mammals he needed local hunters. They could eat their prey and he got the skin and bones for his natural history museum. Soon he needed the tribesmen for their rich companionship; readers will share his respect for their intelligence and his delight in their cutting sense of humor, especially about sex, and in their practical jokes, childish but shrewd tests of the wit of their targets. Rightly, Flannery honored the tribesmen in scientific names he gave a few species. (He had an amusing payback in kind through a youth who helped him clean dead animals and took as reward a gut parasite from them, which he swallowed alive. A parasitologist to whom Flannery sent one of these creatures found it was a new species and named it Flannery's tapeworm: Burtiela flanneryi.) The tribesmen spring vividly from these pages, speaking in their own voices, and you will remember many by name.
Some are cannibals. A lot of lurid speculation has been published about New Guinea cannibalism over the last 50 years, so the sobriety of Flannery's account is a relief. A village headman told him a revealing story about where his son, a young man Flannery admires, came from: The headman's village staged an attack on a neighboring community, killed all the adults, gutted their carcasses to carry home for food and raised the children as their own, among them a baby hidden in a tree -- his son. His wife added: "We ate his . . . parents. . . . They gave me all the milk I needed to nourish two children." Flannery says cannibalism was never ubiquitous in New Guinea -- nothing is -- but other cannibals appear here, including a great hunter who, in a fit of blinding grief, hatcheted his daughter and commanded his family to feast on her.
Flannery offers no excuses, and few judgments. He does say that in some tribes child mortality nears 100 percent and, with governments now curbing the traditional village raids, certain communities face extinction. In fact, the whole population does, every day, from cholera, malaria, ringworm, amebic dysentery, pig tapeworm, tropical ulcers, intestinal roundworms and scrub typhus (not to mention hypothermia on mountain passes where people wearing little more than penis gourds or grass skirts can easily end up as wild-dog food). Flannery's own experience of several of these diseases is grim reading; you know he must love his work.
There can be no animal he is not fond of -- the possums and marsupials he is the world's leading student of, certainly, but also singing dogs, wild pigs, shrieking frogs, a spider that does a Christo number on whole trees and a brilliant array of birds of paradise (their displays, in his words, can raise goose bumps). He has a toe-tickling dalliance with a preposterously affectionate giant anteater and lingers over a yard-long cave rat that "let out a loud, doglike snarl" at him. He even likes a 10-foot black python that nearly bested him in what he calls a match between "the snake and its prospective meal." His passion is tree kangaroos -- they took to the canopies of rain forests when food got scarce below -- although it is unfeeling of him, I think, to say they look "rather clumsy in the treetops." The high point of his scientific career, he says, was his classification of a black-and-white species that was legendary among the tribes but had never been seen by an outsider before a hunter brought him one. He named it dingiso, which is what the locals call it. (It should be said here that Flannery's American publisher gives him little help. He often compares animals in New Guinea with those in Australia, and an American who does not know a wallaby from a wombat is left to wonder. Also, while there is a small gallery of his photographs, only a couple are of animals; pictures or drawings of others are so obviously needed that their absence is a bit insulting.)
ONE wonders: can such rare animals long survive? Taboos are the only protection for some, Flannery says, and the lifting of a taboo or the invasion of a sacred territory by a distant tribe can wipe out a species in months. In 1975 the skull and bones of an ice-age bat of singular rarity were found. The animal entered the scientific roster as Bulmer's fruit bat, the world's largest, extinct for 12 millenniums. In 1977 an anthropologist sent to a bat expert in Sydney a skull saved from a banquet of roast bat he attended in New Guinea. It was a Bulmer's fruit bat. The expert rushed to the cave where the mountain people had gathered their feast and found no sign that a single bat was left -- Extinction II. What had happened was this: The tribe living near the cave observed a taboo against touching the bats. But hunters from another tribe lowered a man on a rope into the cave, armed with a pernicious piece of Western technology: the anthropologist's shotgun. He blasted away at the cave ceiling and thousands of bats fell. Other tribes heard about this and devoured the rest. But not quite all: 10 years later Flannery saw a few bats emerge from the cave. One night, hanging by fingers and toes from treetops teetering over a 1,000-foot-deep shaft above the cave entrance, he and a colleague caught a live Bulmer's fruit bat in a net. If the local tribe can now make outsiders observe its taboo, the species may survive.
The traditional life of the mountain people is unlikely to, despite Flannery's wistful hope. That many younger people are so intrigued by Western clothes, gadgetry, machinery and, most tellingly, money does not augur well for what the tribesmen call "the old ways." The prospect brings a tone of discontent with Western civilization into Flannery's voice -- not complaint but low background noise, perhaps left over from the big bang of political correctness 20 years ago. Thus he repeatedly snipes at Christianity for trying to change morals and clothe nudity. But his own testimony contradicts him: the only outsiders in his book who compete with the locals in vital eccentricity are two European Roman Catholic priests who in dramatically different ways inspire the tribes to hang onto as much of the old ways as they can.
Flannery's fear that Irian Jaya will combust is more compelling. Jakarta promotes migrations of Indonesians into the island and relentlessly tries to impose Javanese social order. Only a large armed force keeps control, and it has killed thousands of tribal people. In 1996 Flannery found that most mountain villagers he visited assumed there would soon be a war between them and the Indonesian Army. A symbol of the situation is a huge gold mine in the Irian mountains, run by an American company. Tribesmen say they could live with the company if it were truly autonomous, but it is as entwined by Jakarta as Flannery was by the python. The Government has built near the mine a Javanese city for 25,000 people (expandable to 250,000) in the midst of a rain forest, gleaming new and as yet unoccupied when Flannery saw it -- a chilling, empty monster. Yet the mining company supported his research, and he dedicates the book to its chairman and those of other mining interests in the region "in the hope that . . . they will understand a little better the people whose lives they so profoundly change."
In fact, he owes to the miners the most lovable character of all, appearing in a few emotionally charged pages at the end that evince the wonder and sweet sadness of the whole book. In 1994 a miner called Flannery in Sydney, summoning him urgently. He returned to find, in a miniature rain forest constructed on a porch, a young male dingiso that had wandered into the mine site, the first living one he met. The miners called it Ding. "As I opened the screen door to peer in, Ding . . . hopped out of the foliage and came towards me," he says, and its gentle personality comes right off the page into the reader's heart. After a few days Flannery and a pilot airlifted the tree kangaroo into the mountains: "When we released him into the alpine herbage, Ding hopped away very slowly, sampling leaves as he went. He was in no hurry to leave us, and it was only after several minutes that he disappeared into a dense tangle of bushes."
