SECTION: Section 6; Page 70; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 453 words

HEADLINE: THE HUMAN HABITAT: Improvising, From Cairo to Kansas;
Beyond the Old Woman In The Shoe

BYLINE: By Witold Rybczynski

 BODY:
What is it with these people? Do they wake up one day and say, "Let's move to that abandoned missile silo" or "Why don't we buy an old plane and turn it into a house"? What drives people to do something this, well, bizarre? Economics, surely, isn't the only reason. Unlike Diogenes, who lived in a tub, they don't appear to be ascetics. Maybe they want to be different, to be noticed; not just to own a conversation piece but to live in one. In fact, these are some of the same sentiments that motivate the clients of high-style architecture. After all, living in a caboose is no more odd than living in a house with all-glass walls or in a house perched over a waterfall, to name but two famous architectural landmarks.
Of course, there is a difference between saying that "a house is a machine for living in," as Le Corbusier did, and making a house out of a real machine. High-style architecture, especially modern high-style architecture, often thumbs its nose at comfort and convenience. It challenges its owners to do without. The challenge for aspiring caboose dwellers is different. Once they have made the plunge -- admittedly a high dive -- they usually work hard to transform their unfamiliar surroundings into something resembling a house. It is not easy to turn a missile silo or a Boeing 747 into a more or less cozy home. Where do you put the bathtub? How do you get in? What about closets? Like Robinson Crusoe, the builder makes do and improvises with whatever is at hand. 
 Curiously, unlike high-art houses, which sometimes appear arrogant, these distinctly quirky homes actually reinforce our shared sense of domesticity. A quaint colonial porch light immediately transforms the vaultlike entrance to an underground missile site. A television in a mausoleum sends an unmistakable signal. A school bus up on cinder blocks is just a vehicle, but a school bus with flower boxes, lace window curtains and a door knocker is somebody's home. Such is the potency of our household symbols.
These odd houses are endearingly makeshift. I am reminded of the nursery rhyme "There was an old woman who lived in a shoe." I think that part of the fascination with improvised dwellings has to do with childhood memories. Children, so conservative in many ways, are inveterate and inventive house builders. Something as simple as a card table, a chair and a blanket can become a house; or the cardboard carton that the refrigerator came in, holes cut out for doors and windows, turns into a bungalow. I remember constructing playhouses in trees, building sand castles on the beach and digging forts deep in translucent snowbanks. Now I live in a house, just like everyone else. Well, almost everyone.

PUB-DATE: March 7, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Page 39; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2945 words

HEADLINE: THE HUMAN HABITAT;
The Real World of Interiors.

BYLINE: By Michael Pollan

 BODY:
The twilight struggle between Life and Design surely counts as one of the great long-running stories of the century now ending. This clash of terms has given us battles drenched in both tragedy and farce, on fronts as different as the Iron Curtain and the curtain wall, Soviet collective farms and Corbusian villas, American urban-renewal projects and, if I may add a somewhat less famous skirmish to the list, the redecoration of my parents' apartment in the early 1970's. It was during this episode, which took place when I was 15, that I first understood how easily our dreams of a more perfect order can founder on the shoals of everyday life.
In my family's case, the dream of a more perfect order was supplied by a man named William Machado, the interior decorator my mother chose from the pages of a home-design magazine to redo the dated and gloomy Manhattan co-op my family had moved into the year before, making the big step up from our ranch house on Long Island. In memory, Machado looks exactly like Jerome Robbins, with the same scrupulously clipped salt-and-pepper beard, the erect dancer's bearing and an austere, somewhat formal manner not at all in keeping with the times. It was always an occasion when he came by to present his color schemes and fabric swatches, my mother according him the deference due a maestro, while my father grumpily eyed his watch and mentally patted his wallet. 
 The summer of the renovation, my parents removed the whole family to the beach for the duration, and it was there that one of the unsolved mysteries of my childhood unfolded -- one that, in retrospect, should have served as fair warning to us all that living under (or up to) Machado's design was not going to be easy. It concerned Binker, our English bulldog. Bought on sale from a pet store by my father, Binker was in every respect a horrible creature. She attacked children without provocation. With a snorty flick of her great, bejowled head, Binker could fling a ropy lariat of drool 20 feet, and if that didn't empty the room, her staggering smell would finish the job. We surmised that Binker's digestive and respiratory tracts had somehow been crossed, for her breath seemed to come from someplace other than a lung. Binker also suffered from eczema and incontinence, though the latter condition may have represented nothing more than an extreme manifestation of her laziness. Either way, Binker's existence, which might be said to represent the antithesis of good design, posed a mortal challenge to Machado's work in progress, and as the renovation progressed, my parents could often be heard fretting about the dog's future in the new apartment.
Then the mysterious thing happened. One morning a few days before we were due to move back into the finished apartment, Binker quietly and conveniently expired in her sleep. It would never have occurred to me to suspect foul play -- Binker was getting on in years -- except that my father made such a big show of taking her to the animal hospital for an autopsy. He returned brandishing an official-looking document declaring that Binker had died, and I quote, of "natural causes."
When I saw the new apartment, I knew right away that Binker was better off having departed this world for what could only be a more imperfect one. All our old stuff was gone, and the living room had been transformed into a meticulously composed tableau, a spacious, tranquil room, done in shades of wheat and sand and clay, that occupied an existential plane somewhere between high-tech and Zen. I remember thinking that it looked just like a magazine, and wondered if the new living room was going to get the sort of velvet-rope treatment I'd run into at some kids' houses. There was one friend's place I must have been over a thousand times before even setting (unshod) foot in the living room, a plushly carpeted Danish Moderne space as blue and airless as the sea.
A few days after we moved in, Machado himself showed up to put the finishing touches on his masterwork. He spent an entire day arranging the wall of books in the living room, until he had satisfied himself that he had achieved the ideal composition of upright Modern Library volumes alternating with great slabs of art books stacked on their sides, and here and there the occasional jaunty leaner canted at a precise 60 degrees off plumb. Books whose spine color or typography he judged unesthetic were exiled to the bedrooms, along with all our paperbacks. To give the whole wall the proper amount of compositional air, he left spaces between the book clusters for a collection of considered objects -- a pair of kachina dolls, a carved Inuit stone and various pre-Columbian tchotchkes. Some of this stuff I recognized as my mother's, but a lot of it I'd never seen before.
I had to admit that the bookshelves were beautiful, as much a work of art as half the volumes perched on them, yet they soon became a symbol of the vague oppression Machado's design had visited on our daily lives. Though to their credit (and peril), my parents never ruled the new living room off-limits to minors, Machado's bookshelves quickly emerged as a source of family tension. My mother informed us that each time we removed a book from the Wall, we were to leave a little slip of paper in its place so the book could be returned to its designated spot. As you might expect, this regime didn't survive very long, and in short order several of the Modern Librarys were found lying down, and a few of the leaners began looking less casual than sloshed.
The creep of entropy took its psychological toll on my mother, but her fidelity to Machado's art never quite exceeded her devotion to her children (a proposition we sought daily to test), because she continued to let us take out books. What we didn't know then was that she had made a graph-paper sketch of Machado's tableau, recording each book's precise address and the cosine of every leaner, and after we went to bed she would set to work putting the Wall right again, holding the picture perfect for one more day.
I realize now that my mother's sketch of Machado's bookshelf arrangement was her way of defending his design against the inevitable frictions of time and habitation -- arguably the Achilles' heel of 20th-century design. Ever since the modernists, whose rise happened to coincide with the advent of architectural photography, much of the energy of interior design has been directed toward that single pristine moment my mother was struggling to preserve: the day the finished but not yet inhabited house gets its picture taken, freezing it in time. This is the moment memorialized in the magazine layout, the still point on which designers' careers turn. After that, it's downhill. "Very few of the houses," Frank Lloyd Wright once complained, were "anything but painful to me after the clients moved in and, helplessly, dragged the horrors of the old order along after them."
A designer's "horrors" are nothing other than the client's favorite stuff -- the furniture, pictures, curios, books, mementos and keepsakes accumulated over a life. We prize these things not necessarily for their beauty, and certainly not for the harmonious way they fit together, but because they tell a story about us, individuals with a particular history that, over time, gets written on the walls of our homes. The problem is, that story is not necessarily the same one a designer wants to tell. He doesn't want his work of art haunted by our past or, for that matter, left open to the imprint of our futures.
All art aspires to the condition of timelessness, but what, in a house, is time? It is simply us, going about our lives, taking books off the shelf and putting them back wrong, adding a souvenir from a vacation to the mantle, taping a report card to the fridge, leaving crescent moons of coffee on the new butcher block. (Did I mention the new kitchen counters? For years my mother would apply a nightly poultice of Bon Ami to the butcher block, hoping to bleach out the traces of the day.) As inevitably as weathering, the process of inhabiting a space leaves the marks of time all over it, and so constitutes a declension from the designer's ideal.
It was the modernists who first came up with a solution to this design problem, a way to keep our stuff and all the other traces of habitation out of the picture. They would insist on designing their interiors down to the very last detail, not only the bookshelves and cabinets (Farewell the chests of yesteryear," Le Corbusier had declared) but also the furniture (built in wherever possible) and window treatments, and even in some cases the light fixtures and teapots and ashtrays. This way they could control everything in the picture. And some didn't stop there: Wright went so far as to design new clothes for one client, the better to insure that her presence in his rooms wouldn't spoil their color schemes. The wonder is that there are clients who actually like the idea of having their lives professionally designed. Architects get asked to arrange not only their clients' books but also the toothbrushes in their bathrooms and even the groceries in their pantry. I've seen blueprints prepared for the express purpose of showing a client where to put her olive oil.
Not many of us would ever think to have a designer pre-position our salad oils, and yet we're avid to look at the homes of the kind of people who do -- that is, the scrupulously styled rooms splashed across the spreads of shelter books like House & Garden and Metropolitan Home. At least, I know I am, even after having spent part of my childhood trying to live within the confines of such a magazine spread. We look, even though we understand no one really lives like that, even when we know a not-very-bookish stylist has handpicked the bedside reading, that the ottoman was brought in to bestow a credit on an advertiser and that the Phalaenopsis has already gone back to the orchid-rental guy.
Yet there's a powerful fantasy on offer here, and it's not just a fantasy of wealth, though surely that comes into it. For me, at least, it's a daydream of a more ordered and coherent existence (not to mention a really good housekeeper). In this other life, the wave of clutter and information threatening to break over us has somehow been tamed. Notice how rarely a TV or computer or even a magazine disturbs the peace of these rooms; indeed, the images themselves implicitly deny the existence -- the pressures -- of the very world that produced them. Also, the harmonious tableaux bespeak an equally harmonious marriage, a meeting of the minds on how two people, or a family, can live happily together. (Never mind that few interludes can ruin a marriage quicker than the building of one of these places.) So, yes, these rooms ask us to suspend our disbelief, and we do, accepting these frozen signs of habitation for the flowing, tangled thing itself.
The picture in the magazine also gratifies our voyeurism, for how often do we get to peer into the kitchens or bedrooms of perfect strangers? Yet we seldom get to see how other people inhabit their houses, which is to say, live their private, at-home lives. Shelter magazines offer only the thinnest sampling of the myriad forms domestic life can take. Even today, when "good design" is no harder to find than the nearest Crate & Barrel, most of us continue to make our places according to our own idiosyncratic lights. We'll buy one of those from there, borrow this idea or that from Martha Stewart or the people next door, but mostly we're happy to let life's accidents and passing fancies shape and reshape our interiors. We might start out with a picture, but we usually end up with a story.
I'm thinking of a couple of rooms I've been in recently, rooms in which the crosscurrents of personal history have exerted a stronger pressure than design or even good taste. The first is a woodsy New England home decorated in what might best be called Amateur Natural Historian. Wasps' nests balloon from tree branches crisscrossing the ceiling; a snake's skeleton stretches out along the mantle; cactuses thick as phone poles tower in the kitchen; a stuffed barn owl supervises the dinner table. Then, in central Florida, a soaring white church of a living room presided over by a floor-to-ceiling hutch displaying, exclusively, a collection of hand-painted Walt Disney plates, each of them tenderly held in a circle of halogen. One more: the handmade house of a friend who died recently, where, on the mantle, his daughters have composed a modest shrine consisting of his first novel, his pocketknife, a family portrait from a sunny time, a guitar pick and a shell from his hunting rifle. The real world of interiors is a far stranger and more wonderful place than any designer or magazine editor can conceive.
The pages that follow -- documenting the insides of homes from Cleveland to Taipei, Brooklyn to Bangkok -- offer abundant, even extravagant proof of this proposition. Taken together, they tell a story of how we go about inhabiting the places we live in, how we make them our own. And though this process is inevitably inflected by the particularities of culture and class, certain elements of the story seem the same just about everywhere.
One is the importance of our stuff -- Wright's "horrors" -- in making, and marking, our places. A novelist could tease entire lives from the contents of a bachelorette's bathroom, or from the boxed dowry items carefully set aside in an Indian farmer's living room, or even from the ghostly marks of furniture pressed into the carpet of an unoccupied house foreclosed on by the bank. Indeed, the emptiest rooms make the point most eloquently -- that, far from being inanimate or mute, our things breathe life into a room. Matter matters.
Particular as we like to think our places are, they seem to pass through predictable phases, not unlike our bodies, and on the walls of our rooms you can read the ages of man. Singles have a specific way of organizing the traffic jam of an apartment share, and the newlywed couple's tentative stabs at interior decoration will tend toward the generic, taking care not to insist on anything too distinctive just yet -- except, of course, images of the newlyweds themselves. Later on our places grow emphatic: think of the richly inhabited, overripe rooms of people who have lived in the same place for 50 years, or the brutally edited last quarters of elderly people who have had to decamp to nursing homes. To peer into such rooms is to realize that what we call "a sense of place" has very little to do with design or space, but is really a function of time.
It was House & Garden that eventually came to photograph our apartment, though in the end my mother wouldn't let them run the pictures. The magazine's stylist had insisted on hanging paintings on the walls and plopping a rented ficus tree on the coffee table in the living room. Machado himself was willing, but my mother refused to go along; if she wasn't going to let her children alter the room's composition, then she certainly wasn't about to let a magazine.
But over time, the press of life got the better of the design. After my grandfather died, my grandmother -- in her 90's and not well -- came to live with us. Machado's living room, where she spent her last afternoons, was gradually transformed by her nurse into a kind of hospital day room, with lots of mismatched chairs for her visitors and a big rented TV on casters. The summer of my freshman year in college, I lived in the apartment with a friend, and we put burns in the butcher block no amount of Bon Ami could erase, though I scoured them till my wrists ached. Books began to migrate more freely in and out of the living room, and new objects gradually infiltrated the Wall, until the whole thing had pretty much relaxed into an unphotogenic normalcy. By then my mother had relaxed, too, and now she'll smile when reminded of her graph-paper sketch.
But the final insult to the design was inflicted by my father, who one day got the bright idea of bringing home another pet store special -- this time a Maltese, a breed he reasoned would be better suited to life in a Manhattan co-op than a bulldog. But though Chauncey may have looked the part, he proved only slightly less awful than his predecessor. He was a macho little mop of a dog who left a white wake of fur and insisted daily on marking every right angle in the apartment, and it wasn't long before it became the sort of place where old Bink might have felt at home.
Looking at the apartment today, a quarter-century after the renovation, it doesn't feel very much like Machado's creation anymore. No, now it seems very much my family's creation, if that's the right word for something shaped by so little intention. The perfect picture has faded almost past recognition, but in its place there's this story -- of one marriage, four childhoods, now a bunch of grandchildren. The last time I was over I noticed that one of my sister's horse- show trophies had found its way onto the Wall, next to my ratty high-school copy of "The Catcher in the Rye." And though the apartment these days can sometimes feel like a museum of my teen years, with my father's original cast album of "The Me Nobody Knows" still on the turntable, one of my wife's paintings recently won a spot on the mantle in the living room, so it's not as though time has stopped here. Le Corbusier, whose own design strove so heroically to escape the press of time, nevertheless knew how it had to end. "Life," he said, "always has the last word."

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- On Language;
Soonerathernlater

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
Whenever a President or other world leader uses a phrase in a highly charged situation, it echoes through the language. Sooner rather than later, it loses its referent and becomes a freestanding idiom; people use the familiar phrase out of voguish habit, forgetting the source that initially popularized it.
On Jan. 22, 1998, during a photo opportunity with a nonplused Yasir Arafat, President Clinton told reporters inquiring about nonforeign relations, "I'd like you to have more rather than less; sooner rather than later." 
 The phrase was repeated supportively by his press secretary, as well as by his former chief of staff, Leon Panetta: "There is going to be a time, and I think it has to be sooner rather than later, where the President has to say to the country what the situation is." As lawyerly counsel was taken and this policy was abandoned, the President's critics used the phrase to beat him about the head. "The President himself states," argued the independent counsel before the Supreme Court, "in January of this year, that the American people are entitled to more rather than less, sooner rather than later."
The phrase was quickly compressed in speech to soonerathernlater and spread far afield. Jane Brenner, a councilwoman from Punta Gorda, Fla., who is striving to save its 1927 courthouse from demolition, told The Sarasota Herald-Tribune, "We're hoping to get the courthouse worked out, and sooner rather than later." A securities analyst in Fort Washington, Pa., asked by Dow Jones about the public offering of Goldman, Sachs, used the phrase as an adjective: "anticipating the sooner-rather-than-later offering of its stock to go public."
The phrase is an outgrowth of sooner or later, the lexicographer Sol Steinmetz informs me. In 1577, Barnaby Googe wrote in his translation of the Dutch author Conrad Heresbach's "Heresbach's Foure Bookes of Husbandry" that "The stones, stickes, and suche baggage . . . are to be thrown out sooner or later." In 1933, J.M. Campbell, writing in Speculum, illustrated both root and branch: "But if efforts to overtake the meaning of a stubborn passage always include the Church Fathers sooner or later, then why not sooner than later?" The earliest citation I can find of S.R.T.L. is in an article from the journal published by the Royal Economic Society in June 1895. Referring to the "Boot War," W.B. Hoffman wrote: "The most we can expect is that repetition of the late disastrous war will not occur for some time to come, but even that hope may be shattered sooner rather than later."
This followed the action of settlers who rushed into Oklahoma before April 22, 1889, to be ready to stake their land claims before the official opening date, and became known as the "Sooners." (Those who followed were called, presumably, the Laters, but left no impact on the language. I put this in as a service to readers in Oklahoma who may not know the origin of their nickname.)
The etymological analogy holds for Mr. Clinton's "more rather than less": that's based on more or less, from 1589, give or take a few years. Give or take, however, in its 1958 sense of "approximate," has not spawned "give rather than take" because it was not used in a crisis of the Presidency.
In stretching out stock phrases resting on the fulcrum of or -- from one thing or another to here or there -- we must ask ourselves, Is this extension necessary? Does the redundancy detract from precision? Is S.R.T.L. any sooner than the unadorned soon? At the end of the day, are we slipping into the easy acceptance of a series of bromides as bad as at the end of the day?
Decide for yourself, one way rather than the other.
 
The New Globality
Globalization was last year's hot word at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Forget it; the world has passed it by. This year's theme was "Responsible Globality."
Coinage was attributed to Daniel Yergin, author of "The Commanding Heights" (appropriate reading in a ski village), who wrote in the May 18, 1998, Newsweek, "We are now beginning to see a reality beyond globalization -- the world of globality."
Reached in Boston, Yergin further explained the term: "What bothered me about globalization," he said, "was that it describes a process. We needed a word to carry it into a state of being. Globality suggests a condition of community and interconnection."
Few feelings are as exhilarating as the thrill of coinage. Some unknown diplomat involved in the normalization of relations smacked his forehead one day and cried, "I've got it -- we've reached normality!" Someday, a soldier denied fraternization with the local girls will long in print for fraternality, an uncoined word to shorten the equally sexist "brotherhood of Man."
Globality is not yet in the dictionaries, though it will be sooner rather than whenever. But sorry, Dan, coinage cannot be claimed; somebody almost always crops up to claim first use of a noun formed from a common adjective.
The correspondent Frank Gervasi wrote in 1943 of "a sense of the globality of the war." The Merriam-Webster files also turn up "even in 1942 a final obstacle to complete globality remained," in the 1942 "Global War," by Edgar Ansel Mowrer and Marthe Rajchman. Econometricians liked it, too: Kiyoshi Kuga observed in the July 1972 Econometrica that "the problem of globality is always important in this topic" of the factor-price equalization theorem, my copy of which does not come readily to hand.
But cheer up, Dan; aside from a 1988 use by an explicator of a papal encyclical (a holy ghostwriter?) and a few murmurings by Eurocrats, globality was awaiting a push. Yergin was the unchallenged popularizer in its current politico-business sense. Globalization, panting, has at last arrived; here we are in a state of doggy-dog globality.

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: Chroniclers of Wayward Souls

BYLINE: By ANN POWERS 

 BODY:
COUNTRY has long been packaged as the classical music of simple American folks. The transformation of hillbilly entertainment into an official repository of our national traditions has extended from the fancy naming of the Grand Ole Opry in 1927 to the appointment of William Ivey, the director of the Country Music Hall of Fame, to the chair of the National Endowment for the Arts in 1998. Not only Nashville's music industry, but also the "alternative" country made by rock- and folk-schooled rebels can be discouragingly orthodox, its vintage trappings turning cultural preservation into historical tourism.
Yet country music is also grounded in dislocation -- in the stories of people facing upheaval in their home towns, their families, their daily life. This is a modern music, tied like the blues to the journeys of working people across America and the encroachment of the city on rural life. The poor wayfaring stranger is as much a honky-tonk cliche as Mama making cornbread, and as country's patina grows ever more nostalgic, even that character's vagrancy becomes strangely fixed. Exile has become another form of home in country, invoked with a warm glow. 
 Country music finds its power in the tension between nostalgia and the need for change, a contradiction mined on two new albums by established iconoclasts. "The Mountain," by Steve Earle with the Del McCoury Band, investigates country's most classical form, bluegrass. "What I Deserve," by Kelly Willis, is more eclectic. Both Mr. Earle and Ms. Willis succeed where many of their contemporaries fail by keeping their focus on restlessness.
"The Mountain" (E Squared, CD, CD 1063-2) is an art project in denim and work boots, a self-conscious effort by Mr. Earle to pay homage to the bluegrass pantheon if not enter it. "My primary motive in writing these songs was both selfish and ambitious -- immortality," he writes in the album's liner notes, and on some songs he has achieved an almost eerie timelessness. It's hard to believe that the murder ballad "Carrie Brown" or the funeral hymn "Pilgrim" hasn't been sung by anonymous town criers for a century, but it's also easy to forget that the plaintive form of "country jazz" that Mr. Earle is reproducing emerged a mere half century ago.
Working with the virtuoso ensemble the Del McCoury Band, Mr. Earle matches venerable themes of heartbreak and war, workingman's struggles and outlaw romance to his casually expert compositions. His patented rocker's snarl meshes with Del McCoury's unearthly wail to form a link across the generations of country renegades. The album's musicianship is notable; its guest roster features many of bluegrass's finest players plus the alternative-country stars Emmylou Harris, Gillian Welch and Iris DeMent. But Mr. Earle's songs make "The Mountain" more than a fine generic exercise as they trace a path of displacement throughout American history.
Mr. Earle has often chronicled the violence of modernization; his early forays into country-rock updated that theme with a Southernized Springsteen sound and a countercultural attitude. Like those early albums, "The Mountain" uses its musical focus to further a strong social agenda. Mr. Earle seeks a common voice grounded not in wistful memory but in thorny reality; his ramblers are the former high school football heroes, drug dealers, gas station attendants and homeless people of the New South. "The Mountain" finds counterparts for those characters in Civil War tales and corny love songs.
The album begins with "Texas Eagle," an ode to trains made unsentimental by its acknowledgment of the American rail system's economic woes. It moves through Irish immigration and the Depression's Dust Bowl before settling in heaven's waiting room with "Pilgrim." There is nothing but motion on "The Mountain," nothing but anxious progress. Mr. Earle drives this point home with the album's title track, in which the miner who declared his undying pride of place in "Harlan Man" finds his beloved mountain ravaged and himself devastated by the march of industrial capitalism. In Mr. Earle's ruthless vision, those who stand fast against cruel change can only hope for obsolescence. By setting his anthology of wandering to the lonesome tones of bluegrass, Mr. Earle disturbs the complacent aura that can sometimes overwhelm country classicism.
Kelly Willis challenges a different set of rules with "What I Deserve," her new album for the independent label Rykodisc (CD, RCD 10458). Ms. Willis made three albums for MCA Nashville in the early 1990's and had modest success, but she never fit into the industry machine. Living in Austin, Tex., she allied herself with the line of singer-songwriters that travels between country, folk, and rock.
Free to explore fully the place where those poles meet, Ms. Willis has emerged with a rich representation of the unsettled life. It begins, like so many in pop, with a bad love affair. "Take Me Down," written with Gary Louris of the Jayhawks, is a sweet swoon of co-dependency; the title track, also written with Mr. Louris, chronicles a more complicated crisis. Set to a loping beat knocked off-kilter by Chuck Prophet's phase-shifted guitar, "What I Deserve" is the confused lament of an ambitious woman. Refusing to take solace in prayer, the beauty of nature or any other old-fashioned balm, Ms. Willis lambastes herself for never slowing down and the world for suggesting that she should.
THIS particularly feminine, very current perspective on emotional ambivalence enriches "What I Deserve." Ms. Willis has a honey-lemon voice that can be as soothing as a lozenge, and it works that way on a lullabye like Paul Kelly's "Cradle of Love," but she mostly she uses it in the service of more wayward desires. She offers painful tales of lost love but then expresses the resolve to move on. Hovering between romantic fantasy and deflated realism, Ms. Willis taps a rare subtlety of feeling.
"What I Deserve" often returns to the subject of contentment, something Ms. Willis doesn't pretend to grasp fully. "If I ran so far that my life can't follow me, would it keep the world from up and swallowing me?" she sings in "Fading Fast"; with such a phrase, she makes the saga of the wayfaring stranger internal and completely contemporary. Like Mr. Earle, Ms. Willis knows that the itinerant world is no paradise, but she's not willing to pretend that there's any other place like home, even for a simple country girl.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1858 words

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Nijinsky's Inner Choreography

BYLINE: By DANIEL GESMER 

 BODY:
VASLAV NIJINSKY, the world-renowned dancer and choreographer of the Ballets Russes, began a diary on the afternoon of Jan. 19, 1919. That evening he gave what would be his last public performance, a disturbing solo recital, "Marriage With God," at a hotel in St. Moritz, Switzerland, where he and his family had taken up wartime residence. For the next 45 days, sometimes all night, the 29-year-old Nijinsky wrote feverishly in four leather-bound school exercise books.
He stopped abruptly on March 4, when his wife, Romola, and her family, took him to Zurich to see the noted psychiatrist Eugen Bleuler. The verdict: schizophrenia, a diagnostic term Bleuler had recently coined. This doomed Nijinsky to a course of recurrent hospitalization and extreme therapies that continued until his death of renal failure on April 8, 1950, in London. 
 The journal has been published before, in an expurgated version edited by Romola in 1936. Now Farrar, Straus & Giroux has come out with a new, complete version, "The Diary of Vaslav Nijinsky," translated from the Russian by Kyril FitzLyon and edited by Joan Acocella, the dance critic of The New Yorker, who also wrote the introduction. This moving document, the original of which has been in the dance collection of the New York Public Library for the Peforming Arts since 1994 and had been circulated among private collectors and publishers since 1979, fully reveals Nijinsky's increasingly knotted inner world. It begs fresh interpretations of his life, artistry, ideas and psychological history.
Nijinsky's advancing mental disturbance and limited verbal skills obscure his expository methods and argument. Despite pervasive evidence of schizophrenia, a close reading suggests that the journal was meant to be a literary work, as experimental as his choreography. Further, his quasi-mystical philosophical ideas, though expressed in jumbled prose, did not emerge from a vacuum and are, in fact, intriguing.
Nijinsky's original journal -- a handwritten 381-page manuscript with virtually no margins -- reveals strikingly neat penmanship. The visual impression is of a man overflowing with a need to express himself. The content itself reveals a man consciously disciplined about writing unself-consciously. "I write without thinking," Nijinsky claims, and that was probably the literal truth. His definition of "thinking" was quite specific, but this writing technique went beyond his doctrinal preference for "feeling." "I don't care what my hand writes." Indeed, midway through the journal he explains a break: "I could not go on writing, because I started to think about my writing."
A doctor had recently given Nijinsky word-association tests, which may have encouraged him to treasure the raw output of his subconscious. He explains at intervals in the journal that he will not edit mistakes in grammar or spelling. He complains often of discomfort in his writing hand. Increasing manic excitement and the goal of publishing in Zurich, where he knew weeks in advance he would be taken to meet a famous "nerve specialist," helped fuel Nijinsky's marathon writing sessions. But part of his intent was simply to keep his pens and pencils in constant motion, faithfully recording his stream of consciousness no matter the cost to style, flow or intelligibility.
Here Nijinsky was in step with the avant-garde of his time; one thinks of James Joyce, Virginia Woolf, Gertrude Stein. This journaling technique is now commonplace among artists striving to override the intellect and plumb the unconscious. It would account for some of Nijinsky's meandering, self-contradiction and obsessive repetition, which otherwise embody the known pattern of schizophrenic writing.
Nijinsky also practiced automatic writing in his diary. To believers, this is a form of "channeling," whereby God or a disembodied entity writes through the hand of a person in a trance. Early on, Nijinsky addresses God: "I shall feel and You shall write. I am writing because You are writing. I shall stop when You stop." Later he adds, "I am a man in a trance . . . I can write in a trance . . . I am in a trance of God."
Nijinsky had long exposure to esoteric ideas. He was well-read and had frequent contact with educated, cultured people. Automatic writing, Ouija boards and trance channeling were trendy subjects. Madame Blavatsky and Rudolf Steiner were prominent figures, and Wassily Kandinsky's "On the Spiritual in Art" had entered European intellectual currents by 1912. Other avant-garde artists, like the Surrealist writer Andre Breton and the Dada painter Hans Arp, were experimenting with automatism.
Nijinsky's diary describes a seance he attended at a classmate's home during his school days. According to Romola, she and her husband experimented in St. Moritz with Ouija boards and "trance dancing." Nijinsky also tried automatic drawing "with remarkable success," Romola wrote. One of the Nijinskys' St. Moritz governesses shared her experiences of "fakirs and yogis" in India, prompting Nijinsky to study these subjects and correspond with the mystic Belgian Symbolist writer Maurice Maeterlinck, the author of "Pelleas et Melisande."
The famous psychic Eileen Garret, whom Romola frequently consulted in the 1930's, reportedly claimed to know Nijinsky well and called him "a perfect psychic subject." Though he rejected Eastern and Occult terminology, Nijinsky was a conscious, willing medium. "I know people who are saying that everything I write is a spiritualist trance. I would like everyone to be in such a trance," he writes. In fact, Nijinsky may have tried to devise a means for God to write through others as well. He intended to patent and market a new pen technology under the brand name "God." Though the pen was never described in the notebooks, the private Nijinsky family archives include drawings of it.
In other respects, Nijinsky's diary is confessional, an attempt to psychoanalyze himself. He confides his sexual history and emotionally charged episodes from his past. He shares his deep commitment to Tolstoyan ascetic precepts and preoccupation with bodily processes. He discusses the arts, politics and personal relationships, alternately with penetrating insight and astounding naivete. He tries to expose the selfish hypocrisies of the elite classes much as does the title character of his last major ballet, "Til Eulenspiegel." Finally, he reveals his growing inner conflicts, delusions and paranoid fears.
 The diary is also a scattershot discourse on Nijinsky's spiritual and philosophical views. He pleads for love, unity, happiness, environmental conservation, socialist economics and wise use of technology. Most important, he argues for the primacy of "feeling" in the universe, though with virtually no rhetorical organization. Lacking a well-developed vocabulary, he burdens a handful of simple terms with enormous weight.
At the top of Nijinsky's philosophical lexicon, "feeling" represents a quasi-mystical form of intuitive, empathic perception. It alone can lead humanity to enlightenment. In his metaphysics of feeling, other primary concepts orbit this central theme. Mental development or discernment is "reason" if grounded in feeling, "intelligence" if not. "Life" is any action, condition, individual or institution that embodies or promotes "feeling"; "death," the opposite. "God" is the Creator of Being, but also a synonym for "feeling," "reason" and "life." "Love," poetically, is "the feeling of God in men."
Nijinsky's emphasis on perceiving and knowing through feeling is typically Russian, typically Romantic and archetypally feminine. According to folk wisdom in "Mother" Russia, the insane have stopped feeling and begun thinking too much. The Russian authors Nijinsky studied, and his collaboration with the pantheistic philosopher-painter Nicolas Roerich on "Le Sacre du Printemps," anchored Russian lore in his mind. The Romantic tradition he inherited and enacted with genius sank deep roots in his psyche.
Nijinsky's philosophy of "feeling" is inappropriate in realms like science, but he was a creative artist. Labeling his system of thought pathological, as his wife and doctors did, is arguably sexist, patriarchal and ignorantly dismissive of Russian folkways and Nijinsky's artistic inheritance.
Another facet of Nijinsky's diary too easily labeled pathological is his frequent self-equation with God and Christ. His doctors, and most subsequent psychological writers, read this as megalomania, an inferiority complex or a desperate attempt to deny the onset of madness.
Although certain passages are self-aggrandizing, for Nijinsky sympathy literally bred identity. As a corollary of his profound faith in the power of feeling, to love (or love like) God or Christ meant in his mind to actually be God or Christ. He writes: "I want to love everybody, and therefore I am God . . . I know many people will say that Nijinsky pretends to be Christ. I do not pretend, because I love his actions." In fact, "feeling" alone sufficed to establish divine union: "I am God if I feel." Despite his verbal limitations and advancing illness, Nijinsky tried to assert the divine unity of all Being through feeling.
The diary records what Nijinsky sincerely experienced as a mystical awakening, real or delusional. This was marked by feelings of universal love (which he literally shouted from the hilltops), a sense of unity with all Creation and experiences of precognition and omniscience. The world became animated, with trees literally speaking to him.
Perhaps the Western psychiatric paradigm is not yet adequate to fully explain his disintegration.
 
'I Was Not Mad, Because I Felt'
Here is an excerpt from "The Diary of Vaslav Nijinsky, Unexpurgated Edition," published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
ONE day I was in the mountains and got onto a road that led up to a mountain. I went along it and stopped. I wanted to speak on the mountain because I felt the desire to do so. I did not speak, because I thought that everyone would say that this man was mad. I was not mad, because I felt. I felt not pain, but love for people. I wanted to jump from the mountain into the little town of St. Moritz. I did not shout, because I felt that I had to go farther. I went farther and saw a tree. The tree said to me that one could not speak here, because men did not understand feeling. I went farther. I was sorry to part with the tree, because it understood me. I went on. I went up to a height of 2,000 meters. I stood for a long time. I felt a voice and shouted in French, "Parole." I wanted to speak, but my voice was so strong that I could not speak, and I shouted, "I love everyone, and I want happiness!" "I love everyone." "I want everyone." I cannot speak French, but I will learn it if I walk by myself. I want to speak loudly so that people will feel me. I want to love everyone and therefore want to speak all languages. I cannot speak all languages, and therefore I write, and my writing will be translated. I will speak French as best as I can.
 
 Revised translation 1999, by Kyril FitzLyon.

HEADLINE: FILM;
The Millennium In Perspective, Without Hoopla

BYLINE: By KAREN DURBIN; Karen Durbin is the film critic for Mirabella magazine. Her most recent article for the Arts and Leisure section was about Liv Ullmann and Ingmar Bergman.

 BODY:
IT'S Dec. 31, 1999. Jesus arrives in New York with his assistant Magdalena on his arm and a vexing question on his mind: should he start the Apocalypse or not?
In Paris, a travel agent invites his closest friends to escape the millennial hoopla by retreating to a primitive island paradise off the French coast, only to discover that, freed from the demands of his busy urban life, he becomes someone he can't stand. 
 The inhabitants of a serenely beautiful red-clay village in Mali pass the time visiting, doing chores, listening to the radio and trying to call distant relatives from the post office telephone. Desperately poor, they live with the kind of unself-conscious simplicity that the Parisian travel agent seeks.
These are story lines from "2000 Seen By," a series of roughly hour-long millennial films from seven countries that opens in New York on Friday at the Cinema Village for the first leg of a tour around the country. The three films described are, respectively, by the American director Hal Hartley, the French filmmaker Laurent Cantet and the Mauritanian-born Abderrahmane Sissako, whose family lives in Mali.
The series also includes a smartly silly screwball comedy from Spain's Miguel Albaladejo; a tale of star-crossed Hungarian lovers by Ildiko Enyedi (the only woman filmmaker in the group); a darkly comic dystopia by the Taiwanese director Tsai Ming liang set in a crumbling, rain-soaked housing project whose inhabitants fall prey to a mysterious plague, and a politically pointed fable by Alain Berliner in which Belgium marks the millennium with a vicious civil war between its two main ethnic groups, the Flemish and the Walloons.
Portmanteau film projects tend to be traps for second-rate work, but this collection is an exception to the dismal rule. Mr. Ming liang's " Hole" and Mr. Sissako's "Life on Earth" are the standouts in the series, but even the least successful films are far from duds. If Mr. Hartley's jazzy-looking "Book of Life" is more than a tad literal-minded, things pick up whenever Martin Donovan's grumpy Jesus appears on screen in a Brooks Brothers suit with the singer P. J. Harvey as his punk Magdalene. Similarly, the terminal romanticism of Ms. Enyedi's "Tamas et Juli" is redeemed by a bluntly graphic sex scene lighted and staged with such startling originality that it remains etched in one's mind long after the rest of the film has faded into one of the picturesque mists that the director favors.
"2000 Seen By" is the brainchild of Carole Scotta and Caroline Benjo, two young partners in Haut et Court, a French production and distribution company specializing in independent cinema. The women struck a deal with Arte, the European cultural television channel, which provided seed money in exchange for broadcast rights. To insure the project's global scope, they solicited proposals from an international roster of directors and selected 10 for production. (The Brazilian, Canadian and German films broke away from the series and are being released individually.) The only full-length feature that remains is "The Hole," at 89 minutes, with the other six films running 60 to 70 minutes.
Like all but the best short stories, movies of less than feature length can feel like minor work. But the brevity of these films turns out to have unexpected virtues. With "The First Night of My Life," for example, Miguel Albaladejo manages to pack eight vivid characters, an ingeniously complicated plot, stylish visuals and deft social commentary into little more than an hour. At a time when American films have fallen prey to a mystifying case of bloat, such artistic economy is both a tonic and a reproach.
Of course, the specter of another sort of bloat is invoked simply by the occasion. Fox Lorber, the series' United States distributor, is releasing these films now, says Wendy Lidell, a company vice president, because "I want to be ahead of the curve."
"There's going to be so much of this millennium branding, so much stuff coming out, I don't know when interest will peak," Ms. Lidell says.
Indeed. The approach of the last millennium triggered mass panic and the threat of hysterical violence. Today, Y2K glitches aside, the worst danger we're likely to face is hysterical boredom. The most overanticipated New Year's Eve in 1,000 years is threatening to roll in on a tidal wave of conspicuous consumption and commercial tie-ins. The T-shirts alone may bury us all.
As a subject for a movie, the millennium arrives pre-bloated, at once too grand and too trivial. On one hand, it seems to demand work that not only predicts the future but survives it. On the other, people can't even agree on when it begins (mathematically, with the first nanosecond of 2001, but viscerally, a year earlier, when all those nines turn into zeroes). Like all attempts to fix time, to pin it down and make it stop, "the millennium" is an artificial construct, fragile and doomed to deflate. Once the last horn is tooted, what remains but the novelty of writing the date with odd-looking numbers?
Most of "2000 Seen By's" directors solved this problem with their own deflationary tactics, treating the subject obliquely and with humor. "The concept of the year 2000 was really a pretext to gather filmmakers together whom we believed in," Carole Scotta says. "When they submitted their synopses, we were happy to see that they dealt with the subject in very personal ways." By far the most personal film is Mr. Sissako's "Life on Earth." Ms. Scotta describes the way he worked. "Abderrahmane convinced Arte to let him go to his father's village with an idea but no script. He stayed for two weeks, taking notes. Then, still with no script, he went back with a four-person crew. The actress in the film wasn't planned; this beautiful woman on her bike passed in front of his camera, and he decided to make her a central character. Abderrahmane really conceived this film in the editing."
The result is a movie of such uncommon delicacy and melancholy grace it looks like the result of months of careful planning. Deploying a soundtrack that moves seamlessly from a Schubert quintet to the artful tenor of the great Malian singer Salif Keita, Mr. Sissako weaves his day-in-the-life footage into a compelling lament for a beloved country impoverished by colonialism and stranded in time. The village is African, but French is the only language anyone speaks: the eloquent French of the anticolonialist Martinique writer Aime Cesaire ("Do not be a sterile spectator/ A screaming man is not a dancing bear") being read aloud on the local radio station, and, finally, the millennial broadcast from Paris, babbling inanely about the Eiffel Tower as the symbol "of our entry into the 21st century." The villagers, who have all they can do to maintain a shaky foothold in the 20th, listen carefully, and then pick up their chairs and go home.

HEADLINE: BY THE WAY;
Ready, Set, Renovate

 BODY:
It takes more than hammers and nails to turn a boarded-up city building into a home or office. It also takes a knowledge of the rules and a familiarity with programs that can provide aid. The state Department of Community Affairs has published a brochure called the Urban Tool Kit aimed at individuals, community groups or city officials considering urban renewal projects. For example, the brochure points out that last year New Jersey instituted what it says is the first building code in the country written just for older structures gives a phone number for more information. The brochure also includes information on getting low-interest mortgages or seed money, on tapping loans for demolishing dangerous buildings, and on programs for revitalizing downtowns and for returning vacant property to productive use. The overall idea is to encourage local people, rather than the state, to take the initiative in renewal. The Urban Tool Kit will be sent free to those who write to the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs, Office of Commmunications and Policy, 101 South Broad Street, Post Office Box 800, Trenton, N.J. 08625-0800, or call (609) 292-6055.

HEADLINE: Those Who Retire to Work or Volunteer

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
EVERY morning, Abraham Landau commutes from White Plains on the 8:26 train to his job as sales manager for Performing Arts magazine in the Graybar Building over Grand Central Terminal. His days are so busy, he sometimes has to rush to make the 4:47 home.
"It's an exciting job, a lot of fun," Mr. Landau said. "I look forward to going to the office. In the 18 months I've been there I've never been late or taken a sick day." 
 Although advertising may be thought of as a youth-oriented profession, Mr. Landau does not fit the profile. "I'm 78, a three-time great-grandfather," he said, "and had been retired six years from a career in advertising and marketing, which included 16 years with Playbill magazine, when I got a job offer I couldn't resist." He had also been an adjunct professor of selling and marketing at the School of Continuing Education at New York University. "Before I went back to work full time, I was active in R.S.V.P., the Retired Senior Volunteer Program, in White Plains, working as a mentor and consultant. "
Mr. Landau is among a growing number of older retired workers who are being drawn back into the work force as the pool of young job seekers drops. Companies are pursuing older potential employees, said Judith Whitted, program specialist in the County Office for the Aging.
The latest county unemployment figures of 2.8 percent, as of mid-January this year are even lower than the 3.4 percent of the preceding year, Ms. Whitted said. "The lowest unemployment figures in history make this the best time ever for mature people to find work," she said. "Right now, we have more requests for qualified older workers than we can fill from companies ranging from mid-size medical and educational organizations up to I.B.M."
Charles Pintchman of Pleasantville has had not one but three jobs since he retired in 1985 as deputy director of corporate affairs at Reader's Digest in Pleasantville.
"It was the first voluntary early retirement program at the Digest," he said. "Yet at 55 I felt I still wanted to work, so for several years I taught the learning disabled, first at a private school in Rye Neck, then at Boces until three years ago, when I retired again, this time to become a full-time volunteer at Blythedale Children's Hospital and School in Valhalla."
When he was offered a full-time job as a substitute teacher at Blythedale, he promptly took it. He did so, he said, because "self-esteem plays a part and so is the feeling of accomplishment that comes with the job, which in my case is teaching disabled kids who range in age from 8 to 13."
Mr. Pintchman also likes the discipline imposed by the job. "As a volunteer, I called the shots," he said. "Now I go where they tell me, and I kind of welcome that. Also on the plus side is the contrast between working and not working. Things like sleeping late and vacations become a real treat again."
Making older workers eligible for a variety of jobs is encouraged by training they receive under the Job Training Partnership Act, Ms. Whitted said. .
"Many are entry-level positions in offices, but we have also placed people in bookkeeping and computer slots," she said. "Employers rave about the job performance of seniors. They are dedicated, have good work habits, they show up on time, and they are very good role models for younger employees."
Toni Wirth, head of the human resource council of the Westchester Chamber of Commerce in White Plains , said: "This past year, we've had a high volume of calls from companies across the board looking for older employees. Banks, in particular, want people with clerical skills."
Businesses are also wooing people 55 or older who are volunteers for nonprofit agencies, said Phyllis Hersh, programming coordinator for the Retired Senior Volunteer Program. "Some of our volunteers, chiefly those with financial backgrounds regardless of their age, have been recruited for paying jobs," she said.
Ruth Ahern, director of the Retired Senior Volunteer Program, cited the County Planning Department's estimate for 1997. "There are 214,467 people who are 55 years and older in Westchester County," she said.
Karen King-Parke, director of the Senior Personnel Employment Council office in White Plains, which helps people 50 and older to find a job, said there were "considerably more jobs now open to seniors, especially in smaller companies and not-for-profit organizations."
Yet mature workers must have updated skills, Ms. King-Parke emphasized. "For a $10 registration fee," she said, "we not only help seniors prepare their resumes but we also link them up with free or reduced-fee computer training courses they need to do office work. And we make our fax and computers in the office available to them."
But given the shortage of workers, Ms. King-Parke said companies should be more flexible in their requirements, if they want to fill jobs. "When it comes to job sharing and flexible work hours, most companies are inflexible, even though we have qualified seniors who want to work four to six hours a day," she said. "This is true especially in the winter when days are short and many prefer not to drive home in the dark."
Another age group, 50 to 65, would also like to work part time to be eligible for reduced health insurance under company plans. Ms. King-Parke said, "They are willing to pay for it themselves."
Getting jobs for people in their 70's and 80's is not unusual, either, Ms. King-Parke said. "We place some as companions for other seniors," she said. "But many have jobs in industry,"
Richard Hobby is one of them. Mr. Hobby, 72, said he has always worked and does not plan to retire. "I've seen what has happened to friends of mine who have retired," he said. "They lose interest in everything. I work 40 hours a week and enjoy it. My last three jobs have come through Senior Personnel. The one I have now is doing clerical work at Mobile, the AT&T wireless company in Mount Vernon. And what makes it really good is that it's close to my home."
Should you expect to find the over-50 crowd flipping hamburgers at McDonald's? Maybe, said Peter Samaha, president of Alps Management in Armonk, which owns 12 McDonald's restaurants, employing 500 people in Westchester and the Bronx.
"We love seniors," Mr. Samaha said. "They fill a variety of jobs. Some have been with us for years; others are new hires. We offer them training and flexible work hours, either day or night."
Mr. Samaha gives older workers very high marks.He said: "They are very reliable, great workers, good with customers. And they rarely miss a day of work."

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
Hartford's Bushnell Theater Growing by a Third

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THE BUSHNELL in downtown Hartford will break ground this spring on an 88,000-square-foot, $30 million addition that will give the 69-year-old, 2,800-seat theater a 950-seat modern auditorium for smaller productions.
"But this is also about economic development and activity in the downtown," said Douglas C. Evans, the Bushnell's executive director. "Phantom of the Opera," he said, brought 135,000 people to the Bushnell's Great Hall from August to October 1995, a record, and grossed $6.7 million. But the impact on the community, for everything from apartments for the cast to meals for theatergoers, was estimated at more than twice that. 
 "The arts community has been slow to embrace that concept, that philosophy, that arts is a driver of the economy," Mr. Evans said. "When we first started discussing it, it was taboo. The economic aspect was considered dirty. But one of my platforms since the day I arrived has been that arts are good for the economy, good for the community."
H. Scott Phelps, president of the Greater Hartford Convention and Visitors Bureau, agrees.
"When you're promoting Hartford as a convention destination, you're not just selling the convention space," he said. "People want to get out and see and do things , and having something like the Bushnell in the downtown is critical."
Arnold C. Greenberg, president of the Bushnell's board of directors, said a fund-raising campaign had set a goal of $45 million, not only to cover the costs of construction but to establish a larger endowment for the expanded theater. The campaign is halfway to its goal, including a $1.25-million gift from a trustee, Anthony D. Autorino, and a $4-million gift from Maxwell M. Belding, a trustee emeritus, and his wife, Ruth R. Belding, of Old Lyme.
"The economic climate now is much healthier than the early 1990's, and I think the vision now is much more compelling," Mr. Greenberg said. "There's an appreciation of what this will do not only for local arts and community groups, but to bolster the economic revitalization of Hartford."
Within the next decade, the city expects a total of more than $1 billion in new construction downtown, including Adriaen's Landing, the $374-million stadium for the New England Patriots; a convention center; a community technical college and 1,000 units of housing, according to figures from the state's Department of Economic and Community Development.
Bushnell's new theater will rise on an employee parking lot at Capital Avenue and Trinity Street to the east of the existing hall.
Glass walls at the front of the addition will enclose a three-story Grand Stair Hall, featuring a curved stairway, as well as a cafe, gift shop and concierge office on the ground floor.
The second floor will be for intermission space or cabaret-style performances. A luxury suite will provide a setting for corporate functions.
"Since we're only increasing the capacity by about one-third, we don't expect the net effect to be that great," said David A. Dalena, the Bushnell spokesman. "Obviously, we'll have to make some changes operationally, such as staggered starting times for the performances, but that is all part of the planning process."
In addition to angling the addition away from the main hall, the site slopes slightly down to the east, which further decreases the impact of the new building on the old, said William D. Clegg Jr., an architect with Schoenhardt Associates in Simsbury, which is working with Wilson Butler Lodge of Boston on the plans.
THERE were some thoughts about enclosing the old building's east portico in glass, but it's an important part of the building and we felt the best way to preserve it was to leave it open," Mr. Clegg said. "It was tough, and it was tight, but it came together."
Mr. Clegg, who specializes in historic preservation, said that the Bushnell was close to his heart. In the late 20's, his wife's grandfather, Howard Christian Peter, assumed the duties of head carpenter on the Bushnell construction on the death of his father-in-law, Ludwig Miller. Mr. Clegg's mother-in-law, Verna Carlson of Bristol, still has pictures of the construction.
"This is not just a project for me, it's a part of my heritage," Mr. Clegg said. "When I found out we had the job, I called my wife and told her to go buy a dozen roses and we went over to tell her mother. As I gave her the flowers I said, 'The heritage continues.' I look forward to taking her to the first show."
The Bushnell project, which has a $10 million grant from the state and $2.5-million from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, is currently being reviewed by the Connecticut Historical Commission.
"It's a very significant structure," said Susan R. Chandler, a staff historical architect with the commission. "It's a cultural landmark as well as a historical landmark. It's one of the most important stand-alone historical resources in the downtown."
Although she has not completed her review, she noted that the designers of the addition had taken an innovative approach, angling it away from the main hall so the east face of the building, with its blend of Georgian-style columns and Art Deco exterior, would still be visible from the street.
Since Mr. Evans arrived to head the Bushnell in 1990, it has strengthened considerably. When he arrived, about 180,000 tickets were being sold each year. This year, it expects to sell 400,000 to 500,000 tickets, thanks to some of the lavish Broadway productions he has attracted to Hartford. Large Broadway shows currently take up 25 percent of the theater's schedule, but account for 90 percent of the revenues.
But the growth also meant a tightening of availability for shows by the Bushnell's tenant organizations -- the Hartford Ballet, Hartford Symphony Orchestra, Connecticut Opera Association, and Chamber Music Plus.
"The addition of the second hall means there's more flexibility in getting dates, and there are a number of ballet shows that we would rather do in a more intimate setting, that sort of cry out for a smaller hall," said Trevor A. Cushman, president of the Hartford Ballet. "So on both counts, we're looking forward to it."
In a normal season the ballet might do four shows, two full-length and two triple-bills, or repertory shows. The repertory shows might sell 800 seats, or fewer, on a slow night, which means almost one out of four seats in the Great Hall would be vacant -- not the message an arts organization wants to send.
"The Hartford Symphony is always squeezed for time in the big hall, and if our vacating some slots in the big hall gives them more time to get in there, we're all for it," Mr. Cushman said. "And in Bushnell II, as we're calling it, there's going to be better seats for our purposes. They're going to be closer to the stage, so everyone is going to be better served."
