HEADLINE: The Art and Economics Of Teaching Creativity

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER 

DATELINE: ROOSEVELT

 BODY:
CECIL BRIDGEWATER was insistent. "I don't care if you don't play the right notes," he told the nine young musicians seated in front of him at Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School. "But you've got to get the right rhythm. Put those instruments in your lap, and let's clap."
Patiently, Mr. Bridgewater, the veteran jazz trumpeter, led the youngsters in sustained rounds of clapping to improve their rendition of a blues scale he had given them the previous week to practice. It was his third meeting with members of the school's jazz band during an eight-week residency sponsored by Friends of the Arts. Clearly, he was still in the preliminary stages of honing the skills -- and interests -- of teen-agers brought up mainly on rap and rhythm-and-blues. 
 Mr. Bridgewater's residency here is just part of a quiet, little-heralded revolution under way in schools all over Long Island: the coming of age of arts-in-education programs.
These programs can be as simple as inviting a calligrapher to teach students "art with a pen" or as complex as investing an entire year in creating ways of using the arts to teach academic subjects like mathematics, science, social studies and language arts. On the Island, the programs will cost $5 million this year, ranging from $100 for a single classroom visit by an artist to $170,000 a year in a four-year pilot project to devise an integrated curriculum.
The money comes from school districts, parent-teacher associations, local arts groups, foundations, and Federal and state agencies. These include the National Endowment for the Arts and the New York State Council on the Arts, which has made 300 grants totaling $2.6 million this year to arts-in-education providers throughout the state. Since 1985, the council has spent nearly $30 million to bring the arts into the schools.
Along with regular classroom instruction in the arts, these programs have traditionally been the first eliminated as frills when budgets are reduced. After substantial cuts when state aid diminished in the late 1980's and early 90's, arts classes have stabilized and even increased on the Island, administrators say.
"Even high school electives seem to be coming back," said Kevin McGuire, superintendent of the Half Hollow Hills School District and president of the Suffolk County Council of School Superintendents.
Salvatore Randazzo, director of art and music in the East Islip School District, said: "When I came here three years ago, we had 16 music teachers and 11 art teachers, which was already up from the late 80's when the staff was reduced by about 6 positions. Now, we're up to 18 music teachers and 12 art teachers, and I sense that this is the case elsewhere."
No arts courses were eliminated during the budget crunch in Wantagh, but "a marvelous arts-in-education program that we had, a 'poet in the school' who for years came and worked with the kids and cost only $5,000, was cut," said George Besculides, the school superintendent and head of the Nassau County Council of School Superintendents.
Like Wantagh, which has budgeted about $20,000 for arts-in-education this year -- up $2,500 from last year -- other districts have experienced a similar growth. "When we bring these cultural programs into the district, we motivate the kids and the community," Mr. Randazzo said. "They're a shot in the arm and help our regular programs build." His district will spend $21,000 on arts-in-education this year.
In Roosevelt, which has budgeted $10,000 for arts-in-education this year, the Friends of the Arts project, underwritten entirely by the Bell Atlantic Foundation, has struck a responsive chord.
"Me and jazz were so-so," said Shantell Cameron, a 12th-grade saxophonist and clarinetist. "I was never really interested in it before. But you know, I'm learning to like it and play it." She hopes to study performance and music education at Ithaca College. Now, jazz is "turning out just as beautiful as classical music and what I play in band," she said. "And some of my friends wish they could do what I'm doing. Get into it, not just get it."
The rhythm tentatively absorbed, Mr. Bridgewater -- a musician, composer and arranger who has appeared with the Max Roach Quartet, the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis Jazz Orchestra and the Horace Silver Quintet -- turned, with quiet humor and dogged perseverance, to translating the sounds into something resembling music. In addition to coaching and cajoling, he filled the session with asides about jazz's history and relationship to the music the students know best ("99 percent of what you hear today, including rap, is based on the blues") and biographical snippets about Sonny Rollins, whose "Tenor Madness" they were about to play.
"Can't we play it faster?" a trumpeter asked.
"Tuning up first would have been a good idea," Mr. Bridgewater replied.
"Your ears are your most important instrument," he continued. "It's kind of like eating things. You bite in, expecting something sweet, but you get something terrible, something that makes you twitch."
Although at various levels of musicianship, all the youngsters paid rapt attention to what Mr. Bridgewater was saying and doing. After all, they were motivated enough to have volunteered for this after-school program, which meant they had to juggle transportation schedules and chores like baby-sitting for siblings. Some ignored class pictures to get to jazz band on time.
The band teacher, Thomas Vojcik, was another attentive participant, listening carefully and even playing in the saxophone section. "I know jazz, but I'm getting a broader knowledge from Cecil," he said. "I'm learning different ways of doing different things. He's giving me more stuff to work with. And the kids are getting more out of it. I mean, coming from someone else -- someone like Cecil, who is a full-time musician -- it means more than if it was coming just from me."
By the end of the session, all involved had gotten what they wanted out of the 90 minutes. Curtis Golding, a drummer in the 11th grade, had picked up pointers on his technique. Shakema Appleton, an eighth-grade saxophonist, had learned "how to listen and know that I'm in tune." And William Turcios, a ninth-grade saxophonist, had accepted the fact that sharpening his prowess "was done step by step, without trying for perfection right now."
The youngsters will test their achievements on March 19 when, at the end of the residency, the jazz band performs at the school with Justin DiCioccio and His Ensemble, a Manhattan-based professional quintet that has been appearing in districts throughout the Island in Friends of the Arts' Jazz-Link program.
Dr. Regina Cohn, assistant superintendent in the Roosevelt school district, came away convinced that her decision to participate in the Friends of the Arts program was right. "If we can affect the lives of 15 kids, then we've made an impact," she said. "They won't necessarily all become musicians, but just their contact with someone who lives and breathes music is important."
As for Mr. Bridgewater, "seeing them respond, sparking something in them, is the greatest joy that I find in the work I do in the schools," he said. "Sure, I like it when the kids become more literate musically and learn to appreciate jazz. But the music also helps them gain confidence in their ability to do other things, and when you feel confident, you can go farther."
 
THE REASONS
Learning by Doing, And Not Just the Arts
Raising self-esteem is just one goal of arts-in-education, an umbrella term that covers anything beyond classroom instruction. The instruction itself varies from district to district because the state requires only one semester each of art and music through eighth grade and another year in high school. Membership in a band or chorus meets that requirement.
The current spurt of growth in both arts-in-education and arts courses can be attributed, Dr. Besculides said, to "the healthy economy" and, to the fact "that increasingly, educators and parents are realizing that the arts are as vital as any other instructional program and can't be eliminated is you want to produce a well-rounded person."
To support their advocacy of more arts instruction, proponents point to studies that suggest the arts play a pivotal role in the learning process. These studies show that "arts help develop creativity and critical thinking," said Marc Summer, who runs the arts-in-education program in the Freeport schools. "And artists themselves are marvelous role models because they're so passionate about what they do."
A study of 1995 S.A.T. scores, for example, revealed that students who had taken four years of arts classes in high school scored much higher in both verbal and math tests than those who had taken few or none.
"Different students learn in different ways, and the arts help kids learn other disciplines," said Dr. David Meoli, the coordinator in Port Washington.
Arts-in-education programs have been around for more than a decade. At first, they were essentially treats -- assemblies, perhaps -- that entertained students but had minimal or peripheral educational content.
But two things happened that increased both the need for and the availability of this type of programming. Cultural organizations began realizing that their audiences were "graying out," and that they needed ways to develop new audiences. And parents became more sophisticated in demanding arts exposure for their children but, in many cases, were less able to provide them directly because there were so many two-career families.
"It's a long-range approach, but yes, you could consider our programs audience development," conceded Amy Wynn, who heads the outreach program at Tilles Center in Brookville. "But they're also a way of contributing to the community and its quality of life." In its seventh year, with a budget of $180,000, the Tilles program will bring in more than 6,000 youngsters from 70 schools for six performances and hold teacher and student workshops based on them.
 
THE PARTICIPANTS
On and Off the Island, Plenty of Willing Hands
Like Tilles, other major Long Island performance groups, presenters, museums and individual artists are heavily involved in arts-in-education. They join New York City organizations involved on the Island, including American Ballet Theater, the Metropolitan Opera and the Brooklyn Philharmonic, and even the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
In addition to the residency pilot program in Roosevelt and another trial 10-week residency, Hands-On Shakespeare, with sixth graders in the Herricks school district, Friends of the Arts' Jazz-Link brings performances and workshops to eight schools for about $100,000. The Long Island Philharmonic, too, has an extensive program that will spend $250,000 this year to take more than 12,000 students from 88 districts to youth concerts and send professional musicians to schools.
Last June alone, Suffolk County schools were involved in 176 arts-in-education programs, ranging from a session of gravestone rubbing to a lesson on "Science in the Kitchen" to a performance by clowns.
"When I took this job 14 years ago, we served 23 school districts that spent $200,000 on programming," said Lynette Bianchi, who directs arts-in-education for the two Suffolk Boards of Cooperative Education. "This year, we're handling at least $2.7 million and working with 67 of the county's 70 districts."
The Nassau board this year is serving 52 of the county's 56 districts, which are spending just under $2 million. Throughout the state, Boards of Cooperative Education screen and assess arts providers and help the districts contract them. If they work through the boards, the schools are eligible for reimbursement from the state. On Long Island, the return could be as little as 36 percent of the cost for wealthy districts or as high as the average of 60 percent for those with more limited funds.
Suffolk and Nassau lead the state in arts-in-education spending through the boards. The seven Long Island school districts that are not availing themselves of the services this year -- Kings Park, New Suffolk, Southold, Malverne, Elmont, Garden City and East Rockaway -- are not necessarily ignoring arts-in-education; East Rockaway and Southold, for example, are relying on parent-teacher associations for programs or making their own arrangements. Some districts just prefer not to pay the boards' fees for their services, 16 percent of the program's cost in Suffolk and 17.5 percent in Nassau.
 
THE GOALS
The State Sets Standards, Then Offers Help
The current spurt of growth in arts-in-education can be attributed, in part, to the "Learning Standards for the Arts" adopted by the state Department of Education in 1996. These four standards establish criteria for "creating, performing and participating in the arts," "knowing and using arts materials and resources," "responding to and analyzing works of art" and "understanding the cultural contributions of the arts."
Statewide assessments, through tests, of how students are meeting these standards are being developed, said Roger Hyndman, an associate in arts curricula and instruction in the Department of Education. "And we anticipate that the entering ninth-grade class in 2001 will sit for those assessments in the spring of 2002."
Paradoxically, similar standards adopted for academic areas threaten those very goals for the arts. The Board of Regents' decision to require students to pass Regents' examinations to graduate alarms some arts advocates.
"Will there be time for the arts when additional attention might have to be paid to prepare youngsters for the Regents?" asked Dr. C. Jeremy Sykes, who supervises arts-in-education for the Nassau board. "Or will this very important part of growing up as a human being disappear?"
To protect their turf by helping students meet the standards, arts-in-education providers are rushing to incorporate them into arts experiences. In the most extensive attempt to prepare students for the arts standards and keep the arts in the schools, the state Council on the Arts and the Education Department have joined forces to create the Empire State Partnerships Project.
"We are putting significant money into this project in order to go deeper, expand the role of the arts," said Nicki Clarke, executive director of the State Arts Council.
The Empire State Partnerships initiative is a way of seeing that the arts, "which are still not a priority," survive in an atmosphere that is fueled by "pressures on the core areas of learning," said Elissa Kane, executive director of the New York State Alliance for Arts Education. Her agency is helping the state Education Department run weeklong summer professional development course for teachers in the partnership.
To apply for a grant, an arts group joins with a partner school to come up with a project that promises to meet the goals. The State Arts council puts up 50 percent of the the money, requiring the school to provide 35 percent of the total cost and the arts group to come up with 15 percent.
After an initial grant of $10,000 for planning and pilot projects, the council will provide up to $100,000 a year for three years. This year, the council has allocated $3.5 million for 57 projects throughout the state. The state education department pays for the teacher training.
On Long Island, Circle of Dance, a Huntington-based modern-dance company that has been involved in Arts-in-Education since 1982, joined the East Meadow and Westbury districts to become the first local recipient, with the goal of integrating dance into the core curriculum. Now in its third year, the project received $85,000 from the council this year.
Two new local partnerships received initial financing this year. Long Island Traditions, a folk-heritage organization based in Port Washington, is working with the Freeport schools to create a multicultural, multi-ethnic curriculum, and the Port Washington schools are joining American Ballet Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company, the Nassau County Museum of Art and Meet the Composer to devise a new, arts-fueled approach to teaching the academic basics.
The success of these and other partnership projects could have a far-reaching impact throughout the United States, proponents say. The new curricula could revolutionize what and how all children learn, said Ms. Kane of the Alliance for Arts Education.
And "this would happen just in time," she pointed out, "for jobs in the next millennium will require people to think creatively and use visual images -- traits that the arts help develop."

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
As Caldor Fades, Retail Market Is Unfazed

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
WHEN Caldor, the discount-store chain, announced in January that it was closing its 145 stores, including 28 in New Jersey, William A. Farber was struck by a sense of deja vu.
Mr. Farber is chief operating officer at Levin Management Corporation of North Plainfield, which owns and manages 66 shopping centers, 45 of them, totaling nearly 4 million square feet, in New Jersey. 
 Over the years Levin worked through the bankruptcies of W.T. Grant and E.J. Korvettes. Now it is faced with the same situation because Caldor anchors five of the company's centers, having replaced Korvettes in the 80's. The centers are in Paramus, West Orange, Woodbridge, Watchung and North Brunswick.
The future of the stores in those centers will signal what impact, if any, Caldor's bankruptcy will have on the state's retail market, and on landlords like Levin. Two of its stores -- one on Route 4 West in Paramus, the other on Route 22 in Watchung -- are already spoken for by Kohl's, a discount department store chain based in Menomonee Falls, Wis., which is looking to build its presence in the New York metropolitan area. If the leases of the other three stores are not taken over by other retailers, Mr. Farber said the space would be reconfigured for new users.
"We're starting with a sound retail market and good real estate locations, where land for new construction is scarce, so even though one retailer couldn't make it, another one will," he said.
Most retail analysts and brokers said Caldor's bankruptcy was not expected to have a harsh impact on the overall market, and might come and go without incident, much like the closing last year of the Rickel stores, said Matthew J. Schnurr, senior vice president of the investment services group at the West Orange office of Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage.
Many of the home-improvement chain's 53 stores, 40 of them in New Jersey, were taken over by Staples, the office-supply store, said Mr. Schnurr, whose firm handled the disposition of the Rickel stores.
A key reason why analysts are optimistic is that the closing of Caldor stores, which average about 84,000 square feet, come at a time when the state's economy and retail market continue to be strong. Projections are that it will remain so at least through the end of the year.
"Because of the booming economy along with the fact that many Caldor stores are in prime locations, very few are expected to be hurt," said Ted Kraus, who heads TKO Real Estate Advisory Group, a retail consulting firm in Mercerville.
The statewide retail vacancy rate is hovering between 3.5 and 4 percent, virtually unchanged from last year, and rents continue to rise, albeit not as aggressively as in the past, according to TKO. For example, the firm puts the rents for stores of 70,000 to 100,000 square feet for stores in good locations at $10 to $13 a square foot, up about $1 from last year.
Even as Caldor closes its stores, other national and regional retailers continue to expand in or enter the state, said Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, a brokerage in Woodbridge.
Some, like Kohl's, as well as Wal-Mart and Kmart, are looking to grow by picking up some of the leases on the stores left behind by Caldor. Under bankruptcy laws, bidders for the company would be able to assume the leases at the same rents Caldor was paying, which may be significantly below today's rents since many of the leases were negotiated years ago.
"It is way for growing companies to get into a tight market in a much quicker and less expensive way " said Mr. Schultz. That, in turn, may "slow development in the state, keeping supply in balance with demand," he said.
ONE negative, added Mr. Kraus of TKO, is what will happen once new retailers take over the Caldor stores. "Some merchants who survived because Caldor was a weak competitor will need to work more aggressively or lose out to the new competition," he said
Late last month Kohl's received approval from the bankruptcy court to buy for $142 million the leases of 33 Caldor stores. Eleven of them are in New Jersey, including the two stores at Levin's centers. They will be added to the six stores Kohl's already has in the state.
"We've been expanding into the mid-Atlantic region over the last two years," said Gary Vasques, executive vice president of marketing at Kohl's. Taking over the Caldor leases is a logical move "and allows us to enter the New York metropolitan area with a critical mass of stores," he said.
The plan, he said, is to invest a total of $165 million to renovate all the stores and open them by the spring of 2000.
At the same, time Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., was given the green light to buy 12 store leases for $75 million, none in New Jersey. And Kmart, of Troy, Mich., put in a bid for 11 stores. Just one, a Levin property in West Orange, is in the state.
The bidding for the leases, analysts said, is likely to continue for another two months and may bring in more bids from the same players or new ones from other retailers. In addition, retailers who may not want to get involved with the bidding process -- waiting instead for the leases to go back to landlords -- are said to be eyeing the stores. Likely candidates are other so-called big-box users, including discounters like Target, Ames and Bradlees, the latter two of which worked themselves out of bankruptcy.
Stores in choice locations -- in densely populated areas with strong demographics and next to and visible from major highways -- will be snapped up quickly, said Mr. Schnurr of Grubb & Ellis. Landlords with stores in less than prime spots "will have to become creative and come up with adaptive reuses," he added.
Mr. Farber of Levin Management said that his company sees opportunities.
In cases where the Caldor stores in his company's centers are taken over by a new retailer at a rent that "is out-of step with today's market," he said, there is room to renegotiate certain aspects of the lease that pertain, for example, to rents based on sales volume. He said there was also the possibility that the new tenant would not need all the space, giving his company the chance to take back any excess space and rent it to other tenants at market rates.
MR. FARBER said that was the plan at the Paramus center, a 270,000-square-foot community shopping strip anchored by a 130,000-square-foot Caldor store.
There Kohl's intends to use only 90,000 feet, enabling Levin to take back the rest, he said, noting that in tandem with Kohl's plans to renovate the store's facade his company will invest $2.5 million to refurbish the center.
Levin intends to repeat that plan at its 400,000-square-foot Watchung Center, which is anchored by a 138,000-square-foot Caldor store.
The center is in the process of a $5 million rehabilitation, which Levin is undertaking with Federal Realty Investment Trust, based in Washington, D.C. That, together with Kohl's arrival, "gives the center a shot in the arm to remain competitive," he said.
The Caldor stores at Levin's other three centers are still up for grabs and Mr. Farber said his firm would be just as pleased if it got back those leases. The first choice would be to lease the space to a single user or to two smaller anchors and "fill in everything else from there," he said, noting that the alternative was to carve up the space for multiple smaller uses.
In cases where the stores are on two stories or have a basement level, he said his firm would do what it had done many times before: lease that space to complementary uses like health clubs or day care centers.
"History has shown that retailers have a limited life span, but as long as the location is viable and the economics are sound, life for the real estate goes on," Mr. Farber said.

HEADLINE: Habitats / Fifth Avenue Near 125th Street;
To Open a B & B, She Takes the A Train

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
IT'S a common enough dream. Ditch the corporate job, buy a big old house, open a bed-and-breakfast and live rent-free while you serve coffee in the morning to interesting guests who want to check out your little part of the world.
But when Jane Alex Mendelson decided to follow that dream, she didn't go to some little hamlet in Vermont. She went to Harlem. 
 After getting a bachelor's degree from the University of Pennsylvania, and then a master's in city planning, she did housing and construction forecasting, first for Chase Econometrics and then for McGraw-Hill. She was getting tired of the work but stayed on. "For the longest time, I felt I couldn't ever give up that paycheck," Ms. Mendelson says. But then, she says, "something happened in my life, something kind of personal, and I just made the decision."
At about the same time, she had gone to Vermont with some friends to see the leaves -- and, of course, to stay at a bed-and-breakfast, a staple of Vermont tourism. When they returned to New York, she and a friend who was also disaffected with her work began looking at houses with the intent of opening a bed-and-breakfast together.
They looked at houses on the Lower East Side, in the Village and in Harlem. There was no contest. In terms of the "value for the price," she says, Harlem offered much more.
That knowledge, of course, is theoretical. It's one thing to know a neighborhood is right. It's another to finally cross the threshold of a house that feels destined. They looked at a number of houses in Harlem, but nothing pulled them in for a second time. Her friend decided she didn't want to leave her work after all.
And then one day, Ms. Mendelson stepped into a house on Fifth Avenue near 125th Street, and she knew. The 18-foot-wide by 50-foot-long building, empty of life, had been chopped up into little rooms when it had been a single-room-occupancy hotel. It was owned by a woman who had hoped to renovate it, but by the time all the tenants moved out she found herself unable to carry the project forward.
Ms. Mendelson couldn't easily see the ultimate shape of each floor, because so many hallways and partitions had been added, but she could see the fanciful, curlicued moldings, and the colorful mosaic tile floor in the hallway.
She bought the house for $125,000, closing the deal in February 1997. She left her apartment on the Upper West Side and moved into the top floor, where she lived initially without heat or hot water. It took far longer than anticipated to get the right to renovate, because proof had to be obtained that no tenants had been illegally removed.
FINALLY, after a year and a half and a tight budget of $200,000, she had created a ground-floor office and bedroom for herself, a parlor floor with a living room, dining room, and kitchen, and two floors above with guest rooms, some with their own kitchens and baths, some shared. The moldings were all stripped back to the original wood, and new oak floors were installed throughout.
Last June, her Urban Jem Guest House -- in a building that is part of the Mount Morris Park Historic District, which stretches from 117th to 125th Street and Fifth to Seventh Avenues -- began accepting guests.
When she is making biscuits and muffins in the morning, does she ever miss the corporate life, the paycheck, the suits, the security? She makes a face that looks as if she has just tasted something sour.
Obviously not.
Does she ever find it intrusive to have people in her house, to have to make small talk in the morning with strangers?
Not at all. "I've had such interesting guests," she says. "They're fascinating people." Recently, for instance, Sobonfu Some, a West African author who was in New York to give a workshop on healing rituals, stayed at her bed-and-breakfast. And for New Year's, she was host to a couple who were about to be married and took the two rooms on her top floor.
Because each room in the house has its own cable television and telephone, and some have kitchens, she and her guests have more distance from one another than is typical in some guest houses.
And yet, her guests are clearly drawn by the opportunity to stay in the home of a New Yorker. Many, she says, want to be photographed with her cat, Jessie.
The visitors, who pay between $90 and $120 a night, depending on whether they share a bath, find her through word of mouth, or her Internet site, www.urbanjem.com. Many come from Japan or Germany.
When she has no guests, she has the house to herself, to share with her family and friends, who sometimes come for lengthy stays and repay her by helping with housekeeping. While it might be easier to just rent several floors as apartments, she says, she would lose the house. It would become a place belonging to others. This way, it remains totally hers.
This summer, she hopes to add a deck off the dining room and replace the crumbling sidewalk in front. Maybe the bluestone that will be lifted out can be used in the back, she says. Thriftiness like that has helped her keep down costs. Most of the fixtures were purchased at Home Depot. She used an architect to file her plans but did the design work herself, using a computer program.
She has furnished the house with a mixture of pieces from every style and era. "I'm a pack rat," she says. "I've been collecting things." In one room, guests can sit at the desk she was given at age 10. Another has an old veneer desk that belonged to her grandmother. A gilt mirror was found at a thrift shop.
MANY of her own paintings are on the walls. In the parlor, her most elegantly furnished room, a sofa is upholstered in brown and black, the same colors that intricately adorn her young pit bull, Petey. There is a photograph of her great-great-grandfather, who lived in Michigan during the Civil War era, the time her house was built.
Also hanging are brightly colored earrings made from clay cooked in the stove. Over the fireplace, she has embedded stones she collected on the beach at Davis Park, many of them with the distinctive purple swirls typical of Fire Island. Sharing a house there, she says, showed her that she would like "big house living," and communal space.
Although she ended up in the neighborhood because it offered the best space for the money, she has become conscious of some old ties that bind her even tighter. As a child, she says, coming in from Long Island with her parents, she always traveled across 125th Street on the way to see her grandparents, who lived near Columbia.
Her enthusiasm for a neighborhood that feels part of her childhood seems to be reciprocated by her new neighbors. Many of the recent signatures in her guest book are from local people who just stopped by to see what the new owner had done.
As in her old business, there are trends to follow, and forecasts to consider. Recently, she attended a convention for the owners of bed-and-breakfasts and discovered that the hot new amenity is an outdoor Jacuzzi.
Well, maybe someday.

HEADLINE: Getting Ready for Baby With a Helping Hand;
Five-Minute Doctor Visits Can Be Replaced With Midwife-Led Support Sessions

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IT is midmorning on a Thursday and women in their teens and early 20's straggle in, one by one, to a conference room at Waterbury Hospital until there are seven of them, bound together in a common -- and obvious -- sisterhood: They're all pregnant.
Each checks her weight on a scale (sometimes with a gasp of dismay), then her blood pressure with a small monitor and records the information from both on a form. Then they will settle back on chairs set in a semi-circle, to chat a bit with each other but mostly to listen a lot to Sharon Schindler Rising. 
 Mrs. Rising is a nurse-midwife.
To many people, the word midwife -- a term for a woman who helps other women in childbirth -- might seem obsolete today, suggestive of the American frontier of the last century or crowded slums at the turn of this century, certainly not part of medicine as the 21st century nears.
But midwifery is growing in Connecticut and elsewhere in the United States. Connecticut now has close to 100 certified midwives and nurse-midwives, Mrs. Rising says, and nationally a professional organization of midwives has set a membership goal of 10,000 by next year.
In addition, the role of the midwife has changed from the woman who traditionally delivered babies at home, mostly to poor families. Today, Mrs. Rising says, "birth centers are becoming more popular, with some very creative practices, some with midwives working independently, others with midwives and physicians working together." Rules about midwives and doctors vary from state to state, even from hospital to hospital. Mrs. Rising says she has delivered babies at Waterbury Hospital, but only with a doctor in attendance because of the hospital's rules. She doesn't agree with the rule, she said, but doesn't worry about it very much because she has little time to deliver babies anymore.
What is commanding her attention, and indeed attracting attention elsewhere around the country, is a system she has devised of having a midwife work with groups of pregnant women in prenatal care.
Mrs. Rising calls it "Centering Pregnancy" and since its inception seven years ago in a pilot program at Waterbury Hospital it has involved several hundred women in Connecticut and an unknown number in eight other states where it has been copied, from Louisiana to Maine to Illinois, even to Vancouver, British Columbia. Centering Pregnancy, Mrs. Rising says, takes pregnant women "out of exam rooms" and into a group setting for most of their prenatal care.
The exam room, is a doctor's office. The usual drill for a pregnant woman there, Mrs. Rising says, is well established: "She checks in, waits, finally gets to see the doctor, and maybe they have five minutes together." That, she maintains, is not enough time for the woman to know what is happening to her body and affords no opportunity to compare the progress of her pregnancy with other soon-to-be-mothers.
What her system advocates, Mrs. Rising says, is that a women see a doctor about four months after she finds she is pregnant and then again before giving birth, both times at such length that the doctor can get a comprehensive idea of her condition.Between the two visits to the doctor, the woman should attend 10 regularly scheduled, hour-and-a-half sessions with a small group of pregnant women with similar due dates, conducted by a midwife.
Mrs. Rising says the sessions afford pregnant women the opportunity to ask questions, talk over concerns and take routine tests.
The system, she says, is based on two premises that are now accepted as fact. One is that the more prenatal care women receive, the healthier babies they will deliver. The other is that pregnant women want to socialize and discuss their mutual concerns and problems.
The plan is not anti-doctor, Mrs. Rising says. In actuality, it is not even exclusively pro-midwife. She has written a 150-page handbook for it and in an explanation has written: "It is an ideal model for nurse-midwives and nurse practitioners to conduct: however, it also lends itself to parent educators, social workers and physicians."
In addition to the "Stay Well" sessions she holds at Waterbury Hospital for the city's community health clinic, she also holds some for a private obstetrics-gynecology office, the Center for Women's Health, with three doctors (Frederick Cohn, Anne McNulty and Jonathan Foster) and another midwife, Gina Novick.
Dr. Cohn, the first to join up in the physician-midwife alliance, is an enthusiast for the added dimension Mrs. Rising's system brings to the office. In addition to the benefits to pregnant woman, the sessions are beneficial to many soon-to-be-fathers who attend and consequently, he says, "are more help in labor and then with the babies when they come home."
Mrs. Rising, now in her 50's, and mother of two college students, is a Midwesterner by birth and a midwife rather than a doctor by choice. "I never wanted to be a doctor," she says. "I'm not interested in doing surgery. I like the more nurturing aspect of health care, working with families."
She first came to Connecticut to attend Yale School of Nursing in New Haven, then stayed on for half a dozen years as a faculty member. In the 70's, she was hired away by the University of Minnesota to help create its Childbearing Childrearing Center. "They sort of recruited me," she says. "They were interested in developing a graduate program in nurse-midwifery at the school of nursing there."
She stayed in Minnesota for seven years but then returned to Connecticut with her husband, Ronald Rising, a minister and graduate of the Yale School of Divinity, who was offered a job in a rehabilitation clinic for youngsters with emotional and addictive problems. By this time, Mrs. Rising had a handle on what she wanted to do, and it could be done in Connecticut as well as Minnesota.
She tested her "Centering Pregnancy" idea in 1993 and 1994 at Waterbury Hospital with 13 groups of eight pregnant women, 3 groups just of teen-agers. She has been at it since, expanding it to the private doctors' office, watching it spread into other states, which, she says, has delighted her.
Sometimes she is called to be a consultant for new groups, but even if not she says it doesn't bother her. "I have copyrighted the handbook," she says, "and it would have been possible, I guess, to franchise as a new health provider system, but I just want people to work with this. I have no great desire to oversee it. And I'm starting to run instructional workshops, including one proposed for San Francisco. I want to get people excited about the concept."
One thing is certain: the pregnant women she works with at the hospital are excited enough to show up regularly, and in good spirits, for the weekly sessions.
The one on a recent Thursday was probably fairly typical. Only one woman was missing but she had a good excuse: she was elsewhere in the hospital, a patient with a medical problem unrelated to her pregnancy.
Three young men were also present, but didn't say much. Mrs. Rising always calls the men who attend partners and knows them by name. "I guess basically I don't use the term 'husband' much anymore," she says. Nor does she ask the women who come to her whether they are married.
Two little girls were also present, one white, one black, both adorable and looking like a great poster for one world. They were out of the toddler stage and into the tearing-around and making noise stage. Eventually they were taken out and amused elsewhere by Mrs. Rising's assistant, Joan Seabury, a nurse.
The women talked to each other, weighed themselves, took their own blood pressures, then were, in turn, given a brief examination by Mrs. Rising. "A woman's belly becomes very public during pregnancy," she noted.
She started the talking part of the program, using two props: a small soft doll about the size of a newborn baby and a simulated pelvic skeleton, explaining the process of birth, what is normal, what isn't. And no college professor ever had a more rapt audience.
She talked on, a pleasant, smiling woman selling a blend of common sense and encouragement: how to make labor easier -- "picture a big wave when you're breathing"; eating better -- "I don't worry about the amount you eat but the quality of the food you eat" and hope -- "Don't worry when you see your baby for the first time, they're all a little bit bluish."
After the session was over, she said that women in general don't really know very much about the birth process, regardless of their economic status or their level of education.
Several mothers accompany their daughters to the sessions at the private doctors' office, she said, and they listen in genuine awe. Then they confess: "I just never knew these things."

HEADLINE: Where Public Housing Meets the American Dream

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
CAROLYN BELLAMY, standing near a large bay window in the living room of her brand new two-story house in Bridgeport, is trying to decide where to put her television set when she moves in later this month.
Ms. Bellamy is excited about the move from Trumbull Gardens, public housing in the North End of Bridgeport, where she has lived for the last 20 years, to a house -- the first that she will have ever owned -- in what is to be known as Pembroke Green in the Lower East Side neighborhood of Bridgeport. 
 The attractive, cream-colored two-story house also includes a unit adjacent to Ms. Bellamy's that she can rent out under a pioneering affordable housing concept. So far, 15 of the 21 two-family houses have been built -- ranging in size from 1,100 to 1,300 square feet -- and four of the owners have moved in.
What makes Pembroke Green noteworthy is that it is a Bridgeport Housing Authority program with homes that will be owned by their occupants, symbolizing a somewhat revolutionary approach to public housing in Connecticut.
Also noteworthy is that Pembroke Green is situated on part of the 37-acre site of the Father Panik Village, which, starting in the 1960's, became so crime-ridden and dilapidated that it came to epitomize the decline in the old concept of public housing.
Built just before the United States entered World War II, in December of 1941, Father Panik Village was named for the Rev. Stephen Panik, a priest and housing activist from St. Cyril and Methodius Church. During World War II, when Bridgeport military plants employed thousands of workers and was fond of calling itself "the arsenal of Democracy," hundreds of residents from Father Panik Village walked to work at nearby factories such as the Bridgeport Brass Company, Remington Arms and the Singer Sewing Machine Company.
The complex, which housed 4,000 people in three-story brick structures, was torn down between 1991 and 1994 and the tenants were relocated to other sites.
Now, on five acres of the old site, stand the neat frame homes, in a variety of hues, directly across from the Hall Neighborhood House, the longtime neighborhood community center and in the shadow of the abandoned Singer and Remington buildings and close to the rubble from the demolition of Bridgeport Brass.
"I had almost given up hope of owning my own home," said Ms. Bellamy, a 42-year-old account supervisor with Cablevision of Connecticut in Bridgeport. "And I'm just thrilled about the thought of moving in." Ms. Bellamy, who has three sons, has a bright and airy three-bedroom duplex that, like the other houses, will eventually have landscaped lawns in front and back.
Closing on Ms. Bellamy's house is March 18, and with an annual income of $35,000 and a good credit rating, she meets the Housing Authority's criteria for Pembroke Green. The houses cost just over $90,000 and she expects to be able to make a down payment of $4,500 (which the Housing Authority sets as a goal for prospective buyers) and the closing costs. Buyers who need help with the down payment, closing costs or mortgage can get aid from several sources including the Bridgeport Community Block Grant Program and Chase Bank, Citibank and People's Bank.
One feature of the program is a $6,000 "buy down" grant through Citibank under the Federal Home Loan Bank's affordable housing program. Under it, each home buyer in Pembroke Green automatically receives a $6,000 grant toward their mortgage, thus reducing the overall purchase price.
"The entire notion of public housing changes with this program," said Collin Vice, the deputy director of the Bridgeport Housing Authority. "And it changes the perception of the area by creating home ownership opportunities and a tax base for the city." Ms. Vice said that Pembroke Green would also serve as a model that the authority expected to expand to other parts of the city.
Ms. Bellamy will also be reducing her monthly housing costs: her monthly mortgage payment will be less than her rent at Trumbull Gardens. "I pay $692 now," she said, "but will be paying only $536 a month at Pembroke Green." And Ms. Bellamy will also be receiving $675 in rent from the tenant who will occupy the adjacent two-bedroom duplex unit.
Ms. Bellamy learned about the home-ownership opportunity from notices sent to residents of the city's housing projects.
Others heard about Pembroke Green at their churches. Among them was Juana Sasso, who became interested when the Bridgeport Mayor, Joseph Ganim, discussed Pembroke Green while speaking at the Church of Christ Assembly of God. Ms. Sasso and her 34-year-old son, Alejandro, were the first family to move in. "It is wonderful," said Mr. Sasso, a shipping clerk, while sitting in his new living room.
For some buyers, moving into Pembroke Green means going home again, since several had lived in Father Panik Village. "Many people who lived here as children want to come back to their old neighborhood, where they grew up," said Melody Thergood, the Bridgeport Housing Authority's family initiatives coordinator for Pembroke Green who lived in the area in the late 60's.
Waldo Emerson Williams, a vice president of residential lending at People's Bank, recalled the evolution of the drug dealing that led to the demise of Father Panik Village. "When our family moved into the Village in 1970, the drug dealers were a laughingstock," said Mr. Williams, who went on to attend Wesleyan University on an academic scholarship. "Then by the time we moved out in 1984 they had become role models to young kids. Fortunately, I had very positive role models, including my mother."
"Now, it's very rewarding to help create home ownership opportunities for a lot of people who I grew up with," added Mr. Williams during an interview at Pembroke Green.
Financial support for the Pembroke Green project also came from the State Department of Economic and Community Development, which contributed a $700,000 infrastructure grant, and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which is providing subsidies to those who rent units from new home owners.
In addition, the Murphy Sign Company donated advertising space to promote the program and two Bridgeport-based companies, United Illuminating and O & G Industries, provided $75,000 in tax credits.
Ms. Vice, of the Bridgeport Housing Authority, said that Pembroke Green was the first step in a revitalization effort at the old Father Panik Village site. "We hope to build another 20 homes on the site -- all single-family -- half of which would be sold outright while the others would be rented. In addition, we're been talking with a manufacturer, who is interested in building a light-industry plant there with a long-term lease, and with a church that would like to build on the site."
Ms. Vice added, "We're all very excited about the program, and, of course, so are the buyers, most of whom have never owned a home of their own. And many of them are going to be doing it in the neighborhood where they grew up."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property / Great River, Long Island;
From Defense Technology to High Technology

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: GREAT RIVER, N.Y.

 BODY:
NOT surprisingly, William Rudin sees parallels between Rudin Management Company's pioneering high-tech building at 55 Broad Street in lower Manhattan and his high-tech joint venture with Cogswell Realty Group that is about to open in an old Northrop Grumman building here on Long Island..
The end of the cold war drastically reduced the demand for the defense electronics that were designed and produced in the 350,000-square-foot plant just south of Sunrise Highway in the Town of Islip. The last employees left in December 1997, and Cogswell bought the property last year, paying about $10 million. 
 "Both buildings needed to be retooled for the 21st century," Mr. Rudin said. "The Long Island Technology Center is like 55 Broad laid on its side." Indeed, the two-story Long Island building stretches over acres of flat land while the 30-story building at Broad and Beaver Streets shoots up vertically on a crowded downtown block.
As the Rudin organization did at 55 Broad, the Long Island partners plan to equip the vacant building, on a 82-acre site, with the latest in high-speed voice and data communications, video conferencing capability and a telephone system that will operate wirelessly within the center. Internet access at a variety of capacity levels will also be available.
The building will also have high-capacity communications links to other Rudin properties, including 55 Broad, 110 Wall Street and, eventually, to the Reuters building that the Rudin organization is building on the west side of Seventh Avenue from 42d to 43d Street,, designated 3 Times Square.
The partners plan to spend about $21 million renovating the property, including putting up office walls inside the building. This prebuilding of interior space is contrary to typical industry practice, but Mr. Rudin said his organization found that high-technology companies like to move into finished space rather than wait for the interior construction work to be done.
"We found at 55 Broad that it was a case of 'If you build it, they will come,' " Mr. Rudin said. Virtually all the 410,000 square feet in the Broad Street building have been filled by dozens of information technology companies since the conversion was completed in 1996, and there is a waiting list of companies that want to get in.
On Long Island, the space will be built out with open, rather than dropped, ceilings for easy installation of overhead cabling, with the first 150,000 square feet of space expected to be available within weeks. Annual rents are expected to be in the low $20's per square foot. The Long Island center may differ from 55 Broad in that it is expected to be populated by a broad range of business and industrial software and technology companies, rather than the strong new-media concentration at the Manhattan location.
Although the conversion of 55 Broad was considered risky when it was first undertaken because of the depressed real estate market in the area, the success of the project has led to imitation. The local business improvement district, the Alliance for Downtown New York, and the city's Economic Development Corporation developed the Plug 'n' Go program, which makes Internet-wired space available to start-up companies at below-market rental rates. That program is now in its third year.
Since people working in rapidly developing technology industries tend to work long hours (24/7 is the industry shorthand for around-the-clock operations), they expect amenities where they work. At the Long Island Technology Center those features will include a fitness center, a recreational area equipped with a pool table and other activities, a child-care center and several classrooms. Outside areas will be landscaped and furnished to encourage outdoor dining in good weather; a volleyball area is also planned.
One of the features at 55 Broad is what the Rudin organization called the Global Community Sandbox, a video conferencing center that provides real-time voice and pictures of people who may be continents away.
IN a recent demonstration of the technology on Long Island, Rudin Management's chief operating officer, John J. Gilbert 3d, conducted a conference with participants in Malaysia, Singapore, Germany and Chicago. A permanent conferencing center is to be built as part of Phase 2 of the Long Island project, scheduled to open in the fall of this year.
The conferencing centers and the classrooms at both locations are intended to help bring people from different companies together so they can trade ideas, form partnerships and develop a community of shared interests.
That community appears to be developing rapidly on Long Island. When the Long Island Software Technology Network was formed a little over a year ago, the organizers hoped they could find 50 to 70 companies willing to contribute a few hundred dollars each to promote software development on the island. When the network recently published its first annual report, it listed 514 member companies and organizations -- and the roster is still growing.
LISTnet, as the organization is known, will be the first tenant of the technology center when it moves into 1,000 square feet over the next few weeks. The rapid growth of the organization is an indication of how much software and other technology is being developed in Long Island.
"There are a lot of people out there who are in the same category of business who really don't know each other," said Peter Goldsmith, the chairman of LISTnet. "You can't tell what a company does by its name."
He said he hopes the technology center will be seen as a neutral site where companies can locate and develop their businesses without fear of being steamrollered by a larger company. "The small companies are always afraid the big companies will gobble them up," Mr. Goldsmith said.
He said that many people are drawn by the attractions of Long Island living and that the presence of the the technology center gives them the opportunity to continue that life style while their business has high-capacity connections to the rest of the world.
"We hope to break down barriers between companies at the technical center," Mr. Goldsmith said. "We think this will help people form alliances."
Some of those alliances are forming already. Richard W. Kruse, a senior vice president of Stratem Computer Group in Hicksville, said he met executives of a company called ARvee Systems at a LISTnet meeting. He said they have arranged for Stratem to market ARvee's imaging products.
Mr. Kruse said that although many companies say they can do a complete technology installation, from cabling to software debugging, most really cannot. "Instead of fighting with each other we should be getting together," he said. "If I can do 60 percent of a job, that's what I should do and get Company A and Company B to do the rest."
The leaders of LISTnet are forging alliances with technology development centers such as Brookhaven National Laboratory and the island's educational institutions. At a recent meeting at the tech center site, Brookhaven displayed its latest developments, seeking business people who can convert them into products. Mr. Goldsmith said he expected Brookhaven to lease an office in the center to stay close to the commercial world.
Yacov Shamash, dean of the college of engineering and applied sciences at the SUNY Stony Brook campus, who is a member of the LISTnet board of directors, said his school would be involved in training programs at the center.
"There are thousands of technology companies on Long Island, but they are scattered all over the place," he said. The technology center, he said, will provide a focus, for the companies that locate there or attend educational sessions or trade association meetings.
The center is also a natural location for companies who outgrow the business incubators being established on Long Island with state assistance, Mr. Shamash said.
Incubators, which are often associated with educational institutions, provide subsidized office and laboratory space for companies in their first years of existence. If successful, the companies are expected to move on to commercial space. One such incubator is at Stony Brook, and Mr. Shamash said there is a state-backed program to develop six more on Long Island.
Mr. Kruse of Stratem said that he had proposed establishing another technology center at another former defense location on Long Island but that it would likely be a long time before the first one was filled. In addition to the 350,000 square feet of space already on the site, the developers have the as-of-right option to build 787,000 more square feet of space on the sprawling site.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Port Authority Sale

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has announced the $9 million sale of its remaining 20-acre property at the Yonkers Industrial Park to Hudson View Associates, a private company in Greenwich. The sale represents the public agency's continuing "movement back to its core mission of transportation," the Port Authority said.
"In 1985, we began transforming an idle and aged manufacturing facility, the former Otis Elevator plant, into a thriving, refurbished industrial park employing more than 540 people," Chairman Lewis M. Eisenberg of the authority said. "Now the time is right to turn it over to the private sector and let the Port Authority focus its resources on its main mission of improving the region's transportation systems and economic competitiveness." 
 The new owner, an affiliate of National RE/sources, a real estate investment company, plans to continue to operate the property as an industrial park.
Two buildings were sold in 1996 and 1997. The other properties include five buildings and about 424,000 square feet of industrial and office space.
The new owner is committed to continuing the operation as an industrial park, retaining among other tenants Kawasaki Heavy Industries, which makes rail cars for the New York City Transit Authority, Long Island Rail Road and the City of Baltimore, the Port Authority said.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Job-Saving Plan

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has started the second round of his "Power for Jobs" program by announcing that 615 jobs will be created and 19,697 protected under new allocations of low-cost electricity recommended by the State Economic Development Power Allocation Board.
The plan is meant to work by converting the savings in energy into more jobs. 
 For Westchester, that means concessions on power use to Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Peekskill, which will in turn be used to create 350 jobs and save 647 existing jobs; Reliable Automatic Sprinkler, Mount Vernon, to create 500 new jobs and save 513, and St. Joseph Medical Center in Yonkers, to create 550 jobs and save 1,136.
Governor Pataki said he would sign low-cost power extensions for 16 Power Authority business customers recently approved by the State Economic Development Power Allocation Board. The 16 businesses, which together employ 6,082 New Yorkers, receive the low-cost power through economic development power programs meant to protect jobs. The power is produced at the James A. Fitzpatrick Nuclear Power Plant on Lake Ontario near Oswego.
In Westchester, the companies are the International Business Machines Watson Research Center of Hawthorne and Yorktown Heights, 2,265 jobs, and J. J. Cassone Bakery of Port Chester, 350 jobs.
The terms of the extended contracts include a price freeze for three years, a near-term reduction for the Power Authority electricity production price and an agreement by the Power Authority to absorb part of future price increases related to the transmission and distribution of power.

HEADLINE: F. Y. I.

BYLINE: By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:

Architectural Gem Theft
 
Q. About 30 years ago, as the Washington Market area in lower Manhattan was cleared for urban renewal, the city dismantled an early cast-iron building and stored the pieces. The building, an architectural gem as I recall, was to be re-erected at a future date. What became of it?
 
A. It was stolen.
James Bogardus, a pioneer in the design and construction of cast-iron buildings, built a group of stores for Edward H. Laing at Washington and Murray Streets in 1849. Using prefabricated cast-iron columns and panels, along with wooden spans and brick walls, Bogardus assembled the four-story structure in two months, an astonishing feat for the day. 
 The Laing Stores represented one of the earliest uses of curtain-wall construction using mass-produced, modular iron parts, and in a sense all skyscrapers are its grandchildren. Scheduled for demolition in 1967, the little building somehow survived on the site until 1971, when preservationists gingerly disassembled the facades, numbered the parts and stored them on a nearby vacant lot. The building was to be reassembled next to its original site, on the campus of the new Manhattan Community College.
In 1974, however, three men were discovered loading cast-iron panels from the Laing Stores onto a truck in a storage lot at Washington and Chambers Streets. Though 22 broken sections were later recovered in a Bronx junkyard, horrified city officials discovered that almost two-thirds of the facade had already been sold for scrap, at $90 a truckload. The remaining panels were immediately placed under lock and key.
A hybrid Laing building, combining original and recast components, was planned for the new South Street Seaport, but, incredibly, all the remaining pieces were stolen in 1977. A facsimile of the building, lacking a single molecule of the original, was built at Front and Fulton Streets in 1983. It remains intact.
 
13 Pillars All in a Row
 
Q. In the woods just west of the Old Putnam Trail in Van Cortlandt Park, near the Parade Ground, are 13 tall stone pillars standing in a row. What is or was their purpose?
 
A. Around 1900, it became clear to Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, owner of the New York Central Railroad, that his Grand Central Depot would have to be rebuilt. The city demanded that steam locomotives be replaced by electrified trains, and the depot on 42d Street was in perpetual expansion and rearrangement.
Sometime before 1903, Vanderbilt arranged for several stone quarries to deliver some huge sample slabs, which were placed outdoors and exposed to the elements. The upper facade of the new Grand Central Terminal would be built with the type of stone that weathered the most handsomely. The slabs were set upright along what was then the New York Central Putnam line, which traveled through Van Cortlandt Park on its way to Boston.
Marianne Anderson, a spokeswoman for Van Cortlandt and Pelham Bay Parks, said the second stone from the south, Bedford limestone from Indiana, was chosen for Grand Central Terminal, not for the beauty with which it aged, but because it could be transported cheaply on Vanderbilt's rails from the quarry to New York. The pillars have been painted battleship gray, she said, to cover the inevitable graffiti.
The Putnam Trail was created when the rails from the Putnam Line were pulled up in 1994. Remnants from the railway, including parts of a chain-link fence, are still evident along the route, which carried passengers until 1958.
 
The Urchins' Champion
 
Q. Whence comes the name Drumgoole, as in Drumgoole Road on Staten Island?
 
A. Born in Ireland in 1816, John C. Drumgoole was the champion and benefactor of New York City's thousands of street urchins, particularly homeless newsboys and bootblacks. Drumgoole was for many years a sexton and janitor at St. Mary's Church on Grand Street, where it was said that he let homeless children sleep in the basement. Ordained a priest at 53, he became chaplain for the St. Vincent's Home for Newsboys at 55 Warren Street and founded a newspaper called The Homeless Child.
In 1881 he founded the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin at 80 Lafayette Street, which provided beds for more than 2,000 homeless children. The mission later moved to the south shore of Staten Island, where it continues today. A bronze statue of Father Drumgoole stood at Great Jones and Lafayette Streets from 1894 until it was moved to Staten Island in 1921.
 DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
For Young Entrepreneurs, A Step Past the Classroom

BYLINE: By PAUL WISENTHAL 

 BODY:
MOST every day after school and on weekends, Federica Bautista, 18, sells fruit, vegetables and flowers from a pushcart stationed at the entrance to Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens. When it's cold outside, she takes delivery orders by telephone at her home, a two-bedroom apartment she shares with seven relatives. Her weekly earnings of $100 to $150 on sales of $400 help support her widowed mother and her 2-year-old son, Abraham.
Ms. Bautista, a single mother who emigrated from Mexico in 1991, used to fear for her financial future. But last year, she helped her family escape welfare by completing an after-school program offered by the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship. The foundation provides students in poor urban neighborhoods with training and seed capital to start their own businesses. 
 The group is one of about 20 nonprofit agencies authorized by school boards across the country to teach business literacy. The largest of these, Junior Achievement, reaches more than 3.1 million students, up 17 percent last year, by bringing business people into the classrooms.
"So many of our kids are disconnected from opportunities and options available to them from our economic system," said James B. Hayes, chief executive of Junior Achievement, based in Colorado Springs. "For many, their only example is playing for the Chicago Bulls or selling narcotics."
Some of the groups are going a step beyond the literacy training by teaching students to run their own businesses.
The National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship had its own origins in New York, after Steve Mariotti, a high school teacher in the South Bronx, saw the effects of narcotics and violence on his students. Though they had little understanding of how the economy worked, many still dreamed of having their own businesses.
To teach them, Mr. Mariotti established the foundation in 1988. Eleven years later, it has a budget of $5 million a year, with 22,000 graduate entrepreneurs and offices across the country. Major donors are the Koch family foundations, the Heinz endowments, Fleet Bank, the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, Microsoft and the Ronald McDonald House Charities.
Ms. Bautista turned to the foundation after seeing a poster at school. She learned everything from how to write a business plan to how to negotiate with wholesalers. Later, she received $50 toward the cost of opening her flower and fruit stand.
Among other agencies, Rural Entrepreneurship Through Action Learning, or REAL Enterprises, based in Durham, N.C., trains entrepreneurs in rural areas across the country. Among its successes are Spencer Hall, 18, who started Expertise Computers in 1994 in Deer Park, Wash. Today, with $750,000 in sales and five employees, Mr. Hall installs computer systems for small businesses, professionals and schools.
EVERY state has some form of entrepreneurship education. But tight budgets often limit the offerings to relatively few students.
To expand the reach, the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship, in partnership with Microsoft, plans in May to start BizTech, an on-line entrepreneurial learning system at www.nfte.com.
Some past sponsors of entrepreneurship programs have had second thoughts. Gary Kaplan, executive director of Jobs for Youth Boston, ran entrepreneurial programs until 1991. He now says that with 25 percent of the population functionally illiterate, "teaching entrepreneurship is not a substitute for teaching reading, math and science."
Last year, a measure that would have allocated $60 million to states for entrepreneurship education in public schools stalled in Congress. Its sponsors plan to try again this spring.
As for Ms. Bautista, she now plans to go to college. "I want to become a teacher or perhaps study medicine," she said. "But I will still want to have my own business."

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
Preserving Medicare's Roots

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach to and arrival at retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN Thomas C. Matzzie graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1997 with a degree in economics, he decided not to follow many of his classmates into high-paying careers on Wall Street or elsewhere. Instead, he took a lower-paying job, as a policy analyst at the Institute for America's Future, a liberal research organization in Washington.
Mr. Matzzie, 23, who grew up near Pittsburgh, credits Medicare -- of all things -- with giving him the chance to follow his interests rather than chase a big salary. "When I was a senior in high school, my grandmother -- who has since died -- became very ill," he recalled. "Medicare was there and helped pay the expenses that would otherwise have bankrupted our family. Because of Medicare I was able to go on to college and then have the freedom to do nonprofit work that pays less, because I know that the burden of taking care of my parents will be a lot less with Medicare." 
 Though he won't use Medicare himself for another 40-plus years, Mr. Mattzie sees how his well-being depends on it. If only the same could be said for the broader public, whose awareness seems to have dimmed.
In the current debate over the program's future, many people have forgotten and others are too young to know what it was like before 1966, when Medicare began. Back then, young people feared that caring for a sick parent, retired and no longer covered by health insurance, could ruin them.
THEODORE R. MARMOR, a professor of politics at the Yale School of Management and the author of "The Politics of Medicare," (Aldine, 1998) says a founding principle of Medicare was the "importance of relieving children of the financial catastrophe that illness could mean for their parents and then for them."
"That understanding has been weakened to the point of amnesia," he added, partlybecause Medicare's benefits have come to be taken for granted, and partly because the financial relief they offer has been blunted by growing drug and nursing home costs, which the program doesn't cover.
Another founding principle of Medicare is threatened by a proposal to split it in two, allowing a choice between the traditional plan, with the Government paying the bills, and the chance to shop for private insurance whose premiums the Government would largely pay. "This so-called premium-support proposal, which is really a voucher plan, would undermine Medicare as a social insurance program," Professor Marmor said. "People would face a dizzying array of private plans and would have to pay the difference between a Federal voucher and the cost of a health plan. This would shift the risks of inflation to the elderly and to health plans and away from the Medicare program itself."
"This is an ideological attack and an effort to reject by stealth the social insurance premises of the Medicare program," he said. "It rejects the original notion that Medicare should be a common program for everybody who is over 65. "
Under the proposal, wealthier elderly Americans could have better coverage. That, he argues, would encourage one Medicare program for the affluent and another for everybody else.
This solution is hardly the only way to rescue Medicare, Professor Marmor said. He cites Congressional Budget Office figures showing that raising the Medicare payroll tax to 2.02 percent, from 1.45 percent, would keep Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund in balance through 2025. Someone making $40,000 a year would pay an additional $228 a year, or 62 cents a day. "Are we to believe that the public is unwilling to accept tax increases of this magnitude to support the growing numbers of their parents and grandparents who become eligible for Medicare?" he wrote last year.
Phyllis Mayer certainly wouldn't object to such an increase, both to insure the program's future and to pay for prescription drugs. Ms. Mayer, 83, of New Bedford, Mass., is the oldest student at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth, where she will receive a B.A. degree in June.
Remembering the days before Medicare, she sees the program as a reflection of our values. "It's important to us as a society that we take care of people," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Untangling Gridlock On the Union Pacific

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
FOR Troy Slinkard, the worst days of the Union Pacific Railroad's service crisis came in late 1997. About a year after the U.P. had merged with the Southern Pacific, the two railroads' combined train traffic was choking to a standstill in the crucial nest of tracks around and through Houston, the heart of the region that Mr. Slinkard helped direct.
"It was 12 to 15 hours a day of complete misery, doing everything in your power to clear it up," he remembered. "And it went on day after day." 
 At the height of the crisis, which flared on and off for 18 months, the gridlock in Houston backed up trains as far away as California and Chicago. The sidings that allow trains to pass each other were persistently full. Freight cars were left stranded for days or weeks, or temporarily lost. Shippers screamed about millions of dollars in losses.
Today, the worst of those headaches are behind Mr. Slinkard. The Union Pacific has become much more adept at managing the country's largest railroad, with 36,000 miles of track sprawling across 23 states in the West and South.
Train speeds through Houston have rebounded from an average of just 12.5 miles an hour last March to 18.2 m.p.h. for the week ended Saturday, Feb. 20, about what they were before the merger, according to the railroad's figures. Several major shippers' claims arising from the debacle have been settled out of court, and safety problems related to the snarl have abated.
Even as the crisis led some critics to call for greater regulation of railroads, coping with it has taken the Union Pacific beyond tactical problem-solving to making fundamental changes in the way it operates.
Giving up on centralized control came first. "We learned this is such a large company that we could not manage it from a single center in Omaha," said Dick Davidson, chairman of the Union Pacific. So it delegated operational control to regional centers in Houston, Omaha and Roseville, Calif., near Sacramento.
And in Houston, the epicenter of the crisis, the U.P. went even further, creating a joint operating center with the Burlington Northern Santa Fe, its main rival.
That's where Mr. Slinkard works now, as a joint director, reporting to both railroads. He is a referee of sorts, making sure that the two sides' dispatchers, who now sit in the same room, coordinate their train movements, and that all trains are handled fairly.
"We have a saying here," Mr. Slinkard said. "We don't care what color the locomotive is, as long as it's pulling cars and leaving town."
So pleased were the railroads with the improvements in Houston that they are planning similar joint operations centers to control trackage in the Powder River Basin in eastern Wyoming and the areas around Los Angeles and Kansas City.
The Union Pacific also simplified train routing in Houston by designating certain tracks for permanent one-way traffic. It stepped up capital spending and hired 6,000 new workers, 1,100 in the Houston area. And Mr. Davidson dispatched a personal representative, Joe Adams, to mend fences in Houston. "We do a great deal of business here, and we want to be partners with Houston and participate in economic development," Mr. Adams said.
WHILE shippers and government officials generally compliment the Union Pacific on its steps to end the crisis, there is still backing for a rethinking of railroad deregulation in Washington.
"Regardless of what happened with the Union Pacific crisis, the industry has consolidated beyond where it makes sense," said Diane C. Duff, executive director of the Alliance for Rail Competition, a Washington-based lobbying group representing shippers who depend heavily on rail service.
Ms. Duff said service is still substantially worse than before the merger. The Society of the Plastics Industry, which represents a large number of rail shippers, said its members' bulk rail shipments took an average of 11 days in December, better than the 15-day average in March 1998 but nowhere near the 6-day average in December 1995. Shippers' groups say lack of competition is to blame: The country's major railroads have dwindled from 42 in 1980 to just 4 today.
Before regulations were lifted by the Staggers Act, enacted in 1980, the Government controlled many aspects of railroad rate setting. The Surface Transportation Board still oversees matters like railroad safety but, critics say, no longer does much to combat unfair pricing practices.
During the service crisis, a coalition of smaller railroads, shippers and state and local representatives asked the board to force the Union Pacific to relax its grip on Houston, where it controls about 80 percent of all track. The coalition wanted running rights on U.P. track for rival railroads and a new independent entity to move traffic through Houston. The U.P. objected that these measures were unnecessarily drastic, and that any area customer served by two railroads before the merger still had access to a second carrier. In the end, the board ordered a few minor measures.
Critics of the railroads have now turned to Congress, backing legislation that would require the board to promote competition among railroads and assure that "captive shippers" served by only one railroad were charged reasonable rates; studies suggest that such shippers now pay 30 percent more, on average, than other rail customers.
Mr. Davidson called the bill shortsighted and said customers would benefit as the Union Pacific corrected mistakes. "We went to hell, looked the devil in the eye and came back," he said. "It has been a profound experience. We have all made a blood-oath commitment that we're going to learn from the desperate situation we were in and come out of it a far better railroad."
