SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3424 words

HEADLINE: Tempest on the River;
It Was Supposed to Be an Urban Utopia. Today, Roosevelt Island Is a Battleground.

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
THEY arrived at Roosevelt Island in stages, beginning in 1975, when the first apartment building opened. Pioneers, they were lured by reasonable, and in some cases subsidized, housing, and by promises of a utopia where 20,000 people of all races and economic levels would mix, traffic would be minimal and greenery would flourish, all within sight of Manhattan's skyline.
Promises, promises. 
 Nearly a quarter-century later, the 8,500 inhabitants of the northern half of the island, the only part developed, are riven by conflict. Although most of some three dozen residents interviewed over two months said they liked living on the island, many were hostile to the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, the state agency that runs the place and plans its future development, and its chief executive, Dr. Jerome H. Blue, appointed in 1996 by Gov. George E. Pataki.
And so, where tranquillity was expected, anger is heard. The Roosevelt Island Residents Association, the largest civic group, and The Main Street Wire, the local newspaper, scorn Dr. Blue, a protege of former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, accusing him of incompetence, arrogance and dishonesty. Elected officials like Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis and Councilman A. Gifford Miller, both Democrats, have jumped on board. In interviews, Mr. Grannis called Dr. Blue "duplicitous" and Mr. Miller called him "an extraordinarily poor communicator" and "ineffective manager."
But others denounce the criticism as racially motivated -- Dr. Blue is black -- and call his detractors upper-middle-class bigots who want to keep the community underpopulated and keep out additional low-income residents. Both sides sometimes engage in shouting matches at town meetings and at monthly gatherings of the operating corporation's directors.
Whatever its motivation, grumbling over Dr. Blue's day-to-day management is widespread, as is consternation over projects he supports, like a $200 million two-tower, high-rise Marriott hotel and convention center proposed for the southern tip that would be linked to Manhattan by ferry. Edward J. Logue, the urban planner who oversaw the creation of Roosevelt Island as president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, now the Empire State Development Corporation, calls the project "an outrage" that would be "a substantial change in the development plan."
Dr. Blue, who has a Ph.D. in neuroscience, remains steadfast. He dismisses Mr. Logue as "a naysayer," and says his opponents do not like him because of fiscal restraint he has imposed upon what he says was a free-spending, deficit-ridden operation. And he says that the hotel and other development plans he advocates will bring jobs to the island and money to the operating corporation.
"My mandate was to make the island self-sufficient," he said. "And I have done that."
Still, some detractors think his boss, State Housing Commissioner Joseph E. Lynch, may be reeling him in a bit. Mr. Lynch, a member of the corporation's board, said of Dr. Blue: "I think he has had a very difficult position. And I think that he has done what he was sent to do -- get the island in the black. But there are huge issues left concerning development, and if we can help and assist him in doing his job, that's a good thing."
In the last year, Mr. Lynch has attended the monthly board meetings rather than send an assistant. At his suggestion, two residents' representatives -- Patrick Stewart, president of the Roosevelt Island Residents Association, and Susan Whitaker, head of the Roosevelt Island Council of Organizations -- are to join the board.
Last month, Mr. Lynch set up two committees, half of whose members are residents, to advise the corporation on plans for the future. Board approval of the hotel project was postponed in December pending the committees' review, which began only last week. Still, Mr. Lynch said, he expected the corporation's directors to recommend "conditional approval," perhaps this week.
The idea for the committees, Mr. Lynch said, came from a team of management consultants who recommended "broadening the base" of the operating corporation and giving Dr. Blue "extra expertise in planning." Mr. Lynch blamed the corporation's directors, not Dr. Blue, for not doing the job "it was envisioned to do" in overseeing the island. In response, a board member, Frank Angelino, said he agreed that input from the committees "would be helpful."
 
A Small Body of Land Surrounded by Indifference
The island has been there, midway between Manhattan and Queens, for as long as the East River has flowed, now running parallel to the Upper East Side for some two miles, from 50th to 86th Streets. Named Minnahanock, or Island Place, by the Indians, and then Varcken Eylandt, or Hog's Island by the Dutch, it has also been known as Blackwell's Island (for an early English settler) and, more recently, as Welfare Island, a dreary appellation that referred to the asylums and hospitals that became its main claims to fame. For centuries, it was unused or underused, relegated to the background of the city's consciousness, accessible only by elevators from the Queensboro Bridge (gone now) or via a small bridge linking it to 36th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens.
But its location proved too attractive to ignore. In the late 1960's, urban planners, led by Mr. Logue, persuaded city and state officials that they could do something better with "the island nobody knows," where many of the older 19th-century structures had fallen into disuse and disrepair. The 147-acre site, still called Welfare Island 30 years ago, was leased by the city to the state for 99 years, and an ambitious plan, created by the architects Philip Johnson and John Burgee in 1969, called "for a town in the center of New York."
There was to be an apartment community at the northern end (Northtown) and another in the middle (Southtown), where a town center would also be built. There would be only one street (Main Street), with minimal traffic thanks to a central garage (Motorgate). Shops, schools and recreation centers would be built, and a space-age garbage disposal system (called AVAC, for automated vacuum collection system, similar to one at Disney World) would transport refuse pneumatically through underground tunnels.
And while two city-owned hospitals, Bird S. Coler, at the north end, and Goldwater Memorial, south of the Queensboro Bridge, were to remain, providing long-term nursing care, most of the remainder of the island would be made into parkland, including its southern tip, Southpoint, where a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt was to be built. (The island was renamed after him in 1973.)
Of the 20,000 people who were to live on the island, a third were to be low-income and elderly, and half in the moderate- and middle-income ranges. The rest would pay market rates for apartments. Once all the buildings were constructed and fully populated, rents and other revenues were supposed to cover all operating costs.
But ups and downs in the city's economy affected the island. A subway station that was supposed to be completed in 1976 wasn't done until 1989, necessitating construction of an aerial tramway, which was not part of the original plan. Northtown, with five apartment complexes, wasn't finished until 1989, and the Roosevelt memorial, designed by another noted architect, Louis Kahn, was never built. Nor was Southtown. Plans for Southtown that were approved in 1990 have been abandoned, though the operating corporation has solicited new ones. With development incomplete, the population never reached 9,000, and the island needed several million dollars in annual state subsidies.
 
Residents Are Manhattanites, But City Has No Role
From the outset, Roosevelt Island has been a political hybrid. The people who live there are legally Manhattan residents, but under the lease with the city, daily operations and development are the responsibility of the state-chartered Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, whose directors are appointed by the Governor. The State Housing Commissioner is chairman of the board, and only three of the nine directors are required to live on the island. The city has no say in island management.
Before Dr. Blue took office, residents said, that arrangement did not seem to matter. "There was always the view that the corporation and the citizens were in things together," Assemblyman Grannis said.
Mr. Stewart, the residents association head, agreed. Dr. Blue's predecessor, Jean Lerman, who was appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, "really had the interests of the residents at heart," he said, citing as an example of her openness a 1995 forum on the island's future at which local residents were encouraged to participate. Equally important, he said, she made sure that the state allocated money for maintenance and repair and that the work was done.
Under Ms. Lerman, who declined to comment, the operating corporation also ran in the red. To meet the deficit and pay for capital improvements, the state contributed $6.7 million in 1994-95 and $6.2 million in 1995-96. Governor Pataki did not want to perpetuate this deficit spending, Dr. Blue said, and his mission was clear: eliminate the deficits and end the subsidies.
And he did. When the 1997-98 fiscal year rolled around, he said, he had reduced expenses to $9.7 million from $11 million the previous year, and was able to pay those from revenues and reserves without any subsidy. Dr. Blue said he expected to do so again for fiscal 1998-99, which ends on March 31.
How did he accomplish this? "By cutting waste," Dr. Blue said. "We had a contractor who mowed our lawns for $70,000 a year," he said. "I got our own workers to do it." He also pared down the scope of a sea wall project near Octagon Park. "When I got here, the agency planned to spend $3.7 million," he said. "But only $3 million was needed. The rest was for Art Deco picnic furniture." He eliminated the money for the furniture, and the project was completed.
Dr. Blue, whose annual salary is $115,000, arrives at work each day from his home in Freeport, on Long Island, in the heart of D'Amato country. After working as a legislative aide to the senator, he was hired in the mid-1980's, at Mr. D'Amato's behest, as a special assistant to the New York regional administrator of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. In 1989, an influence-peddling scandal erupted at H.U.D. The agency's regional economist in New York, David Burns, testified in hearings that Mr. D'Amato had used Dr. Blue and other surrogates to influence the agency to approve pet housing projects. Neither Senator D'Amato nor Dr. Blue was charged with wrongdoing.
Dr. Blue left H.U.D. in 1990 and became the housing commissioner of Freeport. After Governor Pataki was elected in 1994, he appointed Dr. Blue vice president of the State Housing Finance Agency. In June 1996, the Governor appointed him to the Roosevelt Island job.
Almost immediately, controversy erupted. That August, another Pataki appointee, the State Housing Commissioner, Joseph Holland, wrote a scathing memorandum to the Governor, accusing Dr. Blue of "mismanagement," "irrational conduct" and "poor judgment." Calling him a "potential public-relations disaster," Mr. Holland urged that Dr. Blue be dismissed. The New York Post obtained a copy of the memorandum and published a summary. Soon after, Mr. Holland, who was suffering well-publicized private financial problems, resigned.
Mr. Holland, a lawyer now in private practice, would not comment except to say that his memorandum "speaks for itself." And Dr. Blue, who has consistently disputed Mr. Holland's criticisms, said only, "I seem to attract this kind of thing."
Dr. Blue's style -- quiet and deliberate, according to supporters, secretive and dishonest, according to critics -- rubs many people the wrong way, and he made enemies quickly on Roosevelt Island. To cut costs, and without consulting residents, he tried to reduce tram hours, end free tram passes for students who attended school off the island and raise fees for using ball fields -- all unpopular moves that were later abandoned.
Assemblyman Grannis, who is working on home-rule legislation for the island, said that Dr. Blue "plays everything very close to the vest." And, he said, "My gut tells me that he is ignoring the hidden capital needs of the island." Mr. Grannis cited maintenance of the sea wall near Octagon Park as a major concern.
To address their fears that Dr. Blue's economies might hurt the island, residents and local officials sought financial records of the operating corporation a couple of years ago. But Dr. Blue resisted, Mr. Stewart said. More than a dozen Freedom of Information Act requests yielded some information, he said, but not enough. Only after threats by local elected officials to subpoena him and his records did Dr. Blue meet with them and provide documents. But, Mr. Stewart said, there are still "a lot of questions."
Dr. Blue insists that he has been forthcoming with information and that the island is not being neglected. He said the sea wall was fine, an assertion confirmed by Tom Smyth, project manager for the Army Corps of Engineers, which has been examining the island. "Some sections are fairly old and have developed cracks, but there are no major problems," Mr. Smyth said.
And while Dr. Blue's adversaries accuse him of being remote and unresponsive to their concerns, many of his advocates say members of the Residents Association are cliquish.
"We call them the 100 families," said Edward Rademaker, who with his wife, Jessie, is one of Dr. Blue's most vocal supporters. "They are a small, well-educated group that has always had its way on the island," he said, adding that the association is not representative of most island residents, nearly half of whom are nonwhite, including some United Nations employees.
For years before Dr. Blue's arrival, Mrs. Rademaker said, she had tried to get money from the operating corporation to start a group for young adults that would offer computer training. But she said the Residents Association opposed her. She finally got $42,000 from Dr. Blue in 1997, and more than 200 people have since attended the program, she said, all but two or three of them nonwhite. Like Dr. Blue, Mr. and Mrs. Rademaker are black, and they say they believe that opposition to their program, and to Dr. Blue, has a racial component.
"I've lived here 22 years," Mr. Rademaker said. "I know what's racial and what's not. No one can tell me that I don't know what discrimination is."
Deirdre MacNamara, who is white, agreed that some criticism was racially motivated. "Dr. Blue doesn't let himself be manipulated by this small group that wants to control everything," whose members are mostly white, she said.
 
Visions for the Future Form the Crux of Disputes
While the specter of budget cuts remains a constant irritant, the major source of contention between the pro-Blue and anti-Blue forces is development. Having brought the island out of its deficit, Dr. Blue has said that it must be fully developed, as originally intended, so it can continue to be self-sufficient. None of the residents or elected officials who are involved with Roosevelt Island affairs disputes that. But many take issue with the way he has approached the task.
One of their chief complaints, they say, is that Dr. Blue does not come up with his own plans or seek community input in the planning process. Instead, Councilman Miller said, "He puts out requests for proposals, asking developers, 'How would you like to make money with my land?' and then assumes, once he picks something, that the general development plan can be amended to accommodate it."
In rebuttal, Dr. Blue points to a model of the failed 1990 Southtown project, which the corporation drafted after extensive community input but no developer agreed to build. "I keep it up as a constant reminder that that kind of development doesn't work," he said.
Mr. Miller and Mr. Grannis also argue that the master lease between the city and the state requires that any change in the development plan be subject to city approval and, under some circumstances, an environmental impact statement. (Roosevelt Island is otherwise exempt from city land use review procedures.) But Dr. Blue says the projects that are "on the table" -- a town center, a residence for the elderly, conversion of five vacant mini-schools into condominiums and the hotel and conference center -- do not violate the plan.
New plans for Southtown, the original town center, are still in the early stages and have not become controversial. The same cannot be said for other projects. For example, Dr. Blue first proposed that the residence for the elderly be built at Octagon Park, on the north end of the island. After many residents complained about losing parkland, he moved the project to Sportspark, an underused gym near the Queensboro Bridge. But developers say the project can be economically viable only if it is a 31-story building, which opponents say is far too tall for such a narrow site.
More recently, Dr. Blue's plan to convert the mini-schools into condominiums has come under fire. These small schools, in apartment complexes, have been vacant since 1992, when they were replaced by P.S./I.S. 217. Some residents say the proposed condominiums will be larger and taller than the mini-schools, thereby blocking views.
Then there are the plans for Southpoint, the approximately 10-acre site just below Goldwater Memorial Hospital, south of the Queensboro Bridge. Dr. Blue backs the proposal for the Marriott hotel whose 350 rooms would be in two 26-story towers. Plans for the $200 million project include a conference center and spa on the mostly vacant, overgrown land. Dr. Blue and the developers say the hotel would generate at least $2 million in annual revenue for the operating corporation, as well as 400 construction jobs and 100 or more permanent jobs.
A former smallpox hospital on the site, known as the Renwick ruin, will be preserved, Dr. Blue said, and the developers have agreed to "collaborate" with the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in getting the Roosevelt memorial built. But the institute president, William vanden Heuvel, said last week that though he met with Dr. Blue last year, he has had no contact with the developers.
Meanwhile, residents worry about the toll that construction will take on their one-street island, with heavy equipment rumbling to Southpoint from the small 36th Avenue bridge, more than halfway up the island. And they worry that Southpoint will become, in Mr. Stewart's words, a "blocked-off" community to which they will be denied access.
But more than anything, they say, they worry that development of Southpoint will rob them of parkland. The island's general development plan, as last amended in 1990, includes in its list of open space a mention of "Southpoint Park, approximately 10 acres south of the Goldwater Memorial Hospital" -- the very same 10 acres earmarked for the hotel and conference center. Dr. Blue, though, insists there would still be plenty of open space left.
In his office last week, Dr. Blue reflected on the turmoil that has surrounded his tenure. "I will not let myself forget that these people are in the minority," he said of his opponents. "Most people like having a safe, clean community, and I've given them that." He acknowledged that his style had antagonized some, and said that he was trying to change, and that he held monthly resident advisory committee meetings to which all residents were welcome.
But some people say there has been no change. Last Monday, for example, Dr. Blue did not attend an evening meeting on the mini-schools that he himself had scheduled. After residents strongly complained, he scheduled another meeting for March 16. Last month, he skipped a forum on Roosevelt Island development arranged by Councilman Miller and attended by more than 100 people, including Assemblyman Grannis and the Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields.
"Why isn't Dr. Blue here," a man in the audience asked. "Can't he be brought in kicking and screaming?"
"Apparently not," Mr. Miller replied. In a later interview, Dr. Blue said that by the time he had learned of the meeting, it was too late to attend. Asked why he did not send someone to represent him, he answered quietly, "They didn't ask for anyone else."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Reactors: Healthy but Dying

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TWENTY years after the meltdown at Three Mile Island, the nuclear industry has succeeded in ways that were hard to imagine in March of 1979 as Pennsylvania cowered in fear, plants around the country lost their luster and scores of half-built reactors were abandoned. The industry is doing better now, but ironically extinction is in sight.
Today, reactors are quietly producing about one-quarter more electricity each, and the level of radiation exposure to workers is down along with the number of automatic shut-downs. Uranium fuel is cheap and plentiful, and, with low interest rates, so is nuclear power's biggest ingredient, capital. The industry has also happily achieved a lowered public profile. 
 "And everything seems to be falling apart," Michael L. Corradini, a professor of nuclear engineering at the University of Wisconsin, said sadly.
The nuclear industry will be around for years to come, but seems to have peaked in terms of the number of working reactors and their share of power generated nationally. No reactors are being built; the last ordered were Palo Verde 1, 2 and 3 in Arizona in October, 1973, the month the Arab oil embargo began.
Since then there has been an energy revolution, but it wasn't nuclear. A barrel of oil, which has roughly enough energy to run a small house for a month, sold for $12 then; by 1979 it was $40. Today it is back down around $12. These gyrations upward lured utility companies into nuclear decisions that now look ridiculous.
For example, Millstone 3 reactor in Waterford, Conn., was far over budget during construction in the late 1970's. Even after the incident at Three Mile Island, consultants said it was still worthwhile to finish Millstone if oil averaged $96 a barrel over the reactor's lifetime. The Energy Information Administration, part of the Energy Department, predicted that the price would be $100 by the turn of the century. But oil is now about a 10th of that.
Reactors are a bit like the Concordes, the supersonic transport planes that first flew a few days before the Three Mile Island accident, or the Apollo moon rockets, which made the last of their flights to the moon a few years before. They are technological artifacts of an era slipping into history.
Cloning the best practices from one utility to another, policing each other, getting more output from the reactors, the industry essentially adopted the Greenpeace motto: a nuclear accident anywhere is a nuclear accident everywhere. It vowed to have no more meltdowns. Not counting the 1986 catastrophe at Chernobyl, where the nuclear reactors are of a different design, the industry has so far succeeded.
BUT not everyone agrees that the industry's performance is greatly improved. James P. Riccio, a nuclear expert at Critical Mass, a Washington-based nonprofit organization affiliated with Ralph Nader, said that the plants operated more now because the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had shortened the list of equipment that had to be in perfect working order for them to run, and the number of automatic shut-downs has declined because the number of manual shut-downs is up. "They've gotten more intelligent about what they're doing," he said, "but then again, they've had to."
There have been other changes in the last 20 years. If two decades ago nuclear power seemed forbidding and secret, today anyone can log on to Nuclear Regulatory Commission Web site, which offers detailed specifications for each reactor (http:// www.nrc.gov/AEOD/pib/pib.html). For Three Mile Island unit 1, the undamaged twin of the reactor that had the meltdown, the data includes the identification numbers stamped on the water pumps. Another table for Three Mile Island shows the temperatures and pressures at which the emergency systems will automatically start, with different numbers depending on how many coolant pumps are running.
But elsewhere technology is accelerating, too. Natural gas has become cheaper to find and recover, and the system for turning it into electricity has improved steadily. The newest plants produce twice as many kilowatt-hours from a thousand cubic feet as the ones that nuclear power was competing with in 1979.
The real reactor killer, according to Professor Corradini and others, is something that was not thought of in 1979 -- deregulation in the the utility industry. Nationwide, power companies are fissioning into companies that will distribute electricity and sell it to consumers (like local phone companies) and other companies that will generate power and compete to sell it (like long distance carriers).
THE companies that built the 104 reactors still operating ordered them in the 1960's and early 1970's. Asked then which source of power would be the cheapest in the next few decades, they had guessed nuclear, knowing that if they were off by a few tenths of a cent per kilowatt-hour, the consumer would pay or reap the difference. Now, if they are asked the question at all, they say natural gas. Today they are building nothing and buying power from independent producers, none of whom seems inclined to place a multi-billion-dollar bet on a reactor where the output might be uncompetitive in 2010, or 2020 or 2030, for that matter.
"The investment risk changed," said James K. Joosten, a nuclear engineer and consultant and former official of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of industrialized nations. "In old days, people used to talk about nuclear power in religious terms, and say, 'It's good and we need to do it and if the public doesn't buy into it, we'll make them buy into it.' Realistically, today it's a business decision."
By Mr. Joosten's estimate, if electricity is completely deregulated, the market price will be about 2 cents per kilowatt-hour at the wholesale level, a price that about 28 nuclear plants cannot achieve. And if some states offer a one-time payment to their utilities because they have to close such plants in the transition to deregulation, then some reactor owners with marginal plants will jump at that offer while they can get it.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 14, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the robust condition of the failing nuclear power industry misstated the relationship between two technological achievements that never became commercial successes: the Three Mile Island nuclear plant and Concorde supersonic jets. The planes first flew in 1969 and began passenger service to the United States in 1976; their introduction did not come a few days before the Three Mile Island meltdown, which was in 1979.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: A Rise in Allergies to Latex Threatens Medical Workers

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The first signs that Dr. Barbara Zucker-Pinchoff's life was about to come apart were small and seemingly innocuous.
As she lay on an operating table at New York University Medical Center in 1988, preparing for the birth of her second child by Caesarean section, her nose began to itch. She felt terribly congested, her hands started to swell and her face turned beet red. She told her husband she thought she was allergic to the hospital's air-conditioning system. 
 But then her blood pressure started to dive and she was headed toward anaphylactic shock, a dangerous condition caused by an extreme allergic reaction. As doctors rushed to take the baby from her womb, others pumped her with epinephrine to raise her blood pressure.
But it was not the air-conditioner that caused her nearly to die. Nor was it, as she had suspected, the drug she received for pain relief.
It was, she was shocked to discover later, an allergic reaction to the latex gloves that covered the two sets of hands that dipped inside her during surgery. That allergy was so severe, it ended her career as an anesthesiologist because she was unable to wear the gloves or to be near others wearing them.
More than 10 percent of the country's health care workers are allergic to latex, an allergy that was almost unheard of a decade ago.
About a half-dozen state legislatures, including New York's, have introduced legislation to limit the use of latex gloves in hospitals and other medical offices or to develop committees within their health departments to study the issue. No important proposal has become law, however, often because of lobbying by glove makers.
Critics complain that the Federal Food and Drug Administration has been slow to act on the problem and has taken too long even to consider regulating latex use in hospitals.
Glove manufacturers say they are reluctant to turn out alternatives because doctors complain that nonlatex gloves are less comfortable and provide less protection. And hospitals balk at the cost of the alternatives, which are usually about 30 percent more expensive than latex. Further, many medical professionals hesitate to admit that they could have the allergy, for fear of ruining their careers.
"It is extremely serious," said Anne Schott, a spokeswoman for the New York State Nurses Association. "Latex is everywhere in the hospital environment, and if someone develops a serious allergy, that is a huge impediment to a normal life."
Experts said as many as 17 percent of those in health care who work almost exclusively in hospitals and with patients' fluids, like nurses in emergency and operating rooms, could be allergic to latex, since allergies to latex worsen with exposure to the material.
The illness affects roughly 3 percent of the general population, and since the late 1980's, at least 30 people have died of latex-related illnesses, experts on the allergy say. The number is small compared with, for example, allergic reactions to penicillin, which cause 400 to 800 deaths a year.
The sharp rise in reported allergies, experts said, stems from a sevenfold increase in the use of the gloves since 1987, when the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began recommending that most health care workers wear them to protect against infection from H.I.V.
Natural rubber latex, derived from the sap of the rubber tree, contains proteins that can cause allergies. The powder that manufacturers sprinkle inside the gloves to help them slip easily onto hands absorbs those proteins, and when the gloves are snapped on or off, the powder is released in the air. Allergic reactions to the gloves, from direct contact or inhalation of the powder, range from hives to asthma to anaphylactic shock and even death.
There is no known cure for latex allergies, but treatments for the symptoms range from over-the-counter antihistamines, for the mildest symptoms, to steroids, to epinephrine for shock. (Doctors caution that not all hand rashes from gloves indicate a true latex allergy.)
The allergy is unpredictable, and it can be devastating. In some people, allergies build up slowly through the years, starting with hand rashes that turn into a serious respiratory disease. Others, like Dr. Zucker-Pinchoff, have no symptoms until they find themselves in near-fatal shock.
After a person becomes sensitized, routine chores can become threatening, the elastic in a pair of stockings toxic, a trip to the dentist impossible. Someone with the allergy cannot use latex condoms, which are generally believed to offer the best protection against H.I.V. infection.
"Children's birthday parties are a menace," Dr. Zucker-Pinchoff said, since latex balloons can send her into a fit of wheezing and choking.
Most troublesome is that those who are allergic to latex are often made much sicker when they seek treatment because doctors' offices and hospitals, where the air is thick with latex powder, are the most dangerous places.
This was true for Lieut. Harold Henderson, a military nurse in San Diego who went into shock and died in 1997 during a hospital stay for an allergic reaction to latex.
"He had three heart attacks while I was there to pick him up," said his wife, Christine Henderson, adding that although the staff knew he was allergic and tried to keep his room free of latex, powder in a doctor's hair or something else probably caused the fatal reaction.
"It was always in the back of my mind that he could die, but you don't think that it is actually going to happen," she said. "You think it is going to get better if you stay away from it enough."
The market for latex gloves increased sharply when the C.D.C. announced its universal AIDS precaution, with dozens of new manufacturers eager to tap this market. Many critics contend that the gloves were made more cheaply, as a way of competing on costs, and that the cheaper gloves, because they contained more protein, made the problem worse.
What makes the illness especially hard to manage, doctors said, is the difficulty in diagnosing it, because the blood test most commonly used is fairly inaccurate. "One of the biggest dilemmas is actually making the diagnosis," said Dr. Kenneth T. Kim, the chairman of occupational health at the American College of Allergy Asthma and Immunology. "Not many people have access to the well-tested skin prick test, which is in trial already and awaiting F.D.A. approval."
Many who suffer from the allergy complain that the test has yet to be approved, but their complaints about the F.D.A. do not stop there. Although the Federal agency held a conference on the latex problem in 1992, it has not created any of the promised regulations, other than the requirement that medical devices containing latex be identified as a possible allergen. The agency is considering requiring manufacturers to indicate on the label the amount of protein and powder in their gloves.
Officials at the agency say that drafting regulations for latex is difficult because there is no universal agreement about how much powder is dangerous to those who have yet to be sensitized to the allergy, about how effective latex-alternative gloves are, and about how much their higher costs could hurt hospitals.
"A regulation has to be well-grounded in science," said Dr. Bruce Burlington, the director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Devices and Radiological Health. "It is intended to be a thoughtful, contemplative process that involves detailed analysis of economic impact and a number of other factors. This is running along at about average speed, given the scientific complexity."
Glove manufacturers, which have found themselves the subjects of lawsuits, have tried to block legislation banning latex gloves. At the same time, they are creating alternative products.
Representatives from Johnson & Johnson, for example, have written to state legislators to oppose bills that would ban powdered latex in hospitals. Meanwhile, the company has been producing low-powder gloves and options to latex.
"We have been putting forward the alternatives," said John McKeegan, a company spokesman. "But there is a demand out there for powdered gloves, and they are the ones that sell the best."
Regent Medical has been very aggressive in marketing its powder-free gloves, including surgical gloves called Biogel, which have a powder substitute that helps the glove slip on. Yet powder-free gloves make up only 5 percent of the company's glove business, a spokeswoman said.
A handful of hospitals across the country -- including Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn., and Olean Hospital in Olean, N.Y. -- have either banned latex gloves or restricted them to certain parts of their buildings. But in general, doctors, particularly surgeons, resist nonlatex alternatives.
"I have been working with the surgeons to buy into this process," said Deborah Blazys, an emergency room nurse at St. Mary's in Connecticut and a chairwoman of the hospital's latex task force. "A lot of times it is just habit, so we bring them in on choosing the products."
Sometimes, even medical workers with the allergy resist change. "They think, 'I desperately need this high-paying job in this prestigious teaching hospital, I need the medical insurance and I cannot afford to acknowledge a latex allergy,' " said Gail Lenehan, chairwoman of the Massachusetts Emergency Nurses Association's Latex Allergy Task Force. "I have heard female surgeons say they live in a man's world and fear a bias against them, and residents say they won't speak up because they are low on the totem pole."
Still, some hospitals are starting to change. "We wanted to be a leader in this area," said Robert G. Hamilton, an associate professor of medicine and pathology at Johns Hopkins, which is becoming latex free. "Cost is the fundamental question. But we purchased a sufficient volume of stretch vinyl, which resulted in no change in cost."
An increasing number of lawsuits are charging manufacturers with negligence and product liability, or with continuing to market a product that they know to be harmful.
Howell Rosenberg, a partner with Brookman, Rosenberg, Brown & Sandler, a law firm in Philadelphia, estimated that about 250 cases against glove manufacturers have gone to Federal courts around the country, up from about 25 cases two and a half years ago. His office is handling a suit on behalf of all the Federal cases, roughly 12 percent of which are from New York. Dozens more are being tried in state courts.
"I think it is going to be closely watched," Mr. Rosenberg said. "We are talking about lots of people, and the greatest number of victims are in health care. That is a very significant segment of the work force who are doing very important jobs."

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 7 about allergic reactions to latex gloves among medical workers described gloves manufactured by Regent Medical incorrectly. None of the company's gloves are sprinkled with a powder to make them easier to put on (the powder can cause an allergic reaction). The five percent figure used in the article referred to the percentage of the company's gloves that are non-latex, not the percentage that are powder-free.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Las Vegas

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY; BRETT PULLEY is a national correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
For the many people planning to visit Las Vegas since hearing that it had become family oriented, with plenty of affordable fun for the young and old, time may be running out. The place seems to be in a perpetual state of transformation, and the casino companies that built the amusement parks and Disneylike attractions in the early 1990's have now set their sights on more upscale tourists, building luxury hotels and casinos with couture shops and restaurants operated by world-renowned chefs.
Redefining itself is what keeps Las Vegas fresh and keeps people returning -- especially with casino gambling available all around the country. From its gangster beginnings, to its martini-drenched Rat Pack age, its Elvis era, its Sin City days and its most recent family-friendly years, this other city that never sleeps also never stays the same. All along Las Vegas Boulevard, better known as the Strip, there is so much construction machinery reaching into the sky these days that locals now joke that the official state bird is the crane. 
 The cheap buffets and modestly priced rooms are still here -- as is the Liberace Museum -- but the new Bellagio hotel and casino, which tries to combine high cost and high culture, may change all of that.
With an estimated $300 million in paintings and sculptures on display at Bellagio, suddenly everyone's an art expert: The guy parking cars outside raves about the Monets, Picassos and Renoirs inside, while a cocktail waitress discusses Dale Chihuly, the artist who created the lobby's gigantic glass sculpture chandelier, near which champagne and caviar are served daily ($68 for 30 grams of beluga).
Other opulent casino hotels, including the Venetian and the Paris, are scheduled to open in the next several months. But for now, the budget conscious need not be dismayed. The ailing Asian economy, which has kept many of the high rollers away, and the abundance of hotel rooms have kept room rates reasonable. But once the big-spending foreign gamblers return, prices are sure to rise.
 
Events
 The city's newest luxury resort, Mandalay Bay, was to open on Tuesday -- topped off by a separate hotel, the Four Seasons, on its 35th through 39th floors, with a separate entrance and elevators. The show at the main theater of the tropical-theme Mandalay Bay hotel and casino, at 3950 Las Vegas Boulevard South, will be the Broadway musical "Chicago." Tickets are $55 to $75, with eight shows a week.
On April 10, Luciano Pavarotti will open the Mandalay Bay Events Center, a 12,000-seat concert, entertainment and sports complex next to the hotel, with a performance at 8 P.M. Tickets: $50 to $450. Information: (877) 632-7400.
"Treasures of Russia," 1,100 works of Czarist art from the State Museum Reserve of Peterhof, near St. Petersburg, continues through April 15 at the Rio Suite Casino and Hotel, 3700 West Flamingo Road, (800) 752-9746. Timed tickets (10 A.M. to 6:45 P.M. daily) cost $7 to $12 from the box office and Ticketmaster, (702) 474-4000.
For five days of country eating, country music and cowboy competition, the Laughlin Rodeo Days featuring the Laughlin River Stampede Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association Championship takes place 90 miles south of Las Vegas in Laughlin, Nev., April 7 to 11. More than 500 of the world's best rodeo contestants will compete on the banks of the Colorado River. Tickets for April 7 and 8 are $10 a day, for April 9 to 11 $15. Information: (800) 227-5245.
The golfer Hale Irwin will try to win his third straight title at the Las Vegas Senior Classic May 13 to 16. The Senior PGA Tour event will be contested at the Tournament Players Club at Summerlin and the Tournament Players Club at the Canyons. Daily tickets are $15 and $20, and a tournament pass is $50. Information: (702) 242-3000.
A variety of musicians and singers, illusionists, comedians, showgirls and acrobats perform at the casino theaters each evening. A listing of performances can be found at www.lasvegas24hours.com or by calling (702) 892-7575.
 
 
Sightseeing
 Bellagio, which opened in October at 3600 Las Vegas Boulevard South, is full of attractions. Outside it looks like an Italian village and has an eight-acre lake with more than 1,000 illuminated fountains. In the evening, the water jets up to 240 feet in the air, choreographed to popular music. The show is free and performed every half hour from 5 P.M. until midnight Sunday through Friday, and 2 P.M. to midnight on Saturday. Information: (702) 693-7111.
Inside the hotel is the Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art, with a small but blue chip selection of works by Monet, Renoir, Picasso, van Gogh, Pollock and de Kooning, among others (the works can be purchased, so the lineup can change without notice). The gallery is open daily 9 A.M. to 11:30 P.M. (children are allowed from 9 to 11 A.M. only) Admission is $12, and includes a recorded tour. Information: (888) 488-7111.
The wait to enter the gallery is made much more bearable by the fact that the line passes through a breathtaking conservatory and botanical garden, with a 50-foot-high glass ceiling and fragrances and flowers that will change seasonally. Lines are shortest later at night.
Starting April 14, another piece of Italy comes to the Strip. Afternoons and evenings at the Venetian, 3355 Las Vegas Boulevard South, the bell inside the 315-foot-high reproduction of the Campanile will ring on the hour and 500 white homing pigeons will be released from gondolas to fly over the arched bridges and piazzas of this Venice look-alike. A canal will wind through the shopping mall, whose centerpiece is a reproduction of Renaissance era St. Mark's Square, and for a yet-to-be-set fee visitors can ride with singing gondoliers. Along the streets, costumed characters like Napoleon, Casanova and Marco Polo will give live performances. The mall is scheduled to be open 10 A.M. to 11 A.M. Sunday to Thursday and till midnight Friday and Saturday; (702) 733-5000.
To get back to reality, head 55 miles northeast of the city to the 35,000-acre Valley of Fire State Park. Open from sunrise to sunset, the early-morning and late-afternoon sunlight here intensifies the red of the sandstone formations. From Las Vegas, take I-15 north to Highway 169. Admission is $5 a car. Information: (702) 397-2088.
From the observation deck of Hoover Dam, about 25 miles south of Las Vegas on Highway 93-95, you can peer 700 feet down to the Colorado River. Tours (35 minutes) are conducted from 8 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. daily; $8, $7 ages 62 and up, and $2 for children 6 to 16. Information: (702) 293-8367.
Sightseeing Tours Unlimited offers daily bus, airplane and helicopter tours of the Grand Canyon, which is 280 miles from Las Vegas. The all-day bus tour is $90 a person, the airplane tour $100 ($160 with the ground tour), and the helicopter tour is $255 ($305 with the ground tour). Information: (702) 471-7155.
 
Where to Stay
 Despite the recent trend toward higher-priced luxury hotels, there is still a large supply of first-rate accommodations for less than $100 a night. But prices rise and rooms are scarce on weekends or when major events are in town.
Unlike the city it's named after, New York-New York Hotel and Casino, 3790 Las Vegas Boulevard South, (800) 693-6763, fax (702) 740-6920, is medium priced. A 47-story version of the Empire State Building is at the heart of the "skyline," and the property includes such other scaled-down Gotham landmarks as a 300-foot-long Brooklyn Bridge and a 150-foot-tall Statue of Liberty. The 2,033 hotel rooms and suites have an Art Deco theme. Doubles: $50 to $300 on weekdays, $90 to $400 on weekends.
Budget: The Quality Inn, 377 East Flamingo Road, (800) 634-6617, fax (702) 369-6911, is less than a mile from the Strip and has its own casino. All 318 rooms have wet bars, refrigerators and coffee makers. Doubles start at $59.99 on weekdays, $99.99 on weekends.
Two blocks from the Strip and one from the Las Vegas Convention Center is the Best Western Mardi Gras Inn, 3500 Paradise Road, (702) 731-2020, fax (702) 731-4005. All 314 rooms have a separate sitting area and wet bar, and the hotel has a small casino. Doubles cost $49 to $109 during the week, and $69 to $109 on weekends.
Luxury: Still one of the most recognized names on the Strip is Caesars Palace, 3570 Las Vegas Boulevard South, (800) 634-6661, fax (702) 731-7172. This giant hotel and casino has plenty of Las Vegas nostalgia and nouveau extravagance. The newest tower, which opened a little over a year ago, brought the total of rooms and suites to 2,471. All of the rooms have marble baths. Doubles: $79 to $450.
Bellagio, 3600 Las Vegas Boulevard South, (702) 693-7111, fax (702) 693-8585, is luxurious in every detail, from its grand lobby to its Mediterranean-style pool area with six pools. The 3,005 deluxe rooms and suites, all with marble bathrooms, have sweeping views of the resort's eight-acre lake, the Las Vegas skyline and the mountains beyond the city. Standard doubles from $159 to $459, and suites from $375 to $1,400.
 
Where to Eat
 Long known for low-priced buffets, Las Vegas has become a city of high-priced haute cuisine. Celebrity chefs from around the country have opened restaurants in the new luxury casinos and shopping malls over the last few years. Among the most popular is Emeril's, at the MGM Grand, 3799 Las Vegas Boulevard South, (702) 891-7374. Emeril Lagasse serves up Creole cooking, specializing in fish, and a seafood bar. Lunch and dinner are served daily in the wide-open, somewhat noisy dining room. A three-course dinner for two with wine will cost about $125.
Prime, a 1930's-style chophouse operated by Jean-Georges Vongerichten, one of New York City's hottest chefs, is one of many pricey restaurants inside Bellagio, 3600 Las Vegas Boulevard South, (702) 693-7111. The steaks, seafood and chops are top quality, with prices to match, and the garden patio view of the casino's lake and fountain show add to the experience. Dinner only; a three-course meal for two with wine will cost about $250.
At least one big-name newcomer to this city's restaurant scene has struck out on its own, unattached to any new casino projects. Smith & Wollensky, the famous New York steakhouse, has opened a branch at 3767 Las Vegas Boulevard South, across from the Monte Carlo, that copies the look of the original, inside and out; (702) 862-4100. Lunch and dinner are served daily, with a three-course meal for two with an inexpensive wine costing about $150.
For a more affordable lunch or a late dinner, try the Noodle Kitchen at the Mirage, 3400 Las Vegas Boulevard South, (702) 791-7111. The service is fast and the menu includes Chinese noodles, barbecued meats and poultry, and rice porridge. A meal for two, with drinks, will cost about $30.
The casino hotels have a variety of restaurants, including some with huge buffets at low prices. The Stratosphere Hotel and Casino, 2000 Las Vegas Boulevard South, serves a prime rib buffet dinner for $8.99 Monday through Thursday and on Saturday, and a seafood buffet dinner for $11.25 on Sunday and Friday. Information: (702) 380-7777.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Bridgemarket Emerging, After 22 Years

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
SLOW down, you move too fast," Simon and Garfunkel counseled in their "59th Street Bridge Song" of 1966. That may have been the last time anyone thought anything was moving fast around the Queensboro Bridge. Until now.
An almost legendarily stalled project to reclaim the nave-like vaulted hall under the bridge's Manhattan approach is well under construction. The $24 million, 98,000-square-foot Bridgemarket complex is to open later this year, barring further complications. There is to be a market-style Food Emporium, two restaurants operated by Sir Terence Conran, a high-end Conran home-furnishings store reached through a swoop-roofed pavilion on 59th Street and a landscaped plaza with a fountain. 
 "The whole thing fits neatly together, it's 100 percent leased and we're moving forward very rapidly with construction," said Sheldon M. Gordon, the managing partner of Bridgemarket Associates, which is developing the space on a lease from the city that runs to 2036. The architects are Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates.
"The 59th Street Bridge is a seam between two neighborhoods," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which is leasing the space. "This project diminishes the sense of its being a hulking barrier to the neighborhood to the north."
Indeed, the prospect of Bridgemarket has rekindled developers' interest in the block between First and York Avenues, 60th and 61st Streets, where the Glick Organization planned a huge project in the 1980's.
The Milstein Organization is planning its first new development in a decade: a $100 million, 37-story, 430,000-square-foot tower with 170 to 200 apartments, designed largely for families with children. Demolition has begun on the L-shaped site along First Avenue.
On the York Avenue end, the developer Sheldon Solow is planning a project that would be mainly residential, perhaps with retail space and parking. To avoid a single skyscraper so tall that it would ignite the community's wrath -- as Donald J. Trump has done a half mile south with his 72-story Trump World Tower project -- Mr. Solow might construct two buildings in the 40-story range.
One big question concerns the Alexander's site between Lexington and Third Avenues, 58th and 59th Streets. The department store is falling to the wreckers. But the Vornado Realty Trust, which effectively controls the full-block parcel, is mum on its intentions.
There is an even larger question. Does the current wave of prospective development augur economic and esthetic rehabilitation? Or does it threaten to draw so many more people and vehicles that it will choke an already congested gateway and cast a shadow over genteel enclaves nearby?
It is not so much any one project as the cumulative effect that concerns Community Board 8 on the Upper East Side. "With Milstein here and Solow there, you have 600 new families in a single block," said M. Barry Schneider, its chairman. "Do you have the resources -- the playgrounds, parks, schools, transportation, sanitation, neighborhood convenience stores? All of a sudden we have a large community within our community."
Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, believes new buildings can be accommodated. "It's an area that is clearly ready to be redeveloped," he said. "The key issue is to make sure that whatever additional development is allowed works in a way that doesn't aggravate the traffic flow in that area. What uses and what densities are allowed is a sensitive issue in terms of its impact on traffic."
More than sensitive, it is critical, said Councilman A. Gifford Miller, who represents the district. "The entire East Side was zoned with the understanding that the Second Avenue subway was going to get built," he said. "Each new building adds a greater burden to a transportation system that's bursting at the gills."
Although the Alexander's site is not in the immediate shadow of the bridge, it is bound to have an impact. The property is owned by a real estate investment trust called Alexander's Inc., 29 percent of which is owned by Vornado and 27 percent by a partnership controlled by Steven Roth, the chairman and chief executive of Vornado.
In a 1998 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Alexander's REIT anticipated a "large multi-use building requiring capital in excess of $300 million." But Buildings Department records show no application has been received yet for new construction permits.
"There have been no definitive plans announced at this time," is all that a spokeswoman for Vornado would say.
Under the C5-2 zoning designation on the site, the block could accommodate a structure with a floor area up to 12 times the lot size. That would be 1 million square feet, about eight percent larger than Bloomingdale's across 59th Street.
Retail, commercial and residential use would be permitted under the zoning, but not movie theaters. The subway entrance at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue would have to be incorporated into the building.
Word in the neighborhood has it that a Nordstrom department store might be part of the development. A spokeswoman for Nordstrom in Seattle said that while the company would "very much like to be in Manhattan some day," it did not discuss potential sites, as a matter of policy. And the Vornado spokeswoman said she would not reply to rumors and speculation.
For the moment, the action is to the east. Mr. Rose said one important step toward redevelopment around the Queensboro Bridge involved the disentanglement of a restrictive declaration under which the Glick Organization won a rezoning in 1989 against considerable local opposition.
Taking almost the entire block, the Glick project was to have had two 42-story apartment towers, a hotel, shopping gallery, garage, health spa and offices. The architect was Costas Kondylis.
The restrictive declaration obliged the developer to provide public amenities nearby, including the rehabilitation of a small park across 60th Street under the bridge approach. But before Glick could proceed, the collapse of the real estate market achieved what the neighbors could not -- stopping the project cold.
In 1996, Paul Milstein stepped in to acquire the west end of the Glick assemblage. He and his brother, Seymour, completed their last apartment building at Battery Park City in 1990 and have since concentrated on the reconstruction of the New York Presbyterian Hospital at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center campus in Washington Heights, to which their family has given more than $35 million.
Before the Milsteins could proceed, they negotiated a reduction in their obligation under the restrictive declaration, to reflect the fact that they are only building on part of the Glick parcel. They will establish a $700,000 fund, the interest from which is supposed to provide a permanent maintenance fund for the nearby park.
Mr. Kondylis is the architect again. He said the cruciform building would draw inspiration from prewar apartments in design and layouts. "It's going to create an audience for Bridgemarket," Mr. Kondylis said, "and it's going to be an amenity for those in the building to be able to cross the street and be in that market."
Mr. Solow, who is returning to residential development after a 10-year hiatus, must renegotiate the restrictive declaration, since two-thirds of his property was once part of the Glick assemblage. He will also require rezoning for the York Avenue end of his parcel, on which residential development is not currently permitted. Both actions require full land-use review, involving the community board, Manhattan borough president, City Planning Commission and City Council. The site might accommodate a project around 500,000 square feet.
"It is going to be a very high quality residential building consistent with others he has built," said Samuel H. Lindenbaum of Rosenman & Colin, who is Mr. Solow's lawyer. The architects are to be Davis Brody Bond, who designed Mr. Solow's One East River Place, at the east end of 72d Street, completed in 1989.
EQUALLY noteworthy, though far more modest, is the 14-story, 53,000-square-foot building under construction at 315 East 61st Street. The developer is RFR Davis but the target audience is not their typical affluent clientele.
Instead, the developers will turn the building over to the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty, a nonprofit and nonsectarian organization, which will operate it as a 53-unit home for lower-income elderly residents, chosen by lottery. The apartments may rent for as little as $450 to $500 a month. Meltzer/Mandl Architects designed the building, which is to be completed late this year.
In return for constructing this project under the "inclusionary housing" program, RFR Davis will receive a bonus of 200,000 square feet -- roughly 200 apartments -- applicable to the 11 luxury towers it is developing within the boundaries of Community Board 8, which covers the East Side from 59th to 96th Streets. Trevor Davis, a partner in the company, said the bonus would be apportioned among the projects.
"Inclusionary housing is not used that frequently," said Peter Brest, chief operating officer of the Met Council. "We're delighted it's being used in this case. Although 53 units may seem like a drop in the bucket, any additional housing for the elderly is very important."
Many New Yorkers have grown old waiting for something to happen in one of the greatest little-known public spaces in Manhattan: a 120- by 275-foot hypostyle hall under the Queensboro Bridge, from whose terra-cotta-clad columns spring 36 domed vaults over 30- by 30-foot bays, varying in elevation from 24 to 44 feet.
Majestic enough to be likened to a cathedral, as the Landmarks Preservation Commission noted in its 1974 designation of the bridge, the space was designed by Henry Hornbostel with ceiling tiles laid at perpendicular angles to form self-supporting vaults. The method was developed by the Guastavino Fireproof Construction Company, founded in 1889 by Rafael Guastavino y Esposito. Other famous Guastavino vaults are in Grand Central Terminal (they dominate the Oyster Bar) and the old Immigration Station on Ellis Island.
The straw color of the tiles and the basket-weave pattern conjure a marketplace. And as it happens, that was an early function of the hall. It was unenclosed when it opened in 1914 but walls were later added.
Another improvement came in 1919 from Evangeline Wilbour Blashfield, who had been a moving force in the creation of the Municipal Art Society. She noticed on a visit to the market that the vendors' water supply came from just one spigot. Her response was to donate a 17 1/2-foot-tall granite fountain, designed by Charles W. Stoughton, with a carved bull's head for a spout. Above the carving is a richly colorful mosaic depicting Abundance reclining on her cornucopia.
The vendors were nonplussed, wrote Gregory F. Gilmartin in "Shaping the City: New York and the Municipal Art Society" (Clarkson Potter, 1995). Blashfield explained, "Why, painters have no pigment for making pictures that can compare with your lemons and oranges and bananas and grapes, your tomatoes, even your onions."
The market closed by the 1930's and the space ultimately came into the hands of the Highways Department, which used it as a garage, sign shop and storeroom.
It was forgotten until 1973, when plans were unveiled for a Cinematheque designed by I. M. Pei, including a semicircular stainless-steel pavilion on the plaza.
After that fizzled, the developer Harley Baldwin burst on the scene in 1977 with "Bridgemarket," by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer. It was to have a farmers' market, gourmet shops and restaurants, with a three-sided mezzanine inside the vaulted hall and two new structures outside.
"Another so-called farmers' market is quite unnecessary," Suzanne LaCroix, president of the Sutton Area Community group, declared at the time. "As a matter of fact, the proposed Bridgemarket would only exacerbate the devastating vehicular congestion around the bridge."
Opponents managed to derail the plan in the State Assembly. Mr. Baldwin bounced back in 1981 with a revised project, having enlisted Mr. Gordon -- a developer, owner and operator of West Coast shopping centers -- as his partner in Bridgemarket.
In 1983, the Board of Estimate approved a lease for 46,000 square feet but the Koch administration later amended the lease, without seeking board approval, to allow a project of up to 130,000 square feet.
Construction had begun on the project in 1985 when Sutton Area Community sued Bridgemarket and the city. It won two rulings but the Court of Appeals found in 1994 that no additional approval had been needed and that the lease was valid.
"In the meantime, we lost our financing and lost all of our tenants," said Mr. Gordon, who had stepped into the role of managing partner, with Mr. Baldwin becoming a limited partner, which he remains. Rather than seek many small tenants, Mr. Gordon decided in the next go-around to concentrate on a few larger ones.
Enter Sir Terence.
His company, Conran Holdings, was looking to bring its Conran Shop and Conran Collection to New York and also expand its burgeoning restaurant business, which includes Quaglino's, Bluebird and Le Pont de la Tour in London. Conran was introduced to Bridgemarket by Richard Seligman, who was then a broker at Insignia/ESG.
"We fell in love with the site, like many before us," said Joel Kissin, who helped start the restaurant business and is now president of Bridgemarket Restaurant Inc.
Not yet named, the Conran restaurants will occupy 26,000 square feet. The main floor dining room will feature a mid- to upper-priced menu of roasts, grills and shellfish. It will seat 300 people inside and 60 people outside, with private dining rooms for 20 and 40. On a mezzanine will be a more luxurious and higher-priced restaurant for 100, with a private dining room for 40. There will be two bars and a two-story display kitchen. The restaurants and shop are being designed by C.D. Partnership.
The 35,000-square-foot housewares store will occupy a new basement space under a floor slab that has been built in the market hall, slightly higher than the original floor. (The tallest vault is now 34 feet high.) Pamela Loeffelman, a senior associate at Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer, said the additions are independent of the bridge structure. The new exterior windows, she said, would match the originals in profile and scale.
The shop will not be a revival of the fresh-out-of-college-and-still-on-a-budget Conran's that New Yorkers remember at the Citicorp Center. Instead, Mr. Kissin said, it will be a higher quality and higher priced store selling furniture; bathroom, kitchen and table ware and cosmetics.
The shop will be reached through a 3,800-square-foot glass-walled pavilion on 59th Street with a curving roof. "The bridge goes in one direction and this goes in a kind of counterpoint," Mr. Kissin said. "We wanted it very much to be see-through."
East of the pavilion is to be a plaza on which the Blashfield fountain will be relocated. The designer is Lynden B. Miller, whose projects have included the renovation of Bryant Park and the construction of Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park at Battery Park City. The construction manager for the overall project is the F. J. Sciame Construction Company. The bridge rehabilitation is by the city's Transportation Department.
Twenty-four of the bays in the main hall will be occupied by Food Emporium, whose overall space is 35,000 square feet.
But it will not look anything like a standard supermarket. "We want to reinvent Food Emporium for this space," said Roger T. Turley, vice president of development for the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, of which Food Emporium is a subsidiary. "We plan to create a special ambiance capitalizing on the volume and the beauty of the space."
THAT is not so easy under landmarked Guastavino vaults. "We're not permitted to hang things from the open vault space," Mr. Turley said. "Lighting, heating, ventilation, air-conditioning -- the things you take for granted in a normal, traditional space -- became a major challenge." As an example, rather than using forced-air heating, which requires ductwork, the space will be heated by pipes within the floor slab.
Mr. Turley said each department would be distinctive, "almost like a collection of various markets." There will be 275 kinds of cheese, he said; 300 kinds of fish and seafood and 700 produce items; a bakery; a demonstration kitchen, and a flower stand. The store is being designed by Sam Burman of Food Emporium and Roland Gebhardt.
Separated by a glass wall, the tenants profess an "excellent relationship and rapport" (Mr. Turley) that have yielded a "good cooperative effort" (Mr. Kissin). Yet last year at this time, Conran was suing Bridgemarket, since A. & P. was not Sir Terence's idea of an appropriately upscale neighbor. The suit has since been settled and Mr. Gordon is clearly eager to move beyond Bridgemarket's troubled past, although he concedes, "This is not what I'd call the best real estate deal I've ever done."
After 22 years on the job, the architect Hugh Hardy sees a silver lining. "I really do think that the final result is the best of all possibilities -- including all of our other schemes -- having it as simple as it is, with three basic activities," he said.
Jennifer J. Raab, the chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, believes the resolution allows "a very ambitious retail project to go forward in a way that enhances the landmark."
After all, she noted, shoppers and diners will constitute a new audience for the long-lost architectural treasure. "How many people get to see the Guastavino vaults now?" Ms. Raab asked. "Certainly not enough. That's a preservation purpose: bringing people into this marvelous historic space. There's a great preservation investment going on. But it wasn't going to happen without commercial investment as well."
The city will receive a rent of about $400,000 a year and a share of revenues.
At the end of a two-decade struggle, Richard J. Eyen, a leading opponent in the neighborhood, is keenly disappointed.
"The two main things we wanted were: nothing on the plaza and nothing to obscure those gorgeous arches," he said. "We ended up not only with a big structure on the plaza and a mezzanine inside but a vertical separation" -- between market and restaurants.
Councilman Miller, who was only 8 years old when Bridgemarket was first proposed, has not taken a formal stand on the project because his mother, Lynden, is designing the landscaping.
"I did take the position," he said, "that I was sure her gardens would be beautiful."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
After ClimbingSo Many Mountains, a Ski Resort Giant Stumbles

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
IT was a bold strategy: Buy like mad, build like mad, pay for it with an initial stock offering and a lot of borrowed money, and pray that the snow -- and the customers -- would keep coming.
For almost five years it was an exhilarating ride, as the American Skiing Company grew from a single Maine resort in 1994 to nine in New England and the Rockies. Hotels bought, condos built, new snow machines and gondolas installed: The company was pumping millions into its strategy of rapidly building itself into a giant in winter recreation. 
 Then the juggernaut crashed into the season that wouldn't start. Unusually warm weather in the East combined with a dry spell in the West in the first few months of the 1998-99 season to keep trails bare and cash registers empty. And the cracks that soon appeared in American Skiing's financial results call into question the wisdom of barreling ahead so fast in an industry that depends so profoundly on Mother Nature's fickle graces.
The snows last week in New England came too late to rescue the company's second quarter, which ended Jan. 24. On Monday, American Skiing announced a net loss of $10.8 million, even worse than it had forecast in January, on revenue of $109.5 million. Resort revenue fell $3.7 million from the corresponding period the previous year, while real estate revenue declined $1.6 million. And during what was supposed to be the company's most active quarter, 30 employees, mostly in middle management, were laid off at three of the resorts.
"No one can say that they are happy about having the kind of weather that we've had," said Leslie B. Otten, the company's founder, chairman and chief executive. "Long term, I don't think this is going to have any detrimental effect to the company. In the short term, it is something that we understand and expect will happen from time to time."
With two prominent banks, Fleet and BankBoston, in the company's corner as lenders, analysts had high hopes for American Skiing when it went public at $18 a share in November 1997. But within a year, the stock had slid to $5 a share; it closed last week at $3.75
Daniel Noll, a ski industry analyst with the Chapman Company in Baltimore, called American Skiing the most highly leveraged in the winter recreation industry and the most aggressive in real estate development. When the company found that it had to defer some projects, "they disappointed the analysts on Wall Street, and that's just been a big penalty for them," Mr. Noll said.
THE question now is how much of the company's aggressive building schedule can be sustained, and how much must be scrapped to conserve cash and service the company's debt of more than $400 million.
American Skiing has already shelved its planned $30 million Grand Summit Resort Hotel at the Sugarbush resort in Vermont, because of poor advance sales, as well as a related land exchange agreement the company had painfully worked out with the United States Forest Service.
Last month, the company also backed off from a planned $300 million offering of secured notes. Instead, it placed $58 million in secured notes with high financing costs and will use the proceeds to complete projects at its two Western resorts, Steamboat in Colorado and The Canyons in Utah, in time for next season. The switch led Standard & Poor's to downgrade the company's corporate credit and debt ratings, saying it hurt the company's "financial flexibility."
Last week, the company sought to play down its bad earnings report by announcing that it had renegotiated the terms of its debt with its bank lenders. The deal will put about $20 million for capital improvements into American Skiing's coffers during the coming season. Though that is less than the $35 million the company originally planned to borrow, it "gives us more than enough flexibility for the coming year," said Mark Miller, the chief financial officer. "We don't want anyone to get the impression that the banks crimped us."
The new agreement will also allow Mr. Otten to keep pursuing his vision of ski resorts that go beyond winter sports to become luxury vacation destinations with all the trimmings. With much of the basic infrastructure in place at the company's resorts, he added, it is "not a bad thing to be taking a break from that expenditure pace."
Bullish analysts say the company's real estate ventures could have more staying power than its lift-ticket sales.
Ford Frick, an economist with BBC Consulting in Denver, said that aging baby boomers who no longer frequented the slopes were an attractive demographic group for second-home ownership, including resort condos. "The real estate industry has really grown to eclipse the skiing industry" in the West, he said, and he sees a similar trend, though not as advanced, in New England.
Kenneth Hammerle, an industry consultant in Littleton, N.H., said American Skiing should not have much trouble filling its properties. "Across North America, resort real estate is in fairly high demand, particularly in the Rocky Mountain region," Mr. Hammerle said.
Sales of time-share ownerships at American Skiing's hotels, which come with amenities like the use of ski lockers, lounges and libraries, have been brisk and highly profitable, Mr. Noll said.
Some analysts find encouragement in Mr. Otten's track record turning around resorts like his flagship property, Sunday River in Maine, and hope the company can do the same with Steamboat. The Colorado resort looked like a good bet after a 1.1-million-visit season in 1997. But skier visits have slid sharply this season, off 16 percent through January, and the resort's managing director resigned.
AMERICAN SKIING continues to put much of its energy into developing The Canyons, which it wants to transform into one of the largest ski resorts in North America in time for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. More than 1,300 acres of skiable terrain have been added; a hotel and condominiums, many of them already sold, are under construction. Mr. Frick, the economist at BBC Consulting, called it "a make it or break it project" for the company.
But beyond the fate of The Canyons, it remains unclear how America Skiing and the three other big, aggressive group owners -- Intrawest of Vancouver, British Columbia; Vail Resorts of Vail, Colo., and Booth Creek Ski Holdings of Truckee, Calif. -- can keep growing, given that the number of skiers has stayed fairly flat for more than a decade.
"What's clear is that those four companies are spending hundreds of millions of dollars to put in high-speed chair lifts and grooming, and they're all building a lot of housing," Mr. Noll said. "If they don't get some kind of growth, unless those four companies take all of the market, you're going to have some of them changing their life style."

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 3-7-99 -- Salient Facts;
Disposable Outcome

BYLINE: By C.J. Hughes

 BODY:
Despite all the environmental precautions, interstate trash fights -- like the one between Virginia and New York -- are back on the front page. Here's why.
 
Now that we're recycling, shouldn't there be less of the stuff to dump?
Nationwide, about a quarter of all trash -- and much more in some cities -- is recycled, but there are fewer and fewer places to put the nonrecyclables. In 1990, the Federal Government declared that garbage dumps had to install strict environmental safeguards, and fewer than half the country's dumps were left in business.
 
Fewer dumps -- that sounds like a good thing.
It would be, except that now trash has to be hauled a lot farther. National trash companies are busily seeking out ever cheaper places to put refuse. The typical American throws out a staggering three-quarters of a ton of trash a year, and to landfill that amount in New England or New York can cost two or three times as much as it would to dump it in the Midwest, South or, cheapest of all, out near the Rockies somewhere.
 
Is that what's making Virginia so reluctant to take New York's trash?
Not the cost of dumping so much as the potential hazards of hauling it around, which get a lot more likely the farther the trash has to go. Last month, after a traffic accident, several tons of genuine New York City refuse spilled all over a Virginia highway. Waste-industry executives insist these mishaps are rare, but even so, they leave a strong impression.
 
But aren't huge smelly landfills a bigger concern than occasional spills?
From an environmental perspective, perhaps -- but not from a political perspective. Newer dumps tend to be built in remote, economically depressed areas, far from most constituents' homes. The highways and waterways that trash haulers use to reach them, on the other hand, are well traveled. In the past year, interstate trash transit has become a hot-button issue in many states, including Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia.
 
All this uproar must be murder on the big trash companies.
Not really. People generate junk whether politicians are yelling at each other or not, and the big companies are aggressively expanding. While Mayor Giuliani and Virginia's Governor, James Gilmore, were making a stink, one Wall Street analyst reported that Waste Management Inc., the nation's biggest trash-disposal company, was raising its dumping fees by 40 percent. The company's own projections were more prudent. Regardless, competitors are expected to follow suit. C.J. Hughes
