HEADLINE: Fishing Nations, Worried About Supply, Will Trim Fleets

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
In a stark recognition that many commercial fishing stocks are being harvested to the verge of collapse, the world's seafaring nations have promised to make the first far-reaching cuts in their fishing fleets.
Despite limits on how many fish can be caught, trimming the fleets is now seen as the key to heading off economic and ecological calamity, industry experts say. 
 But they acknowledge that the new effort, a nonbinding agreement sponsored by the United Nations, could take many years before having much effect on overfishing.
Without a solution, the question for some of the world's waters will only be which would come first -- the bankruptcy of the fishing companies or the extinction of their quarry.
As things stand, government and private experts said, the industry is wasting tens of billions of dollars each year trying to catch ever-scarcer fish.
At a meeting in Rome in mid-February, delegates from virtually every fishing nation agreed on a plan to reduce fishing capacity, starting within six years. To meet targets, many governments will probably have to pay owners to scuttle vessels, or the governments will have to reduce immense subsidies.
"The bottom line is that some folks are going to have to find a new job," said David Schorr, a fisheries expert at the World Wildlife Fund, adding that politicians will face some tough choices about who is forced out of fishing, and where.
Even without knowing whether the voluntary effort will work, fishery officials call the plan one of the most significant to address the need to preserve fish stocks.
"Globally, the problem of overcapacity in the world's fleet is probably the single greatest threat to the world's fish resources," said Terry Garcia, chief American delegate to the negotiations.
"Within the next decade or so, if we do not take steps to address the problem of overcapacity, then the demand for wild fish stocks is going to exceed the supply."
Some experts say this has already occurred. After decades of growth, the catch has leveled off, suggesting that many fish are being caught faster than they can reproduce.
The new agreement calls for nations to cap their fleets at existing levels and then to scale them back progressively, and to eliminate subsidies to companies that are deemed to overfish.
Past efforts to control overfishing have focused on strictly regulating the quantity of fish that can be legally caught, the size of fish that may be kept, the length of the fishing season and the type of equipment and nets used.
But that approach, the nations agreed, is flawed, given the capacity of many fishing fleets to catch more fish than permitted. Increasingly, countries have recognized that they must find ways to cut the industry's capacity. In 1997 fishing vessels at sea were estimated to have caught 95 million tons, the international food agency says.
Despite strict controls on fishing in recent years, New England fishery managers concluded in December that the cod fishery in the Gulf of Maine is collapsing. The Clinton Administration has already proposed new spending to take some of the region's boats out of service, and last month the National Marine Fisheries Service proposed guidelines for buying back licenses and scrapping boats throughout American fisheries.
The new international measures recommended in February, at the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, will have no immediate impact. The first step is to get an accurate measure of how much fish the world's fleets really can catch.
Each nation that signs the agreement pledges to reduce overcapacity, starting between 2003 and 2005.
"This is the first significant international document on the management of fishing capacity," said Dominique Greboval, a fisheries planning manager with the Food and Agricultural Organization. "It might not look like much, but in terms of approach it is a significant departure."
The agency has estimated conservatively that the fishing industry's overcapacity is at least 30 percent. Gareth Porter, a fisheries expert for the World Wildlife Fund, has estimated overcapacity at almost 150 percent.
And the food agency found several years ago that worldwide, the fishing industry was spending $54 billion more than it was taking in every year.
The world's fishing fleet numbers about four million vessels -- about one-third of them large enough to have decks and motors, the agency says. About 40,000 are larger than 100 tons and longer than about 78 feet. And more than a thousand of those are owned in the United States. The new agreement, which was pushed by the United States and Japan, is one of a series of United Nations pacts since 1995 to address overfishing, and the most explicit on controlling overcapacity.
But the political barriers to following through are daunting.
"There is so much invested in the way things are that changing and downsizing the industry is an enormous task," said Anne Platt McGinn, of the Worldwatch Institute, an environmental research organization. "Probably the European Union is going to have the hardest time of all, because their fishermen are so over-subsidized."
As in the United States, government programs in Europe have encouraged the modernization and expansion of the fishing industry, but other programs have aimed at reducing the size of the fleet to control overfishing.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Little ChangeIn Treasuries After Rally Of Last Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices were little changed yesterday, after rising smartly on Friday, amid increased prospects that tame inflation will keep the Federal Reserve from increasing rates any time soon even as the economy expands.
The price of the 30-year benchmark Treasury issue rose 5/32 , to 955/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.59 percent from 5.60 percent. 
 Kim Rupert, an economist at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis company in San Francisco, said that after the employment data released last week, the sigh of relief in the Treasury market was audible.
Gone were rumblings of unsustainable growth and imminent rate increases by the Fed. Also gone was roughly half the increase in yield that the 30-year bond had made since Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, testified before Congress late last month.
"We expect the progress in Treasuries last Friday to be sustainable," Ms. Rupert said. "But data, Fed commentary and supply still pose a risk after this brief respite from the storm."
Market analysts said that the trading yesterday was within a narrow range, as Treasury prices edged up. A speech by Mr. Greenspan to the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington yesterday was for a time a source of concern, as is the case whenever he speaks, but he did not say anything that surprised the market.
Though the dampened fears of a rate increase have increased the appeal of longer maturities, many traders will probably reserve judgment on buying shorter maturities until after data on retail sales and the Producer Price Index are released later this week.
The market may be intimidated by the threat of strong retail sales, but if the script follows last week's lead-up to the employment report, this week's figures could become a rallying point if the data come in weaker than expected.
Elsewhere, the Government's weekly bill auction went well, with the best demand in a few weeks. The three-month bill was awarded at 4.510 percent, down from 4.570 percent last week, while the six-month bill came in at 4.540 percent, down from 4.585 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: NYC;
Moviegoers Vs. Theaters: Food Fight!

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THE tempest of the season for many here has nothing to do with upstate snows, school vouchers, police shootings or whither Hillary. No, the big storm is over the fact that it now costs $9.50 to see a movie at Loews, Cineplex Odeon and Sony Theaters in the city. That's four bits more than two weeks ago.
It may not sound like much money, especially for those desperate in these days before the Academy Awards to catch "Private Ryan in Love," "Life is Beautiful in Elizabeth, N.J.," or whatever the best-picture nominees are called. 
 Still, the way Loews Cineplex Entertainment sprang a 50-cent increase on New Yorkers struck many of them as an arrogance, considering that the 5.6 percent rise comes at a time of near-zero inflation. In the last five years, movie ticket prices in the city have gone up by 27 percent, more than twice as fast as the cost of living.
It brings to mind the assurances given by a Cineplex Odeon executive a year and a half ago when his company merged with Sony Corporation's Loews Theaters to form the new entertainment concern.
"I can guarantee you that ticket prices will not increase as a result of this merger," the executive, Howard Lichtman, said. Guess that can be put in the file with other classic not-to-worry lines like "the check is in the mail" and "I never had sexual relations with that woman."
Of course, a supply-and-demand purist would say that businesses are free to charge what they wish and the marketplace will let them know when they have overreached. That theory may not work quite so smoothly in a near-monopolistic situation, which we are approaching with Loews Cineplex Entertainment.
It controls almost half the movie screens in Manhattan alone, and would have had about 70 percent had the State Attorney General's office not stepped in last year, threatening antitrust lawsuits unless the company sold several movie houses. Even somewhat slimmed down, Loews Cineplex can feel fairly confident that an entertainment-hungry public will fuss and grumble -- and then fork over the extra 50 cents.
What to do about this "mugging of the middle class," as Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, put it?
Mr. Vallone took his unhappiness directly to Sony executives, according to his spokesman, Michael S. Clendenin. "He came away feeling that they're going to do whatever they want because they can," Mr. Clendenin said.
So for moviegoers looking to strike back, the Speaker has proposed a boycott of theaters on the first Friday of each month, a favorite time for Hollywood to unload its latest exegesis of raging teen-age hormones. Last Friday evening, he stood outside the grand Sony Lincoln Square Theater, urging people to walk on by.
There is no sign, though, that New Yorkers are about to march on the multiplexes with pitchforks. They do like their movies -- enough for a Loews Cineplex spokesman, Marc J. Pascucci, to wave off Mr. Vallone's boycott. "It had no effect on our grosses at all," Mr. Pascucci said yesterday.
MAYBE, some disgruntled New Yorkers say, the answer lies with a different kind of boycott.
Can't give up Gwyneth Paltrow? That's understandable. But how strongly do you feel about Milk Duds?
Concession stands account for much of a theater's profits. "Peter says that if you do go to the movies," the Vallone spokesman said, "don't buy food" -- a munchie boycott also urged in a letter to this newspaper the other day from a New Jersey reader, N. S. Hayden.
While this department is not charged with advocating a particular course of action, it may note that a "regular" order of popcorn costs $3.49 at Sony Lincoln Square and a "regular" soda $2.75. Skip them, and you're well on your way to recouping the price of a ticket (not to mention protecting your arteries).
If you absolutely must have a movie snack, Providence created delis and candy stores, along with handbags and coat pockets to carry the goodies in with you. Note, too, that signs over the Sony food counters say, "Free refills on all fountain drinks." They don't say that the refill has to be the same day. Do you see theater owners patting down hundreds of people looking for cup smugglers? Just a question.
The title of a film making the rounds could become the rallying cry for fed-up moviegoers: "Just the Ticket." It beats the title many feel better suits them now: "Affliction."

HEADLINE: Aerospace Gets Japan's Message;
Without Military Largess, Industry Takes the Lean Path

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: CHULA VISTA, Calif.

 BODY:
Two years ago, the B. F. Goodrich Company's aerospace division factory here fell so far behind schedule producing parts for the new Boeing 737-700 that the Boeing Company threatened to terminate the contract.
"We had rafts of Boeing people coming down here helping us get on schedule," recalled Martin Lodge, an executive here. 
 Today, Boeing people are still coming -- but to help put themselves back on schedule. This factory has significantly improved its efficiency using so-called lean production, the collection of techniques first perfected by the Toyota Motor Corporation. And Boeing, facing serious production problems of its own, has sent more than 300 people here to learn how it's done.
A decade after American auto makers and many other companies began adopting just-in-time delivery and other lean manufacturing techniques, the aerospace industry is embracing the concept to cut costs in the face of reduced military spending and, in commercial aircraft, stiff competition from Europe's Airbus Industrie.
Executives are now bandying about Japanese terms like kaizen (continuous improvement; pronounced KI-zen) and kanban (the just-in-time system; pronounced CON-bon). They often mispronounce them horribly, but are applying them well enough to achieve some startling efficiency gains in an industry long known as much for high costs and wasteful procedures as for cutting-edge technology.
At the Boeing factory in Long Beach, Calif., for instance, production of the C-17 military transport has been doubled in the last three years without raising the head count. That has helped save the Pentagon hundreds of millions of dollars, said Richard D. Harstad, the Air Force's chief of manufacturing and quality for the C-17. Boeing's C-17 operation, which initiated the improvement when it was part of McDonnell Douglas, recently won the Commerce Department's Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award.
Industry executives and analysts said aerospace manufacturers lagged behind in adopting lean techniques mostly because Pentagon contracts generally reimbursed them for their costs and they were insulated from foreign competition that hit other industries.
"The automobile industry had the advantage, if you can call it that, of an early threat," said Thomas J. Allen, a professor of management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is co-director of the Lean Aerospace Initiative, an M.I.T. program supported by the Air Force and many aerospace companies to spread lean manufacturing techniques across the industry. "The aerospace industry hasn't until now had that kind of a threat."
The term "lean" is vaguely defined and refers to many different techniques. But it generally focuses on manufacturing things in smaller batches to meet demand, rather than in large quantities. Parts are delivered just as they are needed and problems are corrected as they occur. The idea is to cut out operations, such as storing parts, that do not directly contribute to the value a company is providing.
Done right, lean manufacturing not only saves time and money directly, but also helps a company quickly identify flaws in its overall production process.
Many of the changes being made seem to be just plain common sense, such as preparing kits of necessary tools in advance.
The Northrop Grumman Corporation videotaped a mechanic whose job was to apply about 70 feet of tape to the B-2 bomber. The mechanic walked away from the plane 26 times and took three hours to gather the chemicals, hoses, gauges and other material she needed just to start. When the factory made kits with all the needed parts, the mechanic did not have to leave the plane at all and time for the job dropped to 1.62 hours from 8.4 hours.
Cutting the time needed to design and manufacture aerospace products could have great economic impact. It now takes so many years to design and build a fighter that the military threat can change in the meantime. Commercial aircraft take so long to build that Boeing has to order parts and materials years in advance. When it reduces its production rate, as happened recently, it and its suppliers are stuck with unneeded material.
How much lean production will save is still open to question. Despite some claimed successes in individual factories, it is difficult to separate any cost savings from those achieved simply because of big industry mergers and layoffs.
Certainly, lean production is no panacea. Boeing is suffering huge production glitches despite supposedly putting into effect some lean techniques for years. Skeptics say leanness could become just the latest in a series of short-lived cost-cutting initiatives by the Pentagon and its contractors.
James P. Womack, co-author of "The Machine That Changed the World" (Rawson Associates), the 1990 book that introduced the term and crystallized the Toyota production system for American managers, said that aerospace was the industry most in need of lean approaches. "It's the most sclerotic industry out there," he said.
But Mr. Womack, who now runs the Lean Enterprise Institute, a nonprofit organization, said most companies were merely "spray painting" lean techniques onto their existing procedures instead of making fundamental changes.
"Whole square miles of factories have to be blown up," he said. Pratt & Whitney, the engine maker owned by the United Technologies Corporation, revived itself with such a radical shift, but most executives are not ready for that, said Mr. Womack, who was dismissed as a consultant to Boeing for being, as he put it, "disruptive and obnoxious."
While Boeing would not discuss the reason for Mr. Womack's departure, it said it remained committed to lean manufacturing.
The Toyota system, designed for factories that make hundreds of thousands of cars a year, is not perfectly adaptable to an aerospace factory that might make only a dozen, highly complex objects annually. In aerospace, which generally does not use moving assembly lines, becoming lean means putting jobs that follow in sequence next to one another.
In many aerospace factories, parts move in big batches to various centralized production centers -- from metal pressing to heat treating to cleaning and so on. Parts can travel miles, either within a factory or around the country to different factories. It can take years from the time a part is started until it ends up in a functioning airplane.
But most parts are actually being worked on less than 5 percent of the time, according to a survey by researchers at M.I.T. The rest of the time they sit idle. That contributes to excess inventory, which takes up capital and is costly to manage.
Here at the Chula Vista factory, which makes parts for engine housings known as nacelles, work had been done in five separate buildings spread over a mile. A map of how a part once traveled through the production process looks like a plate of spaghetti. Sometimes parts were even packaged in paper and loaded onto dollies to be shipped from one building to the next, adding time and expense. The factory was cluttered with excess inventory.
"Three years ago I would have been embarrassed to bring a family member into this plant," said Harold Rhodes, a longtime worker who has moved to factory management.
Now, the company is rearranging production in cells. Instead of one big centralized degreasing center, for instance, there are now dishwasher-size degreasers placed where needed in the various cells.
Metal skins for the Boeing 717 fan cowls, a part of the nacelle, used to travel 17,000 feet and take 43 days to make. Now they travel 4,300 feet and are made in 7 days. Two years ago, the factory could not produce enough parts for even two Boeing 737-700's a month. It now produces enough for 23, with only 14 employees instead of 18.
Production is being consolidated in two buildings, so that the company will be able to give up half the land it is leasing and still have room to spare.
There are other changes as well. The manufacturing manager and many engineers have been moved from carpeted office buildings out onto the factory floor, making them more accessible to workers and closer to the job.
Layers of management have been flattened and the number of job classifications, as defined by the union contract, has been cut from 200 to 28. Workers no longer have to sit idle, unable to do a nearby job because they lacked the proper classification.
The Toyota production system almost seems as if it were a religion here, even though only one factory manager ever visited a Toyota plant in Japan. (The company learned from Toyota's American operations and from consultants.) The conference rooms above the factory floor are named after former Toyota officials.
Some workers greeted the introduction of lean production with suspicion, in part because the word suggested layoffs. Others saw it as just another passing phase. But most seem to appreciate it now.
Morgan Fugate, the shop steward, said the number of grievances filed through union procedure had fallen from several a day to only one or two a month because workers were happier and managers were more responsive.
"I can't believe my eyes when I go through here," said Mr. Fugate, a top representative of the International Association of Machinists and 25-year veteran of the plant.
Lean production can lead to job losses. While Chula Vista's work force has grown to 1,030 union workers from 700 four years ago, it is benefiting from cuts elsewhere. In December, Goodrich announced that it would close four factories in its aerostructures division, eliminating 775 jobs. Some of the work will move to Chula Vista, such as consolidating assembly of parts once shipped to Arkansas. This is already occurring here with fan cowls for the Boeing 717.
The division, which includes the Chula Vista factory, was an independent company called Rohr Inc. until its acquisition in 1997.
Other companies, however, are experiencing more worker resistance to lean manufacturing as well as resentment about the use of Japanese expressions.
When workers who make composite parts for the Air Force's F/A-18 attack fighter at Northrop's factory in El Segundo, Calif., were first organized into cells last October, they compared it to the cells in the Los Angeles County jail, said Joe Geer, a team leader in the section. But costs and time have been reduced 40 percent since October, he said, so workers are coming to like it.
Owing in part to lean production, operating profit margin for Goodrich's aerostructures division has risen to 15.6 percent in 1998 from 9.9 percent in 1995.
But Mr. Lodge, director of continuous improvement in Chula Vista, says that rearranging the factory furniture is the easy part. The big challenge is to apply lean thinking to the company's entire operations, including the engineers and office workers. One aim is to speed product design and design products that can be more easily maintained and manufactured.
"We're scratching the surface," said Mr. Lodge, who is already spouting new terms like hoshin kanri (policy management; pronounced HO-sheen KAHN-ree). "It's daunting, daunting, daunting. Daunting, with no alternative."

By making prepackaged kits for the job, the company cut preparation time to zero and reduced the total time for the job from 8.4 hours to about 1.6.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A trash hauler is buying a much bigger rival, a type of deal that makes Wall Street a bit nervous.

BYLINE: By David Barboza and Laura M. Holson 

 BODY:
WHEN Allied Waste Industries announced yesterday that it would acquire Browning-Ferris Industries, a much bigger rival in the trash hauling business, Allied's message was simple: We can better manage those huge assets.
With its $7.3 billion leveraged takeover of Browning-Ferris -- plus the assumption of $1.8 billion of Browning-Ferris debt -- Allied Waste will be the No. 2 player in the industry behind Waste Management Inc., and it is betting that its more integrated and focused approach to handling solid waste can create a fleet-footed giant that produces profit growth in the high double digits. 
 "The reality is, we're teaming our management with their assets," Thomas H. Van Weelden, the chief executive at Allied Waste, said in an interview yesterday. "The story here is not consolidation; the story here is focusing on growth."
Although shares of Allied, which was the No. 3 trash hauler, fell sharply on Friday on speculation about a possible stock deal, the share price recovered some of that ground yesterday climbing $1.9375, to $16.9375. Shares of Browning-Ferris, which traded just above $30 a month ago, soared for the second day, up $4.125, to $38.875.
With the deal, the trash hauling industry, once run by small, private operators, is further concentrating into a business dominated by a handful of national companies with huge fleets of trucks and enormous landfills. The big players, however, are under growing pressure to become leaner and more profitable.
So when the boards of Allied and Browning-Ferris voted on Sunday night to create a company with about $6.6 billion in revenue, just over half the $12 billion 1998 revenue of Waste Management, executives at Allied also decided that significant cost savings and layoffs would be necessary to generate profit growth in the high double digits. They project a 30 percent profit gain in the year 2000.
Wall Street analysts said the deal was good for shareholders of Browning-Ferris, which had recently begun to turn around a slumping business. But if Allied shareholders are to benefit, Allied executives must now find a way to work their magic on a much larger company while paying off the sizable debt load from the takeover.
"That's my concern," said James Kelleher, an analyst at Argus Research in New York. "They're assuming the best of all possible worlds to service the debt. There's a lot that could happen between now and the $45-deal date in the third quarter."
Although such a leveraged takeover is unusual, this is the second time in less than a year that a giant trash hauler has been taken over by a smaller rival. (A year ago, USA Waste acquired Waste Management in a $13 billion deal.) Wall Street analysts say that industry executives now realize that a focused strategy is just as important as size in the waste management business.
At Browning-Ferris, after years of aggressive acquisitions and expansion into everything from recycling to hazardous waste removal, shareholders had been pressing it to focus more closely on its North American business, and yesterday, Allied executives said the newly formed company would do just that.
The deal began last spring when Allied Waste and Browning-Ferris discussed a stock merger. At the time, people close to the deal said, Browning-Ferris executives were not eager to sell, hoping instead to improve the company's profitability on their own. But over time they became more open to the idea, in part, because a handful of Browning-Ferris's board members supported it.
Negotiations heated up at the end of February. Goldman, Sachs & Company was hired by Browning-Ferris to advise on the transaction, while Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, among others, advised Allied's management. Browning-Ferris initially wanted cash, a person close to the talks said, up to $49 a share. The companies agreed on $45. Then Allied, along with its two majority shareholders, Apollo Management and Blackstone Capital Partners, both of which supported a deal, began arranging financing.
Several banks were asked to commit funds for the deal at the end of February and to agree to put up the money for the buyout regardless of whether other investors could be enlisted. By March 3, one person close to the talks said, three institutions -- Chase Manhattan, Citibank and DLJ Capital Funding -- had committed themselves to provide the $9.5 billion that Allied needed to buy Browning-Ferris.
Adding to that, several investors said they would buy a total of $1 billion in convertible preferred stock, including Apollo Management, Blackstone Capital Partners, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners and Greenwich Street Capital Partners. By Thursday, the two companies had agreed in concept to a deal and to continue talking over the weekend.
On Friday, Allied's stock plunged about $5 a share, or 25 percent. The company was asked by the New York Stock Exchange to make a statement, but did not. Several bankers, along with Apollo and Blackstone, double-checked their numbers to make sure the deal was sound. After their analysis was finished, the two companies hammered out the final details of the acquisition, meeting well past midnight on Sunday.
Mr. Van Weelden, the chief executive at Allied, which is based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said that he expected some layoffs, particularly in Houston, where Browning-Ferris has headquarters, but that the key to driving profits at the new company would be combining a decentralized management style with a vertically integrated business.
"We want to own all the pieces," Mr. Van Weelden said. "We believe in vertical integration."
Responding to those who worry about the leverage in the buyout, Mr. Van Weelden cited his company's acquisition of the Laidlaw Company, a trash hauler about three times the size of Allied.
"This is a kind of repeat; this is exactly what we did with Laidlaw," he said. "We know how to do this."
Several Wall Street analysts, however, say that even after all the cost savings, Allied may have to cope with a large debt load and the possibility of an economic slowdown.
"If we were to run into a recession, the deal could be breached," said Melville Cody, an analyst at Sanders Morris Mundy, a brokerage firm in Houston. "But right now we're in a good environment for waste management."
Other analysts, recalling the problems of Browning-Ferris and the old Waste Management Company, before it was acquired by USA Waste, wonder whether Allied could become too large and unwieldy.
"Allied has a better management team and a better track record than Browning-Ferris," said Charles G. Moody, publisher of American Waste Digest in Pottstown, Pa. "But any time you triple your size, you're going to have new problems."

HEADLINE: At Nicaragua Mudslide Site, Clinton's Aid Offer Falls Short of His Goal

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 8

 BODY:
Beneath a volcano still scarred by the hurricane-induced mudslide that occurred last October, President Clinton vowed to help Nicaraguans reclaim their lives and ravaged land.
"A hurricane, a mudslide, they can destroy lives, they can destroy homes, they can destroy a life's work," the President said as blinding dust swept through a schoolyard in the town of Posoltega where he spoke. "But they must not be allowed to destroy hope." 
 Mr. Clinton announced that the United States would provide an additional $120 million to build temporary shelters, repair roads, provide medical care and remove land mines uprooted by the torrential rains and mudslides of the hurricane. But Mr. Clinton's request for nearly $1 billion more for Central America is stalled in Congress in a partisan dispute over its source.
Casitas volcano, near Posoltega, 70 miles northwest of Managua, was the scene of the deadliest disaster last October: a 30-foot torrent of mud that buried two villages, El Porvenir and Rolando Rodriguez. Some 2,000 people were killed, many buried alive. Thousands were left homeless.
On the first day of a four-day, four-nation tour of Central America, Mr. Clinton saw the remnants of the disaster in Nicaragua, including the single house that remains of the two villages and the shallow graves of hundreds of victims. Thousands are still in temporary shelters. Mr. Clinton placed a spray of flowers at the grave of one victim, a 6-year-old girl crushed by the slide. She was one of many victims who for public-health reasons were not buried but cremated where they lay, their remains then strewn with dirt.
Afterward Mr. Clinton said he had not until now appreciated the extent of the catastrophe. "No picture can convey the feeling of seeing the outline of that small child's body by her grave and seeing the remnants of her skeleton," he said.
In his public remarks, Mr. Clinton alluded to Nicaragua's revolution and counterrevolution of the 1980's and its two democratic elections since then.
"In this decade," the President said, "with courage and with strength you have created a new Nicaragua. You have earned the world's admiration and now you deserve the world's support." The aid announced today is to come from Agency for International Development funds already included in the budget. A proposal worth $956 million is stalled in Congress in a dispute over how to pay for it.
Mr. Clinton had hoped to deliver the nearly $1 billion in aid during his trip this week. But House and Senate Republicans voted last week to attach conditions to the relief bill that the White House finds unacceptable.
The dispute will most likely take weeks or months to resolve, forcing Mr. Clinton to dip into aid agency coffers to pay for a much smaller effort. The country is to get help on housing, health care, education, road and bridge repair and the removal of land mines left from the civil wars of the 1970's and 1980's.
The United States has already given about $300 million in disaster aid to the region, through civilian relief agencies as well as the Defense Department, which provided earth-moving equipment and temporary bridges for the hundreds of spans washed out by the rains.
The Administration also temporarily suspended deportations of Central Americans who illegally entered the United States to escape the effects of the hurricane. But preparations are under way to force the return of many of those refugees, a development that has created friction with the region's Governments, which say they cannot provide housing or sustenance for them.
Mr. Clinton promised today to seek a "fair solution" to the refugee issue but gave no details.
As part of its relief program, the Administration also deferred for two years all bilateral debt payments owed to the United States by Nicaragua and Honduras. That concession would relieve the two countries' obligation to pay $54 million in interest payments. The Administration is also asking other nations holding debt from Central America to forgive or defer payments.
In addition, the Peace Corps is expanding its presence in the region to help rebuild, according to Mark Gearan, the Peace Corps Director, who accompanied Mr. Clinton on the trip. The 500 Peace Corps volunteers already working in the countries hardest hit by the storm will be reinforced by as many as 100 workers for short-term emergency aid.
They belong to the Crisis Corps, a new Peace Corps program that enlists former volunteers to return for six-month stints to the countries where they served, sometimes decades earlier.

HEADLINE: Property Taxes In Nassau Called Biased

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., March 8

 BODY:
The Justice Department says Nassau County's method of assessing property taxes discriminates against black and Hispanic homeowners, causing them to pay disproportionately high taxes, according to Government documents.
Zachary W. Carter, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, in a letter to top Nassau officials, threatened a Government lawsuit unless the county voluntarily takes steps to end "the discriminatory assessments," and consents to a settlement. 
 In a separate but related action, a New York State Supreme Court judge refused today to dismiss a suit about discriminatory assessments filed against Nassau County by the New York Civil Liberties Union on behalf of six black homeowners.
Sanford M. Cohen, chief of civil rights litigation in the United States Attorney's office, said the homeowners' suit would not affect the Government's actions against the county. He added that he was hopeful that Nassau would voluntarily resolve the tax issue. "If not, we are authorized to sue," he said. Mr. Cohen said the county had been aware for years that its assessment system was discriminatory, yet had made no effort to change it.
In Nassau, homes are assessed based on 1938 construction costs, while the land they are built on is assessed according to 1964 property values. Because property values have appreciated faster in wealthier, predominantly white areas than in poorer, more heavily minority areas, homes that may have cost the same when they were built decades ago and are currently assessed at the same rate could have widely varying prices.
For example, Hezekiah Brown, a labor negotiator who says his home on Flower Street in a predominantly African-American neighborhood in Hempstead is worth around $200,000, pays a little over $8,000 a year in property taxes. He said a house similar to his in nearby Garden City was worth more than $400,000, but the owners also paid $8,000 a year in taxes.
"This is a scandal, and it's time for a change," Mr. Brown said in front of his home this afternoon.
Mr. Carter said a Justice Department study compared the assessed and market values of more than 11,000 residential properties in Nassau from August 1995 through July 1996 with Census Bureau figures.
The study showed that the average assessment in predominantly minority areas was 27 percent higher than the total average assessment rate of all property in the county.
Most of the minority homeowners live in southern and central Nassau, in small houses on modest lots. In some areas, such as Lakeview, Roosevelt, Freeport, Hempstead and New Cassel, the minority tracts were assessed at more than twice the average rate, Mr. Carter said.
"As a result, owners of residential property in minority communities have for years borne a disproportionate share of the cost of governmental services that are funded by real property taxes," Mr. Carter said in his letter, dated March 2. Mr. Carter's letter and the Justice Department's findings were first reported today by Newsday.
In response to the letter, Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta defended the county's property tax system as fair and as one that had been upheld by the courts. He had no immediate comment on today's court ruling.
Mr. Gulotta said that Nassau had one assessment system formula that "applies equally to all homeowners and is nondiscriminatory." He said it was not in violation of the United States Fair Housing Act, as charged by Mr. Carter.
"The Federal Government should not impose its will upon our homeowners over their wishes," Mr. Gulotta said in a letter to Mr. Carter dated March 5 that was released by county officials today.
A 1995 study by the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee estimated that a reassessment would cost at least $40 million dollars. Mr. Gulotta said such a step "may be harmful and costly to our taxpayers, regardless of race or national origin."
Mr. Gulotta's response to the Justice Department complaint was sharply criticized by Roger Corbin, who represents one of the two minority districts in the Nassau County Legislature.
"I think the County Executive is clearly off base with this," Mr. Corbin said.
Bruce Blakeman, Presiding Officer of the County Legislature, said that "it might be time to take a look at the Justice Department's data and discuss with the County Executive and Assessor's Office whether any changes would be in the best interest of the county."
"We do not want to be unfair to any segments of the county population," he said.
Mr. Gulotta noted that the county recently enacted a year-round grievance system enabling property owners to appeal their assessments.
In fact, the appeals have been so successful, they have cost the county more than $100 million in tax refunds, which it has had to borrow. In the view of some critics, this expense indicates that the old assessment system should be revised as a means to help solve the county's fiscal crisis.
The county's $2.3 billion budget has become so structurally imbalanced that Standard & Poor's recently lowered the county's credit rating to A minus and placed its bonds on a credit watch. It is facing a $160 million deficit for 1998 and a projected $125 million deficit for 1999, despite the generally robust health of Long Island's economy.
However, a revision of its assessment procedures would not help the county's finances, said Richard J. Marino, a director at Standard & Poor's. "It might shift the burden around among the taxpayers, but the financial outcome would be the same," he said.
Kathy O'Callaghan, former president of the Levittown Property Tax Payers Association, has long called for a revision of the county's tax system. While minority neighborhoods have been the hardest hit, she said, white low- and middle-income communities like Levittown have also suffered.
In the ruling on the homeowners' suit issued late this afternoon in State Supreme Court, Justice F. Dana Winslow noted that the 1938 and 1964 data used by the county in its assessment formula "may be so dated as to defy adjustment except on an individual basis."
Justice Winslow scheduled a preliminary conference for March 26 to consider a resolution of the claims by the six homeowners. He ordered all parties, including representatives of the Nassau County Board of Assessors, the County Executive and County Legislature to be present.
Leon Friedman, a professor of constitutional law and a lawyer with the New York Civil Liberties Union, welcomed Justice Winslow's ruling. "Nassau's system is archaic, costly, unfair and discriminatory, and it's time to go.
"In a nutshell," he added, when the impact of today's ruling by Justice Winslow is combined with the actions by the U.S. Attorney's Office, "you have a powerful case being made."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
JAPAN: NEW JUSTICE MINISTER
A 65-year-old legislator, Takao Jinnouchi, has been appointed Justice Minister, replacing Shozaburo Nakamura, who resigned after a scandal in which he allowed the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger to enter Japan without a passport. Mr. Nakamura, a fan of the actor, has denied that he took home documents permitting the actor to enter Japan instead of filing them with the ministry. (Agence France-Presse)
 
JAPAN: U.S. GETS OKINAWA BASE
Urasoe, a small city on Okinawa, decided to allow a U.S. naval port to relocate there in return for Japanese Government aid to develop the city's waterfront. Under a 1974 agreement, the U.S. agreed to return its military port in Naha, the capital of Okinawa prefecture, on condition that the port be relocated on Okinawa. Until Urasoe made an offer, no city appeared to want the base. (AP) 

INDONESIA: 4 DIE IN RELIGIOUS RIOTS
At least four people were killed and 11 severely wounded in new clashes, left, on the eastern Indonesian island of Ambon, officials and witnesses said. Christians attacked and burned a truck with 28 people aboard, killing two and wounding four others, in the town of Paso, an official at a local mosque said. In the Air Salobar area of Ambon city, Christian and Muslim gangs clashed, leaving two dead. (AP)
 
CHINA: BANNED AUTHOR HELD
An author of books banned by the Communist Party has been detained in China's restive Muslim northwest, where he was researching his latest project, family and friends said. The police notified Wang Lixiong's relatives in Beijing that he was being held in Xinjiang on suspicion of leaking state secrets, said Hao Weizhen, his adoptive aunt. A fellow author said Mr. Wang may have been trying to interview separatist groups. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
FRANCE: SONGBIRD SAVED
The rare ortolan songbird was declared a protected species in France, where a few bons vivants had regarded it as a delicacy to be consumed completely, beak, feathers and tiny bones. A journalist's account about President Francois Mitterrand eating two of the birds at a New Year's dinner before his death from prostate cancer in January 1996 led to an uproar, and the ban on its hunting or sale. Craig R. Whitney (NYT)
 
TURKEY: KURDISH PARTY CAN RUN
The highest court ruled that the leading pro-Kurdish party, People's Democracy, may take part in elections on April 18. A prosecutor sought to bar the party, but several commentators warned that if he succeeded, many supporters would probably vote for the Islamic-oriented Virtue Party, an equally disagreeable choice to the secular elite. Stephen Kinzer (NYT)

IRAQ: U.S. ATTACKS RADAR SITES

HEADLINE: Fluor Is Expected to Announce Revamping

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 8

 BODY:
The Fluor Corporation, the nation's largest engineering and construction company, is expected to announce a reorganization Tuesday that will result in $160 million in annual cost savings, according to a person close to the company. 
 The move is also expected to result in a charge against earnings of about $130 million, this person said.
The company is expected to cut up to several thousand jobs.
Fluor had nearly 57,000 employees as of last Oct. 31. The immediate cuts are expected to be from staff positions.
The company is also expected to narrow the types of construction jobs it will accept, concentrating on only a few industries such as petrochemicals and pharmaceuticals in which it is strong and can obtain reasonable profits. The company is also expected to organize itself into four divisions -- engineering and construction, coal, diversified services such as temporary staffing, and a division that will provide administrative services to the rest of the company.
Fluor, based in Irvine, Calif., has been suffering from a downturn in the construction market caused in part by the Asian economic crisis and the decline in oil prices.

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
A Heart Pumping Poetry

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
Current 93, a British Goth-folk band led by a thin, charismatic poet named David Tibet, is a perfect little cultural operation. It has a small core of fans whose devotion runs shockingly deep; the group lies so safely and cozily within a nook of the underground-rock economy that it is never exposed to attack or unrealistic sales expectations.
And the band doesn't operate on anyone else's field: though it pumps out about two albums a year, it doesn't play at festivals, it rarely gives interviews and it fulfills a deep need among fans, who crave the mordant comfort of fantasizing that the world is one great barren moor. 
 The band's show on Friday night at Tonic, the small club on Norfolk Street in Manhattan, was its 41st performance since forming in 1983, according to one of the many Web sites devoted to the band. Fans from all around North America were there, and even some from other countries; devotion to this band is a commitment. (After tickets had quickly grown scarce, some were offered on line for $150.)
On Friday when Mr. Tibet took the stage in a colorful vest and closely cropped hair, accompanied by his guitarist, Michael Cashmore, the crowd fell deadly silent. Mr. Tibet doesn't sing, but reads his poetry to the quiet accompaniment of acoustic-guitar minor chords with a perfectly enunciating, lissome voice.
His work is fixated on God and on blood, not blood like a horror film, but more metaphorically and with less gusto. He comes across as a perfect modern equivalent of a consumptive turn-of-the-century poet turned drearily obsessed with his illness. He bent his knees and bobbed up and down a bit, quivering with feeling, declaiming lines like "the great bloody bruised veil of this world" and "sell all you have; give it to the kittens/and pour the milk on Louis's grave." He was wide-eyed and unnervingly fragile and serious.
Expanded later with a second guitarist and a violinist, the music became a heavily stylized relative of old English folk ballads.
It is music about being alone and looking within yourself, and the evening's repeated phrase -- one that has cropped up through Current 93's recorded work -- was "the inmost light." Yet the more inward music goes, the stronger are the ties among its constituents. The show was a small, emotional convention of E-mail friends who looked as if they didn't get out much, and there was an ecstatic glow over the place.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
March, Insanity, Sad Facts

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
MARCH Madness is a catchy, alliterative phrase designed to draw attention -- pecuniary preferably -- to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I men's basketball tournament, which begins tomorrow at eight sites around the country. I don't recall it being called March Madness until a handful of years ago when it became a big-time attraction on television, having swelled from a dozen or so teams to 64, a tournament big enough to choke a horse.
Part of the madness -- which is actually pretty sane for the TV network, the organizers and the schools, since they stand to make millions of dollars from it -- is demonstrated by the TV cameras focusing on some of the brilliant students in the crowd who look as if they've had buckets of paint, in two and three colors, spilled on their heads. Added madness is the brassy bands in the arena playing loud enough to be heard in the next county. 
 And then there is the basketball itself, invariably a wonderful show. The Cinderella teams, the buzzer beaters, the Clash of Titans, etc. But for all this, there is a level of suspended disbelief that is necessary to these nutsy pleasures. Some of the suspension is that all of these basketball players are also true students, struggling with their calculus and Economic History of Mesopotamia, and cramming on a paragraph or two during a timeout.
The sad fact is that college basketball players have lower graduation rates than most students. And the black basketball players fare worse than the white basketball players.
In the latest annual survey by the N.C.A.A., compiled last November, male basketball players continued to graduate at rates far lower than other students. "For the eighth consecutive year," wrote The Chronicle of Higher Education, "the rate of Division I male basketball players was far below the rate for all male students at those institutions, which in 1997 was 53 percent." The association found that only 41 percent of men's basketball players who entered college in 1991 had graduated within six years, down from 45 percent the year before and the second-poorest showing since the association began its graduation-rate survey.
White male basketball players graduated at a rate of 47 percent -- their lowest total in the N.C.A.A. graduation-rate survey -- compared with the overall graduation rate for white male students of 56 percent, down by 11 percent from the year before. The graduation rate of black male players fell from 39 percent in 1996 to 37 percent in 1997.
Emerge, a black-oriented magazine, has a "Bottom 50" listing that names the 50 worst Division I schools in regard to graduation rates for both African-Americans and whites. And several of this year's glorious March Madness schools are on it, including James Madison, Ohio State, Syracuse and Cincinnati, all of whom have graduated no black players for at least the past five years. And while the first three of these schools had graduated 67 percent of the white players, Cincinnati was an equal-opportunity school in having graduated no white players, either.
"The statistics aren't good, and it's a dilemma," said Kenneth A. (Buzz) Shaw, the chancellor of Syracuse University and chairman of an N.C.A.A. group that is studying basketball issues at Division I colleges. "We're working on it, and hope to help improve it."
In a related issue, a Federal District Court in Philadelphia on Monday discarded the N.C.A.A.'s minimum test score requirements for athletic scholarships, saying it "has an unjustified disparate impact against African-Americans."
Shaw said that tests have to be important -- the problem is how much weight to give them, in relation to high school grades, classroom competition, courses taken.
What's most important, from this viewpoint, is motivation for schooling. Too many players want the N.B.A. rather than an M.B.A.
"Unfortunately, some guys get the idea they only have to concentrate on basketball because they don't feel a degree will lead to fame and riches," said Steve Milburn, director of academic services for athletics at Louisville.
And it is a cruel fallacy that only sports scholarships will lead some out of mean circumstances.
"Federal and state grants and aids are available to virtually all high school graduates based on need, regardless of class standing and admissible to community colleges and beyond," Shaw said.
Meanwhile, here comes March Madness, that annual assault on the senses, where for some three weeks, we gaily suspend disbelief, and then return to sober reality.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Amtrak Unveils Its Bullet to Boston

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Aiming to bring high-speed rail service to Boston by the start of the new millennium, Amtrak said yesterday that it would start rolling out the first of its new 150 mile-an-hour trains by December.
The new high-speed rail line intends to change commuting habits along the Northeast corridor from Washington to Boston by competing head on with air shuttles and interstate highways. But more important for Amtrak, the high-speed train provides a model for its rail service across the nation, and is the centerpiece of its hopes of economic redemption after operating for three decades with government subsidies. 
 "Today we are kicking off the revitalization of train service in America," Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, who is the chairman of Amtrak's board, said at a Manhattan news conference. He described the new Northeast corridor trains, comparable to the bullet trains of France and Japan, as the first installment of high-speed rail service in this country, with his corner of the Midwest coming next.
"We are giving notice to our competitors," said George D. Warrington, the president of Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, addressing the more mundane, unresolved question of whether trains -- even those making the New York-to-Washington run in two and a half hours -- can compete with discount regional airlines.
With a phalanx of brand-name politicians on the rostrum -- including the former Governors Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Linwood Holton of Virginia, both board members -- the conference provided a more rounded but still incomplete picture of the railroad's long-awaited high-speed service.
Central to its plan, Mr. Warrington said, are trains that speed from Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan to South Station in Boston in three hours, cutting 1 hour and 40 minutes off the time of the trip.
With new, electrified engines pulling rebuilt Amtrak cars, the three-hour schedule has been made possible by extensive track work and electrification from New Haven to Boston, a project that cost $1.6 billion.
The trains will also be used along the line to Union Station in Washington, beginning some time before mid-2000. With the new trains, the trip from Manhattan to Washington will be a half-hour shorter than the current three-hour trip of Amtrak's Metroliner express train, which went into service in 1969 after track upgrades and has a top speed of 125 miles an hour.
Just as critical as their speed, according to transportation analysts, will be the cost of riding the new trains. The announcement comes only weeks after several discount regional airlines disclosed plans to enter the hotly competitive New York regional market, prompting widespread predictions of lower air fares, if not an airline price war.
Officials of Amtrak refused to say what they would charge for the high-speed rail trip. Compared with the current differential between air shuttle and train tickets -- about 40 percent between New York and Washington, where the Metroliner charges $119 and full-fare air shuttles cost just under $200 -- Mr. Warrington said high-speed trains would offer a smaller discount.
"We will still have a more attractive fare" than competing air shuttles to Washington and Boston from New York, he said. But where the savings is now closer to 40 percent, he said riders on the high-speed trains could expect to pay about 30 percent less than for airline tickets.
Amtrak's ticket pricing for high-speed trains could be crucial to its success. Its executives said yesterday that it planned to retain slower, lower-priced service that has alwaysheld an appeal with more budget-conscious travelers or those traveling between smaller cities.
"The market they have to go after is the business traveler who at the moment wouldn't consider Amtrak unless he is just somebody who doesn't like to fly," said Jeffrey Zupan, a transportation analyst for the Regional Plan Association in New York.
To attract more riders, Amtrak said it would schedule more trains along the length of its Northeast corridor, with the biggest service expansion between Boston and New York City. While declining to provide detailed schedules, it said it would begin offering 17 round-trip trains between the two cities sometime next year, compared with nine round trips currently. It declined to say how many would be high-speed versions making the projected three-hour run.
Another question left unanswered yesterday was how many stops the high-speed trains would make, another complex equation for Amtrak planners, since every stop increases travel time for those on board.
Preliminary plans by Amtrak that were released yesterday call for stops of its high-speed express service in Boston, Providence, R.I., New Haven, New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington. But executives of the railroad said it had not been determined how such heavily used rail hubs as Route 128 outside Boston, New London and Stamford, Conn., and Trenton would figure into their plan for high-speed service.
"Obviously, not every train is going to stop at every station, and we are going to have to look at what makes most sense in consideration of speed and convenience," said Barbara J. Richardson, Amtrak's executive vice president.
With such questions remaining until sometime later this year, Amtrak officials sought yesterday to emphasize several improvements in comfort and service that are planned for the new trains, largely aimed at business travelers in an era of cellular phones, laptop computers and increased demands for executive productivity, even on the road.
Among them, Mr. Warrington said, will be electrical outlets next to every train seat that enable travelers to plug in their laptop computers. Video monitors in each train's cafe car will provide news updates, while audio plugs will be provided with headsets for each rider, with pre-recorded music.
Amtrak plans to name the trains Acela (pronounced uh-SELL-uh), which is a made-up name, not an acronym.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
An Early RallyReverses and Dow Finishes Down 33.85

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks declined yesterday, led lower by concern about the performance of Intel and Walt Disney.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.85 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 9,693.76, after coming within 201.07 points of the 10,000 mark. Disney was the average's biggest decliner, falling on concern that revenue from television and movies was falling short of expectations. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 2.89 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,279.84. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.68, also two-tenths of a percent, to 2,392.94. Losers outnumbered winners, 16 to 13, on the Big Board.
Shares of semiconductor makers may have declined on speculation that Intel, the world's biggest computer-chip manufacturer, will warn of weak earnings, said Gary Dvorchak, a money manager for Provident Investment Counsel, which oversees $18 billion in Pasadena, Calif.
"It's fairly well known on the Street right now that they're maybe 10 percent below plan for the quarter," he said. "Especially given the optimism surrounding Intel, there would be a pessimistic reaction to their announcement."
Intel declined to comment. Its shares fell 4 5/16 , to 115 5/16 .
Advanced Micro Devices, the No. 2 chip maker, fell 1 7/16 , to 17 1/2, after warning that it would lose money in the first quarter because of production problems. Intel has been cutting prices to win back sales lost to Advanced Micro's less expensive K-6 chips.
Disney fell 1 3/4, to 34 11/16 . Richard P. Simon, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, lowered his earnings estimates for the world's No. 2 entertainment company, citing lower-than-expected revenue from TV shows and movies.
Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, fell 1 11/16 , to 37 7/8, and was the second-biggest decliner in the Dow after Disney. Alcan Aluminium, the No. 2 producer, said its first-quarter profit would be less than expected because of low aluminum prices, a recession in Brazil and weaker prices for its manufactured products. Its shares fell 1 1/8, to 23 11/16 .
During the session, the Dow rose 71 points, to 9,798.93, an intraday record. Stocks retreated as short-term traders, who hoped the market would push higher throughout the day, were disappointed when the rally stalled and used that as an opportunity to sell, traders said.
On the positive side, shares of Lycos, the No. 3 Internet search service, soared 12 3/8, to 96 1/4, after David Wetherell, the chairman and chief executive of the venture capital company CMGI, resigned from the board of Lycos, saying the terms of Lycos's pending acquisition by USA Networks Inc. were inadequate. CMGI is the largest shareholder of Lycos.
Sony's American depository receipts jumped 8 3/16 , to 94, after the company said it would spend $2.7 billion to buy out three subsidiaries in a reorganization aimed at halting sliding profits. Sony will also cut 17,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and close 15 of 70 factories.
Hypercom, Sterigenics International and A. Schulman slid after saying they expect earnings to fall short of expectations.
Hypercom fell 4 1/8, to 5 5/8, after warning it expected to report a loss for the quarter ending March 31. The maker of electronic-payment systems blamed the Brazilian currency devaluation and "depressed economic conditions" in Asia and Latin America.
Sterigenics tumbled 6 3/8, to 10 1/4. The company said fourth-quarter revenue and earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates because of less business in its medical sterilization division.
Schulman, a supplier of plastic compounds and resins, fell 2, to 13 1/2, after saying net income for the quarter ended Feb. 28 would be less than the current estimate of 33 cents a share, as well as below the 31 cents the company earned in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries UpAs Greenspan Sees No Signs Of Inflation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said there were "no obvious signs" of rising inflation, despite strong growth.
A Government report on productivity also bolstered expectations for tame inflation. Nonfarm productivity increased 4.6 percent at an annual rate during the fourth quarter, up from an initial estimate of a 3.7 percent increase. Unit labor costs -- a separate index measuring changes in worker compensation and productivity -- fell at a 1.1 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, the first drop since the first quarter of 1996. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond rose 26/32 , or $8.13 for a $1,000 bond, to 95 31/32 , pushing the yield down 6 basis points, to 5.53 percent. Yields on two-year notes, the most actively traded Treasuries, fell 8 basis points, to 5.00 percent.
"As long as Greenspan seems happy to let the economy grow without inflation picking up, the Fed doesn't have to do anything," said Chris Iggo, international economist at Barclays Capital. For the Fed to raise interest rates, inflation would have to speed up, "and that still seems some ways off," he said.
Treasuries also rose as some traders reversed short sales, or bets that prices would fall, traders said. In a short sale, traders borrow bonds and sell them, speculating that they will be able to buy them back later at lower prices and pocket the difference. Rising bond prices obviously defeat that strategy, prompting traders to buy bonds to replace the borrowed ones they had sold.
With inflation subdued -- it ran 1.7 percent for the 12 months through January -- and Treasury yields not far from seven-month highs, some investors say bonds are attractive. The 30-year bond, after adjusting for inflation, yields about 3.87 percent, almost the highest since July.
Alan Koepplin, who helps manage about $2.5 billion of fixed-income assets at SG Cowen Asset Management, bought notes and bonds last week and predicts that yields have seen their highs for the quarter, and possibly for the year.
Bonds got a brief lift after the Federal Reserve bought $811 million of Treasury bonds for delivery tomorrow in an outright purchase, or coupon pass. The central bank bought securities due between Aug. 15, 2022, and Nov. 15, 2027, excluding one issue from its purchases.
The Fed makes outright purchases periodically to permanently add money to the economy. The moves do not signal a change in interest rates.
The prospect of several large corporate bond sales could rein in bonds. Freddie Mac is planning to sell $3 billion of bonds and Lucent Technologies Inc. plans to raise $1 billion. AT&T may sell as much as $10 billion in coming weeks.

HEADLINE: U.S. Productivity Rises Sharply

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The productivity of workers shot up in the final quarter of 1998, recording the fastest growth pace in six years and easing concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates.
The Labor Department said today that productivity -- the efficiency at which workers produce goods and services -- grew 4.6 percent in the fourth quarter. That was a revision from previous data that had shown a 3.7 percent rise. 
 "This is the magic bullet that allows us to have strong economic growth with low inflation," said James Annable, an economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago. "If we can continue to get these productivity gains, we can keep this Goldilocks economy going."
Further encouragement came from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who, in remarks to a conference on business access to capital and credit, called the economic expansion "exemplary" and emphasized the lack of inflation pressures.
The fourth-quarter productivity gain was the biggest since a 6.2 percent increase in the fourth quarter of 1992. Because of the year-end surge in productivity, unit-labor costs, a closely watched gauge of wage inflation, fell 1.1 percent.
